webTitle: Cruyff the conductor edges the successful solo artists

fields.headline: Cruyff the conductor edges the successful solo artists
fields.trailText: After all the debate about whether Maradona was better than Pele, I've only one thing to say - Johan Cruyff was better than both of them.
fields.body:
I notice Fifa fudged the issue of whether Pele or Maradona was player of the century by giving an award to both. For me Pele was the better of the two, although top of the lot in my book is Johan Cruyff.

He was quick, lively and agile, and he not only scored great goals but made them. He orchestrated those fantastic Holland and Ajax sides in the way Alfredo di Stefano did with Real Madrid in the 50s and 60s. But as well as being the conductor, Cruyff was a real team man.

I loved watching him. The "Cruyff turn" against Sweden in the 1974 World Cup was unforgettable, and I remember going to Villa Park to see him play for Barcelona in the 1977-78 Uefa Cup. I was manager of West Brom at the time and it was billed as the last time Cruyff would appear in England. Barca were winning 2-0 with a few minutes left and took Cruyff off so the crowd could pay their respects. The home supporters were clapping, cheering and stomping, but then went absolutely wild as Villa scored twice in the last minute to equalise. Barca won the return 2-1.

Another Cruyff memory that stands out was seeing him in his latter years with Feyenoord. I was in Holland watching Jesper Olsen before signing him for Manchester United and Feyenoord hammered their bitter rivals Ajax.

A great moment, though, was when Feyenoord had a free-kick about 30 yards out. Cruyff was lining up to take it when a big, precocious black guy came up and whacked the ball into the net. It was Ruud Gullit. We made a few enquiries about Gullit but were told he wouldn't leave Holland.

For me there was something extra special about Cruyff, with his individual talent and team ethic, but Pele was hardly far behind. Nor, of course, was Maradona, but for me the Brazilian just gets the nod.

Pele had more all round. He could do the unexpected but, if his side were up against it, which admittedly Brazil weren't very often, he could fit into a team pattern. He was a better collective player in terms of joining in with others, whereas Maradona was more a case of: we've got a problem, give me the ball and I'll sort it.

Pele had everything: goals, spring, vision, skill, and a lot of people don't appreciate how powerful he was. One of his stock-in-trades on the ball was the way he held his arm out, almost rugby-fashion, to make it hard for defenders to get close.

I can recall Pele coming to Sheffield and playing in a friendly at Hillsborough with Santos in 1962. He scored a memorable penalty past Ron Springett, doing a hop, skip and jump before stopping and coolly flipping the ball into the top of the net.

Ten years later he was back there again. The kick-off was switched to the afternoon because of a power crisis and I'm told he sat in the dressing room for two hours afterwards signing autographs. The queue went from the dressing room, out of the ground and along the back of the stand to the main road.

The shame was that the English public were robbed of seeing Pele's full majesty in 1966. I was at Everton when the Portuguese kicked him out of the World Cup, and the best we saw of him was in 1970. I watched on the telly and will never forget some of the things he pulled out: the dummy on the Uruguayan keeper, the long shot against the Czechs, the pass to Carlos Alberto.

Pele was also involved in one of the funniest things I've seen. After Brazil reached the 1994 World Cup final I saw him in the VIP car park doing an interview. The Americans had put Alexei Lalas in with him discussing World Cup football and I was thinking: "Hold on a bit, one of them knows everything and the other's a guitar-playing American."

Having said that, I understand Pele could play guitar. Some of the lads who were involved in Escape to Victory with him said every night he would come down, open a bottle of Jack Daniels and sit with the boys and strum.

As for Maradona, I admired not just his power, pace and supreme confidence but his bravery too. Hard as people tried, it was difficult to kick him out of a game. He played against my United team for Barcelona in Europe, although he was carrying an injury and made little or no contribution.

The same doesn't go for the first time I saw him live. That was for Argentina against England at Wembley, when he had a phenomenal dribble, went past everybody and stroked it just wide.

I had been introduced to him earlier in the day at a hotel in Kensington, where Alberto Tarantini, who had a spell at Birmingham City, told me: "This is the best player you'll ever see."

He was close, but my vote goes to Cruyff.

webTitle: Hammers' bid for Keane rejected

fields.headline: Hammers' bid for Keane rejected
fields.trailText: West Ham have failed in an audacious attempt to sign Robbie Keane from Internazionale. Their manager Harry Redknapp said last night that the Italian side had rejected a £10m offer for the Republic of Ireland striker.
fields.body:
West Ham have failed in an audacious attempt to sign Robbie Keane from Internazionale. Their manager Harry Redknapp said last night that the Italian side had rejected a £10m offer for the Republic of Ireland striker.

"We went over to Italy and had a meet with the people from Milan and made an offer of £10m but we couldn't quite agree terms with them," Redknapp said on the official West Ham website yesterday. "It wasn't far away I don't think, but I don't know if they really want to sell the boy and I don't know if the boy wants to leave; I think he probably wants to stay there."

Keane has certainly insisted that he intends to stick it out in Milan, despite failing to hold down a regular place since his summer move from Coventry City. Inter have said they want to keep him, though they may be willing to sell if someone matches the £12m they paid for the 20-year-old.

West Ham, who have money to burn since the £18m sale of Rio Ferdinand to Leeds, have not given up hope of resurrecting a deal that would more than double their transfer record. "I'd loved to have bought him," said Redknapp. "He's a fantastic player. We'd still like to do something if the chance came but if it will I don't know. He would fit in anywhere; he would have been a great player for us."

Chelsea, Leeds and Coventry have also expressed interest in Keane, who came on as a late substitute against Fiorentina on Sunday. A loan has been mooted, though if Inter agreed to that they would most likely send him to a club in Italy, with Napoli emerging as a possible sanctuary.

If Keane needed a first-hand reminder of the volatile situation at Inter, who are 10th in Serie A, it came last night when the team bus he was travelling on to an Italian Cup quarter-final against Parma at the San Siro was hit by a Molotov cocktail thrown by angry fans. The side of the coach caught fire but was quickly extinguished. The players were shaken and got off to walk the short distance to the dressing rooms. Keane made a rare start in the match, which Inter began 6-1 down from the first leg, and which ended 0-0 on the night.

The Arsenal midfielder Paolo Vernazza has joined First Division Watford after rejecting a move to Norwich.

The 21-year-old former England Under-18 international has been on the fringes of the Arsenal first team this season but has failed to make the breakthrough. Watford have signed him for a fee of £350,000, rising to £650,000 depending on appearances.

Meanwhile, the Brazilian midfielder Edu is hopeful of solving the passport difficulties that have held up his move to Highbury from Corinthians of Sao Paulo. "I am only waiting for a document that has been sent from Portugal and which will legalise my passport," he said yesterday.

Craig Bellamy has urged the Football Association not to take action against Leicester's Matt Elliott despite the defenderÍs elbow appearing to make contact with the Coventry striker during Sunday's Premiership match at Highfield Road.

"I want to make it clear that I do not in any way bear a grudge against Matt Elliot, who I respect as a top-class Premiership footballer," said Bellamy. "Sunday's game was a hard battle between players who were desperate to win for their club and Matt's attitude typified the spirit in which the game was played."

Sunderland's Paul Butler will complete a £1m move to Wolves today after spending the past month on loan at Molineux. The Wolves manager Colin Lee has agreed a permanent deal after being impressed by the defender.

webTitle: Batty back in action to boost Leeds

fields.headline: Batty back in action to boost Leeds
fields.trailText: David Batty completed 90 minutes of a reserve team game last night ang has his eyes on a place on the bench when Leeds play Sunderland tomorrow.
fields.body:
A near-deserted stadium, chilly and windswept in the soggy gloom, provided an inauspicious backdrop, but there was plenty to cheer David Batty and Leeds United here last night.

There were no crunching tackles, his trademark in 42 England caps, and much of the reserve game against Sheffield Wednesday passed him by as he hovered at the base of a midfield diamond. But a year since suffering an achilles heel injury, Batty slipped quietly back into the first-team's consciousness.

With a 3-3 draw and 90 minutes of play behind him, the 32-year-old has his sights on a place on the substitutes' bench against Sunderland tomorrow having last played in the Premiership on November 28 last year.

A 20-minute appearance in a Worthington Cup tie at Leicester 12 months ago represents his last first-team appearance; so close is he to a return to the top flight now that the man who replaced him that night at Filbert Street, Matthew Jones, was sold to the Foxes for £3m yesterday.

"This is a big week for me and it could end with me sat on the bench on Saturday," said Batty. "I am still a good month away from playing 90 minutes of first-team football, but there is no reason why I can't be sitting alongside Harry Kewell on the bench this weekend. A lot of people thought I was finished - me included - so it would be great to pull the shirt on once again and run out in front of a full house."

Batty was O'Leary's first signing when he returned to the club from Newcastle for £4.4m two years ago but has managed only 26 first-team appearances since. He was bought to add steel amongst the babyfaces yet proved far too brittle; he broke a rib against Southampton which bruised his heart. Steroid treatment only slowed the healing process before a calf strain and an acute achilles tendon injury left him completely floored.

He had surgery during the close season, but in August was examined by a Dutch specialist and ruled out for 12 months. "I'll be surprised if he plays at all this season," said a dismayed O'Leary then, sentiments shared by the player.

Yet Batty has worked as tirelessly off the field as he ever has done on it. Already ahead of schedule he completed 90 minutes of a specially arranged friendly against Huddersfield Town last week. "I'd be lying if I said I'd felt good after the Huddersfield game," he said. "To be perfectly honest I was knackered - I thought I'd breeze through it after a couple of weeks training, but my legs were like lead and I seemed to spend most of the game tripping over the ball."

Not that his inability to stay upright worried O'Leary. "It's great to see David back on green grass again, but he's still got a long way to go yet," he said. "Even if we could get him back in January that would be a massive boost to all of us and a lot earlier than I was led to believe. That's down to the medical lads here, and to David's mental response and his application. We've just got to see how he goes."

In his absence, his team-mates have excelled in the Champions League, but stuttered in the Premiership. A wise old head is needed and that fillip may be just around the corner.

Last night's match provided a vaguely competitive edge, although Batty plodded calmly around, rarely breaking above a trot, sliding square passes to and fro.

"David's a smashing lad, a Leeds lad," said the chairman Peter Ridsdale. "He is a reminder of our youth policy even if he is now one of the more senior players at the club. Now I cannot wait to see him playing in the first team again."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: The Apartment

fields.headline: The Apartment
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Jack Lemmon and Shirley MacLaine give the sweetest and most human performances imaginable.
fields.body:
Billy Wilder's bittersweet comedy about Jack Lemmon's put-upon office worker, bullied by his superiors into loaning them his conveniently-located Manhattan apartment for their extra-marital shenanigans, looks as fresh as a daisy after 40 years. It might be redolent of an early-Playboy male world of sexual conquest and brittle pseudo-sophistication, but its shabby little tale of socio-sexual envy is the ancestor of 21st-century corporate gender politics.

In other ways, The Apartment is the racy American cousin of David Lean's Brief Encounter. I can't see the traffic on Jack Lemmon's staircase without thinking of the ashen and furious Trevor Howard, caught with Celia Johnson in his colleague's flat, icily acknowledging how sordid the whole thing looks. Lemmon's giant office, with its infinite rows of desks and adding machines in vertiginous perspective lines, arguably anticipated Ermanno Olmi's Il Posto of 1961 and perhaps Tony Hancock's The Rebel the same year. Lemmon and Shirley MacLaine give the sweetest and most human performances imaginable: twin oases of human innocence in this shallow murky water of NY cynicism. Not to be missed on any account.

webTitle: Video releases

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Virgin Suicides |  Mission: Impossible 2
fields.trailText: The Virgin Suicides | Mission: Impossible 2
fields.body:
The Virgin Suicides Rental and DVD (£19.99) Fox Pathé Cert 15 ***

An idyllic, dreamlike and thoroughly mysterious film, The Virgin Suicides, with its white-clad disappearing blondes, has far more in common with Peter Weir's Picnic at Hanging Rock than any American film I can think of. It's a mood piece, deliberately paced and filmed with subtlety and discretion, and is a million miles away from a normal US teen movie and the standard look back at its 1970s setting - no flares, bongs or afros on show.

Some of the decade's blander love songs (Carole King, Gilbert O'Sullivan) are, however, used as an ironic counterpart to the grisly subject matter - the suicide of a family's entire generation in a secure, affluent Michigan suburb. The film wants you to make up your own mind why, and fill in the gaps deliberately left by writer-director Sofia Coppola. The teenagers' parents (James Woods and Kathleen Turner) are not monsters, just a little strict. There's a key exchange early on: "You're not old enough to know how bad life gets." "You've obviously never been a teenage girl."

Though a little anaemic in places, it is a confident debut by Coppola. This must be particularly sweet after her acting in Godfather III (an under-prepared sub for Winona Ryder) was met with such universal condemnation. The other key contribution here comes from cinematographer Edward Lachman. He gives the film a look as soft and dreamlike as his Erin Brockovich was tough and brutal.

Mission: Impossible 2
Rental, retail (£16.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Paramount Cert 15
***

The "should you choose to accept it..." bit and the TV music theme survive from Mission: Impossible's small-scale origins, but otherwise this is pretty much a James Bond franchise by other means. To perk it up, Tom Cruise (a co-producer as well as the star) called up John Woo to put his trademark on it. So you have doves fluttering about indoors, lots of flames and the violence achieves that balletic-mythic dimension he's famous for, mainly in a stunning final fight. Of course, Hollywood was copying Woo's moves right through the 90s, so his style has lost a little freshness.

Most of the stunts here look proficient rather than inspired and the liberal use of face masks only acts as a reminder that if you want a Woo film to mess with your mind as well as your eyeballs, you'd be better off giving his phenomenal Face/Off another look. That was pure Woo where this is a job for hire, but inspired moments remain - check the brilliant red in the flamenco scene where Cruise meets love interest Thandie Newton (the director says he based it on West Side Story) and the touch of amazing grace when villain Dougray Scott catches Newton's windblown scarf with split-second timing.

Newton is a great improvement on the usual Bond bimbo. Her startling debut in Flirting co-starred one Nicole Kidman, so sometimes a producer's wife makes useful suggestions. Ving Rhames is the other survivor from M:I. There's a plot of sorts, about a man-made virus and its antidote but it's the look, the sheen and the love of hi-tech gadgets that stay with you. The DVD looks fine in widescreen and includes a raft of interviews, director's commentary and stunt explanations.

That was pure Woo where this is a job for hire, but inspired moments remain - check the brilliant red in the flamenco scene where Cruise meets love interest Thandie Newton (the director says he based it on West Side Story) and the touch of amazing grace when villain Dougray Scott catches Newton's windblown scarf with split-second timing. Newton is a great improvement on the usual Bond bimbo. Her startling debut in Flirting co-starred one Nicole Kidman, so sometimes a producer's wife makes useful suggestions. Ving Rhames is the other survivor from M:I. There's a plot of sorts, about a man-made virus and its antidote but it's the look, the sheen and the love of hi-tech gadgets that stay with you. The DVD looks fine in widescreen and includes a raft of interviews, director's commentary and stunt explanations.

webTitle: Meet the Parents

fields.headline: Meet the Parents
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A film with lots of funny lines and actors doing an impeccable technical job, but it is somehow less than the sum of its parts.
fields.body:
Until now, the only joke in general circulation about the German name "Focker" has been the celebrated legend about the legless air ace Douglas Bader addressing the pupils of Cheltenham Ladies College about his wartime exploits: "So this fokker comes at me from out of the sun..." "Shouldn't we make it clear to the gels," says the headmistress faintly, "that we are talking about a particular type of German aircraft?" "Indeed so," nods Bader, "This fokker was flying a Messerschmitt."

Now a refinement - if that is the word - of this has arrived with Jay Roach's amiable new sub-Farrelly comedy Meet the Parents, in which male nurse Greg Focker (Ben Stiller) has the weekend-from-hell at the house of Jack and Dina Byrnes (Robert De Niro and Blythe Danner), the parents of Pam (Teri Polo), the woman he loves and wants to marry. Jack turns to his wife in private and hisses: "Oh my God. Pam's middle name is Martha. That would make her... Pamela Martha Focker."

So he's called Focker, and there's the Martha line. But that's it. With a movie that so obviously recalls Stiller's performance in There's Something About Mary you can't help but wonder how the Farrelly brothers would have developed the Focker gag. It wouldn't have been with much more ingenuity exactly, but surely with much more of the essential tactlessness and repetition that justifies its inclusion in the script in the first place.

Either way, this reasonably amiable, watchable farce bears the same relationship to the Farrellys that Diet Coke does to the original. There is something low-sodium about it. As Dr Evil says to his son in Austin Powers 2, an earlier movie by Jay Roach: "Just one calorie - not evil enough!" It has the feeling, sometimes, of a TV pilot development of "Mary", in which the signature flourish of bad taste has been scaled down and the keynote of filth muted.

When Greg nervously arrives at Jack's house, he immediately gets into his bad books for not liking cats. In every other respect a ruthless martinet, Jack is embarrassingly soppy about the family cat, disturbingly named Jinx, and he even calls it by singing a version of the chorus from What's New Pussycat?: "Jinxie-cat, jinxie-cat, where are youuuu?" It's a nice cringe-making touch from De Niro, which he crowns by revealing that he has trained Jinxie to urinate not in traditional kitty litter but in the toilet itself. It sounds promising. But our expectations, simultaneously heightened and depraved as they are by Farrelly animal-scenes, lead us inevitably to yearn for some major grossout from this cat. Although Jinxie is integral to the plot, the much hoped-for awe-inspiring moment of horror never really materialises.

Ben Stiller gives us his distinctive prickly amour-propre in recognising yet resenting the foolish situations that he finds himself in: he can never totally be a good sport, and looks too much like a romantic lead to be an out-an-out clown. In this, he has something of Albert Brooks or Billy Crystal. But his comic presence has a disconcerting shrewdness and sourness sometimes, that was given full and appropriate expression in Stiller's performance in Black and White as the self-loathing crooked cop.

As the grim father-in-law, Robert De Niro is again straining for the Second Act in his career as the Grand Old Man of light-ish comedy. With his habitual rat-trap mouth expression, he radiates a certain menace, and certainly everyone that comes within his forcefield looks intimidated - and that may, I suspect, reflect the effect the great man has on the rest of the cast anyway. The funniest turn comes from Owen Wilson as Pam's absurdly wealthy ex-boyfriend Kevin, who apart from being hogwhimperingly rich is a talented carpenter - inspired by a major role model: "Who better than Christ?"

But his character, like everyone else in the film, is never quite allowed enough air to breathe. Meet the Parents is a film with lots of funny lines and actors doing an impeccable technical job, but it is somehow less than the sum of its parts. It strains to come to life, but never quite makes it.

webTitle: The 6th Day

fields.headline: The 6th Day
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Replete with clichés and rip-offs and the twist ending is visible a mile off.
fields.body:
The most distinguished member of Hollywood's Austrian-American community lumbers once again onto our screens in another of these heavy apocalyptic action movies with all the style, grace and manoeuvrability of the Humvee that Arnie loves to drive around in. The 6th Day is a futuristic bio-tech conspiracy thriller that is not so much Blade Runner as Blade Walker, Blade Limper or just Blade Lie Down and Fall Asleeper. The America of the future is a land where cloning is commonplace. But there is an ethical "Sixth Day" law which prevents human cloning - the sixth day being that on which God exercised his sole trademarked prerogative in this respect.

A sinister corporation is cloning human beings with the help of the ethically troubled Dr Griffin Weir (Robert Duvall) and they create a double of Arnie, with a view to installing this genetically modified alter-ego in Arnie's life with Arnie's wife and kids - and murdering the original.

It is replete with clichés and rip-offs and the twist ending is visible a mile off. Roger Spottiswoode directs, the man who helmed the Bond movie Tomorrow Never Dies, and that connection might remind you, at one or two removes, of Basil Dearden's much superior 1970 movie starring Roger Moore: The Man Who Haunted Himself. As for Arnie, he is looking very much the spent volcano. My own suggestion now is that he does a German-language movie: this might impart a certain something to his performance.

webTitle: Fresh prince of Denmark

fields.headline: Fresh prince of Denmark
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw applauds a stylish American Hamlet that audaciously relocates Shakespeare to modern corporate New York
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Plunges into the drama and the claustrophobia with terrific gusto... This Hamlet is intelligent, energetic and very refreshing.
fields.body:
After the stately Heritage Shoppe Hamlets from Kenneth Branagh and Mel Gibson, Michael Almereyda's new ultra-contemporary adaptation set in corporate New York City is a documentary Hamlet, a fly-on-the-wall Hamlet. It's a Hamlet in which you almost expect Nick Broomfield to wander into shot with his earphones and his microphone, saying: "Um, Hamlet, if I could just - my production company wrote to you asking if we could - um, your Highness? If I could just - when you said 'a little more than kin and less than kind', do you mean that there's a compromise between the two...?"

Actually, Almereyda cuts that famous first line of Hamlet's, with all its sneering dumb insolence, cuts all of To Be Or Not To Be except for the first line which is repeated on a kind of video loop, loses Yorick's skull, and with it - perhaps thankfully - the opportunity for quite a bit of Marilyn Manson gothery. Ethan Hawke is the sweet Prince, with a goatee, a woolly hat and, confusingly sometimes, a chalkstripe suit with no tie - looking like someone keen to return to grad school at Wittenberg University (Dr Faustus's alma mater), but unsure whether to do philosophy or an MBA.

He has returned home to find his father - the former CEO of the Denmark Corporation - dead and his mother Gertrude (Diane Venora) married to his smooth killer Claudius (Kyle MacLachlan), who has taken over the running of the firm. The tense conferences, courtly encounters and hugger-mugger whispers and assassinations are played out in a kind of bad dream along Manhattan sidewalks, suites at the five-star "Elsinore Hotel", laundromats, apartment buildings, corridors and rooftops where Sam Shepard's haggard ghost burdens Hamlet with the duty of revenge and all its moral dilemmas.

One of the wittiest scenes sees Hamlet, morose and almost torpid with introspection, drifting through a branch of Blockbuster in which every movie genre is "Action".

The original Hamlet was a scholar and bibliophile: Almereyda's Hamlet turns him into a video freak, obsessively recording everything with various DV gizmos and playing them back: his girlfriend Ophelia is a photographer, who in her mad scene distributes Polaroids of flowers rather than the blooms themselves. When it comes to the play-within-a-play which Hamlet hopes will terrify Claudius into definitively revealing his guilt, the Prince is inspired, not by a bombastic actor's verse, but by a video recording of James Dean. And he presents a video-collage of animation, old 1950s footage and 1970s porn.

This is a stylish and inventive reading of Shakespeare and Ethan Hawke plays Hamlet perfectly satisfactorily, though he turns him into a bit of an indie-band lead singer. Almereyda's direction steers him away from any of Hamlet's humour and exuberance; we lose much of the ambiguity of Hamlet's mad-act: is he pretending to be mad to evade questioning, or evade his own sense of the horrific truth about what is happening? Moreover, Almereyda persistently makes the vulgar mistake of putting soliloquies onto a voiceover over a shot of the tight-lipped protagonist, as a kind of "thinks" bubble. It was the sort of thing Polanski did with his 1971 Macbeth: a disconcerting and unnecessary trick which you just don't need on film, and which lessens the visceral impact of speech.

The supporting cast has some real gems, though: Julia Stiles, in some ways reprising her performance in the Taming of the Shrew update Ten Things I Hate About You, is excellent, as ever - sensitive, sexy, angry: surely an Academy Award nominee? A really startling success is Bill Murray as Polonius, underplaying the role - counter to the English stage tradition of portraying him as a doddery old idiot - and emerging as a foolish but plausible father-figure. Elsewhere, Steve Zahn and Dechen Thurman play a slightly Bill-and-Ted-ish Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, to whose marginal existence we have learned, since Stoppard, to pay disproportionate attention. Karl Geary is a reticent and morose Horatio, accompanied (bafflingly) by silent girlfriend "Marcella", a gender transformation from the original's Marcellus. Liev Schreiber does an honest job as Laertes, but he seems to be trying for a rather chi-chi quasi-British Shakespearian accent and Sam Shepard himself has some mangled country-ish vowels, worryingly similar to those used by Michael Keaton in his dire performance as Dogberry in Branagh's Much Ado About Nothing.

The modern setting works fine, but the idea of the Corporation replacing the State - however pleasingly apposite it is, given that globalisation is the key worry of the 21st century - loses much of Shakespeare's sense of real violence and warfare raging outside, just within earshot of this Freudian family scene. When Fortinbras's soldiers overrun a Denmark whose Royal court has been transformed into a heap of corpses, Almereyda's movie inevitably transforms this into a boardroom drama; the "1945 Berlin" atmosphere is lost, and the ending depoliticised. And Almereyda has stolen the idea of making a TV newsreader into a modern chorus from Baz Luhrmann's Romeo+Juliet, here ending on a pretty banal Jerry Springer-style "thought".

But there is still so much to enjoy in this film: it plunges into the drama and the claustrophobia with terrific gusto, and the setting exhilaratingly defamiliarises both the classic poetry and the modern cityscape itself. Once again, the question presents itself: why can't we do this? Why is the British movie industry so inadequate in the face of this kind of challenge? No one could dare patronise this American Shakespeare movie when we seem utterly unable or unwilling to try anything similar, contenting ourselves all too often with sloppy gangster comedies. This Hamlet is intelligent, energetic and very refreshing.

webTitle: Judges get a lesson in sex and gender

fields.headline: Judges get a lesson in sex and gender
fields.trailText: The assertions that homosexuality is not contagious and mothers who work full-time are not neglectful might seem like pretty obvious statements of the truth. Hardly worth repeating, in fact. Unless, that is, you belong to that overwhelmingly male, white, middle-aged or elderly group educated mainly at single-sex public schools and known in the past for dropping spectacular social blunders - judges.
fields.body:
The assertions that homosexuality is not contagious and mothers who work full-time are not neglectful might seem like pretty obvious statements of the truth. Hardly worth repeating, in fact. Unless, that is, you belong to that overwhelmingly male, white, middle-aged or elderly group educated mainly at single-sex public schools and known in the past for dropping spectacular social blunders - judges.

In a bid to rid the bench of outdated prejudices the latest chapters of the Equal Treatment Bench Book, launched yesterday by the Judicial Studies Board includes guidelines and advice designed to prevent those embarrassing or offensive interventions.

The book will introduce judges for the first time to the minefields of gender and sexual orientation.

They are already well up to speed on race, which was covered by the first part of the bench book published last year. That section informed them that smoking cannabis was an important part of religious experience for Rastafarians, who treated it as a sacrament.

The chapter on gender acknowledges that most judges and lawmakers are men and "some argue that existing law continues to reflect belief about men's and women's roles that are no longer the norm".

For example, "one needs to be careful not to regard a woman who works full-time as a selfish mother or neglectful of her children. She may also carry the main responsibility for their care. Conversely, a man who stays at home to look after children is not lazy or incompetent."

The judge who branded a rape victim guilty of contributory negligence and the one who told the jury that "women who say no don't always mean no" have long since retired. But judges, it seems, still need reminding of a 1973 case in which it was held that "whereas every consent involves submission, mere submission is not of itself consent".

Although defendants in rape cases can no longer cross-examine the woman personally, the guide notes state: "The demeaning experience of cold, skilful and remorseless questioning by a detached advocate can be even worse."

Judges are told that rape trauma syndrome may make a victim appear calm and composed, masking her true feelings. So her demeanour when giving evidence is not a guide to her truthfulness. And "contrary to common belief, the victim of rape whose attacker was known to her will frequently suffer trauma for longer than if the attacker was a stranger".

Few judges are gay, so perhaps judges need to be informed that "nearly all homosexuals were brought up in heterosexual homes", and "there is no evidence that gay men are more likely to abuse children than heterosexual men".

Bench marks

 No reputable medical opinion now suggests that homosexuality is a catchable or pathological condition.

 A woman who works full-time is not to be regarded as a selfish or neglectful mother.

 Avoid words that imply an evaluation of the sexes, however subtle. For example, use "husband and wife", instead of "man and wife".

 Do not assume that the male in a family is the main breadwinner.

 Being lesbian or gay has nothing whatsoever to do with paedophile desire.

webTitle: President gives farewell warning on global warming

fields.headline: President gives farewell warning on global warming
fields.standfirst: Clinton says he hopes Bush 'will not turn his back on the world'
fields.trailText: Clinton says he hopes Bush 'will not turn his back on the world'
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton used his last big foreign speech yesterday to focus on the plight of the developing world, especially the devastation caused by Aids and by climate change.

Mr Clinton, speaking at Warwick University at the end of his three day visit to Ireland and Britain, ran through a catalogue of problems facing the poorest countries, and said there was a wonderful opportunity to tackle these to create a century of peace and prosperity.

He hoped George W Bush, who during his campaign had been isolationist, would not turn the back on the world. He said: "For eight years, I have done what I could to lead my country down that [international] path. I think for the rest of our lives, we had all better stay on it."

The president's idealistic speech was well-received by an invited audience that ranged from the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to academics such as Stephen Hawking. Joining him on the platform were Tony Blair, who had phoned Mr Bush to congratulate him, Hillary Clinton, daughter Chelsea and Mr Blair's wife, Cherie.

Mr Clinton, who has broken the presidential record for trips abroad while Mr Bush has only been out of the US six times, said that globalisation - and the creation of a global media village - meant "we can no longer have the excuse of ignorance. We can choose not to act, but we can no longer choose not to know."

He added: "Global poverty is a powderkeg, ignitable by our indifference."

Rejecting the maintenance of trade barriers, he pleaded with developed countries such as Britain and France, as well as the US, to help poorer nations by reducing, or even ending, subsidies to their own farmers.

"If the wealthiest countries ended our agricultural subsi dies, levelling the playing fields for the world's farmers, that alone could increase the income of developing countries by $20bn a year."

He urged the continuance of debt relief to the poorest countries and more cash from developed countries to help provide clean water supplies and tackle malnutrition and, above all, Aids.

Western countries should pay pharmaceutical companies, either directly or through tax credits, to develop vaccines since the poor could not pay for them.

He had little time for those who criticised the west for suggesting that computers were not a solution because electricity was in short supply in some developing countries and that the money should be spent on health or other pressing problems. It was a false choice: "There should not be a choice between Pentium and penicillin."

On global warming, he said: "This is a big deal." The last decade had been the hottest for a thousand years and there was a danger that the Florida Everglades could end up covered in water if no action was taken to cut down on greenhouse gases.

He expressed disappointment that the latest round of talks on the climate had failed and urged the developing world not to be suspicious of the proposed cuts in gas emissions, saying it should not be seen as an attempt by the rich to keep the poor in poverty. Mr Clinton, speaking at Warwick University at the end of his three day visit to Ireland and Britain, ran through a catalogue of problems facing the poorest countries, and said there was a wonderful opportunity to tackle these to create a century of peace and prosperity. webTitle: BAA in domain name wrangle

fields.headline: Close shave for BAA in domain name wrangle
fields.standfirst: Useful link: Baa.com
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The owner of a bizarre website dedicated to sheep has won an out-of-court settlement from the British Airports Authority, writes Daniel Rogers.
Useful link: Baa.com
fields.body:
The owner of a bizarre website dedicated to sheep has won a large out-of-court settlement from the British Airports Authority in the latest in a series of David and Goliath battles over domain names.

BAA has paid Tom Bourke, owner of Baa.com, an undisclosed amount to avoid further legal wrangling.

Mr Bourke could not comment on the case or the payment because of a confidentiality agreement.

However BAA said it was the payment was the equivalent to what it would have paid out in litigation. Observers estimate this to be around £200,000.

Mr Bourke's baa.com features a Dolly-cloned sheep puzzle game and other sheep-related news.

BAA originally offered Mr Bourke £8,000 for the name. He reportedly asked for £2m. In April BAA announced it was serving a writ against him.

Months of legal shenanigans have cost Mr Bourke over £50,000. He ran a campaign against BAA on the site.

BAA says it now owns the domain name and says it will use it as its global website.

The news comes on the same day that film giant Warner Brothers dropped legal threats against a British schoolgirl's Harry Potter website.

Last week Warner Brothers, owner of the film rights to author JK Rowling's blockbuster book, warned 15-year-old Claire Field after discovering she owned the domain name www.harrypotterguide.co.uk.

It gave Ms Field 28 days to hand it over and offerd her a £9.99 fee.

But Warner Brothers head of publicity Barbara Broliatti saw sense and is now looking at granting Claire a free licence to become an official Harry Potter site.

webTitle: Uncomfortable for some

fields.headline: Uncomfortable for some
fields.standfirst: A mock war crimes trial of a deceased emperor has embarrassed and angered the Japanese establishment, writes Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: A mock war crimes trial of a deceased emperor has embarrassed and angered the Japanese establishment, writes Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
The Japanese establishment was in denial again this week over one of the country's most shameful activities in the second world war, and the extent to which the deceased emperor Hirohito might have been involved.

On Tuesday, a mock tribunal held in Tokyo to judge who was responsible for the imperial army's use of sex slaves found the wartime emperor, along with several senior politicians and military leaders, guilty of crimes against humanity.

Presiding judge Gabrielle McDonald, former president of the Yugoslavia War Crimes Tribunal, said "the emperor knew, or should have known, the troops were committing atrocities".

Another of the judges, Christine Chinkin, a law professor at the University of London, said individual victims were "entitled to compensation from the government".

As the trial was organised by the victims and their support groups, it could certainly not claim to be impartial. The defendents - dead wartime leaders - were not represented and the judges' ruling carried no legal authority.

In many other ways, it was a historic, controversial and emotional event that attracted huge international attention. But as far as most people in Japan were concerned the tribunal made hardly a ripple because the domestic media mysteriously decided to give it almost no coverage.

It could hardly be argued that this omission was based on a lack of newsworthiness of the event, which broke new ground in several ways. The organisers billed the tribunal as a "moral court" that would provide a sense of justice to former "comfort women" - the euphemism for the estimated 200,000 Asian women who were forced to work in brothels organised by the imperial army to control sexual frustration and the spread of venereal disease among its troops.

This subject - along with the question of the emperor's responsibility for wartime atrocities - was not covered at the 1946-48 Tokyo War Crimes Tribunal because the allies were seeking to rebuild Japan as an ally in the Cold War and few of the women were willing to come forward.

With more than 40 victims giving testimony, the tribunal last weekend was the largest ever gathering of former "comfort women." For the first time, victims from North and South Korea spoke on the same platform, along with others from the Philippines, Taiwan, Indonesia, China and the Netherlands. In two days of harrowing testimonies, women related how they were dragged away from their homes by Japanese troops to work in "comfort stations" where they were forced to service dozens of soldiers each day. Some were as young as 10 when it started and most said they had been scarred for life physically, mentally and socially. In almost every case, they had been unable to marry or have children.

The Japanese government only acknowledged its involvement in organising "comfort stations" in 1993. Since then it has issued a vaguely-worded apology and encouraged Japanese corporations and individuals to contribute to a non-governmental fund to compensate the women.

But donations to the fund have fallen short of expectations and most of the victims are refusing payments on the grounds that Japan is evading its responsibility.

Privately, right wing journalists say the comfort women - and others seeking compensation such as former slave labourers and prisoners of war - are simply trying to extort more money from Japan. There is also a growing movement, which includes academics, politicians and sports stars, who argue that Japan was wrong to admit its involvement because the comfort women have no evidence for their claims.

While such views are expressed in public only by a minority, politicians from the conservative Liberal Democratic Party often voice their anger at having to constantly apologise for the war. In a sharp contrast with Germany, many senior Japanese politicians believe that their country's war guilt has been exaggerated.

Given the events of last week, it is easy to see how such views can flourish when the flow of information through the media is subject to such self-censorship. The comfort women have had a chance - albeit only in a mock tribunal - to set the record straight, but several expressed disappointment that domestic media coverage meant that for most Japanese, it was as though the "trial" - like the events of 55 years ago - never happened.

webTitle: Week 3: Pushkar to Jaipur

fields.headline: Sunsets, safaris and special tea
fields.standfirst: Sue gets a henna tattoo, meets a maharaja and a camel called D-rrrrr, and toasts the season with 'special tea'
fields.trailText: Week 3: Pushkar to Jaipur Sue gets a henna tattoo, meets a maharaja and a camel called D-rrrrr, and toasts the season with 'special tea'
fields.body:
Namaste!
Another action-packed week in India. Definite highlights were the puppet theatre and the camel safari. Lowlights - an absolute stinker of a cold and hours spent in internet cafes waiting for dodgy connections that fail the minute you go near the 'send' button. I bet the other two are not having this much trouble!

On Saturday we had another day in Pushkar. I am obviously too slow as I ended the day smothered in dye - from being blessed at the ghats - and henna - when my hand was held in a vice-like grip by a very small woman outside the temple (Look at the pictures).

After Pushkar it was on to Jodhpur to visit the very impressive Meherangra Fort where you can look over the blue city (apparently the blue in the wash was originally to prevent termites).

Jodhpur is the only place since Bombay that I have not felt totally comfortable wandering around on my own. That evening we had the first of our proxy Christmas dos. Luckily the hotel served beer. The waiters all shook their heads as we made paper hats out of serviettes. Anyone who knows me will be amazed at how little alcohol I have drunk - mainly because many areas are dry - also there is no wine in India.

On to Jaisalmer which I liked very much. The centre is a walled fort full of narrow lanes heaving with shops, cafes and guesthouses where you can easily get lost or trapped by a cow coming in the opposite direction. In the evening we went to the Desert Museum to see a Rajastani puppet show. It was delightful - innocent, charming and funny. The owner, Mr Sharma, on a crusade to preserve the ancient art, was excited to hear that his show would get a mention on the internet. If ever you are in Jaisalmer do go! The local maharaja was in the foyer, looking suitably aloof, portly and beautifully mustached.

The next day was truly exciting - the camel safari. I admit to some trepidation as the camels here are huge. Bruce put on a very brave face. (Look at the pictures). But it was great fun. We could chose our camels, but 'Big Mike' was firmly shown a large strong beast. Mine was apparently called D-rrrrrrrrr and was very docile.

We trekked through the desert for a couple of hours with a rest on some amazing dunes, and ended at 'sunset point' and a young drinks seller latched onto us while we waited for the sunset. With the naturalness of youth, he could not disguise his shock and disgust when, having cleared my streaming nose yet again, I put the soggy tissue back in my pocket. The others fell about laughing at his expression, but it was a salutary lesson in not judging cultural differences. At least I had used my unclean left hand to do it!

We were taken to our campsite in the desert, where the crew prepared a simple but delicious meal which we ate round a fire. We were blessed by a huge full moon which lit up the whole desert. We even emerged from the thick quilts to watch the sun rise. It was a magical experience.

Not feeling too well I had a lazy day next day before we returned to Jodhpur and on to Jaipur. The long journeys are broken up by Carol's daily 'lessons' on the history of India and its religions - she keeps threatening a test at the end of the trip. She also has an endless fund of tour guide stories. How will we be remembered I wonder? I will be the one who kept sidling off only to be found in yet another net cafe.

For the journeys I also treat myself to a little walkman time. My children each made me a tape which I am rationing and listening to in birth order. I have just finished 'Eclectjetter' by my eldest - great tape Ben! I confess to a little lump in my throat when I heard 'Don't you worry bout a thing' by Stevie Wonder.

Jaipur is a busy bustling place and is known as the pink city, although terracotta is closer. The colour was in honour of a visit from the Prince of Wales in the 19th century. We visited the Amber fort yesterday and the city museum and observatory today.

This afternoon I am hoping to be able, at long last, to be able to reply to a few of your emails. Be assured that even if I can't reply to them all they are being read. It is a strange but good and comforting feeling to know that people are following your journey and wishing you well.

The digital camera is a great ice breaker with the locals who love to see their picture on the camera. One net cafe owner gave me a disc and asked me to take shots of him and his shop. He then sat at his computer admiring himself while my machine crashed away!

May I just say Merry Christmas to my work colleagues who are having their Christmas party today. I hope you received my 'ode from India' and I will raise my glass of 'special tea'(gassy beer) to you all this evening.

I get a surprise when I remember what it will be like at home at this time of year - all that rushing about and stress in the lead up to Christmas. I will miss my friends and family but nothing else. Do they do curried turkey in Kathmandu?

My last week in India is coming up, and my last week with the group. It was a good decision to start this way. I am not sure how well I could have coped with India on my own, and I certainly would not have seen and done so much. It has been great.

Til next week - bye!

webTitle: Back on a learning curve

fields.headline: Back on a learning curve
fields.standfirst: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen attends a meeting on a report judgment that the council is not serving its people adequately
fields.trailText: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen attends a meeting on a report judgment that the council is not serving its people adequately.
fields.body:
This was a week that definitely got better as it went on. Monday had been marked with a red spot on my year planner for some considerable time - and I don't use the red spots lightly.

It was the night of the special council meeting at which the joint review was to be presented. We've been working on the action plan to address the findings for so long now it takes some effort of imagination to remember how it feels to hear the results for the first time. It was a sober occasion, which was appropriate to the judgment that Lambeth is not serving people well.

The good news was that I was scheduled to follow the joint review presentation with one that would go through what we have done and are planning to do to address the problems. The bad news was that the PowerPoint technology failed at the start of the evening and I had to sit through the presentation - using back-up overhead slides - realising that my only back-ups were the hard copies of my presentation, which anyone with less than 20/20 vision in poor light would have great difficulty reading. In the end, the mayor summoned a replacement projector and I could continue in 21st century style.

Once that was over it was straight into another council meeting that had been requisitioned to discuss the Barratt report and SSI inspection of children's services. I emerged at about 11pm feeling like a limp dishrag - but with a sense that the proverbial watershed had been reached. No more reports and inspections until September next year. There was a fabulous turnout of managers and a senior colleague from our health authority, who all agreed that there is a sense of optimism and a clear plan to take us forward.

As part of the preparation for members I had put together a list of achievements over the last year. Heartening to see it stretched to three pages and included some pretty meaty stuff, so I took the time to go through it at the regular managers' meeting on Wednesday. This - coupled with presentations of bouquets to staff who had been nominated for commendation by clients - created a real feeling of positive energy.

This carried me through what would otherwise have been a rather daunting "star chamber" meeting with the chief executive, leader, director of finance and what felt like hordes of others senior finance members and officers. It was a learning experience, not least because we are still getting to the bottom of the budgets and some old legacies. Once again, however, I was left with feelings of great corporate support backed up with tangible offers of resources to help crack the issues.

On Thursday I visited our stand at Community Care Live and added my efforts to persuade people that Lambeth is the happening place in social services. We signed up 47 people who are interested in working for us, so we were obviously convincing.

The week finished in the warm haze of the corporate management team's Christmas lunch, over which I shall draw a discreet veil.

webTitle: Jazz CD of the week:  Trygve Seim -  Different Rivers

fields.headline: He did it Norway
fields.standfirst: John Fordham  hails a master of tantric sax
fields.trailText: John Fordham hails a master of tantric sax
fields.body:
Trygve Seim

Different Rivers (ECM 1744)

*****

£13.99

Destined to become one of ECM's classics, this is close enough to the German label's north European ambient-jazz stereotype to be conveniently dismissed as more of the same by the idiom's detractors. Yet it's more explicitly jazzlike than much of Jan Garbarek, more dramatic and idiomatically varied than much minimalist ECM empty-fjord music, and despite its general slowness of pace is jammed with subtle textural excitement and surprise.

Seim is a tenor and soprano saxophonist from Norway, which is an identity that carries a lot of baggage. But Garbarek's influence is not particularly evident. The sound more closely resembles a free-jazz, up-tempo Wayne Shorter playing Ben Webster on a very slow-running record player on slow pieces, and at other times no kind of sax player you've ever heard - more like wind in trees, or chimneys, or wooden flutes.

webTitle: Wright named IPR president

fields.headline: Wright lands IPR presidency
fields.trailText: The Institute of Public Relations has named Ian Wright, group communications director at Diageo, as its president for 2001. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Institute of Public Relations has named Ian Wright, group communications director at Diageo, as its president for 2001.

Mr Wright will take over the presidency from Alison Clarke, chief executive of Shandwick Asia Pacific, on January 1.

He has said he wants to concentrate on three key areas during his presidency: setting and raising standards in public relations education and training; improving IPR services for members; and building support for the IPR among practitioners under 30.

"Increasingly the management of reputation is moving to the top of the corporate agenda," said Mr Wright.

"At the same time, not-for-profit organisations have recognised that their reputation is a key weapon in the battle for air space.

"Public relations and communications specialists have the chance to own the management of reputation and so be at the heart of the management decision process.

"But we face a strong challenge from other professionals. Management consultants have identified the management of reputation as a critical opportunity for business development.

"So this is a critical moment in the development of our business. In the next year the IPR will take a lead in charting a course for our business."

Before he joined Diageo, Mr Wright was director of communications for chemist chain Boots.

He also acted as press spokesperson to Paddy Ashdown during the 1997 general election and 1999 European election campaigns.

webTitle: Cod quotas reduced to an all-time low

fields.headline: Cod quotas reduced to an all-time low
fields.standfirst:
Future bleak for British fishermen as emergency measures taken to rescue dwindling North Sea stocks on the brink of extinction

Special report: the fish crisis
fields.trailText: Future bleak for British fishermen as emergency measures taken to rescue dwindling North Sea stocks on the brink of extinction
fields.body:
The government bowed to the inevitable last night and agreed to endorse the biggest cuts in North Sea cod quotas ever seen in a controversial decision which it acknowledges will put hundreds of UK fishermen out of work.

However, last night at a marathon meeting of EU fisheries ministers in Brussels the UK was continuing to hold out for less swingeing catch quotas for other species such as haddock and whiting.

But for the British fishermen who trawl for cod the future is bleak - quotas for next year are set to be slashed by 40% to just 48,600 tonnes, down from this year's figure of 81,000 tonnes which is already a historic low.

Although the meeting was far from over last night UK officials confirmed that a deal on cod was already done - all that remained was to agree quotas for other species such as North Sea prawns which the EC wants to cut by 20%.

Elliot Morley, the UK's fisheries minister, told the Guardian: "We're now ready to go along with the European commission's proposals on cod. We accept that there is a proper scientific case for a cod recovery programme since stocks are in such a dire state."

North Sea cod stocks have dwindled to their lowest levels since records began in 1963 and are now on the brink of extinction thanks to overfishing.

There are an estimated 70,000 tonnes of adult cod in the North Sea compared with a figure of 250,000 tonnes in the 1960s. The minimum stock level to guarantee the species' survival is 150,000 tonnes.

But Mr Morley argued last night that the EC's proposed cuts in catches for other species were unacceptable to the UK.

"We think that the commission has gone beyond scientific advice for a number of other species using an across the board kind of approach."

"I'm not trying to argue up the quotas simply to get more fish but some of these cuts are not scientifically justified."

The EC was last night also pressing for a 74% cut for hake catches next year together with a 56% cutback in cod caught off the west of Scotland and a 35% cut on west of Scotland whiting.

Cod have become so scarce in the North Sea that a special recovery programme of the kind put in place for the Irish Sea would have to be agreed. That would involve the total closure of spawning areas at key times to protect breeding and young fish.

Barry Deas, head of Britain's National Federation of Fishermen's Organisations, admitted that the decisions would wreak havoc upon the UK's already hard-pressed fishing industry.

"It looks very bleak at this stage. Plans would be utterly disastrous. There are so many vessels that are already barely economically viable."

The EC insisted last night, however, that there was no choice if cod and other stocks are not to collapse altogether and said that member states were holding out for more modest quota cuts despite the seriousness of the situation.

"There's a lack of understanding that we have to cut so-called associated species, which are caught together with cod. Some member states want to decouple these quotas and this is completely unacceptable to us," spokesman Gregor Kreuzhuber argued.

Industry leaders have already warned that the cuts will put hundreds of fishermen out of work and acknowledge that many of those left in the business will have to be made to spend far fewer days at sea chasing an ever-dwindling number of fish.

Britain's fish and chip industry is also likely to find it more difficult to buy cod although much of what it sells is sourced from countries outside the EU.

webTitle: 'Politicians tried to rig Today vote'

fields.headline: 'Politicians tried to rig Today vote'
fields.trailText: Radio 4's Today axed its 'Personality of the Year' programme because politicians were trying to rig votes, it has emerged, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Radio 4's Today programme axed its popular "Personality of the Year" programme because politicians were trying to rig votes, it has emerged.

After four years, editor Rod Liddle wants to bring the vote back but has banned politicians from the nominations.

The BBC axed the award in 1996 after suspect nominations were received on behalf of a number of politicians.

On one occasion "a couple of dozen" letters in the same handwriting were received to nominate Teresa Gorman, Conservative MP for Billericay.

But according to a BBC News spokesman, "they were all at it".

And some politicial administrators had sent chain emails that included automated nominations from their friends and colleagues.

"I've decided to bar politicians because there is a real danger they or their supporters will try to rig the vote," said Mr Liddle.

It will be rebranded "Hero and Villain of the Year", with listeners also voting for their least favourite public figure.

A shortlist will be drawn up from December 18, with essayists giving their opinions on why certain "heroes" and "villains" should be nominated. Chris Woodhead, Matthew Pinsent, Susan Greenfield and Sir Bob Ayling will be the first to air their views on the nominations.

The final shortlist will be read on Wednesday December 27 and voting will end on Thursday December 28 at midnight.

The winners will be announced on the Today programme on Saturday December 30 and will be invited on to the programme.

webTitle: Extract from William Hague's speech to the Centre for Policy Studies

fields.headline: 'Less PC and more PCs'
fields.standfirst:
An extract from William Hague's speech to the Centre for Policy Studies

Special report: Macpherson report - one year on
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: An extract from William Hague's speech to the Centre for Policy Studies
fields.body:
We will make criminals scared of getting caught and scared of punishment, so they will choose not to commit crime. We will make convicted criminals pay a heavy price for their actions, so that others are scared off following their example. We will give our police force the backing and resources they deserve, so that there is less PC and more PCs. We will wage war against crime like no other government in the history of our country has ever done, and we will win. I say to the law abiding majority: I will give you back your country - I will give you back your streets, and your town centres, and your homes, and your shops.

The next Conservative government will need to challenge and replace decades of liberal thinking on crime.

Over that 40 years the murder rate doubled, violent crime has risen from 24,000 cases a year to 664,000, and burglaries have gone up more than tenfold to 1m a year. Yet there are some who still deny that crime and disorder are much worse today than they ever were.

There is a still more urgent task facing the next Conservative government, and that is restoring police morale which has been collapsed in so many places ever since the publication of the Macpherson report ... the tragedy of the Lawrence murder and the further urgent work that needs to be done building up trust between our ethnic communities and the police, do not excuse the way in which the Macpherson report has been used to brand every officer and every branch of the force as racist, has contributed directly to a collapse of police morale and recruitment, and has led to a crisis on our streets.

webTitle: Something fishy going on

fields.headline: Something fishy going on
fields.standfirst:
As ever, reports of Brussels bureaucrats destroying another British industry - in this case fishing - are wide of the mark, writes Andrew Osborn

Special report: fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: As ever, reports of Brussels bureaucrats destroying another British industry - in this case fishing - are wide of the mark, writes Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
Newspaper stories about 'swingeing cuts' in cod quotas imposed from Brussels are, excuse the pun, often wracked with red herrings. And the idea that the decline of cod stocks in the North Sea spells the end of what used to be Britain's favourite tucker - cod and chips - is a whopper of immense proportions.

It is true that Britain's fishing industry does find itself in an appalling state of affairs which, if the truth be told, it is unlikely to emerge from anytime soon.

It is also true that stocks of the venerable white fish in the North Sea have plummeted to their lowest levels since records begun. That's bad news if you're a fisherman and even worse news if you're a cod.

But it is not true that cod and chips as we know it will cease to exist as some newspapers would have you believe. To say this is the case makes a good story and makes readers feel even more sorry for the unfortunate fishermen whose job it is to chase after an ever dwindling number of fish, but it is highly misleading.

A lot of the cod sold in British chippies already comes from the waters around countries such as Iceland, Norway and Russia, while only 8 percent of the world's cod catch is sourced from the UK's territorial waters.

That's not to say that fish lovers across the country won't be hit by the decision to introduce what are without doubt the deepest cuts in cod quotas ever agreed.

They will. More and more cod will have to be imported from further afield which is likely to push up prices and fish and chip shops are increasingly bound to offer consumers cheaper alternative white fish suppers. But for those who really want cod and are willing to pay the price for what is, after all, an endangered species, supplies are not about to dry up.

There may be plenty of other fish in the sea but if it's cod you want, a species which is the victim of massive overfishing, then it seems only right that the price tag should be a bit higher.

Another popular myth about the fishing industry is that quota cuts are imposed by the European Commission or 'Brussels'. They are not. What really happens is that the EC each year comes up with some suggested reductions in catch quotas for the European Union's territorial waters based on the latest scientific advice.

But it is member states who haggle over the final figures and no deal is done until some kind of consensus has been reached. The EC may lean on certain countries to accept harsher cuts than they want to but the final decision rests with member states who can hold out for a better agreement if they are not happy.

But of course if you are a newspaper with a eurosceptic agenda this kind of story is manna from heaven. It's just another stone to throw at the all impinging beast that is Brussels. Grey, inhuman and hellbent on destroying what's left of our 'old' industries such as fishing and making cars.

Brussels now has another dilemna to face down: well know for its generosity when it comes to handing out subsidies and aid payments to Europe's hard pressed farmers, will it now be ready to do the same for Europe's ever dwindling number of fishermen?

webTitle: Welsh children's commissioner to break new ground

fields.headline: Welsh children's commissioner to break new ground
fields.trailText: Britain's first children's commissioner is about to start work, and children will play a big part in the running of the office. The new children's commissioner for Wales, Peter Clarke, will break new ground by appointing children in a key advisory role.
fields.body:
Britain's first children's commissioner is about to start work, and children will play a big part in the running of the office. The new children's commissioner for Wales, Peter Clarke, will break new ground by appointing children in a key advisory role.

His appointment itself was pioneering, with a dozen children drawn from across Wales playing a part by interviewing the six shortlisted candidates on the day prior to the formal interviews.

As Mr Clarke, currently director of Childline Cymru, gets used to his appointment, it's emerged that he is to have additional responsibilities.

The existing powers, largely centring on children in care, are to be expanded in a new parliamentary bill announced in the Queen's Speech on December 6. The bill is expected to extend the commissioner's brief to cover children in NHS hospitals and schools in Wales.

The commissioner's brief takes in domiciliary services for children with disabilities, the social care elements of day care services for children under eight, and adoption agencies and services. It also covers children's homes, services for children in private and voluntary hospitals and clinics, residential family centres and welfare inspections of boarding schools.

"The bill is expected to expand the commissioner's role by applying the commissioner's powers to review and monitor arrangements for complaints, whistleblowing and advocacy on behalf of children to a wider range of bodies, including schools and NHS hospitals which provide services for children in Wales," said a spokesperson for the Wales Office.

A national assembly spokesperson said that the brief would apply to hospitals in Wales: "Jurisdiction under the bill will not extend to the services themselves if they are provided outside Wales. However, the commissioner will be able to look at and comment on the action of public bodies in Wales in arranging such services provided outside Wales."

The commissioner is also likely to be given powers to review the operations of the Welsh national assembly and other public agencies where they involve children.

With the appointment, the principality becomes the first part of the UK to have a children's commissioner. A commissioner was one of the main recommendations of the Waterhouse tribunal into abuse in children's home in north Wales.

Clarke is expected to take up his £70,000-a-year appointment some time in the new year with a budget in the first year of around £700,000.

Clarke says children will be closely involved in the operation of the office, and that he planned to have an advisory group of children.

"One of my first tasks will be to set up procedures for advocacy and complaints, and I will draw on the experience of children to form an advisory group of young people. I want Wales to be a child-centred country," he said.

The post of Welsh children's commissioner is for a fixed seven-year term without the possibility of re-appointment, an arrangement designed to bolster the commissioner's independence from the National Assembly for Wales.

"He will be an independent officer who will report to the assembly but who will work like an ombudsman," said assembly first minister Rhodri Morgan.

Assembly health minster Jane Hutt said: "Wales is taking the lead in the UK in placing the rights and needs of our children and young people centre stage. The appointment itself was an innovative process that took into account the views of children and young people."

There are as yet no plans for commissioners in other regions of the UK, although the NSPCC and a number of other agencies have been campaigning for them.

A number of other countries already have their own children's commissioners. New Zealand made one of the first appointments in 1989, while some Scandinavian countries and British Columbia in Canada also have commissioners.

New Zealand made one of the first appointments in 1989, while some Scandinavian countries and British Columbia in Canada also have commissioners.

webTitle: Football website hits back at Robson

fields.headline: Football website hits back at Robson
fields.trailText: Football website Football365.com have responded angrily to claims by Newcastle manager Bobby Robson that they "distorted" an interview with Didier Domi, in which he criticised the "old-fashioned" training methods at the club.
fields.body:
Football website Football365.com have responded angrily to claims by Newcastle manager Bobby Robson that they "distorted" an interview with Didier Domi, in which he criticised the "old-fashioned" training methods at the club.

At a press conference yesterday, Robson read a prepared statement from Domi, which said: "The stories are a total distortion. I have not made any such statements to any members of the press criticising the training methods of Mr Robson, who is highly regarded throughout the world of football."

But today Football365.com said they were today standing by their initial story, which was based on an interview by journalist Arnaud Brely.

"Domi claims that the quotes which appeared on Football365.com this week and subsequently in national and local newspapers, calling Robson's training methods old-fashioned, were a distorted version of an interview he gave to French paper Le Parisien," said a statement on their website. "But Domi actually gave an interview to our French colleague on Monday - before the Le Parisien article was published.

"Robson questioned Football365's integrity at a press conference on Thursday and subsequently we are seeking legal advice," it continued.
