webTitle: Crisis, Crowbar, and Crustacean

fields.headline: Crisis, Crowbar, and Crustacean
fields.trailText: JAMES DROPS BOMBSHELL, NOT CROSS
fields.body:
JAMES DROPS BOMBSHELL, NOT CROSS

If there's one thing the Fiver can't stand it's Christmas - all that merry-making and frivolous spending frankly makes us sick. But we're not the only ones, because Aston Villa chairman Doug Ellis doesn't like it either. Only he hates it even more than we do! And today he gave us another masterclass in his dark arts. The day started well for Ellis - and badly for John Gregory - when Villa's "skinflint board." (© the Daily Star) told their manager to jettison planned big-money moves for Benni McCarthy and Juan Pablo Angel. "If you can't buy a BMW then you go for a Rover," admitted a weary John Gregory, as he watched Sunderland reject Milton Nunez trudge his way around the training ground.

But at lunchtime worse things got even better for Ellis when David James rejected a new contract offer, and instead demanded a transfer - citing, like Gareth Southgate before him, Villa's (i.e. Ellis's) lack of ambition. James then disappeared into hiding, but seeing as he said last week: "I was one of those in the summer who was worried about which way the club were goingI need to be satisfied that the club harbour the same ambitions as myself," it seems Ellis's penny-pinching ways have got to him too.

By 2pm Ellis had offended his manager and his second England international of the season. So who else was there to pick on? Why, the fans of course. When we logged onto the Aston Villa website (avfc.co.uk) this afternoon we found that the link to Ellis's Christmas message sent us, appropriately enough, to a blank screen. Fortunately, the link to "The Perfect Christmas Present for Villa Fans" -an executive £95-a-head package to see Villa v Leicester, featuring "a welcome pack and drink, a "pay bar facility" and a "warm welcome by a senior official" still works. Ho ho ho.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ROBBIE: MOST POPULAR MALE

With all his other worries at the moment, Gordon Strachan could be forgiven for taking a short moment, running his hand through his hair and, before getting it stuck in his tangled mop, thinking: "I signed that Robbie Keane, I did." Because for all the heinous errors, the Cedric Roussels if you will, that have marked Strachan's tenure at Highfield Road - he once bought the Irish striker. And that's a darn sight more than West Ham or Chelsea's of Chelsea look like doing.

Keane became the latest target of Claudio Ranieri's "Buy young and British" policy (not strictly accurate in this case Claudio, there's a bit of history involved) when the Blues had a £12m bid for the 20-year-old accepted by Internazionale. "We have had discussions with Inter Milan about Robbie Keane", said Colin Hutchinson with all the enthusiasm of a neutered pitbull. Because no matter how much cash the fashionable West London boutique is willing to splash, the striker is not prepared to leave the San Siro for anyone. Apart from David O'Leary, of course.

Well that's what Appy Arry Redknapp would have you believe. The Upton Park 'ead 'oncho failed in a typically cheeky attempt to sign Keane earlier this week, and he believes that the only club Baby Irish will sign for is Leeds. "They accepted our offer," said Arry, "and the lad's wages would not have been a problem because he isn't on silly money over there. But his agent told us Keane wanted to hang fire to see whether Leeds were going to come in for him. It would be a bit rich if they take Rio from us - and then get Keane from under our noses." Rich? That's Leeds alright.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We have reached the fourth round of [Euro Vase] and the semi-finals of the Worthington Cup. Those are signs of how we are developing. Even if we beat United on Sunday they will win the league. You may say that is defeatist but I say it is reality. We will need another 50 games to get the kind of solidarity and confidence they have."

Gerald Houllier gives another confidence-boosting team talk ahead of Sunday's visit to Manchester United.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PRAWN AGAIN

It isn't often that Roy Keane has to make a point twice. Normally one two-footed sliding challenge that, at its peak, reaches speeds of 15 miles per hour is enough to get the message across. However, it isn't often that Kean-ouch dabbles in social commentary, and so it's only fair that he went on record today to clarify that his moan about Old Trafford's prawn sandwich-munchers wasn't simply referring to the executive box crowd. No, he meant everyone.

"Because I mentioned prawn sandwiches a lot of people assumed I was just getting at the executive fans, but that wasn't actually the case," Keane clarified today, with the aid of a Powerpoint presentation. "My anger was aimed at most of the crowd, to be honest." It is a mark of the man that Keane is willing to take on 60-odd thousand men, women and children all at once, but even more impressive that he thinks they know he's right. "I think the fans in general probably agreed with me", he roared as United supporters scattered for cover in the leafy Home Counties.

Keane's clarification raises important questions about the symbolic meaning of a prawn sandwich. If it is the type of snack consumed by everyone at Old Trafford, does that make it a snack of the masses? Or does it retain the kudos afforded to it after Keane's first outburst, thus transforming all United fans into ponces? We really could go on all day, although Keane would rather we didn't. "I don't have one regret about what I said. Actually my only regret is that people keep bloody mentioning it to me! I'll probably have it written on my gravestone!" Alright, alright, we get the message.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Roma are preparing a £15m bid for Leeds striker Mark Viduka, reports the Daily Mail. They quote Nils Liedholm, the chief advisor to Roma's chairman Franco Sensi, who says: "The most important thing now is to get him before another big club does because this guy could be our new Gabriel Batistuta."

David Jones has been linked with the vacant manager's position at Norwich.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Uefa have blocked Celtic and Rangers' bid to join a lucrative Euro League. "The officials from these clubs have nothing against Uefa, but they wanted more receipts and a more attractive competition," said general secretary Gerald Aigner today. "But they have forgotten an essential point, that the sole judge of football is the supporter. How are the supporters going to react if we take away the tradition of derbies?"

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has denied reports in this morning's papers claiming he has signed Edu. "He cannot get his passport until January and we haven't actually had the chance to sign him from Corinthians," revealed Wenger. "If we were to sign him, we can almost certainly forget about seeing him play this season because I feel that Brazilians take around five or six months to develop in the English game."

Former Celtic director of football, Kenny Dalglish, has been awarded more than £600,000 by a Court of Session in Edinburgh after being sacked by the club last summer.

Celtic are on the verge of signing Ramon Vega on a loan deal until the end of the season. The 29-year-old Swiss international flew into Glasgow this afternoon and Martin O'Neill hopes to complete the paper work in time for him to make his Celtic debut against Aberdeen tomorrow.

Watford have signed Carlton Palmer on a three-month loan from Coventry. "I am looking for what I consider to be leaders," revealed Graham Taylor. "I worked with Carlton at international level and I know that he is a leader.

Alan Shearer underwent a full training session today, and looks set to return for Newcastle's match against Bradford tomorrow.

Blackburn Rovers have completed the signing of Henning Berg for £1.75m.

Arsenal have sold Liberian striker Christopher Wreh to Saudi Arabian club Al-Hilal Al Saudi for an undisclosed fee.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports One: Hold the Back Page (11pm) Now that the Charlies Angels "flick" hairstyle is back in fashion.

Premier League Preview (1am) Do you think the Brian Woolnough "king-sized bouffant" will follow suit?

webTitle: Interview with director Samira Makhmalbaf

fields.headline: Angry young woman
fields.standfirst: Samira Makhmalbaf is 20 years old. She has a girlish laugh and likes skating, swimming and cycling. She is also the youngest director ever to win the jury prize at Cannes.  Sally Weale  talks to the extraordinary Iranian film-maker about art, politics and censorship - and the sense of injustice that drives her
fields.trailText: Samira Makhmalbaf is 20 years old. She has a girlish laugh and likes skating, swimming and cycling. She is also the youngest director ever to win the jury prize at Cannes. Sally Weale talks to the extraordinary Iranian film-maker about art, politics and censorship - and the sense of injustice that drives her
fields.body:
When Samira Makhmalbaf was a little girl growing up in Tehran, she lived in a house filled with talk of cinema. She remembers earwigging as her mother and father, the celebrated Iranian film-maker Mohsen Makhmalbaf, discussed movies from dawn till dusk; she went with him on location, she watched him editing, she starred in his films. The world of film and film-making filled her every waking hour and excited every sense. Little wonder, then, that the daughter of this father is now making her own films. And to great international acclaim.

Makhmalbaf is as striking as her films. Tiny and dark, she is intense, urgent, ferocious. Her kohl-rimmed eyes are penetrating, her small hands agile and expressive. She wants you to understand her work; she harangues and charms you, her husky little voice - like a teenage boy's - getting higher and higher as she battles with her English.

Makhmalbaf is in London to promote her new film, Blackboards (Takhte Siah), which is by general agreement an extraordinary achievement by an extraordinary young film director. It is only her second, but it has already confirmed her as a mini film genius of staggering maturity. She's still only 20, a young woman with a girlish laugh who likes skating, swimming and cycling.

She has again teamed up with her father, who co-scripted and edited Blackboards, as he did with her first film, The Apple. There have inevitably been dark whispers about how far they are her own work and how much her father's. Makhmalbaf doesn't care. She is wonderfully defiant: "I want him to edit my films so why should I have to, because he is my father, say, 'No, please don't edit it'?" She does not know if she will work with him again. "Being young, yeah, you want to be independent. But at the same time, I'm not that much young. At the moment I'm so old. Even older than what he is. He is 40 and something, and I am 90 years old."

Blackboards is the sort of film that takes your breath away and leaves its images burned indelibly on your mind. The story opens with a group of teachers roving the mountains between Iraq and Iran, in a landscape of breathtaking beauty and danger, their blackboards on their backs, in search of students. The original idea, Makhmalbaf says, was her father's, conceived while they were travelling together in Kurdistan. The development was all her own.

The film follows two of the teachers who break away from the group - one, Reeboir, comes across a trail of boys, who like him are carrying their livelihoods on their shoulders. These children are "mules", smuggling contraband over the border. He offers to teach them in return for bread. The second teacher, Said, joins up with a group of Kurdish refugees made up of old men, one woman and a young child, who are making their way back to their homeland of Iraq to die. They refuse his offer to teach them, but they pay him in walnuts to guide them to the border.

Some of the scenes, so tender and strange, are unforgettable: two old men trying to encourage their friend to urinate - he hasn't passed water for two days and is in agony; a mother trying to get her little boy to do the same, gently splashing him with water as she croons encouragement; an old man with his face covered, tossing hay seemingly aimlessly into the air, who has a letter he cannot read. It is from his son, a prisoner of war in Iraq.

Makhmalbaf spent four months shooting the film in the Kurdish mountains near Halabcheh, a city on the Iraqi border where the Iraqis gassed the Kurds during the Iran-Iraq war. She dodged landmines daily and used a cast of 200 local villagers, with just two professional actors taking leading roles. "It was one of the best experiences I had, living with those people," she says. "Because I loved them. They were humans, good humans, suffering from different things. It was a deeper kind of life compared to most of the other places I've lived."

The film works through allegory, metaphor and the surreal, rather than documentary - and explores what happens to people caught up in conflicts. Violence is never far away: the film echoes with the sound of gunfire and helicopters. At one point, near the border, the Kurdish refugees throw themselves to the ground believing themselves to be under chemical attack. The camera, held at shoulder level, meanders among these stoical people trekking through the mountains, giving the viewer a refugee's-eye view of this beautiful but frightening world.

On a chilly day in London, Makhmalbaf is wrapped up in black, heavy cotton, like a precious object. When she has met other interviewers she has worn jeans; today she is wearing more traditional dress, which would not look out of place on the streets of Tehran. Maybe it's because she's about to catch a plane home. I think she's had enough of media interviews, being quizzed about politics and Islam. Lots of western journalists expect her to be much more angry and openly critical of the political situation in Iran.

She says she's more interested in deeper, greater, universal truths, rather than the specifics of a particular political system. Which is clearly true - she is an artist rather than a political activist - but there must be an element of self-preservation in her reticence. Iran is her home, she loves it, and she has to live and work there, in the shadow of the censors, who - remarkably - have left her films untouched.

And of course there are her father's experiences to take into account. As a young man, Mohsen Makhmalbaf was an Islamic revolutionary opposed to the Shah's regime. When he was 17, he was arrested after he stabbed a policeman with a knife. He was saved from the firing squad because of his youth; his prison sentence was cut short when he was freed as a result of the 1979 revolution, and on his release he became a propagandist film-maker for Ayatollah Khomeini. Later, he started to read the philosophers and moved away from dogma to a poetic cinematic vision. (Her mother apparently burned to death in a house fire and her father subsequently married his late wife's sister.)

Earlier this year Makhmalbaf cast aside her usual reticence to make a rare political statement in public, dedicating a prize she picked up at Cannes for Blackboards to the "heroic efforts" of the pro-democracy moment in Iran. I ask her how the movement is progressing - there have been serious setbacks since the landslide victory of the reforming President Mohammad Khatami three years ago with liberal newspapers shut down and hundreds of reformers jailed - but she is reluctant to elaborate. "It is starting. Something has started. It is better than not to have started. It might have some ups and downs, but I'm optimistic."

She pauses, then turns her laser-like attention on her interpreter for an intense little discussion before turning it back on me. "I imagine no politicians from Iran come here. No? They never have any interviews with you, so when we come here, you think we are politicians. No, I'm not a politician. If I was born somewhere else, I wouldn't be talking this much about politics. I could use the language of art.

"Even if I made that kind of direct movie talking about politics, it's nothing. Nothing, because it's just talking like a journalist. You are saying something superficial. The movies I make are deeper. This kind of work can live more, longer, deeper, compared to that kind of journalistic work." There is no hint of arrogance in what she says. She is one of those people fired by a natural, instinctive self-belief, the sort of self-belief that enabled her to walk out of school at the age of 15 because she felt her teachers were not teaching her anything new. She asked her father to tell her about film-making and, three years later, she made The Apple - becoming the youngest director in the world to compete in the official section of the 1998 Cannes film festival.

The Apple is another film that leaves you shellshocked. It is the true story of a man, married to a blind woman, who keeps his twin 12-year-old daughters locked up behind bars at home. The characters all "play" themselves, and the film records the girls' first steps into the world beyond the bars of their home and their magical awakening to the wonders of ordinary life. The Apple tells us about life for women in Iran today but its power is in its humanity, rather than in exposure - the father is not vilified for what he has done, the film struggles instead to explain his actions. He is simply doing his best, however misguided, to protect his daughters according to the teachings of the Koran.

Makhmalbaf kept in touch with the daughters. After their mother died, their father was persuaded to let another family look after them because he could not accept their freedom. They receive a monthly allowance from the profits of the film and are now studying at school.

I ask about life for women in Iran. "We have a lot of limitations," she says. "From all the written and unwritten law. But, still, I hope and I believe that it will get better. It has started with the democracy movement. But some things don't happen consciously. I wanted to make films, I made films to say something else, but in a way I became a kind of example. It was breaking some kind of cliche. Another new way of thinking started. Yes, we have a lot of limitations, but these limitations made a lot of strong, different kinds of women in Iran who, if they find a chance to express themselves, I'm sure have plenty of things to say. They may have found a deeper way through all these limitations."

But what makes her most angry about the restrictions imposed on women? "This kind of narrow-mindedness which is in the schools or in the mind of the people. They think you are not a first class human being, you are second class. And you might have a kind of limitation in your mind because you are a woman. This is the worst." She really crackles when she says this. I think it makes her very angry.

It's time to go the airport. She's going home to Tehran, to see friends and family - perhaps she'll go skating, or swimming or cycling. And, yes, she has got an idea for her next film. Nothing much yet, just an image. In her head. Quietly growing, slowly taking shape. She's not saying any more. "You have to keep it a secret in your heart, in your mind," she says, "and not talk about it at all with anybody - so that it comes to a kind of maturity. Then it's the time."

Take your time, Samira. If the first two are anything to go by, the third will be well worth the wait.

 Blackboards is released on December 29.

The second teacher, Said, joins up with a group of Kurdish refugees made up of old men, one woman and a young child, who are making their way back to their homeland of Iraq to die. They refuse his offer to teach them, but they pay him in walnuts to guide them to the border. Some of the scenes, so tender and strange, are unforgettable: two old men trying to encourage their friend to urinate - he hasn't passed water for two days and is in agony; a mother trying to get her little boy to do the same, gently splashing him with water as she croons encouragement; an old man with his face covered, tossing hay seemingly aimlessly into the air, who has a letter he cannot read. It is from his son, a prisoner of war in Iraq. Makhmalbaf spent four months shooting the film in the Kurdish mountains near Halabcheh, a city on the Iraqi border where the Iraqis gassed the Kurds during the Iran-Iraq war. She dodged landmines daily and used a cast of 200 local villagers, with just two professional actors taking leading roles. "It was one of the best experiences I had, living with those people," she says. "Because I loved them. They were humans, good humans, suffering from different things. It was a deeper kind of life compared to most of the other places I've lived." The film works through allegory, metaphor and the surreal, rather than documentary - and explores what happens to people caught up in conflicts. Violence is never far away: the film echoes with the sound of gunfire and helicopters. At one point, near the border, the Kurdish refugees throw themselves to the ground believing themselves to be under chemical attack. The camera, held at shoulder level, meanders among these stoical people trekking through the mountains, giving the viewer a refugee's-eye view of this beautiful but frightening world. On a chilly day in London, Makhmalbaf is wrapped up in black, heavy cotton, like a precious object. When she has met other interviewers she has worn jeans; today she is wearing more traditional dress, which would not look out of place on the streets of Tehran. Maybe it's because she's about to catch a plane home. I think she's had enough of media interviews, being quizzed about politics and Islam. Lots of western journalists expect her to be much more angry and openly critical of the political situation in Iran. She says she's more interested in deeper, greater, universal truths, rather than the specifics of a particular political system. Which is clearly true - she is an artist rather than a political activist - but there must be an element of self-preservation in her reticence. Iran is her home, she loves it, and she has to live and work there, in the shadow of the censors, who - remarkably - have left her films untouched. And of course there are her father's experiences to take into account. As a young man, Mohsen Makhmalbaf was an Islamic revolutionary opposed to the Shah's regime. When he was 17, he was arrested after he stabbed a policeman with a knife. He was saved from the firing squad because of his youth; his prison sentence was cut short when he was freed as a result of the 1979 revolution, and on his release he became a propagandist film-maker for Ayatollah Khomeini. Later, he started to read the philosophers and moved away from dogma to a poetic cinematic vision. (Her mother apparently burned to death in a house fire and her father subsequently married his late wife's sister.) Earlier this year Makhmalbaf cast aside her usual reticence to make a rare political statement in public, dedicating a prize she picked up at Cannes for Blackboards to the "heroic efforts" of the pro-democracy moment in Iran. I ask her how the movement is progressing - there have been serious setbacks since the landslide victory of the reforming President Mohammad Khatami three years ago with liberal newspapers shut down and hundreds of reformers jailed - but she is reluctant to elaborate. "It is starting. Something has started. It is better than not to have started. It might have some ups and downs, but I'm optimistic." She pauses, then turns her laser-like attention on her interpreter for an intense little discussion before turning it back on me. "I imagine no politicians from Iran come here. No? They never have any interviews with you, so when we come here, you think we are politicians. No, I'm not a politician. If I was born somewhere else, I wouldn't be talking this much about politics. I could use the language of art. "Even if I made that kind of direct movie talking about politics, it's nothing. Nothing, because it's just talking like a journalist. You are saying something superficial. The movies I make are deeper. This kind of work can live more, longer, deeper, compared to that kind of journalistic work." There is no hint of arrogance in what she says. She is one of those people fired by a natural, instinctive self-belief, the sort of self-belief that enabled her to walk out of school at the age of 15 because she felt her teachers were not teaching her anything new. She asked her father to tell her about film-making and, three years later, she made The Apple - becoming the youngest director in the world to compete in the official section of the 1998 Cannes film festival. The Apple is another film that leaves you shellshocked. It is the true story of a man, married to a blind woman, who keeps his twin 12-year-old daughters locked up behind bars at home. The characters all "play" themselves, and the film records the girls' first steps into the world beyond the bars of their home and their magical awakening to the wonders of ordinary life. The Apple tells us about life for women in Iran today but its power is in its humanity, rather than in exposure - the father is not vilified for what he has done, the film struggles instead to explain his actions. He is simply doing his best, however misguided, to protect his daughters according to the teachings of the Koran. Makhmalbaf kept in touch with the daughters. After their mother died, their father was persuaded to let another family look after them because he could not accept their freedom. They receive a monthly allowance from the profits of the film and are now studying at school. I ask about life for women in Iran. "We have a lot of limitations," she says. "From all the written and unwritten law. But, still, I hope and I believe that it will get better. It has started with the democracy movement. But some things don't happen consciously. I wanted to make films, I made films to say something else, but in a way I became a kind of example. It was breaking some kind of cliche. Another new way of thinking started. Yes, we have a lot of limitations, but these limitations made a lot of strong, different kinds of women in Iran who, if they find a chance to express themselves, I'm sure have plenty of things to say. They may have found a deeper way through all these limitations." But what makes her most angry about the restrictions imposed on women? "This kind of narrow-mindedness which is in the schools or in the mind of the people. They think you are not a first class human being, you are second class. And you might have a kind of limitation in your mind because you are a woman. This is the worst." She really crackles when she says this. I think it makes her very angry. It's time to go the airport. She's going home to Tehran, to see friends and family - perhaps she'll go skating, or swimming or cycling. And, yes, she has got an idea for her next film. Nothing much yet, just an image. In her head. Quietly growing, slowly taking shape. She's not saying any more. "You have to keep it a secret in your heart, in your mind," she says, "and not talk about it at all with anybody - so that it comes to a kind of maturity. Then it's the time." Take your time, Samira. If the first two are anything to go by, the third will be well worth the wait.  Blackboards is released on December 29.

webTitle: The Cartagena protocol on diversity

fields.headline: The Cartagena protocol on diversity
fields.standfirst: The first intergovernmental meeting on the risks posed by biotechnology takes place this week. Chris Howe, senior environmental campaigner with WWF, outlines his concerns
fields.trailText: The first intergovernmental meeting on the risks posed by biotechnology takes place this week. Chris Howe, senior environmental campaigner with WWF, outlines his concerns.
fields.body:
The first intergovernmental meeting aiming to minimise the potential risks to the environment and human health posed by biotechnology and its movement between countries takes place this week in Montpellier, France.

This interim intergovernmental committee of the Cartagena protocol on biodiversity (ICCP) faces the urgent task of implementing measures to address the safe transfer, handling and use of living modified organisms (LMOs) - the term used for any organism that has been modified by biotechnology- in the face of continuing concerns about their release into the environment.

WWF, the global environment network, is particularly concerned about the imminent commercialisation of modified trees and fish. Research has shown that just one modified species of fish can wipe out local populations.

There are also concerns about the unintentional effects modified trees may have on insects and birds, the environmental impacts of their greater demand for water and the increase in pesticide and herbicide use they may promote.

Other concerns include the entry of modified products into the seed and food chain. These have been recently illustrated by the contamination of oilseed rape seed in Europe. These organisms also pose a threat to species such as the Monarch butterfly -the larvae of which have been damaged by modified maize.

The protocol arose from the convention on biological diversity established at the Rio Earth Summit in 1992. The convention committed contracting parties to the "conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of the utilisation of genetic resources."

The 178 states which have signed and ratified the convention, including the European Union, agreed that biotechnology could make a contribution towards these aims if developed with adequate safety measures. The biosafety protocol was established to ensure that this would be the case.

The original intention to finalise the protocol in February 1999 failed as a result of objections by a group of countries known as the Miami group. This included Canada, Argentina, Australia and Uruguay and the USA - even though it was not a party to the convention.

These big grain and pulse producing countries objected that the protocol would conflict with free trade rules. They were particularly concerned about the inclusion of products - such as animal feedstuffs - not intended for direct release to the environment, the precedence of the protocol over other multilateral agreements and the requirement that recipient countries be notified of any intended shipment. The protocol mostly stood firm against the attempt of these countries to impose their economic muscle on others and was finally concluded in January 2000 in Montreal.

The protocol will not come into force until ninety days after the fiftieth country has ratified it. Since the protocol was open for signature in May, 80 countries have signed and two - Bulgaria and Trinidad and Tobago- have ratified it. WWF is encouraging governments who have not signed or ratified the protocol to do so quickly so that it can enter into force.

WWF is urging the intervening meeting of the ICCP, which exists in the period before the protocol comes into force, to move forward on some key issues, including

 Making sure that all goods are labelled clearly
 Insisting that recipient countries have agreed to take modified goods before they are transported
 Insisting that modified and non-modified organisms be segregated
 Setting up a fund to help countries prepare for implementation
 Setting up an information sharing system between signatories
 Establishing clear rules for liability and redress for damage or loss caused by modified organisms.

WWF is also urging governments to establish national measures to meet the demands of the protocol, declare a moratorium on the use or release of LMOs until their environmental impacts have been fully researched and safeguards put in place, and co-operate with other countries to put regional mechanisms in place such as a revised directive in the EU.

We have already had an insight into the potentially devastating effects of these modified organisms once they are released into the environment. This protocol poses an ideal opportunity to keep check on this technology while recognising that it may hold answers to many of our problems if used responsibly. It is vital that we understand the full nature and consequences of unleashing these organisms because there will be no putting the gene genie back once it is out of the bottle.

webTitle: BBC apologises for Cherie cock-up

fields.headline: BBC apologises for Cherie cock-up
fields.standfirst:
Dec 15: No 10 rubs salt into wounds
Dec 15: BBC in Cherie Blair gaffe
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
2.45pm update: BBC chiefs have apologised to Cherie Blair after a Christmas stunt involving the PM's wife backfired spectacularly, writes Claire Cozens.
Dec 15: No 10 rubs salt into wounds
Dec 15: BBC in Cherie Blair gaffe
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
BBC chiefs have apologised to Cherie Blair after a Christmas stunt involving the PM's wife backfired spectacularly.

The corporation was forced into the embarrassing climbdown after footage of Cherie Blair dressed as a punk turned out to be false.

It was Downing Street which first pointed out that the pictures, due to feature in a celebrity Christmas special of Angus Deayton's Before they were Famous, were not of Mrs Blair.

To add to the BBC's humiliation it turned out that she wasn't even at the event featured in the film.

The BBC said this afternoon: "The pictures were obtained from library footage of a 1985 GLC fundraising even and the production team believed them to be of Cherie Blair.

"However, Mrs Blair's office have told us that it wasn't her, and indeed she wasn't actually at the event, so we have removed the footage from the programme. We regret the mistake was made."

A spokesman said researchers who had been trawling through BBC archives genuinely believed the footage to be of Mrs Blair.

He said no one had approached Downing Street to verify the authenticity of the footage because it wasn't deemed necessary.

"You don't always approach people in these type of programmes. But a genuine mistake was made and we have naturally apologised for it," the spokesman added.

The appearance of stills from the film in today's Mirror is also a huge embarrassment to the newpaper, which also failed to spot the mistake.

The footage, which is amateur, is not crystal clear and staff there said they believed it was Mrs Blair.

"We took the pictures from the BBC in good faith," said a spokesman for the paper.

The Mirror's mistake is reminiscent of the gaffe made by the Daily Mail in August when it published a picture of Prince William apparently on manoeuvres in the wilds of Belize.

The pictures turned out to be taken more than a year previously on Salisbury Plain.

webTitle: BT launches web service to rival Vizzavi

fields.headline: BT launches web service to rival Vizzavi
fields.trailText: 2pm: BT has intensified its rivalry with Vivendi Universal by launching POP, a web service to compete with Vizzavi, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT has raised the stakes in its confrontation with French media giant Vivendi Universal by unveiling a rival web service.

Today it launched a multiple-access portal called POP as a counter-punch to Vizzavi, the mobile internet service co-owned by Vivendi Universal and UK mobile phone giant Vodafone.

"It will be a competing portal to Vizzavi. The market is in its early stages, but we welcome the competition," said a BT spokesman.

BT is seeking compensation from Vivendi Universal, claiming that the Vizzavi service breaks a shareholder pact between the companies.

They are partners in French telecoms operator Cegetel, and BT is furious that Vivendi Universal has signed up the mobile phone arm to the Vizzavi portal.

BT refused to comment on its legal action, but Vodafone boss Chris Gent has poured scorn on the company's actions, accusing it of overreacting.

Vizzavi has kept a low profile since it was unveiled to great fanfare in the summer, but it has a potential customer base of 80m across Europe, and there are plans for a global launch.

The POP portal, which will be available on the BTopenworld service, is aiming for an identical customer base of Wap and PalmPilot users.

Vivendi Universal was formed by the £50bn merger of the French company and Seagram of Canada, owner of Universal Film and Universal Music.

The new company's extensive content, which includes programmes from the Canal Plus pay-TV channel, is one of the key selling points for the Vizzavi service.

Meanwhile, BT is to launch a new, unmetered access service as the cornerstone of its internet strategy. The service, to be called BTinternet Anytime, will offer 24-hour access for £14.99 per month to existing customers.

Latest figures also revealed BT as the UK's largest unmetered internet service provider, with over 500,000 customers.

webTitle: Daily Mail shrugs off declining profits to keep spending

fields.headline: Daily Mail shrugs off declining profits to keep spending
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Newspaper publisher Daily Mail and General Trust said yesterday it will continue with £70m investment plans for the coming year, including online projects and a further roll-out of its Metro free papers, despite reporting a fall in profits.
fields.body:
Newspaper publisher Daily Mail and General Trust said yesterday it will continue with £70m investment plans for the coming year, including online projects and a further roll-out of its Metro free papers, despite reporting a fall in profits.

DMGT recorded a 7% drop in pretax profits to £191.5m for the year to October on turnover up 15% to £1.86bn. Stripping out exceptional charges caused by increasing the investment budget from £20m to £70m, DMGT recorded an operating profit up 23% to £311.5m.

Financial director Peter Williams said the fledgling Metro papers had a circulation of around 2.5m across a number of cities, with new editions for central Scotland and Yorkshire in the pipeline.

While the free paper business had posted a loss of £2m, he was confident all of the Metro papers would eventually follow the footsteps of the profitable edition in London.

Some of the group's investment budget will also go on new media projects including the Teletext business, which is being "migrated" online. Mr Williams hinted to reporters that the group was considering floating the rolling news service at some stage.

Some analysts suggested that a forecast rise in newsprint costs of up to 15%, a dropping off in advertising and an increase in competition from Richard Desmond's Express newspapers would hit DMGT's core publications, which have long since dominated the black-top tabloid market.

Analysts at WestLB Panmure, the German investment bank, reduced their forecast for 2001 from £240m to £215 as a result. "Although in the short-term the share price could be affected...DMGT's formidable investment track record, substantial budget - £100m compared with £62m at the Express - and unrivalled market knowledge, underpin a positive long-term oulook," it said.

webTitle: BBC Breakfast's Thompson quits for sports team

fields.headline: BBC Breakfast's Thompson quits for sports team
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: BBC Breakfast editor Andrew Thompson is quitting the programme to join Peter Salmon in the BBC's sports department, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Breakfast editor Andrew Thompson is quitting the programme to join Peter Salmon in the BBC's sports department.

Mr Thompson, who was responsible for the rebranding of Jeremy Bowen from flak-jacketed hero to laid-back morning host, will be working with Mr Salmon on new projects.

Mr Thompson said: "I'm looking forward to taking a lead with Peter Salmon in driving forward new opportunities for BBC sport."

But he added that it was too early to talk about specific plans.

As head of special projects and development, Mr Thompson will work across BBC1, BBC2 and the new digital channels, focusing on interactive programmes.

Mr Salmon, the former controller of BBC1, was put in charge of the BBC's sporting output in September.

He was also given a seat on the BBC's board of executive directors in a bid to give sports a higher profile.

The repositioning of sport within the BBC is part of a concerted effort by director general Greg Dyke to boost the ailing sports department.

BBC Sport has suffered years of crushing defeats including the loss this year of premiership football highlights, Formula One, Test cricket, the Ryder Cup and the Derby.

But recently Mr Dyke has renewed his attempts to boost the corporation's rights portfolio.

Mr Salmon is planning to launch a digital sporting channel, and the BBC is working on an exclusive rights package with boxer Audley Harrison that could pave the way for a new wave of managing rights for sporting heroes.

Mr Thompson was responsible for the relaunch of Breakfast News in October and was the man who persuaded Jeremy Bowen to end his career as a war correspondent and tries his hand at TV anchoring.

However, Mr Bowen has not been an outright hit despite his widely regarded experience as a foreign reporter.

Last week he came under fire from broadcaster Sir Ludovic Kennedy, who said he was "so laid back he might be in a coffin".

But Mr Thompson said the remarks had nothing to do with his decision to leave the breakfast job. "Jeremy's a good presenter," he said.

webTitle: Ministers may back down on tube plan

fields.headline: Ministers may back down on tube plan
fields.trailText: John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, was facing growing isolation over his plans to part privatise the London Underground as alternative proposals put forward by mayor Ken Livingstone won growing political and business support.
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, was facing growing isolation over his plans to part privatise the London Underground as alternative proposals put forward by mayor Ken Livingstone won growing political and business support.

Mr Livingstone was pinning his hopes on signs that the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, was willing to compromise between the proposals doggedly defended by Mr Prescott and those set out this week by Robert Kiley, Mr Livingstone's nominee as London's new commissioner of transport.

In an intensive four day public relations drive, Mr Kiley, the man credited with saving the New York subway, is pressing his alternative scheme of keeping the Underground in one piece and and in public hands with a bond issue supported by fare revenue. He would target £10bn investment on track, signals and tunnels.

Yesterday the Conservative transport spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, swung behind the Kiley plan saying "his scheme is infinitely preferable to the complete mess of the PPP. We are currently giving it serious and active consideration".

In a potentially crucial development, the national audit office will today to publish its evaluation of the "public sector comparator" being used by the London Underground and the government to decide whether the public private partnership represents better value for money than keeping the scheme in the public sector.

Mr Prescott and Lord Macdonald will meet Mr Kiley today for a second time in a week. The deputy prime minister has said he will shelve his plan if the NAO report shows there are fundamental flaws in his proposals. The report is not expected to reject the PPP option outright but will provide enough critical ammunition to challenge the government's methodology. An aide to Mr Prescott insisted the deputy prime minister was "not about to change his mind. We are standing by the model of the PPP. What Kiley is proposing is a different animal".

Mr Livingstone has backed off from legal challenges in an effort to strike a deal. Mr Kiley wants details of the private sector bids, but the government is refusing on the grounds that they are commercially confidential.

Mr Kiley has warned contracts drawn up with private sector bidders to run the tube are "most unlikely to produce the performance necessary to restore the system to a good state of repair".

His own blueprint claims £10bn can be raised over 15 years through a mixture of passenger revenue, congestion charging, a £250m annual government grant and cash raised from the private sector.

Mr Kiley proposes a limited company would sell about £2bn worth of bonds to the private sector to finance tube development. The plan is different from that previously proposed by Mr Livingstone since there is no government guarantee on the bonds, so ensuring the taxpayer is not the lender of the last resort.

Maintenance work would be contracted out with penalties or threat of loss of contract for sub-standard performance. Responsibility would remain with a single board.

Mr Kiley is opposed to divsion of the tube into different sections, an idea integral to the PPP, because he believes it creates a safety risk similar to the difficulties currently crippling the railways.

Mr Prescott's PPP would see private sector consortiums taking over lines, while signals services and train services would remain in the public sector.

fields.headline: What happens next
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
December 18
Members of the electoral college are due to gather in state capitals to announce the candidate their state has voted to support.
fields.body:
December 18
Members of the electoral college are due to gather in state capitals to announce the candidate their state has voted to support.

December 27
Deadline for arrival of electoral college votes.

January 3 2001
New Congress convenes in Washington.

January 5 2001
Senate and House of Representatives count electoral college votes in joint session, and hear any objections. Mr Gore will preside in twin roles as US vice-president and president of the Senate.

January 6 2001
Congress is to announce the winner of the electoral college. The task falls to the vice-president, meaning Al Gore may have to announce his own defeat.

January 20 2001
Inauguration day. George W Bush and vice-president-elect Dick Cheney are sworn in. They take office.

webTitle: The Worst Case Scenario Survival Handbook by Joshua Piven and David Borgenicht

fields.headline: The Worst Case Scenario Survival Handbook by Joshua Piven and David Borgenicht
fields.standfirst:
Chronicle Books, £9.99
America's Christmas bestseller, condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know for spending Christmas with Arnie, Bruce or Sly
fields.body:
CAUTION: The Editor disclaims any liability for anyone undertaking these activities. This information is designed for trained survivalists only. Like us.

How to fend off a shark:

1. Hit back. Use fists or harpoon gun to whack shark in the eyes or on the gills.

2. Keep on hitting the shark until it slopes off with its tail between its fins.

How to hotwire a car:

1. Open the hood and locate the coil wire.

2. Run a wire from the positive battery terminal to the positive side of the coil. Locate the solenoid. Cross the two with pliers. ALTERNATIVELY go to any young offenders' institution and offer $5 to an inmate to do it for you.

How to jump from a motorbike to a moving car:

1. Make sure both vehicles are travelling at the same speed.

2. Get the vehicles as close together as possible.

3. Stand crouched with both feet on the seat. Hold throttle till last instant.

4. Time your leap so your torso lands in the car. Easy.

(If you miss, see section on jumping out of a moving car.)

How to perform a tracheotomy:

1. Find the indentation between Adam's apple and the cricoid cartilage and make a half-inch incision.

2. Insert finger into slit to open it. Then put a tube in.

How to perform a heart transplant:

1. Cut open sternum; take out heart.

2. Put new heart in and stitch up.

How to land a plane:

1. Drag pilot out of seat and put on the headset. Identify all the instruments and chat to ground control. Begin descent, deploy landing gear and reduce power. Make sure rear wheels touch down first.

How to survive a mid-air explosion:

1. Take a deep breath and perform 3,000 somersaults in the pike position.

2. Clench buttock muscles and grab hold of your crotch. Hit the sea feet first and swim 1,000 miles to safety.

How to identify a bomb:

1. Beware of bulky packages with excessive postage and no return address.

2. Check for stains, wires or any label marked "bomb".

3. Say to a colleague: "I think this parcel is for you."

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: Everything you need to know for spending Christmas with Arnie, Bruce or Sly

webTitle: Young carers speak out

fields.headline: Young carers speak out
fields.standfirst: A collection of writings from children forced to care for their parents shows that social workers need to be more sensitive to their needs, writes Saul Becker
fields.trailText: A collection of writings from children forced to care for their parents shows that social workers need to be more sensitive to their needs, writes Saul Becker.
fields.body:
"I think social workers are stupid. I had my first one when I was about seven. They didn't come round to see me. I never saw them. The next thing I knew I was in a strange house with total strangers," said Rah, aged 13.

Rah, who lives with his ill mother and younger brother, went to stay with a succession of neighbours and friends when his mother went in and out of hospital because of a long-standing illness. "I never saw the social workers. I lost trust in them and felt alone," he said.

Lucie, 15, lives with her mother who has a bad back and has battled against cancer on three separate occasions. Her father often has to work away from home. "When my dad is away I have to look after my mum and younger brother. I have to cook, clean the house and help my mum. I have to fetch my mum's pills and help her to get out of bed. It's hard work and sometimes I feel really tired. This is made worse because I have to go out to work to earn my pocket money." Lucie also reported problems with social workers. "When my dad is away I become responsible for everybody and the house. I don't get on with social workers because they keep trying to take me and my brother away from my mum when my dad is working," she said.

Rah and Lucie are "young carers" - children who carry out, often on a regular basis, significant caring tasks and assume a level of responsibility which would usually be associated with an adult. There are an estimated 50,000 children like Rah and Lucie in Britain today. Theirs are just two of the accounts in the first ever collection of writings from young carers, published by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation.

The youngest contributor is nine, the oldest 18. The children's own words reveal a secretive and hidden world, where children and parents are often frightened of what social workers, doctors, teachers and other professionals might do, and yet at the same time families would benefit from the help and support that could be provided by these professionals. It's a world where children are involved in a wide range of caring tasks and family responsibilities, but their contribution is usually overlooked - even ignored - by many professionals.

Many of the children are looking after a mother, often in single-parent families. But even in two-parent families children often have to provide care. Ten-year-old Michelle, for example, looks after her mother, who has epilepsy, because there is no other adult in the family to do it. Lucylee, 13, has to care for her mother who suffers from manic depression and a curved spine. Her stepfather is a police officer "and works long shifts which can be hard for us when mum is really ill". While she enjoys helping her mum she only wishes that, it could be a bit easier".

Some of the children, such as 10-year-old Jasmine, show maturity beyond their years. Jasmine's mother is often in and out of hospital. On the last occasion Jasmine found her mother smoking in the garden. "I was so upset. When I was telling her off I sounded like the mother. I was saying things like, 'Get back to bed. Do you want to kill yourself smoking? Give me your cigarette or put it out.'"

Some of the children's accounts make harrowing reading, especially where parents have a mental illness or misuse alcohol or drugs. Then there are those children who are crying out for attention, like Katie, 12, who says in an open letter to her mother: "I wish that you and me could spend some more time together sometimes. I feel really sad and left out. You make me feel like a pair of hands, just there to help, instead of a daughter ... please spend some time with me."

Many of the young carers are critical of social workers, teachers and health care workers, who are seen as unhelpful, or at worst ignorant or punitive. Clearly, these professionals, but especially social workers - who play such a pivotal role in gate-keeping access to family services - need to become more aware and sensitive to the needs of young carers and their families.

Professionals need to look for signs that children might be acting as carers. Social workers and social care staff, for example, need to:

 Find out whether parents with disabilities or long-term illness are receiving any support, assistance or care in the home from other family members, and if so who provides this support, what it is that they do, and why they do it.

 Check if children have health or social problems, such as a strained back, or emotional, behavioural or educational difficulties, and whether this might be linked in any way with having to care for another family member or from having to take on other responsibilities normally associated with an adult.

 Assess what help and support children and parents need in order to prevent children from having to continue to provide care or to reduce their responsibilities, and what help parents need with personal care and with parenting.

Young carers and ill or disabled parents have the right to an assessment of their needs by social services, but many don't know about their rights or may be frightened to seek help. Breaking that cycle of ignorance and fear is important. The emphasis in assessment and service delivery must be on preventing children from taking on inappropriate caring responsibilities in the first place, and stopping these roles from becoming firmly established once started. To do this, professionals must acknowledge and recognise the contributions made by young carers and their ill or disabled parents, and assesses the needs of all family members.

Young carers will welcome such developments. As Julie, 16, says: "Some people do the things they want to because they choose to. Young carers don't always get the choice, but what we want is not sympathy and apologies for our supposed misfortune, but recognition and encouragement for what we do."

 Young Carers in Their Own Words, eds Andrew Bibby and Saul Becker, from Turnaround Publisher Services Ltd, Tel 020 8829 3000, priced £7.99 incl p&p.

 Dr Saul Becker is Director of the Young Carers Research Group at Loughborough University.

webTitle: Email boaster gets his comeuppance

fields.headline: Email boaster gets his comeuppance
fields.standfirst: A graphic electronic correspondence about a sexual encounter has spread round the world and landed a lawyer in hot water
fields.trailText: A graphic electronic correspondence about a sexual encounter has spread round the world and landed a lawyer in hot water.
fields.body:
For a lawyer working in a top international firm, recognition can be hard to achieve.

But the testimony of a former girlfriend to Bradley Chait's sexual powers soon brought him to the attention of his employers - and millions of envious email users worldwide.

When Mr Chait received an email from a female friend, Claire Swire, containing graphic details of her enjoyment of a sexual encounter between them, he couldn't resist forwarding their correspondence to a select group of friends with the comment: "Now that's a nice compliment from a lass isn't it?"

Unfortunately for Mr Chait, one of them, Edward Drummond, decided it was too good to stop there. The correspondence, about oral sex, "beggars belief", he wrote, forwarding it to a dozen more people with the comment: "I feel honour bound to circulate this."

Another responded: "What a top lass! Let's start a campaign to find her."

The hunt expanded swiftly. The message was estimated by internet experts to have passed through the inboxes of a million readers, via City firms and such institutions as the Guardian, the BBC and the Science Museum.

Mr Chait's law firm Norton Rose reportedly had "no recollection" of her, and internet searches proved fruitless. One promising lead proved fruitless as the Optician X company added a press release to its website, above a photo of its customer relations manager Claire Swire, stating: "Sorry Folks, this is not the Claire Swire you are searching for."

The Daily Mail finally tracked Ms Swire down to her parents' home in Uckbridge, East Sussex. The young woman, dark-haired and wearing glasses, refused to comment on her new-found fame.

Online newspaper the Register printed two - probably spoof - responses from a purported Claire Swire, saying she did indeed exist, was an ex-Norton Rose employee and "was not ashamed".

"I can't believe this," one message ran. "First of all, I don't know any of you!! What do you care about my social life? Don't you sad bastards have anything better to do with your time?"

The Register initially speculated that the whole exchange was a hoax - a view given some credence when Mr Chait told the paper: "It's a hoax. A very good one though, I have to admit."

However, Norton Rose is taking the incident seriously. The company claims to have "a robust approach to email abuse", and Mr Chait and several other staff at the firm are reportedly facing disciplinary action over the forwarding of the email. It appears he has learnt the hard way that in some circumstances it is important to keep your mouth shut.

webTitle: Chelsea agree £12m fee for Robbie Keane

fields.headline: Chelsea agree £12m fee for Robbie Keane
fields.standfirst: Read about West Ham's £10m bid for Keane by clicking here.
fields.trailText: Chelsea have agreed a £12m fee for Robbie Keane with Internazionale - but could face similar problems to West Ham in their attempt to bring him back to the Premiership.
fields.body:
Chelsea have agreed a £12m fee for Robbie Keane with Internazionale - but could face similar problems to West Ham in their attempt to bring him back to the Premiership.

Keane is understood to be reluctant to move to Stamford Bridge, and would prefer to either to stay in Italy or wait to see if Leeds mount a serious bid.

Chelsea's offer has been accepted by Inter, and despite West Ham's similar interest, their managing director Colin Hutchinson believes they are still the only club to reach an agreement with the Serie A club over Keane.

West Ham's bid for Keane also failed, with boss Harry Redknapp revealing "his agent told us Robbie wasn't really sure he wanted to leave Inter".

fields.headline: Group meets to discuss plans for Concorde's return
fields.standfirst: Special report: the concorde crash
fields.trailText: An Anglo-French group is meeting in London today to discuss progress on plans to get Concorde back in the sky.
fields.body:
An Anglo-French group is meeting in London today to discuss progress on plans to get Concorde back in the sky.

No official date has yet been put on a return to service for Air France's five remaining aircraft and the seven owned by British Airways, but April 2001 is a possibility.

British and French aviation authorities have agreed on the modifications necessary to put Concorde in the air, but no work can take place until an investigation into July's crash is complete.

The crash, which claimed 113 lives, happened after a tyre on the New York-bound Concorde ran over an object left on the runway in Paris by another aircraft and burst.

It is thought that fragments from the burst tyre shattered the fuel tank. The plane crashed in flames shortly after takeoff, killing all 109 people on board and four on the ground.

Concorde's Anglo-French manufacturers are now working with the aviation regulators of the two countries on a variety of measures to prevent a recurrence of the accident, including fuel-tank protection plans.

Air France took its remaining Concordes out of service immediately after the crash. BA carried on flying theirs until mid-August before withdrawing them in advance of a decision by the UK's Civil Aviation Authority to remove the airworthiness certificate for each of the BA Concordes.

"We remain confident that Concorde will fly again - and sooner rather than later," a spokesman said today.

"Although at this stage we can't give a date for Concorde's return to service, we continue to do everything we can to get our flagship back in the sky."

webTitle: James demands transfer from Villa Park

fields.headline: James demands transfer from Villa Park
fields.trailText: England goalkeeper David James has asked for a transfer from Aston Villa.
fields.body:
England goalkeeper David James has asked for a transfer from Aston Villa.

James joins club captain Gareth Southgate on the transfer list, with first choice defender Ugo Ehiogu having already left the club, after he rejected their offer of a new contract.

The former Liverpool player - like Southgate - wants to leave Villa because of what he perceives as their lack of ambition.

Villa manager John Gregory had offered James a new three-and-a-half year deal which would put him on the same pay level as the club's other big earners like Southgate, Paul Merson and Dion Dublin.

But James has insisted all along that money was not the reason for him stalling on signing a new deal with Villa.

James was unavailable for comment today but he admitted only last week: "I was one of those in the summer who was worried about which way the club were going.

"For me money is not the main concern, it's all about the direction Villa are heading in. I need to be satisfied that the club harbour the same ambitions as myself."

Clearly James has come to the conclusion that is not the case - and his decision is likely to spark another angry backlash by fans against club chairman Doug Ellis.

At the last two home matches Villa supporters have held up pound note signs in protest at the lack of money spent by Ellis on new signings.

Gregory, himself, has become increasingly frustrated at his failure to strengthen the squad - a move he feels is top priority if Villa are to challenge for a champions league spot.

webTitle: Downing Street reaction to Cherie Blair pics

fields.headline: Downing Street rubs salt into wound
fields.standfirst: Dec 15: BBC in Cherie Blair gaffe
fields.trailText:
1.45pm update Downing Street today offered its mock-congratulations to the BBC for promoting TV footage of Cherie Blair which turned out to be false.
Dec 15: BBC in Cherie Blair gaffe
fields.body:
Downing Street today offered its mock-congratulations to the BBC's press department for promoting TV footage of Cherie Blair which turned out to be false.

In an episode that is likely to haunt both the BBC and the Mirror, which published the pictures today, Downing Street even went so far as to hint that the corporation might have been subjected to a hoax.

A spokesman for Number 10 said: "These so-called pictures are not actually genuine. It was a good effort by whoever flogged them to the BBC and an equally good effort by the person who got them into the Mirror from the BBC PR department."

The photographs of a woman with well-gelled hair and lurid punk-style make-up looks similar to Cherie because of her unusual-shaped jaw.

Some say the pictures look like This Life actress Luisa Bradshaw White, who played secretary Kira.

However, on closer inspection, they transpired to be of someone else.

The pictures were due to appear in a BBC Christmas Special of Before They Were Famous.

webTitle: Report calls for overhaul of engineering profession

fields.headline: Report calls for overhaul of engineering profession
fields.trailText: The national body for engineers must lead a major overhaul of the profession, recommends a report to the government today. The review even questions whether the term 'engineer' should be dropped altogether, as it no longer describes the range of expertise in the profession. The Engineering Council itself may need to be renamed, says the report.
fields.body:
The national body for engineers must lead a major overhaul of the profession, recommends a report to the government today. The review even questions whether the term 'engineer' should be dropped altogether, as it no longer describes the range of expertise in the profession. The Engineering Council itself may need to be renamed, says the report.

These are among the recommendations in a report to Lord Sainsbury, Minister for Science, on the future role of the Engineering Council - the lead registration and regulatory body for the profession.

A group led by Dr Robert Hawley, the current chairman of the Engineering Council, say that the council needs to play a number of new roles: helping to give engineers entrepreneurial and business skills; exploiting the web for keeping up with new developments; and supporting businesses in matching skills to jobs.

Crispin Simon, chief executive of Biocompatibles plc, and one of the senior industrialists consulted, said: "The development of the future careers of scientists and technologists, of which we employ many, will be seriously enhanced if many of these proposals are taken up."

The Hawley group argues that the 34 professional engineering institutions in the UK has led to a situation where "too many voices are currently giving confused messages".

One goal for the council is to bridge 'old' and 'new' economy skills and to help people cope with quickly changing knowledge and the resulting information overload.

The report aims to set the course that the council, the profession and the Government should follow "to maximise the value of engineering and technology skills to the economy".

webTitle: Cod

fields.headline: Cod
fields.standfirst: Emergency measures are to be taken to rescue declining North Sea stocks of cod on the brink of extinction. Here's our guide to the best sites on the fading fish (while stocks last)
fields.trailText: Emergency measures are to be taken to rescue declining North Sea stocks of cod on the brink of extinction. Here's our guide to the best sites on the fading fish (while stocks last).
fields.body:
1. The European Union is demanding emergency action to preserve cod stocks in the North Sea.

2. And the catch? Well, there is no catch, or at least a much reduced one - British fishermen have been told to reel in 40% less of the fish over the coming year.

3. Cod has taken a battering over the last 30 years. In 1970, there were 250,000 tonnes of the adult fish in the North Sea, but today some estimates put the figure as low as 70,000.

4. The fear is that if the stocks slip any lower there will not be enough cod left to rebuild the population and we will have effectively hunted the fish to extinction.

5. As this graph shows, all species have suffered, but none more than the cod.

6. It is partly the fish's fault. Its milky-white soft flesh has proved irresistible to mankind over the centuries whether baked, salted or deep fried with chips.

7. It's not just us. Seals eat 15,000 tonnes of cod a year, so some fishermen suggest a mass cull of the beasts.

8. Though it would be a politically difficult decision to take.

9. There may be yet be hope from the White House. After Bill Clinton's triumphs in Ulster, George W Bush is surely looking for his own place in history.

10. "I know the human being and fish can coexist peacefully," remarked the president-elect in one of his more lucid moments.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week eighteen

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week eighteen
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. What are the wasters up to this week?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £194.83, Sean Ingle = £84.98, Football Unlimited punters collective = £54.87, Paul MacInnes = £51.32
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £194.83, Sean Ingle = £84.98, Football Unlimited punters collective = £54.87, Paul MacInnes = £51.32

Scott Murray:Manchester United v Liverpool - Liverpool to win at half-time, Manchester United to win at full time £5 @ 25/1

Well, it's the last column before Christmas so I suppose I'll have to work in some seasonal references. Ho ho h... no, I can't be bothered.

But I suppose it is party season after all, and if folk must insist on enjoying themselves then I may as well let my bookmaker in on the fun. I'm sure, for example, that this bet will put a big smile on his face.

The problem is, I've seriously talked myself into thinking this would come off more often than one time in 25 (and the bookies can't have thought about it too much, because the prices in this market are nearly always the same).

Liverpool are past and present masters at starting well before throwing it all away. And Manchester United have a habit of making heavy weather of this fixture (think Paddy Berger last term and Michael Owen's Cup goal the season before) before storming back (think Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and, erm, Ole Gunnar Solksjaer).

So there you have it, justification of sorts. But if I'm talking out of my "amusing" musical Santa hat with flashing lights, then there's nothing more festive than spending all your money on eff all, is there?

Sean Ingle: Ipswich v Southampton - Southampton to win £5 @ 7/2

Christmas is a time for giving. So, Blue Square's Patrick Murray, in the spirit of the season I give you this: a value single.

Of course I feel like I've just tongued my great-aunt - and she's dead - but sometimes these things have to be done. And if I'm going to dirty myself, then I might as well do it properly.

Ipswich lie third, and Southampton are lounging in fifteenth. But when you peer a bit deeper into the formbook the good-God "upset" starts jabbing you fiercely on the shoulder.

Ipswich's home record isn't great (three wins, three draws, two losses) and they recently lost to Derby. What's more, although Southampton's away record is even worse (just one win against Bradford) they have earned creditable draws against Charlton, Derby and Sunderland - and seem to be on a reasonable run of form.

It's also the case that the Saints beat Ipswich 1-0 at Portman Road in the FA Cup, almost a year ago to the day. So if they did it then, why can't they do it tomorrow?

This week's guest punter is Aerny Connor from Derry. £5 treble: Watford v West Brom - Watford to win @ evens; Port Vale v Bristol City - Bristol City to win @ 5/4; Cardiff v Cheltenham - Cardiff to win @ 4/6.

A treble picked from lower division English clubs, all in the promotion hunt, all giving their all, looks good to me.

Watford are massively over-priced, and are decent value bet to beat WBA. Bristol City also offer value - they're a team who travels well and they are up against a struggling side. Finally Cardiff should easily outclass their weaker opposition - and although the price reflects that, the bet is a good filler!

Paul MacInnes Newcastle v Bradford - draw at 13/5 @ £7.50

I'm a winner! I'm a winner! I am a w-i-n-n-e-r! Yeah, that's right, and don't forget it. Why all you losers out there are crying into your homebrew (cos you can't afford a pint) after blowing all your money on a perm system that never fails, I'm taking my winnings (approx. £5.32) all the way to the bank. Believe.

So stick with Daddy Mac, as I offer you the hot inside tip on the weekend's football. Bradford - haven't won away all season. Newcastle - only one win in six. Put the two together and what have you got? A home win, obviously. But odds of two-and-a-half-ish to one on the draw look pretty good to me all the same, and I'm taking them.

Catch you in the New Year, losers!

webTitle: View from elsewhere: Arabophobia in the air

fields.headline: Arabophobia in the air
fields.standfirst:
A security scare at Heathrow airport over a pack of playing cards has drawn attention to widespread racism among airlines, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker

The crash of EgyptAir 990
fields.trailText: A security scare at Heathrow airport over a pack of playing cards has drawn attention to widespread racism among airlines, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
There was a bizarre security alert in London this week. A British Airways Boeing 747, with 329 passengers on board, was just about to take off from Heathrow airport for Miami when a few playing cards were found in the lavatory by a crew member.

On the back of the cards was something printed in Arabic (suspicious, eh?), so the pilot abandoned his takeoff. Closer scrutiny of the Arabic writing revealed that it was nothing more sinister than a calendar, and the plane - having missed its flight slot - eventually took off five-and-a-half hours late.

British Airways remains far from apologetic. "You do not take chances," a spokeswoman said, as if that explained everything. Not taking chances is one thing, but in their attitude towards Arabs, many airlines display a phobia that is not just irrational but thoroughly racist.

Since the crash of TWA flight 800 off the coast of Long Island in 1996, Arabophobia has run riot in the American air industry. Various media commentators blamed terrorists for the crash and pointed the finger at the Arab-American community.

In response to that, the Federal Aviation Administration, on the recommendation of a committee headed by Vice-President Al Gore, introduced a system of passenger "profiling" that was supposed to pick out likely terrorists.

Profiling assesses the trustworthiness of passengers by matching them against a list of criteria. The criteria are mostly secret, but it is known that a passenger travelling alone who has paid cash for the ticket and booked less than five days before departure is more likely to arouse suspicion than one who didn't and is travelling with family or friends.

Why that should point to a terrorist intent is baffling. Like many journalists, I often travel alone, pay cash and book at the last minute. There was also an incident a few months ago where the hijacker brought his family along for the ride.

After several years of applying this mumbo-jumbo to millions of passengers, the FAA is unable to point to a single case where profiling has led to the arrest of anyone who posed a threat to a plane or an airport. What profiling achieves in practice is to single out innocent passengers, mainly of Arab origin, for discriminatory treatment.

So many have been submitted to embarrassing public searches in front of other passengers, or to interrogations which made them miss their plane, that the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee now provides a complaint form on its website for aggrieved passengers to fill in.

Basically, profiling gives a veneer of scientific respectability to something much more familiar and abhorrent: anti-Arab prejudice of the kind that has been promulgated over the years by countless Hollywood stereotypes. We saw this last August when American investigators of the EgyptAir crash tried to portray the co-pilot as an Islamic extremist then, when that failed, as a sex maniac.

In another controversial case, an American pilot abandoned his flight from Phoenix to Washington at Columbus (Ohio) because two Saudis on board were behaving "suspiciously". Security teams and sniffer dogs surrounded the plane and passengers were evacuated on to the runway.

The Saudis, both postgraduate students in their 30s, had, according to a security official, been "very interested in the airplane, asking questions passengers normally wouldn't ask about the plane and where it was going and where it had come from".

One was alleged to have jiggled the handle on the cockpit door, though he said he had only been looking for the toilet. After three hours' questioning the men were released and the FBI declared itself satisfied that no laws had been broken.

By way of explanation for its extraordinary behaviour, the airline said it had only been following rules laid down by the FAA: profiling is compulsory for all American airports and for all American airlines abroad.

In the meantime, the original justification for profiling has evaporated. Last August the National Transportation Safety Board concluded that the TWA crash which led Vice-President Gore to recommend profiling was not, after all, caused by a terrorist but by a technical fault.

fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
1.15pm: BBC footage of Cherie Blair publicising a Christmas special of Before They Were Famous has turned out to be false, writes Claire Cozens.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
In what appears to be an extraordinary gaffe, BBC footage of Cherie Blair released yesterday to publicise a Christmas special of Before They Were Famous has turned out to be false.

The source of the pictures of "Cherie the Banshee" which appeared in today's Mirror is unclear, but Downing Street is adamant that the woman in the BBC programme is not the PM's wife.

The images, which purport to show Mrs Blair in 1985 cavorting at a fundraising bash dressed as a punk, came to light today because the Mirror splashed images from the programme over page 1 and page 3.

"The shots will come back to haunt her [Mrs Blair] this Christmas when mischievous Angus Deayton presents his fifth series of Before They Were Famous on BBC1," the article said. But Mrs Blair, it seems, will have the last laugh.

The issue of the rogue pictures was raised in the parliamentary lobby this morning, when amused political hacks asked whether they were real.

A Downing Street spokeswoman said: "They are not Cherie. We will be pointing out to both the Mirror and the BBC that the footage was false."

The provenance of the pictures remains a mystery to everyone at the BBC.

"I can't comment. We might be preparing a statement," said a spokeswoman for the BBC.
