webTitle: Coroner's 'unique' verdict on conjoined twin

fields.headline: Coroner's 'unique' verdict on conjoined twin
fields.standfirst: More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: A coroner today recorded a verdict that conjoined twin Mary died following High Court-sanctioned surgery to separate her from her sister Jodie.
fields.body:
A coroner today recorded a verdict that conjoined twin Mary died following High Court-sanctioned surgery to separate her from her sister Jodie.

Leonard Gorodkin said at the inquest on the baby in Manchester that he was discarding all the usual verdicts listed in the coroner's rules.

He recorded simply: "Mary died following surgery separating her from her conjoined twin, which surgery was permitted by an order of the High Court, confirmed by the Court of Appeal."

Mr Gorodkin said that he would not record any of the usual verdicts of accident, misadventure, unlawful or lawful killing or an open verdict.

He made his ruling after hearing evidence during the two-hour inquest that Mary had had no chance of survival following the operation to separate her from her stronger sister Jodie at St Mary's Hospital in Manchester on November 6.

The coroner said that the case had been unique to the Court of Appeal.

He said: "It is as unique for me as a coroner as it was for the judges. I don't believe any coroner has had to consider a death from surgery when it was known beforehand the patient was going to die.

"All surgery carries with it a mortality rate but in the case of Mary that was a one hundred percent rate."

He said a verdict of lawful killing was one which might have been considered.

But he added: "The purpose and the reason for separation was not to kill Mary even though her death arose from it."

He said that clearly an unlawful killing verdict was not applicable "although some people emotionally believe that Mary was murdered, of course that isn't the case".

The twins were born at St Mary's on August 8.

There followed a long legal battle after their parents Michaelangelo Attard, 44, and his wife Rina, 29, strict Roman Catholics from the island of Gozo, off Malta, opposed the separation.

Mary died within minutes of the separation during a 20-hour operation.

webTitle: Obituary: Carlos Guastavino

fields.headline: Carlos Guastavino
fields.trailText: The voice of Carlos Guastavino, who has died aged 88, was, perhaps, the most quietly distinctive in 20th-century Argentinian music.
fields.body:
The voice of Carlos Guastavino, who has died aged 88, was, perhaps, the most quietly distinctive in 20th-century Argentinian music. Vigorously rejecting the stylistic radicalism of Alberto Ginastera and his younger compatriot Mauricio Kagel, he followed in the footsteps of 19th-century nationalists such as Julián Aguirre and Alberto Williams.

Yet Guastavino was a no less influential figure for the younger generation of composers - particularly in popular music - growing up in Argentina in the 1960s and 70s. Atonality and musique concrète he dismissed as "nastiness" and "falsification", believing that music should be based on melody and harmony.

"I love melody," he once said. "I love to sing. I refuse to compose music only intended to be discovered and understood by future generations." His distillation of local folk elements into an avowedly romantic-nationalist idiom was also markedly different in aesthetics from Ginastera's early works or the later, hugely successful, concert works of the cult tango king, Astor Piazzolla.

Guastavino was born in Santa Fé, in northern Argentina, the son of a painter and decorator. Originally marked out by his father for a career in science (his brother took up law), the boy's precocious talent for music, particularly the piano, eventually proved decisive. He studied the instrument locally with Esperanza Lothringer and Dominga Laffei, and later, in Buenos Aires, with Germán de Elizalde, while going to Athos Palma for composition.

During the late 1940s, he travelled to Britain on a British Council scholarship and broadcast several times for the BBC; Walter Goehr also premiered his orchestral Three Argentinian Romances at this time. In 1956, he toured Russia and China in programmes featuring his songs.

Guastavino wrote some 300 works, more than half of them the delightful songs, often winsome or tinged with sadness, on which his reputation rests. Latterly, those for unaccompanied chorus, particularly the Canciones Populares Argentinas, often embodying fugal or contrapuntal devices, have come to dominate performances of his vocal music.

Primarily a miniaturist, in his earlier years he essayed larger forms, including orchestral and ballet scores, the most popular being the Divertissement: Fue una vez (premiered at the Teatro Colón, Buenos Aires, in 1942) and the Suite: Argentina, later toured successfully in Europe.

Guastavino's output featured several works for guitar, including three sonatas, as well as a good deal of piano music (including many suites and five sonatinas), plus pieces for other instruments, such as the recorder. He was also an assiduous arranger of his own music, with pieces appearing in several guises, for one or two pianos, guitar or orchestra.

After a period spent exploring classical sonata form in the 1940s, Guastavino's music moved on to a more nationalist expression, as exemplified by his piano suite, 10 Cantilenas Argentinas (Argentine Songs, 1956-58), hailed by some critics as the high point of his piano output. Thereafter, his style underwent a radical simpli-fication, eschewing orthodox development, seeking to encapsulate the musical essence of each inspiration in a single short span. Larger pieces still occasionally appeared, such as the piano duet sonatina, Romance del Plata (1987), after which he retired from composition.

Guastavino received many awards during his lifetime, including several from his home city and Buenos Aires (especially for his songs), from the Justice Ministry, the Organisation of American States and the Inter-American Music Council. Dogged by illness and failing memory in his final years, he returned to Santa Fé, where he was looked after by his sister, who survives him.

 Carlos Guastavino, composer, born April 5 1912; died October 28 2000

webTitle: Underground debate 'going down the tubes'

fields.headline: Underground debate 'going down the tubes'
fields.standfirst: The London underground debate does not appear to be about what needs to be done to improve the network, but is merely a squabble over finances, writes Tony Elliston
fields.trailText: The London underground debate does not appear to be about what needs to be done to improve the network, but is merely a squabble over finances, writes Tony Elliston
fields.body:
The long-running pantomime over the funding of improvements to London Underground is moving relentlessly towards its farcical denouement. The story so far is that deputy prime minister John Prescott - cast in the role of villain - has invented a complex and controversial public-private partnership (PPP) scheme that he intends to foist on Londoners. Meanwhile, local hero and mayor Ken Livingstone has seized the initiative by importing American transport guru Bob Kiley to scupper Mr Prescott's plans.

Mr Kiley has now outlined his alternative funding proposals, which have the merit of being just as intricate and unintelligible as Mr Prescott's. Mr Livingstone has accused Mr Prescott of failing to make vital information available to his man, although this hasn't deterred Mr Kiley from rubbishing the government's plans. Mr Prescott, with customary aplomb, has referred to Mr Kiley as "this guy from America". Mr Livingstone has reciprocated by threatening US-style legal action over the non-disclosure of information, presumably in an attempt to make Mr Kiley feel at home.

One could be forgiven for questioning the relevance of this arcane squabble to the daily reality faced by those unfortunate enough to have to use the service. The tube is an unmitigated disaster zone characterised by continual disruptions, overcrowding, filthy carriages, extortionate fares and fifth rate customer service.

However, the debate does not appear to be about what needs to be done to improve the underground network, but purely about how these improvements are to be financed. Having ruled out taxation as a source of funding, we are left with two options whose comparative merits and demerits appear to be largely doctrinal. Both the bond issue favoured by Mr Livingstone and the government's preferred PPP rely on funding investment from future income streams, although the impact on fares, which are already among the highest of any major city, is unclear.

Both camps predictably claim that the cost of raising the many billions needed will be lower under their proposals. However, given the fact that they both have access to the same financial markets, any differences are likely to be a product of the way the loans are structured rather than the proposals themselves. The PPP option involves some measure of transferred risk, but this is a somewhat specious argument. Future generations of passengers will have to pick up the tab for any cost overruns regardless of who causes them. It is the customer who ultimately bears the risk.

The government's proposals have been described as the partial privatisation of the underground. However Mr Kiley's own proposals rely heavily on the private sector through a system of private performance contracts. Even the acronyms are becoming practically indistinguishable. A more important distinction is that PPP will involve a structural dismemberment of the tube network, with responsibilities split between four separate consortia. Quite why such a split is necessary under the PPP proposals is less than clear, unless the intention is to confuse the customer and eliminate any shred of accountability. And why the government should be so intent on replicating the hydra-headed system that is proving such a spectacular disaster on the railways is even more difficult to fathom.

But what we have heard very little about is what all this money is actually going to be spent on. Mr Kiley has spoken about the need to concentrate on the hidden infrastructure, those parts of the system that are invisible to customers. One can only hope that the impact will not be equally invisible.

London Underground, on the other hand, appear to be more interested in renovating a few stations, presumably on the basis that it will look better even if it doesn't work. Of course, the only questions that Londoners are really interested in are: is the service going to improve and when? However, one suspects that there are still a few more acts of the pantomime to unfold before these questions are answered.

webTitle: Sting makes up with Disney after animated musical bust-up

fields.headline: Sting makes up with Disney after animated musical bust-up
fields.trailText: A documentary made by Sting's wife, Trudie Styler, reveals the behind-the-scenes wrangling which took place when Disney decided to cut some of the singer's work from a new film
fields.body:
A behind-the-scenes documentary is to be released next year describing how Disney axed six songs penned by UK singer-songwriter Sting from their new animated feature, The Emperor's New Groove (pictured). The film, called The Sweatbox, which was made by the musician's wife, actress Trudie Styler, will include footage of Sting receiving the phone call informing him that the songs had been cut. "I'm not a particularly easy person to call and say, 'We're not using your songs' and I didn't make them feel any easier about it," Sting told the AP.

The battle between studio and songwriter began when, having commissioned and received six tracks for an animated drama based on Mark Twain's The Prince and the Pauper, Disney changed tack, reworking the film into a comedy. The love story was cut, rendering Sting's duet with Shawn Colvin, One Day She'll Love Me, redundant.

A subplot featuring a character aged by the sun also got the chop, so Snuff Out the Light went too. "In the original version, characters sang in a more traditional way," said director Mark Dindal. "And as this evolved into the comic tone, that idea didn't fit the sensibility of the movie."

"At first, I was angry and perturbed," says Sting now. "Then I wanted some vengeance. We couldn't use the songs in this new film because the characters they were written for didn't exist anymore." His dark mood hardly brightened when Disney asked him to pen two new tunes for the reworked cartoon. "It was hard on him. There's no question," says producer Randy Fullmer.

But the healing process didn't take long to start. Sting recalls: "After about five minutes of ranting and raving, I thought, 'OK, let's get back to work. Let's try to make this thing happen'"

The new compositions - My Funny Friend and Me and Perfect World - are now both fixtures in the Emperor's New Groove, which is released this weekend in the US and on February 16 in the UK.

According to Disney historian Michael Koenig, over 100 songs have been written for the studio's animated features and later dropped. Disney is not believed to be opposing Styler's documentary on the crisis and the company's head of animation, Thomas Schumacher, who has seen footage, says: 'I think it's going to be great!'

Meanwhile, Sting is impressed by his wife's work. "It's not just a run-of-the-mill making-of film, which is kind of boring. This has got real drama."

webTitle: The Way You See It

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler - we still believe
fields.body:
Robbie Fowler - we still believe

Yesterday, Paul MacInnes asked whether Robbie Fowler would ever again be the player he once was (you can read the article here. Judging by our electronic postbag, it was a question that wasn't worth asking

"God will never die", writes Shaun Webb. "I understand what you're going through and I'm in the same boat. I too can't comprehend fully what he is going through or why he looks so out of place but I will never give up hope. It just needs a little bit of time."

Shaun's view is supported by Peter Borland, who says he is: "Certain, in fact totally convinced that Mr. Fowler will return to his incredible best, within the next few months. God, we are waiting patiently."

Alison Boles was slightly more forceful in her opinions. "Paul MacInnes sounds worse than me after a night of whiskey trebles!"

Meanwhile Daniel Gurr asked: "Without wanting to sound arrogant... who the hell does Paul MacInnes think he is? Not sure really."

"As for the comments about Fowler and Owen not combining, they won't build up an understanding until they are given a fair go - and that won't happen until they are both fully fit for long periods. It is also difficult as they are similar players, with Emile Heskey a natural foil for both of them to play with."

Matthew Reid offers a more tactical assessment of Fowler's plight. "The simple fact of the matter is that the current state of Liverpool's football doesn't allow him to [perform]," he reasoned. "You said that against Fulham he was sluggish, and had his head down. But the fact is that Robbie tried hard and made some good runs - but he was forced to come deep because support was at an extreme minimum.

"How many times did Robbie have the ball and look to give it wide? I'd say on at least seven occasions. And because there was no one out there, Robbie couldn''t give it and then make a run into the box. This stems from Gerrard Houlliers policy of playing four central midfielders and no wingers. How the hell can we give Robbie chances when there's no to give him the service?"

Gary Seabourne agrees. "I believe that Houllier's squad rotation is causing more problems for Fowler than Heskey - not because Fowler is in and out of the side, but more because there is a constantly changing midfield, which means it is harder for him to build up the understanding that he had previously with the likes of McManaman."

But the final word on this subject goes to Martin Sutcliffe. "You lot really know how to wind up a Liverpool fan," he says. "Granted, it's taking a while, but no-one would be foolish enough to write God off yet."

I am the greatest! No, I am!

After all the kerfuffle between Pele and Diego Maradona at this week's Fifa player of the century awards, Big Ron Atkinson waded into the debate this morning by declaring his belief that Johan Cruyff was the best of all time (get your fill here). Here's what you thought of that.

"I appreciate what Big Ron is saying about Cruyff, who was a great player," writes Lee Calvert, "but he never had the same cultural impact as Pele or Maradona, and he was a sullen swine. Maradona may have been a cheat, but at least he looked happy!"

"Maradona wins in my book" he goes on, "because no-one did what he did, win a World Cup virtually single-handedly in 1986, and take a unfashionable club, the Italian equivalent of Southampton, to the Scudetto virtually single-handedly."

Harold Kelly takes the opposing view. "Maradona had marvellous technique, was an outstanding dribbler and played with incomparable agility, but Pele was a genius, had flair and was inventive. His physical presence and skill made him a target in terms of foul play by others (for example during the 1966 world cup in England when he was kicked out of the game). Moreover, Maradona behaved disgracefully, while Pele has been a great ambassador for the sport. In my book, King Pele rules."

"If you want to discuss who should be mentioned in the same breath as Pele," writes Dan Herbst, "try Cruyff or Pele's New York Cosmos teammate Franz Beckenbauer. Maradona, sad to say, should be saved for the conversation on the biggest wastes of talent, for which his only real competition remains George Best."

Finally, Keith Finucane has some words of advice for the duelling duo. "They should have respect for each other, and behave with dignity. They are blessed that they could do something with there lives that they loved doing, that didn't mean WORKING for a living, like their parents had to, as do we."

Amen.

How the hell can we give Robbie chances when there's no to give him the service?" Gary Seabourne agrees. "I believe that Houllier's squad rotation is causing more problems for Fowler than Heskey - not because Fowler is in and out of the side, but more because there is a constantly changing midfield, which means it is harder for him to build up the understanding that he had previously with the likes of McManaman." But the final word on this subject goes to Martin Sutcliffe. "You lot really know how to wind up a Liverpool fan," he says. "Granted, it's taking a while, but no-one would be foolish enough to write God off yet." I am the greatest! No, I am! After all the kerfuffle between Pele and Diego Maradona at this week's Fifa player of the century awards, Big Ron Atkinson waded into the debate this morning by declaring his belief that Johan Cruyff was the best of all time (get your fill here). Here's what you thought of that. "I appreciate what Big Ron is saying about Cruyff, who was a great player," writes Lee Calvert, "but he never had the same cultural impact as Pele or Maradona, and he was a sullen swine. Maradona may have been a cheat, but at least he looked happy!" "Maradona wins in my book" he goes on, "because no-one did what he did, win a World Cup virtually single-handedly in 1986, and take a unfashionable club, the Italian equivalent of Southampton, to the Scudetto virtually single-handedly." Harold Kelly takes the opposing view. "Maradona had marvellous technique, was an outstanding dribbler and played with incomparable agility, but Pele was a genius, had flair and was inventive. His physical presence and skill made him a target in terms of foul play by others (for example during the 1966 world cup in England when he was kicked out of the game). Moreover, Maradona behaved disgracefully, while Pele has been a great ambassador for the sport. In my book, King Pele rules." "If you want to discuss who should be mentioned in the same breath as Pele," writes Dan Herbst, "try Cruyff or Pele's New York Cosmos teammate Franz Beckenbauer. Maradona, sad to say, should be saved for the conversation on the biggest wastes of talent, for which his only real competition remains George Best." Finally, Keith Finucane has some words of advice for the duelling duo. "They should have respect for each other, and behave with dignity. They are blessed that they could do something with there lives that they loved doing, that didn't mean WORKING for a living, like their parents had to, as do we." Amen.

webTitle: New crisis for fishermen

fields.headline: New crisis for fishermen
fields.standfirst: The government has agreed to a European plan to slash North Sea cod quotas,   plunging Britain's dwindling fishing fleet into a new crisis. Derek Brown   explains
fields.trailText: The government has agreed to a European plan to slash North Sea cod quotas, plunging Britain's dwindling fishing fleet into a new crisis. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
What does the EU propose?
It wants swingeing cuts in the tonnage landed each year by the various national fishing fleets. Britain, which has more coastline and therefore more national waters than any other member state, is naturally the most severely affected nation. Also, because of our obsession with cod - we eat one-third of the global catch - we are going to be clobbered by moves to protect North Sea stocks, now at crisis level.

Crisis? What crisis?
EU experts say that stocks of adult, breeding, cod in the North Sea are now down to 70,000 tonnes. That's less than half the level they say is needed to guarantee the survival of the species.

Why don't they halt cod fishing altogether, until stocks recover?
It would be political suicide for fisheries ministers. As it is, the Blair government is going to take some stick for agreeing to a 40% cut from this year's already low quota. Hundreds of jobs are going to lost from the once-mighty fishing industry, which now employs just 15,000 men.

What do the fishermen say?
Barry Deas, head of the National Federation of Fishermen's Organisations, calls the plan disastrous. Already, many vessels are barely viable, and the reduced quota means that specialised cod-fishing boats will have to be laid up.

Another dastardly European plot, eh?
Of course, if you believe that kind of thing. The fishing industry, even more than agriculture, is an inviting target for the Europhobes, who foam with fury about foreigners who never play by the rules, but who are hard put to come up with any evidence for the claim.

Anyone else we could blame?
Ourselves, perhaps. Consumption of fresh fish is climbing steadily, on the back of health fads and the foody trend. The steady decline of fish sales since the 1950s has been reversed: they're rising 3.5% a year by volume, and 6.5% by value. The once-humble cod is now equally at home in smart eateries as in deep-fat fryers. Cod, you might say, is the new halibut.

Should we be socially responsible and stop eating fish?
No, say the food stylists. No, say our doctors. No, says common sense. What we should, perhaps, stop eating is the factory-made gunk from the freezer cabinets, produced from fish indiscriminately Hoovered from the deep.

webTitle: No tears for Gwyneth as stalker is locked up

fields.headline: No tears for Gwyneth as stalker is locked up
fields.trailText: A man who stalked Gwyneth Paltrow for two years has been jailed by a Los Angeles judge who ruled that he was insane
fields.body:
Gwyneth Paltrow (pictured) has become the latest public figure to become the victim of a stalker's attentions. Dante Michael Soiu of Ohio was convicted this week of harassing the lachrymose Shakespeare in Love star who is reportedly "very pleased" that he is now in custody.

The 51-year-old stalker's campaign of pursuit began two years ago. During that time, Soiu sent the willowy actress "four or five letters, emails [and] packages a day" which ranged from flowers and sweets to pornography. He also made "a threat of a sexual nature," said LA deputy district attorney Rhonda Saunders.

In May 1999, Soiu appeared outside the LA home of Paltrow's parents. Although he was asked to leave by Paltrow's mother, actress Blythe Danner, he returned the following day.

Los Angeles superior court judge Robert P O'Neill ruled that Soiu was insane and confined him to a lockdown mental facility where he will remain until at least June 14.

After stalker trials involving high profile names, such as Madonna and Steven Spielberg, the case had been kept confidential at the request of the actress, who is said to have been "very frightened" by Soiu's interest. Paltrow was referred to in court as 'Jane Doe' while the case continued.

webTitle: Scooby-Doo scribe sees stars over adaptation

fields.headline: Scooby-Doo scribe sees stars over adaptation
fields.standfirst: Plus: Al Pacino to stomp on New York streets again, web bootleggers sued by Motion Picture Association of America, and Dark Horizons website hosts teaser poster for Harry Potter movie
fields.trailText: Plus: Al Pacino to stomp on New York streets again, web bootleggers sued by Motion Picture Association of America, and Dark Horizons website hosts teaser poster for Harry Potter movie
fields.body:
 The writer of the upcoming Scooby Doo (pictured) movie has been discussing his big screen adaptation of the famed cartoon. Says James Gunn, "the problem with most cartoons-to-movies is that they attempt to be exact replicas of the cartoons - people speaking like cartoons, etc. I never wanted to simply watch a couple hundred episodes of Scooby-Doo and then vomit them out in a different order, longer and with real people. Instead, I wanted to say: let's take it as fact that there's this dog that can talk, and this group of mystery-solving teenagers who've come up against numerous men in masks posing as supernatural entities, and that all the other traditions of Scooby-Doo really happened as well. If that were all real, what would these people be like? What would be their strengths and weaknesses? What problems would they have between them? What are they like between mysteries? What don't we see on the show? In essence, if they are real, who are they?" The film will star Sarah Michelle Gellar and Christina Ricci and is expected to be released at the end of 2001.

 Al Pacino may take the lead role in People I Know, to be directed by Dan Algrant. Pacino would play a press agent whose practice is waning, and who gets involved in a mystery involving New York politics and celebrity.

 A Massachusetts man is being sued by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA), writes the Hollywood Reporter, for selling unauthorised copies of films over the internet. The case marks the first ever lawsuit by the MPAA against web bootleggers, and is being heralded as a big step in the battle against piracy.

 A teaser poster for the movie of JK Rowling's massively popular Harry Potter stories has made it onto the web. The poster, which can be seen in all its glory at Dark Horizons, features an owl carrying a letter addressed to the bespectacled teen sleuth.

webTitle: Hall wooed for return to newspapers

fields.headline: Hall wooed for return to newspapers
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Former News of the World editor Phil Hall is being wooed for a return to newspapers, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former News of the World editor Phil Hall is being wooed to return to newspapers.

Mr Hall said he has had talks with several publishers.

"I have been offered three situations on three national titles, but all of them have been below editorship," he said.

He added that he would "love to work on any of these" but that the jobs on offer were not senior enough.

Editorships arise rarely, but there could be an opportunity for Mr Hall at Express Newspapers following speculation that owner Richard Desmond is considering launching a new Sunday edition of the Daily Star.

Friends say Mr Hall is "bored" working in public relations after the intensity of running the country's biggest newspaper.

Mr Hall denied recent reports that he was going to be offered the editorship of Hello!, following speculation that editor Maggie Kuomi's position on the celebrity magazine may be under threat.

And it is thought that the competition from the new "common enemy" of the Express and OK! has raised the stakes for Hello!, which is now seeking an editor with national newspaper leadership skills.

Hello! publishing director Sally Cartwright was keen to quash the rumours.

"The truth at the moment is that the editor is under no pressure to resign," she said.

But press reports have linked a series of other journalists with the job, including former Tatler editor Jane Procter and former OK! editor Richard Barber.

webTitle: In brief: Susan Sarandon sizes up another younger man

fields.headline: Susan Sarandon sizes up younger man
fields.standfirst: Plus: Tom Hanks denies any political aspirations; Lisa Kudrow's life as a dog; Robert Downey clears Anne Heche of any part in his downfall; Liam Neeson to star in film about real-life miscarriage of justice
fields.trailText: Plus: Tom Hanks denies any political aspirations; Lisa Kudrow's life as a dog; Robert Downey clears Anne Heche of any part in his downfall; Liam Neeson to star in film about real-life miscarriage of justice
fields.body:
 Susan Sarandon has been speaking about her latest role as a middle-aged woman who seduces a man much younger than herself. Rialto is the latest in a string of parts where she has been romantically linked with younger men. Her husband Tim Robbins, who she met on the set of Bull Durham, is himself 12 years her junior. The Thelma and Louise star said: "They keep paying me to jump into the sack with these guys! But seriously, there is no reason why a middle-aged woman shouldn't have the same needs as a middle-aged man. It's brave of some movie-makers to head in that direction. I know I'm game."

 Tom Hanks has denied rumours that he is to run for political office in America. According to Ananova, rumours started circulating that Hanks was considering a political career after the Oscar winner appeared in a number of adverts to raise money for a second world war memorial on Washington's National Mall. However, Hanks denies any such aspirations: "I would not want to live in a country that would have me as a leader in any sort of political bent," he said.

 Friends actress Lisa Kudrow is to play a woman who thinks she is a dog. The star, who plays ditzy Pheobe in the hit show, is in final negotiations to take the role of a woman who has a nervous breakdown and believes that she has changed species in a romantic comedy called Bark. Vincent D'Onofrio will also star in the movie to be directed by newcomer Kasia Adamik.

 Robert Downey Jr has cleared Anne Heche of recent allegations that she provided the troubled actor with drugs (see earlier story). Speaking for the first time since his arrest for drug possession at the end of November, the actor blasted a recent story printed in the National Enquirer, which claimed that Heche had supplied him with drugs. He told reporters: "It's not true." Downey, who has been working with Heche on the set of Ally McBeal adds, "Everyone at Ally McBeal is incredibly supportive. They set up my schedule so my recovery comes first, and the show is second." Downey is due to appear in court on 27 December.

 Liam Neeson is keen to star in a movie about a British man who has served 27 years in prison for a murder that he says he did not commit. Stephen Downing, 44, who was convicted for the murder of typist Wendy Sewell when he was 17, has fought to prove his innocence ever since. Neeson is anxious to play the part of local newspaper editor Don Hale, who has campaigned for Downing's release and also written a book about his efforts.

webTitle: India's film industry reels over directors cut

fields.headline: Bollywood reels over director's cut
fields.trailText: Indian director Nazim Rizvi has been arrested and charged with conspiracy to kill several of Bollywood's leading actors
fields.body:
It was a complete mystery: how could Nazim Rizvi, an obscure director, recruit three of Indian cinema's hottest stars for his first major film? And why had other film-makers put back the release of their own films, giving Rizvi a free run at the box office next week?

A possible answer emerged yesterday when Rizvi was arrested at his plush Bombay home and charged with conspiracy to kill. Among his alleged targets were several of Bollywood's leading actors, including Hrithik Roshan (pictured), India's latest male pin-up.

After investigating Rizvi's affairs, police claimed they had uncovered evidence that underworld money had financed his mercurial film career.

The trail led to Chhota Shakeel, the right hand man of India's most feared underworld chief, Dawood Ibrahim. Bollywood's leading film financier, the popular Bharat Shah, was also implicated.

Rizvi's arrest is the most concrete step yet taken by detectives to expose the deep nexus between the underworld and a section of Bollywood.

Last night, a host of other celebrities faced police questioning over their underworld links. Officers said they had obtained 25 tapes of Rizvi talking to Shakeel in which they discussed two, as yet unnamed, Bollywood stars.

After swooping on Rizvi, who tried in vain to escape, police seized all the reels of his film from a laboratory where they were being processed. The film Chori Chori Chupke Chupke (Steal My Heart Quietly), stars three household names in India: Salman Khan, and actresses Preity Zinta and Rani Mukherjee. "Other people are involved. The question is what evidence we can get," one police officer said.

Detectives claim Rizvi used Shakeel to persuade reluctant stars to take part in his project. "He manipulated the release dates of movies produced by other film-makers to suit his own films," claimed assistant crime branch commissioner Shankar Kamble. Rizvi had also planned to eliminate several successful personalities in the film world, he alleged.

As well as Rakesh Roshan, Rizvi allegedly threatened Bollywood producer Ajay Devgan, whose new blockbuster was due out on December 28, the same day as Chori Chori. He also allegedly tried to persuade a host of Bollywood stars to visit Dawood Ibrahim in Karachi, Pakistan, where they would be forced to sign contracts.

Veteran Bollywood observers expressed little surprise at the arrest. "The mafia has emerged as the biggest film financier," cultural critic Kumar Ketkar said.

"The state has not been patronising art for some time. All kinds of artists are making a beeline for the mafia which has acquired a kind of respectability."

Rizvi's arrest is the latest in a series of blows to Bollywood's prestige.

In September, income tax officials raided the homes of several actors and directors, including Salman Khan, looking for evidence of earnings hidden in foreign banks. Investigations by the police, tax officials and the intelligence bureau are continuing.

webTitle: US milk campaign signs up Elton John

fields.headline: US milk campaign signs up Elton John
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Sir Elton John is the latest celebrity to sign up for a US ad campaign encouraging Americans to drink more milk, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sir Elton John is the latest celebrity to sign up for a US ad campaign that shows celebrities at their least glamorous - wearing a milk moustache.

Sir Elton joins top celebrities including Joan Rivers, Jackie Chan and ER star Noah Wyle, all of whom have been photographed wearing the distinctive moustache to encourage Americans to drink more milk.

The latest ad will appear in the Christmas issue of Time magazine.

A photo of Sir Elton will appear alongside the words, "I'm still standing. Want strong bones? Drinking enough low-fat milk now can help prevent osteoporosis later".

Sir Elton is to donate his fee for the ad to the Elton John Aids Foundation.

webTitle: Q appoints McKie editor

fields.headline: Q appoints McKie as new editor
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Smash Hits editor John McKie has been appointed new editor of Q magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Smash Hits editor John McKie has been appointed as the new editor of Q magazine, ending months of uncertainty following the departure this summer of Andy Pemberton.

Mr McKie will replace editorial director Andrew Harrison, who has edited the magazine since Mr Pemberton's departure.

Mr Pemberton left the magazine suddenly amid rumours that its owner Emap was pushing its new digital strategy at the expense of popular magazine brands.

Insiders say Mr McKie, who has been editor of Smash Hits since 1997, is a "safe pair of hands" and predict that he will bring stability to the magazine.

webTitle: Neil Lyndon takes on the feminists

fields.headline: Back in the fray
fields.standfirst: He was shunned, vilified and even physically attacked. He lost access  to his son, his career dried up and his money ran out. So why has Neil  Lyndon decided to take on the feminists again? Jim White finds out
fields.trailText: He was shunned, vilified and even physically attacked. He lost access to his son, his career dried up and his money ran out. So why has Neil Lyndon decided to take on the feminists again? Jim White finds out.
fields.body:
For a martyr, Neil Lyndon looks in remarkable fettle. As anyone would who could easily pass as 10 years younger than he is (54). Nor is the man who claims his career was destroyed by a monstrous regiment of feminist media types selling the Big Issue while billeted in a cardboard box. He lives in a comfortable flat in Edinburgh, in the shadow of the cranes constructing the new Scottish parliament, while the house he is building, on a hillside overlooking the glorious Firth of Forth, nears completion.

"No, I'm doing fine now," he says. "But it has taken me 10 years to get back to where I was. Last year, for the first time, I earned what I did in 1989. A decade to recover: it's a long time."

Readers of the Sunday Times will know all about Lyndon and his life. For the past fortnight his story has dominated the paper. Under headlines such as "Return of the heretic" and "Fighting the fundamentalists", he has detailed how, since he began writing a series of critiques of feminism, culminating in a book called No More Sex War in 1991, he has been vilified. As a direct consequence of his writings, he reckons, he could not find work as a journalist, he was dropped by friends both male and female, he was assaulted while standing beside a luggage carousel at Heathrow, and, most seriously, he lost custody of his teenaged son. Which, presumably, was not what he was hoping when his work was published.

"No, what I was hoping was that I might stir up a bit of debate," he smiles. "Oh, and I was hoping I might sell a few copies of the book."

In fact, for Lyndon, all publicity turned out not to be good publicity. Despite being written about in every paper, despite being the subject of countless debates on radio, despite a publicity tour which saw dozens turn up to heckle him in bookshops, he sold only marginally more copies of his tome than Anthea Turner did of her recent autobiography.

"It reached its nadir when Yvonne Roberts wrote a book in answer to my book and for some reason known only to themselves, my publishers thought it would be a good idea to go on a publicity tour together and I stupidly agreed," he says. "We'd go to bookshops, we'd both speak, nobody would listen to me, then, supposedly, we'd sign copies of our books. Except night after night, there'd be a great long queue at her table, while if I signed one of mine I was lucky."

As his career imploded, there were no royalties to cushion his fall. In August 1992, he was declared bankrupt.

Which makes you wonder: why is he revisiting the pain nearly 10 years on? Why not quietly get on with the business of reviving his career, writing about motoring for the Sunday Telegraph? It can't be out of pique that the car his paper has just given him to review is a Korean tin box which you would be embarrassed to be seen using to store your paper clips. So why has he done it?

"It was partly because I hoped to be more calmly received this time round," he says. "But also I think it's really interesting what my story says about the treatment of dissidents in what is supposed to be an open society. Not for a moment would I compare myself with Salman Rushdie. It is nonsense to compare the phenomena. But I do find it paradoxical that many of the people who defended Rushdie's right to write whatever he wanted should be so censorious and destructive about wanting to limit my freedom to do the same. The way I was treated seemed to be a deliberate attempt to discourage interest in my book by lampooning me."

Name names, here. Who exactly?

"Well, just one example: Helena Kennedy. She concluded her recommendation once in a round-up of books of the year with a plea to readers not to buy mine. No discussion, no criticism, just don't buy it."

It was certainly true that, at the time, Lyndon's dismissal of feminism provoked some aggressive personal assaults. Looking back at the cuttings, there was not much discussion of the content of his writings, rather it was the size of penis, his ability to attract women and the fragrance of his breath that were called into question. One adjective was so routinely applied to him, you began to wonder if it was part of his name: the Inadequate Neil Lyndon. And though he claims that he laughed at the time, his Sunday Times essay last weekend concluded with this: "And, yes, just in case anybody is wondering, I have got a lovely girlfriend. 'Magical' my son calls her. Some guys get all the luck."

So if his aim was to reopen an intellectual debate on the nature of feminism, why did he feel the need to tell us he could still pull?

"Well, so many of the attacks were so personal, in a way I just wanted to prove that since they had got it so wrong about me, then it suggested they had got it wrong about my argument. It's difficult, you know. One doesn't want to get embroiled in this sort of thing, but when someone who has never met you writes in a national newspaper that you have only written the book because you can't attract women, it's hard not to point out that when you worked at Honey magazine and the news leaked that you were getting married, the female members of staff almost suffered a collective breakdown."

Underneath all this is clearly a sense of hurt. Anecdotal evidence suggests that he had always been a popular sort of guy, that despite an ability sometimes to pick a fight in an empty room, through school, through university, at work, everyone liked Neil. So when he found himself a pariah, a public joke figure, his pride was wounded.

"Mmm, well, I was always the most popular kid at school, so I suppose it came as a shock," he says. "But I was more shocked at what it revealed about the way anyone dissenting could be treated in our society. It really was Maoist."

Which leads to the core of his complaint: that his life was systematically ruined by feminists bent on revenge. Does he have any evidence?

"Look, no editor actually told me to fuck off when I phoned up with an idea," he says, "but you can tell. Honestly, when you are being cold-shouldered you know. Phone calls weren't returned, letters were ignored, perfectly good ideas for television series which I know, because I had plenty of experience of telly, would have at least got to the lunch meeting stage, didn't even get a reply. In 1989, I earned 70 grand from journalism. In 1991, I earned seven. That's tangible."

There is, of course, another explanation: his ideas weren't very marketable. The only place in a newspaper where gender politics are discussed is in the women's pages, and a man with a specialisation in attacking their very purpose was hardly box office. As for men in other sections of the media, well I can't be alone in not being remotely interested in this sort of thing. And if I had ever been in a position to do so, I'm not sure Lyndon's was a campaign I could be bothered to champion: as a middle class white male, I don't honestly think of myself as a victim of discrimination.

"You're right," he says. "A lot of men aren't interested, until they wind up in the divorce court and they discover that the system is absolutely stacked against them."

This is perhaps the most compelling part of Lyndon's story. During a bitter divorce case soon after the furore over his book, he lost all rights of access to his son, and wasn't even able to speak to him for more than two years.

"Do you have children?" he says. "Just try to imagine what that is like, you can't even begin to comprehend how awful that is until it happens."

But why did he believe this had anything to do with his feminist antagonists?

"Every day, my wife's QC would come into court with great piles of newspaper cuttings in which I was routinely denounced as mad, bad and dangerous," he says. "I'm not suggesting the presiding judge in the Edinburgh court of sessions was a feminist, but I think he had a chivalrous instinct to protect my wife from a man who must have been a nutter, because every newspaper in the land said he was."

Eventually, Lyndon was reunited with his son. Now 18, the youngster lives with him before taking up a place at Edinburgh University (the video of the men's movement's favourite movie Fight Club which lies next to Lyndon's television belongs, he is quick to point out, to the boy).

These days the martyr is happy, solvent and excellent company. So chipper is he indeed, he has decided to return to the subject that made him briefly notorious 10 years ago. This time round, however, his work has caused hardly a ripple. Which suggests one of two things. Either, as Lyndon hopes, that much of what he suggested first time round - about males becoming second class citizens in health, education and divorce - is now being more regularly discussed, which means he does not appear such an iconoclast. Or, maybe it is something else. Maybe his campaign is such an idiosyncratic one, nobody has even noticed that Lyndon is on the warpath once more.

webTitle: Turner-Laing takes acting role at BBC marketing

fields.headline: Turner-Laing takes acting role at BBC marketing
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The BBC has appointed Sophie Turner-Laing as acting marketing and communications director, reports Claire Cozens.
Dec 4: Two candidates in running for BBC head of marketing
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC has signalled that a replacement for marketing chief Matthew Bannister is still some way off by officially appointing Sophie Turner-Laing as acting marketing and communications director.

Ms Turner-Laing will add the temporary role to her responsibilities as controller of acquisitions for BBC TV, and is not in the running for the permanent job.

Her appointment was announced to staff yesterday.

A BBC spokesman said the corporation was still some way off finding a replacement for Mr Bannister, who leaves today.

Jane Frost, BBC head of corporate marketing, is understood to be the only remaining internal candidate for the top marketing post after Sally Osman was handed the number two job of head of communications last month.

Another name in the frame is that of Jim Hytner, Channel 5 marketing director.

webTitle: STV considers legal challenge to ITC ruling

fields.headline: STV considers legal challenge to ITC ruling
fields.standfirst: Dec 14: Byelection sparks STV political coverage order
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Scottish TV is considering legal action over allegations that it has given Labour an unfair electoral advantage, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 14: Byelection sparks STV political coverage order
fields.body:
Scottish TV (STV) is considering legal action over allegations that it has given Labour an unfair electoral advantage.

The station is expected to decide today whether to challenge an order from the Independent Television Commission following its screening of a question and answer session with Tony Blair earlier this week.

The station has been pulled up by the TV watchdog over the broadcast because of rules obliging proportionate airtime to all parties in the run-up to elections.

While the broadcast was deemed to be problem-free south of the border, the ITC said it broke the rules in Scotland because of an upcoming byelection.

STV now faces the possibility of being forced to clear its schedules to give airtime to William Hague, Charles Kennedy and John Swinney, head of the SNP.

Sandy Ross, STV managing director, said: "We believe we have satisfied all our obligations as an impartial and balanced broadcaster.

"However, it is simply not clear what is now being asked of us and until we receive that clarification we can only reserve our position."

An ITC spokesman said it was for STV to decide how to comply with the direction, but made clear that the broadcaster did not necessarily have to offer an identical programme to the other three party leaders.

"It is now up to STV to come up with a formula before the byelection which is acceptable to the ITC," he added.

webTitle: Black anger over US elections

fields.headline: 'This is not about Gore. This is about us'
fields.standfirst:
Justices verdict stirs African Americans to renewed struggle

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Justices verdict stirs African Americans to renewed struggle
fields.body:
The Rev Jesse Jackson returned to one of the shrines of the civil rights movements yesterday to call for a continued struggle over the disputed election results, giving a pointed message that black American leaders had not reconciled themselves to a Bush presidency.

Mr Jackson held a rally outside the former Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee, where Martin Luther King was assassinated in 1968, and told a crowd of African Americans that the irregularities in Florida showed that the civil rights struggle was far from over.

Despite Al Gore's concession, black activists have vowed to pursue through the courts widespread allegations of systematic disenfranchisement of black voters in Florida.

At a protest in Tallahassee on Wednesday, Mr Jackson condemned the supreme court ruling which gave finally gave victory to Mr Bush, and yesterday he continued to call the legitimacy of Mr Bush's win into question.

"When the supreme court issues a ruling calculated to deal a setback to the causes of civil rights in this country, the people respond," he said.

"The struggles have been long and painful, but in the end the cause of justice prevails.

"Our lesson today is that the fight that our parents and grandparents fought, a fight that many of us remember participating in, must never cease.

"In order for justice to prevail, the civil rights struggle must continue."

Charles Rangel, a New York Democrat congressman, said: "We may well be witnessing the greatest mass disenfranchisement of African Americans since passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965" - the act which barred racially discriminating practices.

Violations investigated

Evidence of voting rights violations will be given public hearings in Tallahassee in the second week of January, just weeks before George W Bush's inauguration, the US commission on civil rights announced.

The justice department is already conducting a preliminary investigation into claims that blacks were intimidated from voting by a heavy police presence around some polling booths, and that the names of thousands of minority voters were purged from the Florida electoral rolls in the run-up to the election.

Mr Bush made a huge effort to portray his version of the Republican party as an inclusive haven for all Americans, and filled the podium at the party convention in August with black speakers and entertainers.

But the change in image backfired. He got only 8% of black votes, less than almost any other Republican candidate in recent history.

"The way they had blacks parade across the stage at the convention was almost demeaning," Ronald Payne, a Democratic congressman from New Jersey, said.

The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People (NAACP), the trade unions conducted an unprecedented get-out-the-vote campaign in black districts, broadcasting advertisements portraying Mr Bush as a threat to black aspirations. One NAACP advertisement associated him with the savage racist murder of James Byrd in Texas two years ago. It blamed him for failing to bring in hate-crime legislation after the killing, and triggered allegations that the Democrats and their allies were using scare tactics to bring out the vote.

"Democrats realised that they could not get their base sufficiently enthused about Al Gore, so they demonised George Bush," Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster, said.

Distrust grows

The black turnout was 51% in November, up from 48% four years earlier. In Florida, where black voters were angered by the abolition of affirmative action by Jeb Bush, the state governor and George W Bush's brother, the black share of the total vote rose from 10% to 15%, despite the problems on election day. Black Floridians preferred Mr Gore to Mr Bush 93% to 7%.

The Bush camp hopes to win the confidence of black Americans by an ethnicly diverse list of appointments. The retired general Colin Powell is almost certain to become the first black secretary of state and Condoleezza Rice the first national security advisor.

But those appointments were loudly signalled in the course of the campaign, clearly without making an indentation in the almost monolithic black support for Mr Gore.

The trauma of the election dispute and the controversy about the black vote has only deepened distrust. Kweisi Mfume, the NAACP president, who invited Mr Bush to address the organisation during the campaign, said yesterday that the president-elect had to go further in acknowledging the problems faced by black voters.

"Anything short of a collective condemnation will only foster a deeper belief in the minds of a lot of people that this nation does not care about them ... or how they feel," he said. "That leads to anarchy and division and mistrust."

Mr Mfume said the black campaign for an investigation into black disenfranchisement would not end just because Mr Gore had given up the struggle for a Florida recount.

"This is not about him. This is about us."

webTitle: Real terms rise for English research grants

fields.headline: Real terms rise for English research grants
fields.trailText: Block research funds for English academic institutions will stay level in real terms over the next year, totalling just under £890m, funding council officials confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Block research funds for English academic institutions will stay level in real terms over the next year, totalling just under £890m, funding council officials confirmed yesterday.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England will next week consult universities and colleges on plans to allocate an extra £330m over three years to improve pay among academic and non-academic staff. Institutions will have to submit strategies describing how they are managing staff in order to qualify for the funds announced by the government last month.

The money for pay increases will be allocated as a separate stream to core teaching funds.

Details of the council's decisions following the advice of education secretary, David Blunkett, last month will be released in a grant letter to institutions in the next few days. The council will allocate just over £5.5bn to English universities and colleges in 2001-02.

Apart from the recurrent research funds - distributed mostly on the back of the results of the Research Assessment Exercise - the council is allocating an extra £300m for capital projects over the next three years.

Unlike the previous schemes for distributing grants for equipment and buildings, the new Science Research Investment Fund, funded jointly with research councils and the Wellcome Trust, will respond to institutional wide strategic plans rather than specific bids. The grants will meet 75% of the total costs of projects, with universities expected to provide 25% from their own or third-party resources - except where two or more institutions are collaborating.

The funding council will announce the final winners of the Joint Research Equipment Initiative next week.

webTitle: Arafat resumes peace talks

fields.headline: Arafat resumes peace talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yasser Arafat has resumed high-level talks with Israel six weeks after he and Israeli cabinet minister Shimon Peres negotiated an unsuccessful truce in the fighting.
fields.body:
Yasser Arafat has resumed high-level talks with Israel six weeks after he and Israeli cabinet minister Shimon Peres negotiated an unsuccessful truce in the fighting.

The Palestinian leader, this time meeting foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami, was in discussion until early this morning at the Erez crossing point between Israel and the Gaza Strip.

The two sides will make another effort to implement understandings regarding a truce and lifting of the Israeli blockade around Palestinian cities agreed at the October summit in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt.

A meeting between Mr Arafat and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak could be the next stage after the talks. "We certainly want to check the willingness of the Palestinians to complete the (peace) process," said Mr Ben-Ami before leaving for Gaza last night.

The Palestinian leadership will meet later today to consider resuming peace negotiations, though an unsourced report on Israeli army radio said peace talks would resume next week in Cairo.

Meanwhile, the killing continues. Five Palestinians were killed overnight in three shootings on the West Bank and Gaza, according to Palestinian officials and Israeli radio. The Israeli army confirmed two of the incidents.

webTitle: Obituary: Gaylord Carter

fields.headline: Gaylord Carter
fields.trailText: When the classic movie epic, Ben-Hur, opened in 1926 at the Million Dollar theatre in Los Angeles, it ran continuously for six months. Gaylord Carter, who has died aged 95, was there every night playing the score, which he knew by heart
fields.body:
When the classic movie epic, Ben-Hur (pictured), opened in 1926 at the Million Dollar theatre in Los Angeles, it ran continuously for six months. Gaylord Carter, who has died aged 95, was there every night playing the score, which he knew by heart, at the console of one of 7,000 organs that proliferated across America during the silent film era. Only about 100 survive today, many as unplayed curiosities.

At the keyboard in 1927 for Ernst Lubitsch's The Student Prince, Carter nimbly handled the Sigmund Romberg music to fit the jerky movements on screen. He also played the score when the first Phantom Of The Opera opened in California in 1925.

He visited Europe, Britain and Australia, played the famous Wurlitzer at the Forest Lawn cemetery, and at such famous resorts of the 1920s and 1930s as the Avalon theatre on Santa Catalina Island, the Pasadena civic auditorium, and, in recent years, at the massive glass-and-steel Crystal Cathedral in Orange Grove, California.

Carter often composed his own background music to the early silent films - he could sound a bugle call, imitate a gong, strike a percussive note for a comedian's pratfall, and conjure up ominous chords for villains, heroic music for battles, and dreamy passages for love scenes. "At its best, the music is felt but not noticed," he said. "When it's right, you should lose yourself in the picture."

He was born in Weisbaden, Germany, and emigrated to Wichita, Kansas, with his parents as a child. He took six months of piano lessons and another six at the organ, and by the age of 10 was accompanying the services at his local congregational church. At 14, he began playing in a cinema for children's matinees. In 1922, Carter's family moved to Los Angeles, and he quickly began earning pocket money by playing for the films.

Two years later, he was accompanying a Harold Lloyd comedy, The Kid, when the legendary actor and producer came to see how the film was doing. Impressed by Carter's playing, Lloyd hired him as his personal organist, and recommended him for a job at the Million Dollar theatre. It paid $110 a week, an astronomical wage for the time. Carter gave up his law studies at the University of California, using the money to put his sister and brother through college.

During one of Lloyd's most famous scenes, when he is hanging off the hands of a clock high above a city street in Safety Last, Carter swung into the popular number, Time On My Hands. Lloyd was not amused and told him: "Gaylord, I do the jokes."

When the silent movie era ended, Carter switched to radio. For seven years, he played the introduction to television's Amos 'n' Andy show. In later life, he was rediscovered, and played at dozens of silent movie revivals. He never married.

 Gaylord Carter, pianist and organist, born August 3 1905; died November 20 2000

fields.trailText: Roma are preparing a sensational £15m bid for Leeds striker Mark Viduka, the Daily Mail reports. They quote Nils Liedholm, the chief advisor to Roma chairman Franco Sensi, as saying: "The most important thing now is to get him before another before another big club does because this guy could be our new Gabriel Batistuta. That is how highly we rate himI have not seen a more exciting player in Europe this season."

They quote Nils Liedholm, the chief advisor to Roma chairman Franco Sensi, as saying: "The most important thing now is to get him before another before another big club does because this guy could be our new Gabriel Batistuta. John Gregory has been forced to jettison big-money moves for Benni McCarthy and Juan Pablo Angel by his "skinflint board," reports the Star. "If you can't buy a BMW then you go for a Rover," admitted a disappointed Gregory. "It's frustrating for me when I look at my subs bench and see babies on there." One 'Rover' who could be coming to Aston Villa, the paper suggests, is Sunderland's £1.5m rated Honduran striker Milton Nunez, who was spotted at Villa's Bodymoor Heath training ground yesterday.

Celtic are hoping to sign Ramon Vega in time for him to make his debut against Aberdeen tomorrow. Planet Football claims that Martin O'Neill has already met Vega in London and hopes to complete a £350,000 deal later today.

Dave Jones could return to football as manager of Norwich. "I want to return to football as soon as possible," Jones told The Sun. "There has been talk of Norwich's interest and it is very flattering."

Ryan Giggs and David Beckham could become the first £100,000-a-week players in British football when their contract negotiations begin the in the new year, according to the Express.

Sunderland defender Paul Butler is set to sign for Wolves for £1m later today, reports Teamtalk.

Preston are hoping to sign Titi Camara on loan.

webTitle: Style: Handsome prints

fields.headline: Handsome prints
fields.standfirst: Jazz up your life and your wardrobe with bright, bold geometrics, says  Hadley Freeman
fields.trailText: Jazz up your life and your wardrobe with bright, bold geometrics, says Hadley Freeman.
fields.body:
We are such style cowards. Sensible solid colours form the basis of our wardrobes. It is as if we are doing our best to meld in with the general landscape and deflect attention from ourselves.

For far too long, bold optical patterns have been seen as eccentric at best, the province of batty aunts with a fondness for the Bloomsbury set. Then Sigourney Weaver, as she has done before, showed us the error of our ways in Ang Lee's film The Ice Storm. Resplendent in purple patterned blouses, she was a vision of beauty, individuality, sexuality. Never before had 70s cocktail party fashion looked so pantingly desirable.

Designers such as Versace, Gucci, Paul Smith and Julien Macdonald have all helped this Mrs Robinson bandwagon along, playing with gorgeous, strongly patterned clothes, sharpened and sexed up for a new, younger clientele (Macdonald decorated his Tetris-like patterns with sequins). The lovely Lucy Liu, of Charlie's Angels and Ally McBeal, looked hypnotic in Versace at the Oscars and the Pucci print-clad All Saints gobbled up the paparazzi flashbulbs at the Cannes film festival in the summer. Welcome back to the Valley of the Dolls.

Labels whose distinctive bold patterns did not suit the muted 90s have fallen back into fashion's favour. Missoni's characteristic stripes have been rediscovered by a new generation, appreciative of their Technicolor elegance.

Pucci prints swirl around the most fashionable of bodies once more. And heaven strike us down if we forget the rise of the Burberry check, proof of the allure of the geometric print beyond the usually quarantine-like confines of the fash pack.

The point of these clothes is, quite simply, optical pleasure. There is a cheeky joy to be had when you look down at your lap on a grey afternoon and are greeted with a colourful explosion of patterns and shapes, like popping into a museum or seeing a favourite film on a rainy day.

Also, there is something rather luxurious about taking such an attention-grabbing fashion risk purely for your own aesthetic enjoyment. It is a cocking a sartorial snook at the style police who hide timorously behind black, grey and dark blue, raising their eyebrows at those who resist that sort of tyranny. No one would suggest wearing nothing but patterned clothing - far too headache-inducing for one closet to handle. But it is worth letting your pattern inhibitions slip occasionally, for these prints are charming.

webTitle: Obituary: Lionel Rogosin

fields.headline: Lionel Rogosin
fields.standfirst: His films exposed racism and injustice in South Africa and the US
fields.trailText: Lionel Rogosin, who has died aged 76, became something of a hero of the anti-apartheid movement with the release of his 1959 semi-documentary, Come Back Africa
fields.body:
It is difficult to describe the impact Lionel Rogosin's semi-documentary, Come Back Africa (pictured, 1959), had on a young South African freshly arrived in London. Having been brought up in the restrictive atmosphere of the racist regime, I had never been able to see a film in which blacks and whites interacted, let alone one that was critical of apartheid.

I have not seen it for more than 20 years, but I still vividly remember almost every frame, the use of the negro spiritual, Go Down, Moses, on the soundtrack, with its refrain of "Let my people go", and the black hero's agonised cry of angry frustration with which the picture ends.

Rogosin, who has died aged 76, became something of a hero of the anti-apartheid movement. The title, Come Back Africa, was a translation of an African National Congress slogan, and it was one of the first films to look unblinkingly at the degradation of the apartheid system. Shot clandestinely in South Africa, it told of a poverty-stricken Zulu farmer who leaves his village to seek work in Johannesburg, but is unjustly sacked from various jobs.

The film has various other strands, such as a white man (played by Patrick Magee) suddenly finding himself classified as black, a group of black intellectuals (among whom is Miriam Makeba) drinking illegally in a shebeen and, most powerfully, a white ambulance refusing to take in a dying black victim of a car accident.

Rogosin's first film was On The Bowery (1954), a portrait of the tramps and drunks who live in the heart of affluent Manhattan, some of it acted by the real inhabitants of the downtown area. The weakest parts of both the South African film and On The Bowery were the rather stilted staged incidents; the strongest were the starkly realistic pictures of social alienation.

Both films were made on location under difficult circumstances, before the introduction of 16mm ciné and sound equipment, and were forerunners of direct cinema of the early 1960s.

Born in New York, the son of an industrialist, Rogosin was brought up in luxury on Long Island, yet he became aware of the inequalities in American society at an early age. He went to study chemistry at Yale, interrupting his education to serve as an engineer in the US navy during the second world war. Afterwards, he returned to Yale to complete his degree, and worked as a chemical engineer before deciding to make films.

Rogosin received immediate recognition when On The Bowery won the grand prize for documentary film at the Venice film festival, and was nominated for an Oscar. After Come Back Africa, he devoted much of his time to running the groundbreaking Bleecker Street cinema, in Greenwich Village, which he opened in 1962. It was at this art house that adventurous filmgoers would seek out the experimental and the radical.

These audiences, who had rejected the social status quo of racial segregation and sexual repression, also demanded that movies incorporate new forms of expression to parallel those being created in painting, like abstract expressionism and pop art, and in literature, with the beat poets. As a creative film exhibitor, Rogosin provided a venue where such work, American and foreign, could be seen.

Two years earlier, he had been one of the signatories of the New American Cinema Group manifesto, which claimed that "the official cinema of the world has run out of breath. It is morally corrupt, aesthetically obsolete, thematically superficial, and temperamentally boring."

In the mid-1960s, Rogosin returned to film-making with an anti-war documentary, ironically titled Good Times, Wonderful Times (1966). He then concerned himself with the growing civil rights movement, particularly the move for racial equality in the United States, with Black Roots (1970), Black Fantasy (1972) and Wood Cutters Of The Deep South (1973). Last year, he returned to South Africa in the television documentary, The Long Walk Of Nelson Mandela.

The film included interviews with many anti-apartheid revolutionaries, but it could never equal the powerful cry for liberty that resounded through Come Back Africa, decades before the abolition of apartheid.

Rogosin is survived by two sons and three grandchildren.

 Lionel Rogosin, film director, born 1924; died December 8 2000

webTitle: TalkSport  licence renewed

fields.headline: TalkSport  licence renewed
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group has had its TalkSport licence renewed for a further eight years, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group has had its national analogue licence, TalkSport, renewed for a further eight years.

Under the terms of the deal, the Wireless Group's annual cash bid payment to the Radio Authority has been slashed from £4.3m to £0.5m.

The group, formed out of the old Talk Radio and headed by the former Sun editor, is the fourth largest national commercial radio group, following the acquisitions last year of the Radio Partnership and Independent Radio Group.

Mr MacKenzie said the renewed licence would allow TalkSport "to continue to invest in its future and move faster towards break-even".

A spokesman for TalkSport said the dramatic reduction in the payment to the Radio Authority was designed to give TalkSport to have "greater financial flexibility" over the period of the licence.

He said that the two other national commercial licence holder, Virgin Radio and Classic FM, had also had their payments slashed.

webTitle: Leader: Planning permission

fields.headline: Planners in limbo
fields.standfirst: This judgment will rock the system
fields.trailText: In the three months to October, English districts received 137,000 applications for planning permission. The majority went through on the nod - uncontroversial, except perhaps to neighbours
fields.body:
In the three months to October, English districts received 137,000 applications for planning permission. The majority went through on the nod - uncontroversial, except perhaps to neighbours. Appeals will be lodged against a handful of refusals of permission and inspectors will then judge them in the light of guidance on land use and development issued by their civil service colleagues in the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR). Some may be "called in" by the DETR; environment secretary John Prescott has the power to overrule his own inspectors. This system of overlapping judgments has been in existence since 1947. England's topography, green belts, second-rate city office blocks and all, are its products.

But as a system it offends against the Human Rights Act. Environment secretaries are judge and jury in their own cause; DETR inspectors are not independent. A high court judgment this week saying developers were denied a fair hearing under the act was not unexpected. Even if it is overturned on appeal, it has highlighted anomalies in the relationship of government and citizen that will surely require substantial changes in planning law.

The rewrite is not going to be easy. The very point of planning is to impose on the free market a collective judgment about what development should take place and where: planning is unavoidably "political". The trick will be to separate the ministers and councillors who make planning policy from judgments about whether a specific application from a developer contravenes the general guidelines. That suggests the need for a gilt-edged inspectorate with the same kind of authority as the courts of law. Which points to the conundrum at the heart of this argument. How can judges or inspectors - who must at some point account for themselves in public to elected politicians - be both accountable and autonomous?
fields.bodyText: In the three months to October, English districts received 137,000 applications for planning permission. The majority went through on the nod - uncontroversial, except perhaps to neighbours. Appeals will be lodged against a handful of refusals of permission and inspectors will then judge them in the light of guidance on land use and development issued by their civil service colleagues in the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR). Some may be "called in" by the DETR; environment secretary John Prescott has the power to overrule his own inspectors. This system of overlapping judgments has been in existence since 1947. England's topography, green belts, second-rate city office blocks and all, are its products. But as a system it offends against the Human Rights Act. Environment secretaries are judge and jury in their own cause; DETR inspectors are not independent. A high court judgment this week saying developers were denied a fair hearing under the act was not unexpected. Even if it is overturned on appeal, it has highlighted anomalies in the relationship of government and citizen that will surely require substantial changes in planning law. The rewrite is not going to be easy. The very point of planning is to impose on the free market a collective judgment about what development should take place and where: planning is unavoidably "political". The trick will be to separate the ministers and councillors who make planning policy from judgments about whether a specific application from a developer contravenes the general guidelines. That suggests the need for a gilt-edged inspectorate with the same kind of authority as the courts of law. Which points to the conundrum at the heart of this argument. How can judges or inspectors - who must at some point account for themselves in public to elected politicians - be both accountable and autonomous?

webTitle: Volunteers get a makeover

fields.headline: Volunteers get a makeover
fields.standfirst: The government and the voluntary sector have realised that volunteering has the potential to be a powerful force for social change - but the public are still unsure about how to donate their time, writes Joe Saxton
fields.trailText: The government and the voluntary sector have realised that volunteering has the potential to be a powerful force for social change - but the public are still unsure about how to donate their time, writes Joe Saxton
fields.body:
Volunteering is in the process having a makeover. Ask most people what their image of a volunteer is and the most common stereotype that emerges is an elderly woman, fairly well-off, behind the till at the local charity shop, and motivated as much by companionship as by the cause that the shop supports.

For the two years I worked in a charity shop, the biggest revolt came when the local shops organiser insisted that all volunteers wear badges, so the public knew who was serving them.

The current shift in the image of volunteering is because both the government and the voluntary sector have realised that volunteering has the potential to be a much more powerful force for social change than the stereotypes suggest and there is a raft of recent initiatives to prove it.

The Timebank appeal through the BBC has tried to persuade people to volunteer, the Active Community Unit has given a grant to put volunteering information on the web. And the excellent millennium awards for individuals have tried to boost grassroots community development by fostering community social entrepreneurs.

All these projects are trying to change the image of volunteering to give it a wider appeal, particularly to young people and those with specific skills.

At the heart of promoting volunteering is the issue of motivation. People give time for very different reasons from giving money: volunteers may want to build their skills and experience, reduce their own isolation or loneliness, do something about their local community or fill their time in retirement. So many people who volunteer are primarily motivated to find the right volunteering opportunity, while the cause is secondary. In contrast for donors, the cause is all important.

For this reason, volunteering should be easier to promote at the local level since many opportunities, from a breadth of causes, can be handled locally by a single agency. However, recent research by the Future Foundation suggests that the public is unclear about who to talk to about volunteering.

As part of our regular survey on the public's awareness of charities, we asked what organisation would people approach if they wanted to volunteer locally. No organisation was mentioned by more than 10% of people and when we suggested a list of methods of finding information, the most popular responses were the local library, the local charity shop and the local CAB. Fifteen percent even thought that Voluntary Services Overseas (VSO) might be worth contacting. None of the recent initiatives was mentioned by more than a handful of those polled.

In other words, for all of the recent energy rightly being put into volunteering, there is still little clarity in the public's mind about who they should be contacting if they wanted to volunteer. And having rung my local library, they told me they had a list of local charities I could ring!

As the make-over of volunteering progresses it is clear that if national initiatives are to become local action, the public need to be much better informed about who they should talk to if they want to volunteer, and the local agencies need to be better geared up to help.

 Joe Saxton is head of voluntary services for the Future Foundation
