webTitle: Whitbread celebs oust 'real critics'

fields.headline: Whitbread celebs oust 'real critics'
fields.trailText: Fascination with celebrity reached a new level yesterday as judges were announced for the finals of Britain's richest prize for general writing, the Whitbread book award.
fields.body:
Fascination with celebrity reached a new level yesterday as judges were announced for the finals of Britain's richest prize for general writing, the Whitbread book award.

For the first time in the 30 years of the awards, half the judges are showbiz, television or sporting faces rather than authors or critics. Last year Whitbread drew criticism over the choice of one judge, the actress and model Jerry Hall.

This year's five celebrities, led by Evita lyricist Sir Tim Rice, also include the Olympic gold medal oarsman Matthew Pinsent, breakfast TV presenter Penny Smith, TV racing presenter Clare Balding, and stand-up comic Alan Davies.

Alongside five writers, they will pick the winners of the £3,500 Whitbread children's book of the year prize and the climactic overall book of the year prize, worth £22,500. The results will be announced on January 23.

In previous years, up to four out of nine judges have been celebrities. These are chosen to maximise ratings for the awards ceremony, which is shown live on BBC2.

But for this 30th anniversary year, the Whitbread organisers decided to have 10 judges, and to give the extra place to a personality rather than a writer.

Yesterday Sunita Rappai, spokeswoman for the organisers, said: "There is no set limit on who we should have as judges. The five celebrities are all people who are passionate about books. We do not have anyone who doesn't have a keen desire to read the eight books.

"We would reinforce the message that the Whitbread is not a literary prize in any way. It is about good books that are enjoyed. These judges provide a very useful ordinary perspective".

Last year's organisers were accused of diminishing the prize for picking Ms Hall, Mick Jagger's ex-wife. The administrator of the rival Booker prize, Martyn Goff, said at the time: "Putting celebrities on the panel never works. These people speak a different language. When the other judges talk about form and narrative dialogue, they are left in the dark."

Yesterday, Mr Goff was unavailable for comment. Last year he promised that the Booker prize, which is broadcast live on Channel 4, would not follow the same route. This year's five Booker judges included one celebrity, the TV presenter Mariella Frostrup.

The five authors on this year's Whitbread panel are Sally Beauman, Minette Walters, Michael Holroyd, Jo Shapcott, and Michael Morpurgo.

webTitle: Top woman manager quits NHS

fields.headline: Top woman manager quits NHS
fields.trailText: One of the most senior women managers in the NHS has announced she is to quit to become director of aid charity Oxfam, less than a fortnight after taking up a top health service post. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
One of the most senior women managers in the NHS has announced she is to quit to become director of aid charity Oxfam, less than a fortnight after taking up a top health service post.

Barbara Stocking, who will join Oxfam on a £75,000-a-year contract, was appointed as director of the NHS modernisation agency only in November, and took up her post on December 1.

Her departure, scheduled for mid 2001, leaves the NHS without one of its most experienced, respected and high-profile female managers.

It will inevitably lead to concerns that the so-called "glass ceiling" is still intact in the NHS - most of whose top managers are male - and is failing to hang on to its top women managers.

At the time of her appointment Ms Stocking said part of her role at the modernisation agency was to develop a new NHS leadership centre that would "make the most of our key resource - NHS staff".

The modernisation agency was set up by health secretary Alan Milburn to spearhead the introduction of good practice across the health service and implement the NHS plan.

Ironically, her appointment to the agency was accompanied by criticisms that the NHS had breached equal opportunities policies by failing to advertise the job.

Ms Stocking, who was previously south east regional director for the NHS, was the only woman seen as a contender for the NHS chief executive job, which went to Nigel Crisp in October.

Only one woman made the top 15 most powerful people in the NHS Power 90 list published by societytheguardian.com - Royal College of Nursing general secretary Christine Hancock, who is quitting her job in the new year.

However, Ms Stocking was replaced on a temporary basis at NHS south east region by a woman - Ruth Carnall, chief executive of east Kent health authority.

Ms Stocking will manage a £90m budget and a worldwide staff of 2,600 at Oxfam, where she replaces David Bryer, who is leaving after 10 years.

It is unclear whether Ms Stocking, who was unavailable for comment, knew she may be leaving for Oxfam when she agreed to take up the modernisation agency job "for an initial period of six months".

webTitle: BBC plans youth news show for BBC3

fields.headline: BBC plans youth news show for BBC3
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
9.30am: The BBC is set to launch a flagship TV news bulletin for teenagers and 20-somethings, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC is set to launch a flagship TV news bulletin for teenagers and 20-somethings.

BBC News is poring over plans to put BBC Choice's successful youth magazine programme, Liquid News, at the centre of its strategy for the new digital youth channel, BBC3.

The programme would be transformed into a regular news bulletin based largely around showbusiness and entertainment.

Liquid News, which was launched earlier this year under the auspices of executive producer Chris Wilson, focuses solely on entertainment, and has been a minor hit with younger viewers.

It covers all the mainstream showbiz stories such as today's news about a man convicted of stalking Gwyneth Paltrow.

Mr Wilson is working on a project to build on the programme's success by creating a new bulletin aimed at the younger generation.

BBC3 will face the challenge of attracting enough younger viewers to justify its licence fee funding, but also adhering to the BBC's public service charter.

A BBC News insider said: "Young people are not interested in news unless it's Liam Gallagher. There will have to be a lot of entertainment news at the heart of BBC3 to make it compelling for the audience."

But a BBC Choice spokeswoman stressed that no details about the programming strategy for BBC3 had been finalised. She added that the BBC's new digital channels were still undergoing public consultation.

But the move could herald a concerted effort on the part of the corporation to attract new showbusiness reporting talent, an area that has not been a central focus until now.

webTitle: Sharp decline in social trust

fields.headline: Sharp decline in social trust
fields.standfirst: Seven out of 10 British people don't trust others, says a new survey. But those involved in voluntary activities are twice as likely to be trusting, reports Nicola Hill
fields.trailText: Seven out of 10 British people don't trust others, says a new survey. But those involved in voluntary activities are twice as likely to be trusting, reports Nicola Hill.
fields.body:
Seven out of 10 British people don't trust others, according to a survey released yesterday. This is the sharpest decline in social trust since the European Values Survey (EVS) began in 1959. Ten years ago 44% said that most people could be trusted - by 1995 this figure had dropped to 30% and it has remained at this level for the last five years.

The UK study of the EVS conducted by the London School of Economics found, however, that those involved in clubs, societies or some other voluntary sector organisation are nearly twice as likely to trust others compared with those who are not involved in any kind of voluntary activity.

People who do participate in voluntary activity are likely to be of a higher socio-economic status, be educated to a higher level and attend church regularly.

Chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) Stuart Etherington, said: "This survey demonstrates a clear link between involvement in one's community and an increased level of trust and general social satisfaction."

However, he added: "It is worrying that we could be heading towards a modern Britain of sceptics who feel insular and removed from their communities."

Young people are the most mistrustful. More than three-quarters of people under the age of 30 said they did not feel they could trust others.

Tim Burke, spokesperson at the National Youth Agency, said: "Too often young people aren't given a sense that they can have a stake in society, but when communities do accept them there are benefits all round."

The figures show that involvement in voluntary sector clubs and societies has not altered much over the past decade. Fifty per cent of the population claimed to participate in associations or other voluntary activities.

The public is also losing confidence in a range of institutions. Since 1981, levels of confidence in the police force, church and legal system have fallen. However, two-thirds of people had confidence in community groups and charities. The armed forces enjoy the highest levels of public confidence.

webTitle: Arnie denies getting too touchy-feely

fields.headline: Arnie denies getting too touchy-feely
fields.trailText: Arnold Schwarzenegger refutes claims that he has behaved improperly towards female interviewers during his visit to Britain to promote The 6th Day
fields.body:
As reported in an earlier story, The 6th Day star Arnold Schwarzenegger stands accused of reminding female interviewers in London of one of his earliest movies: Predator. The teutonic action hero allegedly became 'frisky' with a gaggle of British TV presenters this week, in consecutive interviews to promote his new film.

According to reports in The Sun, Schwarzenegger grasped Boddington's model turned TV starlet Melanie Sykes around the waist. "Get your hands off me - I'm scared," she is reported to have said, whereupon the married father-of-four made a lunge for Sykes' breast instead. The further accusations revolve around interviews the actor had with presenters Denise van Outen and Anna Richardson, also conducted in London's Dorchester hotel.

Richardson told the tabloid: "I wanted to say, 'You dirty bastard'. But you can't tell a powerful man like him to f*** off... He kept saying how fantastic I looked and staring at my [breasts]." At the end of the interview, claims Richardson, "He pulled me onto his knee, saying 'I really want to know if your breasts are real'"

Spokesperson for Schwarzenegger, Jill Eisenstadt, flatly denies the charges. "I wasn't there. I don't know this woman [Sykes]. But he's always had a great relationship with journalists, and he's always acted appropriately... I just don't believe it for a second." Eisenstadt pointed out that Richardson's complaint was filed only after she was barred by Columbia Tri-Star from future interviews because of alleged improper behaviour during her meeting with Schwarzenegger.

Schwarzenegger's lawyer Marty Singer agrees. He says Richardson: "Is the one who basically came on in a very provocative manner to Mr Schwarzenegger... Asking him to basically check her out. She left in a very happy mood. It's a case of three people getting their name in the paper ... Quite frankly, my client didn't do anything inappropriate."

webTitle: Losses deepen at West 175

fields.headline: Losses deepen at West 175
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The company behind Johnny Vaughan's new sitcom today blamed increased losses on investment in new TV and internet ventures. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The TV and media company behind Johnny Vaughan's new sitcom today reported increased losses, blaming heavy investment in new shows and internet ventures.

West 175, which secured a deal with independent TV production company Union Pictures earlier this year, said that losses had risen from £1.4m to £2.2m for the first six months of the year.

Union Pictures, which has been renamed Union 175 as part of its joint venture with West 175, is responsible for a string of hits on UK television, including the BBC adaptation of Iain Banks's the Crow Road and the long-running MasterChef series.

Next year, it will unveil 'Orrible, a BBC2 sitcom starring and written by Big Breakfast host Vaughan.

Rohan Courtney, West 175 chairman, said that the Union 175 venture should break even in its first year, with 10 projects in development.

"The stock market has shown confidence in West 175 when we raised £11m in August. We do not intend to disappoint," he said.

Mr Courtney added that his company will start film production activities in the UK and the US, where it runs a successful version of MasterChef.

webTitle: Desmond sells the Express websites for £1

fields.headline: Desmond sells the Express websites for £1
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Richard Desmond's fierce attack on costs at Express Newspapers continued yesterday when he sold the internet assets for a nominal sum, report David Teather and Julia Finch.
fields.body:
Richard Desmond's fierce attack on costs at Express Newspapers continued yesterday when he sold the internet assets for a nominal sum.

Mr Desmond is understood to have been shocked at the rate the four websites were burning cash and had put their 50 staff on notice of redundancy. The sites were said to be costing £7m to £8m a year to run.

The sites have been sold for £1 to stockbroker Seymour Pierce which acts as an adviser to Mr Desmond. The company will attempt to sell them as going concerns but otherwise will put the online operations into "hibernation" for sale at a later stage.

Whether some staff will keep their jobs depends upon the ability to make a quick sale. "Seymour Pierce sees some value in the sites," said one source.

The four websites included in the deal are ie Express.co.uk, Sportlive.co.uk, Companyleader.com and Allaboutparents.com - a favoured project of Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott.

Seymour Pierce has reached a content supply agreement with Mr Desmond for Express.co.uk, essentially an online version of the newspaper.

Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell acquired the newspaper group for £125m last month and has since subjected the titles to rigorous examination.

Meanwhile United News and Media, which sold Express Newspapers to Mr Desmond, yesterday underlined the dramatic change in sentiment towards the dot.com sector.

United announced that it was to cut back its internet investment plans to £180m. In February it said it would pour £370m into new media.

United's decision to slash the resources it had planned to sink into online activities follows a similar move last month by magazine publisher Emap, which is halving its planned investment to £120m.

United also announced it is to return £1.25bn to share holders in one of the biggest ever share buy-back programmes.

As expected, United has opted to take cash rather than shares from Granada Media in payment for the TV business it sold to them in July. At the time of the deal, United took £500m in cash and had the option to take the rest of the £1.75bn purchase price in shares. Granada's shares have tumbled from 585p to 438p since then. The buy-back will start in February, after United publishes its full-year results, which the group said would be in line with expectations.

United has done an about turn in strategy this year. Chief executive Lord Hollick had intended to dominate commercial terrestrial TV by merging with Carlton, but his plans were scuppered by the competition authorities and United decided instead to abandon the TV business altogether.

Last month it sold the Express, and also plans to dispose of its internet service provider and portal business, LineOne, a joint venture with BT. Yesterday the group said discussions were under way with a number of interested parties and hinted that it would soon ditch its remaining business-to-consumer internet operations - which include the Megastar and Dotmusic sites as well as youth broadcaster Rapture.

Mr Desmond is understood to have been shocked at the rate the four websites were burning cash and had put their 50 staff on notice of redundancy. The sites were said to be costing £7m to £8m a year to run. The sites have been sold for £1 to stockbroker Seymour Pierce which acts as an adviser to Mr Desmond. The company will attempt to sell them as going concerns but otherwise will put the online operations into "hibernation" for sale at a later stage. Whether some staff will keep their jobs depends upon the ability to make a quick sale. "Seymour Pierce sees some value in the sites," said one source. The four websites included in the deal are ie Express.co.uk, Sportlive.co.uk, Companyleader.com and Allaboutparents.com - a favoured project of Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott. Seymour Pierce has reached a content supply agreement with Mr Desmond for Express.co.uk, essentially an online version of the newspaper. Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell acquired the newspaper group for £125m last month and has since subjected the titles to rigorous examination. Meanwhile United News and Media, which sold Express Newspapers to Mr Desmond, yesterday underlined the dramatic change in sentiment towards the dot.com sector. United announced that it was to cut back its internet investment plans to £180m. In February it said it would pour £370m into new media. United's decision to slash the resources it had planned to sink into online activities follows a similar move last month by magazine publisher Emap, which is halving its planned investment to £120m. United also announced it is to return £1.25bn to share holders in one of the biggest ever share buy-back programmes. As expected, United has opted to take cash rather than shares from Granada Media in payment for the TV business it sold to them in July. At the time of the deal, United took £500m in cash and had the option to take the rest of the £1.75bn purchase price in shares. Granada's shares have tumbled from 585p to 438p since then. The buy-back will start in February, after United publishes its full-year results, which the group said would be in line with expectations. United has done an about turn in strategy this year. Chief executive Lord Hollick had intended to dominate commercial terrestrial TV by merging with Carlton, but his plans were scuppered by the competition authorities and United decided instead to abandon the TV business altogether. Last month it sold the Express, and also plans to dispose of its internet service provider and portal business, LineOne, a joint venture with BT. webTitle: Study raises doubts over consent in infant medical trials

fields.headline: Study raises doubts over consent in infant medical trials
fields.trailText: Researchers today raise new concerns about the way in which parents are asked for permission for their babies to be used in medical trials.
fields.body:
Researchers today raise new concerns about the way in which parents are asked for permission for their babies to be used in medical trials.

A cross-Europe study suggests shortcomings in about seven in 10 cases, including researchers seeking consent when mothers were still overwhelmed by the birth, failing to give parents sufficient information or not telling them they could change their minds and withdraw their babies.

It also found that consent was three times more likely to be "compromised" when the research was considered urgent.

Organisers of the survey, which included parents of 200 children and 107 researchers in nine countries, including Britain, call for medical staff to be given better guidance on the legal and ethical constraints governing consent. They also say parents should be given oral and written information at the same time and be made aware that research projects have been examined by ethics committees.

The paper, in the Lancet medical journal, says many parents gave consent thinking their own child would benefit, that it would help other infants or at least their own child would not suffer distress. Those who refused sometimes feared risk to their children, distrusted researchers, were too shocked or unable to decide, or thought follow-up procedures were inconvenient.

Su Mason, from Leeds University, one of the leaders of the EU-funded research, said it was difficult to find a solution, such as seeking consent when parents were less stressed. There had been cases when researchers considered approaching mothers before they gave birth.

"The problem with that is you may be dealing with a condition that affects one in a 1,000 babies and you would be worrying another 999 about possible problems with the birth."

Parents in the survey overwhelmingly valued European requirements for consent. One said: "The medical environment cannot do what it wants."

Doctors were sometimes less convinced. One said: "In my opinion, it is not an informed consent but it is enlightened information which we ask them to sign."

The study coincided with advice from the British Medical Association in a book, Consents, Rights and Choices in Healthcare for Children and Young People. It says the views of children about their own health and treatment are extremely important. "On the whole we are against the withholding of information if the child seems willing to know it, even where parents request secrecy."

webTitle: Letters: Battle lines drawn for the clone vote

fields.headline: Battle lines drawn for the clone vote
fields.trailText: We are not fearful of defeat (Row over timing of clone vote, December 14). In fact, we are hopeful MPs will recognise the real health benefits of embryonic stem cell research
fields.body:
We are not fearful of defeat (Row over timing of clone vote, December 14). In fact, we are hopeful MPs will recognise the real health benefits of embryonic stem cell research. In today's debate and free vote on the issue, we urge MPs to not only take account of the position of doctors and scientists, but also to take seriously the views of people with diseases such as Parkinson's, and their families.

Politicians should listen to Emma Bennion, for example, who has lived with Parkinson's for 12 years since being diagnosed when she was just 38. "Stem cell research offers hope for a cure, and a positive vote in parliament will give encouragement to everyone living with health problems," she says.

There are tens of thousands like Emma - living with diabetes, cancer, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis and other devastating diseases - and MPs should be mindful that these patients will expect their help. For children with these diseases in particular, stem cell research provides real hope for a healthy and happy future.

Dr Howard Scarffe
Medical director, Wellcome Trust
h.scarffe@wellcome.ac.uk
Dr Michaael Wilks
BMA medical ethics committee
Robert Meadowcroft
Parkinson's Disease Society

The regulations the government seeks to implement will increase experiments using embryos by allowing research related to: increasing knowledge about the creation and development of embryos; increasing knowledge about disease; and enabling any such knowledge to be applied in developing treatments for disease.

Introducing the additional categories will, in practice, also allow "therapeutic cloning". In theory this has enormous potential medical benefits long term, particularly for Parkinson's disease sufferers and people with spinal injuries. However, important ethical and safety issues are at stake here and genuine public debate is essential. Further, there is a non-controversial and ethical alternative in the potential for using stem cells from adults.

The government's proposals are not a "simple" extension to the 1990 Act but take us across a new ethical and moral boundary.

Dr Andrew Fergusson,
Centre for Bioethics and Public Policy

webTitle: PPL moves from Dolly to cows

fields.headline: PPL moves from Dolly to cows
fields.trailText: Biotech company PPL Therapeutics - which created Dolly, the world's first cloned sheep - is diversifying into genetically modified cows through a tie-up with a New Zealand research institute.
fields.body:
Biotech company PPL Therapeutics - which created Dolly, the world's first cloned sheep - is diversifying into genetically modified cows through a tie-up with a New Zealand research institute.

The company has agreed a joint venture with Celentis, a company backed by the New Zealand government, to clone cows which secrete a human protein in their milk for the treatment of multiple sclerosis.

If successful, research will move on to producing the human serum albumin in cows' milk to treat burns, and adapting cattle to produce nutritional products to aid digestion.

PPL's chief executive, Ron James, said the company was working outside Europe to avoid the risk of mad cow disease: "New Zealand is a good place to have your cattle. We chose to work in New Zealand and America some time ago because we could see problems looming with BSE."

PPL has dabbled with cattle before - the company's US subsidiary produced Mr Jefferson, its first cloned cow, in 1998. However, its in-house work on cows stopped as part of a cost-cutting drive last year.

Under the terms of yesterday's deal, Celentis will fund research on the first three products, taking advantage of PPL's patented cloning techniques. Beyond that, the cost will be split equally between the two partners.

Analysts said the agreement made sense for cash-strapped PPL. Julie Simmonds of stockbroker Beeson Gregory said: "It's a way of them expanding their pipeline without having too much to worry about financially."

The Edinburgh-based company is one of the world leaders in cloning. It has exclusive rights to genetics technology developed by the Roslin Institute.

The company struck a deal with the German firm Bayer this year to commercialise a cystic fibrosis treatment produced in sheep's milk. PPL is also attempting to grow human hearts and lungs in pigs, to satisfy demand from transplant patients.

 PPL's shares edged up 1p to 206.5p.

webTitle: Overfishing brings more bad news to struggling ports

fields.headline: Overfishing brings more bad news to struggling ports
fields.standfirst: Special report: the fish crisis
fields.trailText: There used to be 2m tonnes of mackerel swimming in the North Sea, and even more herring. For centuries they had been supporting communities all along the east coast.
fields.body:
There used to be 2m tonnes of mackerel swimming in the North Sea, and even more herring. For centuries they had been supporting communities all along the east coast.

Annual catches of 1m tonnes were not unknown but they gradually dropped to nothing. Mackerel are now commercially extinct, in order words, there are so few it is not worth fishermen leaving port. Herring are recovering after numbers slumped so low in 1995 that fishing for them was banned.

Cod, haddock, hake, plaice and prawns are going the same way. The sea has lost its former abundance and some scientists believe the end looms for almost all commercial fishing.

Not that it has to be that way. Two accidental experiments of fish conservation - the first and second world wars when no fishing effort was made in the North Sea - yielded recoveries of all species in the five years after hostilities ended.

Cod landings were more than 300,000 tonnes a year in the 1950s and 60s. This year British fishermen were restricted in their catches to 34,262 tonnes. Up to November 9 this year, boats had only managed to catch 23,045 tonnes.

All those extra fish in the post war years were caught without the sophisticated equipment essential on the modern fleet. There can only be one explanation, there are no longer any more cod to catch - 95% of supplies are already imported.

The reasons are obvious. For the last 20 years smaller and smaller cod have been taken. Instead of 5ft monsters, cod are sometimes only inches long - 80% of those caught are below breeding age.

It is not that fisherman or politicians have been unaware of this impending disaster. Scientists from the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, employed by the European commission, have been issuing increasingly dire warnings of the imminent end of the stock.

They pointed to the fate of the richest cod fishery in the world - the Grand Banks off Newfoundland which collapsed eight years ago and has never recovered. So why, with the spectre of what happened in Newfoundland, and past experience of the disappearing mackerel and herring, have the commission failed to act?

Each year officials have taken the scientists' advice and watered it down, passing it on to the ministers of EU states who have compromised still further. Instead of smaller quotas which would allow stocks to recover, fishermen bullied their representatives to allow larger allocations to save the industry from collapse. Using ever more sophisticated equipment and faster, more efficient boats the fishermen caught more and more of the remaining stock disguising the fact that total numbers of each species were going down.

This year the catastrophe has finally caught up with the industry. It is not just cod that have become depleted. Plaice, haddock, whiting, prawns, sole and hake are in steep decline. Partly this is because as one species has become depleted fishing effort has concentrated on others. Haddock particularly are in danger because there are less cod.

There are signs that the industry is coming to its senses. For years fishermen and conservation organisations were at loggerheads. Last year for the first time parts of the Irish Sea were closed for 10 weeks in the areas known to be used by cod for spawning. This year the closure will happen again and when the boats are finally allowed out they will use larger mesh and have escape hatches for smaller fish. Its success will not be known until the cod reach the breeding age of three years. The same proposals are being discussed for the North Sea and the West coast of Scotland.

Not that all fisherman have been won over. One of the greatest scandals of the last 20 years has been the practice of discarding undersized dead fish back into the sea and catching bigger ones to get full value out of the quota system.

This year French and Spanish fisherman were accused of not taking proper conservation measures to release undersized hake. This has led to the demand by the commission of a 74% cut in quota to barely 6,000 tonnes of hake. Many fishermen face bankruptcy as a result.

This downward spiral has led to dishonesty. Promises to take fishing boats out of the industry have not been met. Blind eyes have been turned to "black fish" - extra landings not part of the quota system.

But as ministers meet in Brussels it is the moment of truth. Euan Dunn, senior marine officer for the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, said "For too long ministers have failed miserably to stem the relentless decline of stocks. It would be unforgivable if they did not bite the bullet this time - but it may already be too late for North Sea cod."

webTitle: John Vidal on how Britain lost its favourite fish

fields.headline: Dead in the water
fields.standfirst:
Britain has always had a special relationship with cod - we eat a third of the world's total catch. But as EU ministers cut our quotas once again, the industry is heading towards crisis point. John Vidal goes to Grimsby to meet the men who will suffer most

Special report: Global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: Britain has always had a special relationship with cod - we eat a third of the world's total catch. But as EU ministers cut our quotas once again, the industry is heading towards crisis point. John Vidal goes to Grimsby to meet the men who will suffer most.
fields.body:
On a calm day you can smell the cod in Grimsby three miles inland. Not now. A gale force nine is ripping through the streets of the huge old Victorian docks. It lashes the shiny new food processing works, the semi-derelict engineering factories, the chandlers, the ropeworks, landing bays, paintshops and repair yards. It whips up the litter, bends the grass horizontal on the desolate wasteground, and whistles through the broken windows of the old ice works.

There's no one out to sea and the water is turbulent even in the main harbour where the Beverley, Soraya, Rachel, Aisha and 30 other small fishing vessels, together with two deep sea trawlers, are lashed together and to the docksides. They are vulnerable and mainly venerable, the remnants of the 300-strong North Sea fishing fleet that was based in Grimsby only 30 years ago.

In this foul weather and confused political climate they are going nowhere. But some time later tonight, if the forecast is better, Billy "the Fish" Hardie, skipper of the 50-tonne Stormy C, will call his three crewmen - Dave, Basher and Gilly - and set off on the 90-mile journey towards the Netherlands and the shoals of cod. The trip will take 20 hours and they will be away for up to eight days.

Hardie will concentrate on the old wrecks where cod congregate at this time of year. He will think like a fish. When the tide is coming in he will drop his gill nets on the side of the wrecks where he knows the cod will be sheltering and feeding off the plankton and smaller fish; and then, when the tide flows out, like them, he will be round the other side. With skill and luck he will avoid the other fishermen and follow the cod's mysterious migrations across the Brown Banks, the Borkum Flats, the Cleaver Bank, the Dogger Bank and the Clay Deep.

But right now Hardie is sitting in a Grimsby bowling club feeling as furious as the weather. European scientists have declared that cod stocks in the North Sea and to the west of Scotland are collapsing because of overfishing. The fish that the British have adopted as part of their culture for more than 100 years are said by conservation groups, such as the World Wildlife Fund, to be so rare that in places they are officially an endangered species.

The North Sea, marine scientists say, is in danger of going the way of the Newfoundland Grand Banks. In the 80s it was the world's most fished ground - so much so that fish virtually disappeared and stocks have never fully recovered.

Hardie knows that he and other fishermen in Britain are about to be gutted. They have had plenty of warning. Early this morning EU fisheries ministers meeting in Brussels imposed savage cuts on all EU cod and other North Sea fishing quotas. The cuts will affect the British most. Coming on top of similar cuts in the past two years, it means the virtual end of cod fishing in European waters.

Instead of the Stormy C being allowed to catch 170-plus tonnes of cod next year, Hardie will be limited to just a few tonnes a month - the amount, in better times, he could have caught in a few weeks.

Thirty months ago, Hardie invested almost £250,000 in the Stormy C, its licences and quotas. Today he regrets it. One of the most successful fishermen of his generation, he faces bankruptcy - not for bad management, lack of salesmanship or marketing, nor because subsidies are being phased out, but, he says, simply because he has done exactly what the scientists, the governments and all the other "experts" have told him was necessary to save the cod.

Britain now has 15,000 full-time fishermen, with the industry concentrated in northern Scotland. It has 435 deep sea trawlers and 1,782 inshore vessels such as Hardie's. Most are owned by families, and small groups of friends or partners, and they are the ones who will be hit hardest by the EU cuts.

Cod is their biggest and most valuable catch. The British have a bizarre love affair with the fish. We eat a third of the world's catch and are desperately loyal to the species, unlike the Americans or continental Europeans who are more than happy to eat other fish. We love its moistness and pale taste. But we may not love what is going to happen in the next few months.

Few fishermen, it is widely reckoned, will survive the quota cuts if they last more than a few years. They do not have the option, like farmers, of switching "crops". A cod boat is set up for a certain sort of fishing and would cost tens of thousands of pounds to convert to catching, say, mackerel. Nor can they sell up because no one will buy a boat in such hard times. So far, neither the government nor the EU is offering to pay them not to fish - like they pay farmers to set aside land - or to decommission them completely. Their lifetime investments are worth little and their bank managers are already writing letters.

"It's a ruddy awful mess," Hardie says. "I'm not being greedy and I understand the need for conservation, but I need 170-odd tonnes to make this business viable. This isn't a hobby. If it goes on like this I predict that 70% or more of the entire British fishing fleet will go to the wall. That's the end of Britain as a seafaring nation. It's the end of more communities, more skills. Once the fishing has gone, it will never come back. You will never be able to find crews, set up the infrastructures and start again. That's it."

Hardie has been here before. In the 70s he became, at 21, one of the youngest skippers of a deep sea trawler. Just like his father, also a skipper, he fished from the north of Russia to Greenland and all points in the Atlantic. He took part in the "cod wars" with Iceland and then watched his local MP, Anthony Crosland, who was then a Labour foreign secretary, "give away half of what had until then been British fishing rights".

The fleet was devastated. Grimsby and many other coastal towns never fully recovered. "It used to be pay day every day," he says. "There would be dozens of boats coming in every day, each paying men three or four weeks wages. The town was thriving."

Hardie was jobless and young, so he gambled. He bought a gill netter and learned to fish the North Sea for cod. It paid off. Today he drives a BMW convertible, but not for long, he thinks.

His anger, shared by fishermen in Hull, Petershead and the Scottish ports, is directed mainly at successive governments over the past 20 years. "They have consistently traded off our fishing rights for political advantage in Europe," he says. "What is it about fishing? This is the most risky business in the world. We lose many men every year. We die but we do not complain because that is the culture of fishing. But cannot any British government support us? Tell me why not. Other governments subsidise their fleets, protect their interests. Ours doesn't. Other governments help people invest in new ships. Ours doesn't."

Hardie does not even believe that there is a full-scale crisis in the North Sea. "Fishing has always gone in cycles. There are lots of signs that next year will be better. The scientists only go to certain places. They don't talk to us."

He recognises he sounds like an extremist - which he says he isn't by nature - but admits he is ready now to blockade ports and try to embarrass the government at every point. He believes the public is on the side of the fishermen and there is talk about concentrating direct action efforts to coincide with an election. "They are going to make us bankrupt so we may as well go down fighting. We could stop the Humber by this time tomorrow."

Grimsby will escape the worst, ironically because it was hit so hard after the cod wars. Then it started to turn itself round from a fishing port to a food processing one and now it boasts Heinz, Baxters, Birds Eye, Northern Foods and other food giants such as Bluecoat. The football team is still called the Mariners, but the port is slowly de-linking itself with its fishy past, calling itself "the food town".

It's another matter in Scotland. The Scots catch 60% of British cod and the small fishing ports of Fraserburgh, Scrabster, Mallaig and Lochinver, which have only limited processing facilities and are mostly dependent on the boats, will be the worst hit. The Scottish fishermen's association is scathing about the confusion, lack of scientific certainty and crude operation of the EU's fishing policy. But it is pragmatic about the changes it accepts are necessary.

"Anything less than decommissioning [boats] risks both fish stocks and fishing communities collapsing," says a spokesman. But he predicts real hardship if no acceptable money is made available and the government continues to allow businesses to fail. "It would be very great indeed. The fishing jobs are concentrated in small communities with no alternative economic activity.

fields.bodyText: On a calm day you can smell the cod in Grimsby three miles inland. Not now. A gale force nine is ripping through the streets of the huge old Victorian docks. It lashes the shiny new food processing works, the semi-derelict engineering factories, the chandlers, the ropeworks, landing bays, paintshops and repair yards. It whips up the litter, bends the grass horizontal on the desolate wasteground, and whistles through the broken windows of the old ice works. There's no one out to sea and the water is turbulent even in the main harbour where the Beverley, Soraya, Rachel, Aisha and 30 other small fishing vessels, together with two deep sea trawlers, are lashed together and to the docksides. They are vulnerable and mainly venerable, the remnants of the 300-strong North Sea fishing fleet that was based in Grimsby only 30 years ago. In this foul weather and confused political climate they are going nowhere. But some time later tonight, if the forecast is better, Billy "the Fish" Hardie, skipper of the 50-tonne Stormy C, will call his three crewmen - Dave, Basher and Gilly - and set off on the 90-mile journey towards the Netherlands and the shoals of cod. The trip will take 20 hours and they will be away for up to eight days. Hardie will concentrate on the old wrecks where cod congregate at this time of year. He will think like a fish. When the tide is coming in he will drop his gill nets on the side of the wrecks where he knows the cod will be sheltering and feeding off the plankton and smaller fish; and then, when the tide flows out, like them, he will be round the other side. With skill and luck he will avoid the other fishermen and follow the cod's mysterious migrations across the Brown Banks, the Borkum Flats, the Cleaver Bank, the Dogger Bank and the Clay Deep. But right now Hardie is sitting in a Grimsby bowling club feeling as furious as the weather. European scientists have declared that cod stocks in the North Sea and to the west of Scotland are collapsing because of overfishing. The fish that the British have adopted as part of their culture for more than 100 years are said by conservation groups, such as the World Wildlife Fund, to be so rare that in places they are officially an endangered species. The North Sea, marine scientists say, is in danger of going the way of the Newfoundland Grand Banks. In the 80s it was the world's most fished ground - so much so that fish virtually disappeared and stocks have never fully recovered. Hardie knows that he and other fishermen in Britain are about to be gutted. They have had plenty of warning. Early this morning EU fisheries ministers meeting in Brussels imposed savage cuts on all EU cod and other North Sea fishing quotas. The cuts will affect the British most. Coming on top of similar cuts in the past two years, it means the virtual end of cod fishing in European waters. Instead of the Stormy C being allowed to catch 170-plus tonnes of cod next year, Hardie will be limited to just a few tonnes a month - the amount, in better times, he could have caught in a few weeks. Thirty months ago, Hardie invested almost £250,000 in the Stormy C, its licences and quotas. Today he regrets it. One of the most successful fishermen of his generation, he faces bankruptcy - not for bad management, lack of salesmanship or marketing, nor because subsidies are being phased out, but, he says, simply because he has done exactly what the scientists, the governments and all the other "experts" have told him was necessary to save the cod. Britain now has 15,000 full-time fishermen, with the industry concentrated in northern Scotland. It has 435 deep sea trawlers and 1,782 inshore vessels such as Hardie's. Most are owned by families, and small groups of friends or partners, and they are the ones who will be hit hardest by the EU cuts. Cod is their biggest and most valuable catch. The British have a bizarre love affair with the fish. We eat a third of the world's catch and are desperately loyal to the species, unlike the Americans or continental Europeans who are more than happy to eat other fish. We love its moistness and pale taste. But we may not love what is going to happen in the next few months. Few fishermen, it is widely reckoned, will survive the quota cuts if they last more than a few years. They do not have the option, like farmers, of switching "crops". A cod boat is set up for a certain sort of fishing and would cost tens of thousands of pounds to convert to catching, say, mackerel. Nor can they sell up because no one will buy a boat in such hard times. So far, neither the government nor the EU is offering to pay them not to fish - like they pay farmers to set aside land - or to decommission them completely. Their lifetime investments are worth little and their bank managers are already writing letters. "It's a ruddy awful mess," Hardie says. "I'm not being greedy and I understand the need for conservation, but I need 170-odd tonnes to make this business viable. This isn't a hobby. If it goes on like this I predict that 70% or more of the entire British fishing fleet will go to the wall. That's the end of Britain as a seafaring nation. It's the end of more communities, more skills. Once the fishing has gone, it will never come back. You will never be able to find crews, set up the infrastructures and start again. That's it." Hardie has been here before. In the 70s he became, at 21, one of the youngest skippers of a deep sea trawler. Just like his father, also a skipper, he fished from the north of Russia to Greenland and all points in the Atlantic. He took part in the "cod wars" with Iceland and then watched his local MP, Anthony Crosland, who was then a Labour foreign secretary, "give away half of what had until then been British fishing rights". The fleet was devastated. Grimsby and many other coastal towns never fully recovered. "It used to be pay day every day," he says. "There would be dozens of boats coming in every day, each paying men three or four weeks wages. The town was thriving." Hardie was jobless and young, so he gambled. He bought a gill netter and learned to fish the North Sea for cod. It paid off. Today he drives a BMW convertible, but not for long, he thinks. His anger, shared by fishermen in Hull, Petershead and the Scottish ports, is directed mainly at successive governments over the past 20 years. "They have consistently traded off our fishing rights for political advantage in Europe," he says. "What is it about fishing? This is the most risky business in the world. We lose many men every year. We die but we do not complain because that is the culture of fishing. But cannot any British government support us? Tell me why not. Other governments subsidise their fleets, protect their interests. Ours doesn't. Other governments help people invest in new ships. Ours doesn't." Hardie does not even believe that there is a full-scale crisis in the North Sea. "Fishing has always gone in cycles. There are lots of signs that next year will be better. The scientists only go to certain places. They don't talk to us." He recognises he sounds like an extremist - which he says he isn't by nature - but admits he is ready now to blockade ports and try to embarrass the government at every point. He believes the public is on the side of the fishermen and there is talk about concentrating direct action efforts to coincide with an election. "They are going to make us bankrupt so we may as well go down fighting. We could stop the Humber by this time tomorrow." Grimsby will escape the worst, ironically because it was hit so hard after the cod wars. Then it started to turn itself round from a fishing port to a food processing one and now it boasts Heinz, Baxters, Birds Eye, Northern Foods and other food giants such as Bluecoat. The football team is still called the Mariners, but the port is slowly de-linking itself with its fishy past, calling itself "the food town". It's another matter in Scotland. The Scots catch 60% of British cod and the small fishing ports of Fraserburgh, Scrabster, Mallaig and Lochinver, which have only limited processing facilities and are mostly dependent on the boats, will be the worst hit. The Scottish fishermen's association is scathing about the confusion, lack of scientific certainty and crude operation of the EU's fishing policy. But it is pragmatic about the changes it accepts are necessary. "Anything less than decommissioning [boats] risks both fish stocks and fishing communities collapsing," says a spokesman. But he predicts real hardship if no acceptable money is made available and the government continues to allow businesses to fail. "It would be very great indeed. The fishing jobs are concentrated in small communities with no alternative economic activity. "Perhaps the greatest irony [of not decommissioning or compensating fully] would be that the very conservation objectives generating the social dislocation would be completely compromised if fishermen, left to twist in the wind, sought to do what was necessary to pay the bills. Conservation would be the first casualty. Government should bear in mind that fishermen are also an endangered species." Hardie and others take this to mean that fishermen will carry on fishing and simply duck below the surface to survive. Just like the cod. webTitle: Microsoft issues profits warning

fields.headline: Microsoft issues profits warning
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Microsoft has sent shockwaves through the technology sector by issuing its first-ever profits warning, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Microsoft, the icon of the new economy, has sent shockwaves through the technology sector by issuing its first-ever profits warning.

A catastrophic fall in market confidence has already seen similar announcements from tech heavyweights such as Apple and Compaq, but Microsoft's predicament underlines the scale of the slowdown in the US economy.

Microsoft blamed the situation on weak computer sales and a fall in corporate investment in technology. As a result, the tech-rich Nasdaq index in New York shed around 3% of its value, with inevitable consequences across the Atlantic.

European stock markets tumbled this morning, with the FTSE TechMARK index falling 1.6% and the flagship FTSE 100 0.6%. The TechMARK, which tracks the UK's top technology stocks, has already lost 43% of its value over the past three months.

In Germany, the Neuer Markt slid 4.4% and in France the Nouveau Marche dropped 2.3%. Fund managers expect tech stocks to come under pressure for the rest of the morning.

Colin McLean, fund manager at Scottish Value Management, said: "The UK always follows US tech stocks, so it will be affected this morning. Investors are now beginning to worry that the US is heading for a hard landing with slow growth next year."

However, he added that Microsoft and Apple's problems also reflected the migration of internet access from PCs to other mediums, such as mobile phones and television. He said UK technology companies werre less dependent on the PC market.

webTitle: Comment: New US  administration misunderstands past and present

fields.headline: Bush's team think we, the allies, crave US leadership
fields.standfirst:
The new administration misunderstands both past and present

Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: The new administration misunderstands both past and present
fields.body:
The Republican team which will soon take control of the White House has a single big idea about the relationship of the US with the rest of the world, which is that what other countries secretly crave is assertive American leadership. This magic ingredient is supposed to dissolve all the differences, some of them grave, which have already set America at odds with most other nations, including close allies, and which will certainly increase under a Republican administration. Unhappily the big idea is deeply flawed, since it involves a romanticisation of the past and a misunderstanding of the present.

Leadership, as presented by George W Bush and his advisers, is less a real policy than a shaky intellectual construct which enables them to get over the undeniable fact that much of what a Republican White House will want to do is unpalatable even to America's best friends. It draws on a Republican "history" in which Reagan's escalation of the arms race, regarded as dangerously over the top by the allies, in fact led to the end of the cold war, and in which Bush senior's firm approach brought victory in the Gulf.

It also draws, going further back, on what was genuinely a cyclic pattern in the affairs of the Atlantic alliance, with America proposing to its European allies changes, usually in weapons deployment, which they initially found alarming but later accepted. There was, on this account, a golden age of American decision-making to which, after the fumbling and floundering of the Clinton years, the world can now return.

So the assumption is that Russia, Europe and China will soon see that an American missile defence system is necessary and that it will not undermine arms control. The Europeans, the UN and others will also quickly grasp that it is quite right that the US contribute neither money nor soldiers to humanitarian operations, since America make its contribution to world security in so many other, more important, ways.

The Europeans will understand, in time, that it is not the business of the 82nd Airborne Division to escort children to school in Kosovo, in Condoleezza Rice's well known example, while it is perfectly reasonable to expect British or Italian troops to do so. They will also take in that, while it is proper that they should create new military capacity, this should only be used when and how America wants it to be used.

They will eventually go along with an American definition of the central problem in the Middle East as a mysterious Palestinian refusal to accept a very fair bargain. And the world in general will understand that the US has little interest in an International Criminal Court and in more than minimal environmental agreements, and that it cannot, for very good reasons, join in any ban on land mines.

The first Republican error here is the old one of believing that what America does abroad, particularly what it does militarily, is done for all and should be appreciated by all. The $300bn annually spent on the military are thus a "public good" contributed to the world by Americans and for which they surely deserve some compensation.

Out of this comes the burden-sharing philosophy which, for instance, allows Americans to think that having 11,000 troops in the Balkans is a wildly generous arrangement, and some Americans, apparently including the president-elect at one point, to blunder along under the impression that the US is policing the Balkans alone.

Any idea that American military spending is, in the first place, to do with American national interests, with American fantasies of encirclement and attack and with the political competition between the parties to appear most ready to meet these alleged threats puts burden-sharing in a different light. American arms have indeed been vital to the world in the past and could be vital in the future, but that is far from the whole story of American military power.

The second error is to imagine that laying out your policy and then saying "Like it or lump it" constitutes leadership. Leadership involves convincing and enthusing others. When others go along in spite of being unconvinced it is either because they have been coerced or because, over a long period of decision-making they have seen enough success to swallow their doubts in a particular instance.

This is why the Republicans invoke Bush senior and Reagan. There is a lot of room for argument about any simple cause and effect relationship between Reagan's policies and Soviet reform and then disintegration. But even setting that aside, the continuity to which Republicans appeal is fractured, not least by the foreign policy mistakes of the Clinton years, mistakes to which partisan Republicans in the House and Senate contributed so much.

Would Clinton have dithered so much on the Balkans had he not been fearful of Republican attacks? Would there have been such an unthinking response to the Asian economic crisis without Republican influence? Would Clinton have embraced national missile defence had the Republicans not made such an issue of it? And would not the US now be a signatory to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty had the Republicans in the Senate not voted the treaty down?

The Clinton administration's worst failure, in the Middle East, owes little to Republican sabotage. Even so, it does not add to the body of trust in American leadership. This is especially the case since the Republicans, even though in the past they were a little readier than the Democrats to apply pressure to the Israelis, are unlikely to be so bold this time round.

The third error in Republican strategy is also a product of the destructive partisanship of the last eight years. In spite of all the rhetoric about Bush reaching for the political centre and the Democrats responding to his sincere efforts, the reality is that Republicans in the House and the Senate - not all of them but enough of them - did their best to ruin Clinton's policies. Why then should Democrats ease Bush's path, when everybody agrees that campaigning for the 2002 Congressional elections has already begun? It will be hard to exercise international leadership when American decisions are seen abroad as the almost accidental product of bitter political battling at home.

The weird outcome of the election certainly makes it harder for the Republicans to be the international decision-makers they aspire to be. But the essence of their problem is that, far more than the Democrats, they embody the contradictions of American society - the sense of entitlement to world power allied to the sense that they are being asked to take too much responsibility for others, the worship of military strength allied to a deep disinclination to use it and the desire to be in charge allied to the desire to be left alone. That is what could make the next four years a dangerous time in the life of the world.

martin.woollacott@theguardian.com

webTitle: Flood aid boost for local authorities

fields.headline: Flood aid boost for local authorities
fields.trailText: Local authorities have received a financial boost after the government extended emergency flood aid, introduced for the October and November crisis, to cover the new spate of swamped houses and drowned roads.
fields.body:
Local authorities have received a financial boost after the government extended emergency flood aid, introduced for the October and November crisis, to cover the new spate of swamped houses and drowned roads.

Yesterday's package from deputy prime minister, John Prescott offered full reimbursement of flooding costs to all local authorities beyond the 0.2% of total council budget.

The aid was originally set at 85% of costs, but the government said it was impressed by local councils' response to the crisis.

Mr Prescott guaranteed 100% grants to meet the bill for temporary rehousing, school closures and other "exceptional" costs, as 15 severe flood warnings were imposed across the country.

The environment agency gave a pessimistic forecast for river levels in the Severn valley, warning that floods could reach four inches higher than last month's peak. A spokesman said high tides from the Bristol Channel, persistent rain and saturated water meadows were combining to cause rapid rises in the Severn.

Monitoring of the river suggests that the Tewkesbury area will see a 15ft 4in peak, compared to 15ft in November, and in Gloucester a rise to 14.7ft compared to 14.4ft last month.

Flooding is also expected to persist along the Great Western railway route to the south west, where stretches of track between Swindon and Bristol, and between Taunton and Exeter, are under water.

The National Farmers' Union is pitching for extra emergency funding by announcing a national audit of flood and storm damage to winter crops, many of which cannot survive more than three weeks' inundation. The report will go to the Ministry of Agriculture, which is liaising with the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

webTitle: Women still denied top public sector jobs

fields.headline: Women still denied top public sector jobs
fields.trailText: Women still have serious problems breaking the 'glass ceiling' and moving into top jobs in the public sector and government, a report reveals.
fields.body:
Women still have serious problems breaking the 'glass ceiling' and moving into top jobs in the public sector and government, a report reveals.

The report, Women at the Top, by the Hansard Commission, comes 10 years after its first study, and finds that, while there has been some progress, the public sector has come "nowhere near" matching the abilities and ambitions of the most talented women.

The report's author, Karen Ross, called for a "strong steer" from government to encourage action from employers to ensure that qualified women are not passed over for promotion in government, the civil service, the courts, the NHS and the education system.

The commission chairwoman, Lady Howe, said: "The attitudinal barrier - the clubby culture as we sometimes called it - to women entering the very top decision making levels remains firmly fixed."

The Hansard Society director, Shelagh Diplock, said: "Since the launch of the influential commission report in 1990, there has been much talk of women moving up and even taking over from men in the world of work and public life.

"Dr Ross's report is a timely reminder that urgent consideration still has to be given to ensuring that women's talents are properly valued in the public sector."

Meanwhile, Britain's most powerful civil servant, Sir Richard Wilson, head of the civil service and cabinet secretary, admitted that Whitehall will have great difficulty in meeting its target of opening one in three top jobs to highly qualified women.

Figures released in the civil service annual report reveal that although the percentage of women getting jobs among the top 3,000 civil servants has jumped from 17.8% to 22%, it was still far short of the government's target of 35%.

Among the most senior civil servants - from under secretaries to permanent secretaries - the percentage of women had risen from 12.7% to 18%. But this still fell far short of the government's target of 25%.

Sir Richard said yesterday: "Although for the first time among new recruits there is a parity between men and women getting jobs, we will have great difficulty in reaching the 35% target among senior civil servant posts."

The civil service annual report showed that Whitehall's record has improved in recruiting people from ethnic minorities and disabilities. More top jobs are open to people from outside and inititatives are being made to get better feedback from staff.

webTitle: Comment: Hague: looking for an enemy

fields.headline: Looking for an enemy
fields.standfirst: If I'm the only opponent Hague can find - in the guise of the 'liberal elite' - then his party is really in a bad way
fields.trailText: If I'm the only opponent Hague can find - in the guise of the 'liberal elite' - then his party is really in a bad way
fields.body:
That old monster "the liberal elite" is to blame for everything. For "the rising tide of crime", for Damilola Taylor and Sarah Payne's deaths, for Tony Martin's imprisonment, for the death of the family, single mothers, paedophiles and every other social evil under the Sun. "Political correctness" is to blame, the esperanto of liberalism.

William Hague may be intoxicated by the sight of George W Bush ascending the White House throne after ordering the frying of over 100 men and women on death row. If law and order won it for Dubya, maybe it can win it for William too. The phrase "liberal elite" is American, something that may exist on the East Coast, in the Ivy League or the New York Review of Books world, but has never wielded power this side of the Atlantic, or not since Asquith and the death of liberal England.

Who is this liberal elite? My own name is the only one to feature in Hague's speech to the Centre for Policy Studies yesterday - a great honour. But the truth is, if one columnist from the small sliver of the British press that is to the left of centre is the best he can find, it shows how pitifully thin on the ground liberals must be. It is quite difficult to be an elite of just one. This happens frequently with the anti-liberal rants in the Sun or far-right commentators: in all their fulminations about this shadowy but immensely powerful liberal entity they can never think of anyone within shouting distance of government to call liberal. New Labour never has been liberal. Hague only mentions Jack Straw's name once. Why? Because no one hearing his name thinks this government is run by a bunch of lily-livered limousine-liberals.

Out there in the 70% of the press that is not just to the right, but these days far right, there is a plethora of comment pouring out of the pens of the likes of Peter Hitchens, Bruce Anderson, Michael Gove, Boris Johnson, Peter Mackay, Janet Daley, Melanie Phillips, Paul Johnson, Richard Littlejohn, Peter Dobie - I could fill the page with this roll of honour. Their words infuse the air the country breathes, serving just three press magnates whose pernicious influence corrodes all political discourse.

Against these forces of conservatism the liberal voice is pathetically weak. The great majority of the population will rarely hear or read a liberal sentiment. That is why people believe crime is rising when it has fallen for six straight years right across the western world. Stoking up fear of crime is these rightwing commentators' black art, a fear deliberately inflamed to tip the people rightwards.

The influence of this rightwing army spreads far wider than just the declining readership of newspapers. For all its claims of balance, inevitably the BBC's agenda uses these far-right fruitcakes as one marker, dragging the whole debate further over to the right than the general consensus. Take an issue like abortion: 85% consistently support it in opinion polls, yet the BBC always has an archaic anti-abortion voice in every embryo discussion, a Victoria Gillick in every contraception debate, simply because the threatening but unrepresentative noise of the rightwing press demands this as "balance". So too with most other issues. It is time the BBC recentred itself, ignoring the cacophony of the press. It may be gratifying to be named as the liberal threat and enemy but how absurd: the liberal end of the rope is always tugged far to the right by the press bullies.

As for Hague's speech, this is all desperate thrashing about by a failed leader of a failed party. Like a fish in a net, the more he thrashes, the more he is doomed. Since he took over the wreckage of the Conservative party he has made every navigational error, taken every wrong turn and has now beached it in the shallows on a desert island. His issue, Europe, is a dead duck now. Once the strongest genuine difference between the parties, firm ground on which to stand and fight, it turned to quicksand on Monday when Tony Blair returned from Nice with all his QMVs and weighted votes in place - no inch of flesh vulnerable to the Eurosceptics.

Every other issue has turned to dust in Hague's inept hand. His tax cut guarantee demolished, he is left pledging implied billions on everything he mentions yet each time he promises more nurses, police or teachers his tax cuts look the more implausible and undesirable. The more he describes the plight of public services, the more voters are reminded of the need for more public money.

His fantasy economics promised yesterday 10 more secure training centres for 1,000 young offenders. Each place costs £403 per day yet he refuses to commit to matching, let alone increasing law and order spending. All that is left for a man stagnant at one third in the polls, with only an aging cohort of supporters, is to rant.

The last refuge of desperate conservatism is always race. Hague's speech is racist in every sentiment, linking crime with colour, blaming Macpherson and fewer random stop and searches on black youths for street crime. Even those words sympathising with the honest black community's suffering as prime victims of crime only serves to fix the black/crime connection more firmly. Forget the experimental baseball cap and coconut at the Notting Hill carnival - it will be black crime and asylum seekers from now on. If the election campaign begins this low, it will sink below anything ever seen in this country by election day.

Do race and extreme illiberalism on single parents, gays, abortion or sex education really pay political dividends? From the timbre of the British press an outsider might presume that the soul of the country resides within the black heart of Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail. Luckily it does not. (Only 14% of Mail readers ever voted Labour). The British Social Attitudes survey reveals a country far more progressive - at ease on all these issues, uncensorious about personal morality. In the world of Goodness Gracious Me and Lenny Henry, Britain, says the Runnymede Trust, is the least racist country in Europe.

We liberals are closer to the majority. Hague is marooned in yesteryear with his shrinking blue-rinse party while we are swimming in the sea of pluralism, multiculturalism, complex families, difficult choices, all the muddle born of freedom. If we are the elite, that is because we are winning: British Social Attitudes shows people become more liberal the more educated they are. Conservatives have always been the stupid party. Graduates will soon be half the population, so Tories will be educated out of existence. To be liberal is to be free of superstition and irrational fear, open to the new, optimistic about the future, knowing there has never been a better time to be alive than now.

webTitle: Incinerator firm faces charges over toxic waste

fields.headline: Incinerator firm faces charges over toxic waste
fields.trailText: An incinerator company and a city council are to be prosecuted by the environment agency for depositing 2,000 tonnes of toxic ash on parks, public bridleways and allotments, putting children at risk and the public in danger, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
An incinerator company and a city council are to be prosecuted by the environment agency for depositing 2,000 tonnes of toxic ash on parks, public bridleways and allotments, putting children at risk and the public in danger, it was announced yesterday.

Newcastle-upon-Tyne council and the Cambridge-based Combined Heat and Power are between them facing 19 charges of illegally disposing of toxic waste and breaching environment protection regulations at the Byker incineration plant in the city.

The charges follow a 10- month investigation by the agency after protest groups and the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who represents the area, lodged complaints.

The decision is certain to raise fears about the health dangers of incinerators which are being expanded under Labour as part of the government's initiative to reduce the level of landfill dumping.

The reuse of ash from incinerators is being examined by a Commons environment committee inquiry, which is looking at the government's waste strategy.

The city council had already banned children under the age of two from playing in 27 allotments and people were warned not to eat eggs or poultry there. A big clean-up by the council this year also led to removal of the poisoned ash from 14 footpaths, bridle paths and parks. Samples supplied to Newcastle's public health department revealed the ash contained mercury at 2,406% above accepted levels, cadmium at 785% above normal levels and lead at 136% above normal.

The city council will now face 15 charges concerning allegations of illegally depositing waste, and of disposing of waste in a manner likely to pollute the environment or cause harm to human health under the Environmental Protection Act of 1990 and the environmental protection regulations of 1991.

The council-appointed plant operator, Contract Heat and Power, faces four charges concerning duty of care offences and breaches of authorisation under the Environmental Protection Act 1990. All the offences carry unlimited fines on conviction.

An environment agency spokesman said: "If the agency believes that environmental legislation has been breached a number of courses of action can be taken. The most serious is to bring a prosecution and the agency believes this to be the appropriate response in the circumstances."

When the Byker reclamation plant was built by the former Tyne and Wear council at a cost of £4m more than 20 years ago, it was hailed as a breakthrough in recycling. It was the first of its kind in Europe to reclaim metal and turn household waste into fuel, which was burned to provide heat and hot water for thousands of homes in the neighbourhood.

But before long residents began complaining of pungent smells and a rise in throat and nose complaints. The plant began falling short of targets and by 1993 council chiefs were considering closing it down. But it survived and in 1998 switched from burning refuse to burning coal.

Plans are now being considered to expand the incinerator to burn some 80,000 tonnes of municipal waste and 13,000 tonnes of tyres - and this has led to strong protests.

Mr Brown has also demanded an investigation by the environment agency into dioxin emissions from the incinerator .

The city council will now face 15 charges concerning allegations of illegally depositing waste, and of disposing of waste in a manner likely to pollute the environment or cause harm to human health under the Environmental Protection Act of 1990 and the environmental protection regulations of 1991. The council-appointed plant operator, Contract Heat and Power, faces four charges concerning duty of care offences and breaches of authorisation under the Environmental Protection Act 1990. All the offences carry unlimited fines on conviction. An environment agency spokesman said: "If the agency believes that environmental legislation has been breached a number of courses of action can be taken. The most serious is to bring a prosecution and the agency believes this to be the appropriate response in the circumstances." When the Byker reclamation plant was built by the former Tyne and Wear council at a cost of £4m more than 20 years ago, it was hailed as a breakthrough in recycling. It was the first of its kind in Europe to reclaim metal and turn household waste into fuel, which was burned to provide heat and hot water for thousands of homes in the neighbourhood. But before long residents began complaining of pungent smells and a rise in throat and nose complaints. The plant began falling short of targets and by 1993 council chiefs were considering closing it down. But it survived and in 1998 switched from burning refuse to burning coal. Plans are now being considered to expand the incinerator to burn some 80,000 tonnes of municipal waste and 13,000 tonnes of tyres - and this has led to strong protests. Mr Brown has also demanded an investigation by the environment agency into dioxin emissions from the incinerator .

webTitle: Ministers reject calls for 'shocking' tobacco ads

fields.headline: Ministers turn down calls for 'shocking' tobacco ads
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Europe's health ministers have rejected calls for the introduction of images of blackened teeth and charred lungs on cigarette packets, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Europe's health ministers have unanimously rejected calls from Euro MPs for the introduction of shocking images of blackened teeth and charred lungs on cigarette packets.

Health ministers from the 15 European countries rejected the proposals, which would have forced manufacturers to put images of cancerous lungs and rotting teeth on cigarette packets.

In a vote in Strasbourg on Wednesday, the European Parliament approved legislation that would require the tobacco industry to cover 30% of the front of every packet sold in the EU with a health warning and introduce graphic pictures by 2003.

In the UK, just 6% of every packet surface is taken up with a warning.

But at yesterday's meeting of the Council of Ministers, health ministers including Britain's Alan Milburn said they could not accept the new requirements.

The proposals form part of a tobacco directive due to be passed by the European Parliament and ministers.

As a result of the deadlock, the directive will go into conciliation with the European Commission acting as arbitrator.
