webTitle: FSA seeks to close Equitable stable door

fields.headline: FSA seeks to close Equitable stable door
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The financial services authority is considering proposals to force insurance companies to release more information about their financial position to prevent a repeat of Equitable Life's shutdown.
fields.body:
The financial services authority is considering proposals to force insurance companies to release more information about their financial position to prevent a repeat of Equitable Life's shutdown.

Equitable, the world's oldest mutually owned insurer, discovered a £7.5bn black hole in its accounts last week and was forced to close its doors to new business after failing to find a buyer.

The FSA says it recognises the difference in the detailed information that insurance companies must reveal for statutory regulatory purposes, in the past in the form of filings to the Department of Trade and Industry, and the more limited information displayed in their annual reports accounts.

"At the moment there is only limited correspondence between annual reports and the regulatory returns," a spokeswoman for the FSA said.

The FSA, which has faced criticism about its role in the fate of Equitable, yesterday posted fresh information on its website to try to field some the questions which have been raised.

The regulator warns policyholders against making hasty decisions and asks them to take detailed notes of any conversations with financial advisers when deciding whether to move their policies to another provider. Some financial advisers are thought to be prepared to waive their fees when discussing the Equitable situation.

Equitable is trying to sell off parts of its business after the decision to close its doors to new business.

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which advised Equitable on its failed sale, is said to be reapproaching some of the 15 bidders who originally expressed an interested in the entire company.

webTitle: Damilola police release 7 of 11 arrested youths

fields.headline: Damilola police release 7 of 11 arrested youths
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Gallery: the CCTV shots
fields.trailText: Seven of the 11 teenagers arrested in connection with the fatal stabbing of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor ahve now been released.
fields.body:
Eleven teenagers were arrested in connection with the fatal stabbing of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor in a series of dawn raids on addresses across Peckham conducted by 200 police officers yesterday. By late last night, one had been released, and another six let out on bail.

The original 11 were questioned at various police stations across London and a Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "Six youths have been bailed to return to various London police stations on a date in January 2001 pending further inquiries,"

The four remainning boys - three 15-year-olds and one 13-year-old - remained in custody. Of the four teenagers, two are of Mediterranean appearance and two are black.

None of the boys attended Damilola's school, Oliver Goldsmith primary in Peckham.

The original group included two boys who were previously detained along with a 39-year-old woman, who was not re-arrested, but it is not yet known if these are among those still held.

Among those originally arrested were a 12-year-old, two 13-year-olds, two 14-year-olds, two 15-year-olds, and one 16-year-old. All the arrests were videotaped by police and the boys' homes were searched.

Police confirmed that some of the boys were suspects, while others were potentially important witnesses.

An extra six police constables and one sergeant had been drafted in full time to police the Peckham area and deal with issues such as youth crime, a police spokesman said.

Dozens of children have been interviewed as witnesses by detectives during the investigation, along with a number of adults. Police hope the arrests will lead further witnesses to come forward.

The development comes almost three weeks after Damilola bled to death in a stairwell on the North Peckham estate. He was stabbed in the leg as he walked home from an after-school computer class at Peckham library on November 27. He dragged himself 100 yards along Blakes Road before collapsing and bleeding to death.

Police said earlier this week that two groups of witnesses had not come forward, and that they wanted to speak to two groups of youths seen during Damilola's final journey.

On Tuesday, police said a new witness had reported seeing a group of youths standing by telephone boxes at 4.30pm in Blakes Road, near where Damilola died. One of the group, the smallest, stood apart from the others and was wearing a jacket similar to the one Damilola was wearing when he was attacked.

Rio Ferdinand, the Leeds United and former West Ham footballer, who was brought up in Peckham, yesterday joined the appeal for more information about the murder.

webTitle: Rebuke for Labour MP who gambled on Speaker

fields.headline: Rebuke for Labour MP who gambled on Speaker
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The embarrassing political row over Labour MPs who placed bets on the succession campaign to elect Michael Martin as new speaker of the Commons ended yesterday after one self-confessed punter was censured - but suffered no further penalty.
fields.body:
The embarrassing political row over Labour MPs who placed bets on the succession campaign to elect Michael Martin as new speaker of the Commons ended yesterday after one self-confessed punter was censured - but suffered no further penalty.

The Commons committee on standards and privileges endorsed a decision by the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, to uphold a complaint by members of the public and fellow MPs against the Labour MP for Motherwell and Wishaw, Frank Roy.

At least 20 MPs bet on Mr Martin - but Mr Roy was the only one to admit doing so to Scottish newspapers.

He put £200 at odds of 20-1 on his Glaswegian colleague on July 20 before most MPs had realised how formidable the Martin campaign would be. A syndicated bet placed by a friend at the same time got odds of only 14-1, so Mr Roy split the difference and pocketed only £3,400, not £4,000, Ms Filkin reported to the committee.

webTitle: Rabbi pillories recalcitrant husband

fields.headline: Rabbi pillories recalcitrant husband
fields.trailText: An orthodox rabbi has named and shamed a Jewish husband by criticising him in an advertisement in today's Jewish Chronicle for refusing to grant his former wife a religious divorce.
fields.body:
An orthodox rabbi has named and shamed a Jewish husband by criticising him in an advertisement in today's Jewish Chronicle for refusing to grant his former wife a religious divorce.

Yiki Loewenstein will wake up in his parents' home in Hampstead, north London, to find the newspaper carrying the large advert, which criticises him for denying his wife Bryna a divorce, known as a get, for nearly nine years.

Rabbi Pini Dunner of the Saatchi orthodox synagogue, is also threatening to lead demonstrations outside Mr Loewenstein's parents' home if he refuses to comply. Only husbands can grant their wives gets and failure to do so means that the wife cannot be remarried in a synagogue, and offspring of future marriages are regarded as illegitimate.

Mr Loewenstein, understood to be in his 50s and to have been married for two years while living in the US, was unavailable to comment last night.

webTitle: A star is stillborn as unknown flops in starring role

fields.headline: A star is stillborn as unknown flops in starring role
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: In showbiz talk, Melanie Johnson, an unknown junior finance minister who has the fine title of economic secretary to the Treasury, bombed. She bottled it. Lost the plot. A total flopperoo.
fields.body:
In some old Hollywood films there was a scene where the top act was taken ill, and an unknown understudy took their place. Cut to shot of audience standing and cheering the debut of a lifetime. The screen filled with revolving newspapers featuring unlikely headlines: "A Star Is Born"; "Fanny Brice is Broadway Box Office Boffo!"

I don't know what you'd call the opposite - a star is stillborn, perhaps. Anyhow, that's what happened to poor Melanie Johnson, an unknown junior finance minister who has the fine title of economic secretary to the Treasury. In showbiz talk she bombed. Bottled it. Lost the plot. A total flopperoo.

Her first answer at Treasury questions yesterday was about the savings ratio: the amount of national income we are all putting by. The question had been asked by David Tredinnick, an MP for Leicestershire, who helped his own savings ratio in the last parliament by agreeing to ask questions for cash. He wanted to know how Ms Johnson could "look my constituents in Hinckley in the eye and say that savings have improved under Labour?"

(This is one of those batty formulations MPs like to use. Does Mr Tredinnick imagine that people in Hinckley market are going to storm up to the minister: "Look me in the eye, Ms Johnson, and tell me that the savings ratio has improved under Labour"?)

That was no problem. But then came Sir Peter Tapsell, perhaps the grandest of all the grandees left in the Tory party. When he rises, the Hansard writers put aside pens and pick up chisels, for he speaks as if his words are to be engraved in stone.

Sir Peter is obsessed by gold. He believes that it was a disastrous mistake for Gor don Brown to sell off much of our gold reserves. He probably thinks it was also a dark day for Britain when we lost our myrrh and frankincense stockpiles too. He drew himself up in his full pomp.

"Will. The economic secretary. Agree. That over the year. Since July 1999. The Treasury sold 225. Million tons of. Gold!" Labour MPs chortled merrily. But he had a serious point. Mr Brown used the $2bn from the sale to buy euros, which had since lost a fifth of their value. This required an answer. It did not get one.

Ms Johnson announced airily that the government had "made the right decision to diversify our portfolio". She would probably have said the same if Mr Brown had bunged the whole lot on a Today programme racing tip, or Al Gore to win.

"But perhaps he doesn't want to remember some of the issues that face the economy now and the opposition at the present time. He doesn't want to face the fact that we have no fiscal rules being offered by his Rt Hon friend the shadow chancellor _" On and on she droned. As I woke up, seemingly hours later, she was still boring on: "And we have built a stable economy and put an end to boom and bust!" Angry Tories bellowed "Answer, answer," but in vain.

Another MP asked about savings. She was up again, banging on in exactly the same way. Unemployment was down. Inflation was down. By asking the question the MP was "avoiding the issue", which turned out to be the indubitable success of the Labour government in all possible respects. In her view, only one Tory question is permissible: "Why are you all so wonderful?"

This "answer" trundled on endlessly, like a hamster on a treadmill, expending energy but getting nowhere. Labour has a new John Prescott, able to say nothing at the most tremendous length.

It was terrible, embarrassing, gut-writhing stuff. "This is an insult to the house!" some Tory shouted - pompously, but for once quite correctly.

webTitle: Comment: Hague: looking for an enemy

fields.headline: Looking for an enemy
fields.standfirst:
If I'm the only opponent Hague can find - in the guise of the 'liberal elite' - then his party is really in a bad way

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: If I'm the only opponent Hague can find - in the guise of the 'liberal elite' - then his party is really in a bad way, writes Polly Toynbee
fields.body:
That old monster "the liberal elite" is to blame for everything. For "the rising tide of crime", for Damilola Taylor and Sarah Payne's deaths, for Tony Martin's imprisonment, for the death of the family, single mothers, paedophiles and every other social evil under the Sun. "Political correctness" is to blame, the esperanto of liberalism.

William Hague may be intoxicated by the sight of George W Bush ascending the White House throne after ordering the frying of over 100 men and women on death row. If law and order won it for Dubya, maybe it can win it for William too. The phrase "liberal elite" is American, something that may exist on the East Coast, in the Ivy League or the New York Review of Books world, but has never wielded power this side of the Atlantic, or not since Asquith and the death of liberal England.

Who is this liberal elite? My own name is the only one to feature in Hague's speech to the Centre for Policy Studies yesterday - a great honour. But the truth is, if one columnist from the small sliver of the British press that is to the left of centre is the best he can find, it shows how pitifully thin on the ground liberals must be. It is quite difficult to be an elite of just one. This happens frequently with the anti-liberal rants in the Sun or far-right commentators: in all their fulminations about this shadowy but immensely powerful liberal entity they can never think of anyone within shouting distance of government to call liberal. New Labour never has been liberal. Hague only mentions Jack Straw's name once. Why? Because no one hearing his name thinks this government is run by a bunch of lily-livered limousine-liberals.

Out there in the 70% of the press that is not just to the right, but these days far right, there is a plethora of comment pouring out of the pens of the likes of Peter Hitchens, Bruce Anderson, Michael Gove, Boris Johnson, Peter Mackay, Janet Daley, Melanie Phillips, Paul Johnson, Richard Littlejohn, Peter Dobie - I could fill the page with this roll of honour. Their words infuse the air the country breathes, serving just three press magnates whose pernicious influence corrodes all political discourse.

Against these forces of conservatism the liberal voice is pathetically weak. The great majority of the population will rarely hear or read a liberal sentiment. That is why people believe crime is rising when it has fallen for six straight years right across the western world. Stoking up fear of crime is these rightwing commentators' black art, a fear deliberately inflamed to tip the people rightwards.

The influence of this rightwing army spreads far wider than just the declining readership of newspapers. For all its claims of balance, inevitably the BBC's agenda uses these far-right fruitcakes as one marker, dragging the whole debate further over to the right than the general consensus. Take an issue like abortion: 85% consistently support it in opinion polls, yet the BBC always has an archaic anti-abortion voice in every embryo discussion, a Victoria Gillick in every contraception debate, simply because the threatening but unrepresentative noise of the rightwing press demands this as "balance". So too with most other issues. It is time the BBC recentred itself, ignoring the cacophony of the press. It may be gratifying to be named as the liberal threat and enemy but how absurd: the liberal end of the rope is always tugged far to the right by the press bullies.

As for Hague's speech, this is all desperate thrashing about by a failed leader of a failed party. Like a fish in a net, the more he thrashes, the more he is doomed. Since he took over the wreckage of the Conservative party he has made every navigational error, taken every wrong turn and has now beached it in the shallows on a desert island. His issue, Europe, is a dead duck now. Once the strongest genuine difference between the parties, firm ground on which to stand and fight, it turned to quicksand on Monday when Tony Blair returned from Nice with all his QMVs and weighted votes in place - no inch of flesh vulnerable to the Eurosceptics.

Every other issue has turned to dust in Hague's inept hand. His tax cut guarantee demolished, he is left pledging implied billions on everything he mentions yet each time he promises more nurses, police or teachers his tax cuts look the more implausible and undesirable. The more he describes the plight of public services, the more voters are reminded of the need for more public money.

His fantasy economics promised yesterday 10 more secure training centres for 1,000 young offenders. Each place costs £403 per day yet he refuses to commit to matching, let alone increasing law and order spending. All that is left for a man stagnant at one third in the polls, with only an aging cohort of supporters, is to rant.

The last refuge of desperate conservatism is always race. Hague's speech is racist in every sentiment, linking crime with colour, blaming Macpherson and fewer random stop and searches on black youths for street crime. Even those words sympathising with the honest black community's suffering as prime victims of crime only serves to fix the black/crime connection more firmly. Forget the experimental baseball cap and coconut at the Notting Hill carnival - it will be black crime and asylum seekers from now on. If the election campaign begins this low, it will sink below anything ever seen in this country by election day.

Do race and extreme illiberalism on single parents, gays, abortion or sex education really pay political dividends? From the timbre of the British press an outsider might presume that the soul of the country resides within the black heart of Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail. Luckily it does not. (Only 14% of Mail readers ever voted Labour). The British Social Attitudes survey reveals a country far more progressive - at ease on all these issues, uncensorious about personal morality. In the world of Goodness Gracious Me and Lenny Henry, Britain, says the Runnymede Trust, is the least racist country in Europe.

We liberals are closer to the majority. Hague is marooned in yesteryear with his shrinking blue-rinse party while we are swimming in the sea of pluralism, multiculturalism, complex families, difficult choices, all the muddle born of freedom. If we are the elite, that is because we are winning: British Social Attitudes shows people become more liberal the more educated they are. Conservatives have always been the stupid party. Graduates will soon be half the population, so Tories will be educated out of existence. To be liberal is to be free of superstition and irrational fear, open to the new, optimistic about the future, knowing there has never been a better time to be alive than now.

New Labour never has been liberal. Hague only mentions Jack Straw's name once. Why? Because no one hearing his name thinks this government is run by a bunch of lily-livered limousine-liberals. Out there in the 70% of the press that is not just to the right, but these days far right, there is a plethora of comment pouring out of the pens of the likes of Peter Hitchens, Bruce Anderson, Michael Gove, Boris Johnson, Peter Mackay, Janet Daley, Melanie Phillips, Paul Johnson, Richard Littlejohn, Peter Dobie - I could fill the page with this roll of honour. Their words infuse the air the country breathes, serving just three press magnates whose pernicious influence corrodes all political discourse. Against these forces of conservatism the liberal voice is pathetically weak. The great majority of the population will rarely hear or read a liberal sentiment. That is why people believe crime is rising when it has fallen for six straight years right across the western world. Stoking up fear of crime is these rightwing commentators' black art, a fear deliberately inflamed to tip the people rightwards. The influence of this rightwing army spreads far wider than just the declining readership of newspapers. For all its claims of balance, inevitably the BBC's agenda uses these far-right fruitcakes as one marker, dragging the whole debate further over to the right than the general consensus. Take an issue like abortion: 85% consistently support it in opinion polls, yet the BBC always has an archaic anti-abortion voice in every embryo discussion, a Victoria Gillick in every contraception debate, simply because the threatening but unrepresentative noise of the rightwing press demands this as "balance". So too with most other issues. It is time the BBC recentred itself, ignoring the cacophony of the press. It may be gratifying to be named as the liberal threat and enemy but how absurd: the liberal end of the rope is always tugged far to the right by the press bullies. As for Hague's speech, this is all desperate thrashing about by a failed leader of a failed party. Like a fish in a net, the more he thrashes, the more he is doomed. Since he took over the wreckage of the Conservative party he has made every navigational error, taken every wrong turn and has now beached it in the shallows on a desert island. His issue, Europe, is a dead duck now. Once the strongest genuine difference between the parties, firm ground on which to stand and fight, it turned to quicksand on Monday when Tony Blair returned from Nice with all his QMVs and weighted votes in place - no inch of flesh vulnerable to the Eurosceptics. Every other issue has turned to dust in Hague's inept hand. His tax cut guarantee demolished, he is left pledging implied billions on everything he mentions yet each time he promises more nurses, police or teachers his tax cuts look the more implausible and undesirable. The more he describes the plight of public services, the more voters are reminded of the need for more public money. His fantasy economics promised yesterday 10 more secure training centres for 1,000 young offenders. Each place costs £403 per day yet he refuses to commit to matching, let alone increasing law and order spending. All that is left for a man stagnant at one third in the polls, with only an aging cohort of supporters, is to rant. The last refuge of desperate conservatism is always race. Hague's speech is racist in every sentiment, linking crime with colour, blaming Macpherson and fewer random stop and searches on black youths for street crime. Even those words sympathising with the honest black community's suffering as prime victims of crime only serves to fix the black/crime connection more firmly. Forget the experimental baseball cap and coconut at the Notting Hill carnival - it will be black crime and asylum seekers from now on. If the election campaign begins this low, it will sink below anything ever seen in this country by election day. Do race and extreme illiberalism on single parents, gays, abortion or sex education really pay political dividends? From the timbre of the British press an outsider might presume that the soul of the country resides within the black heart of Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail. Luckily it does not. (Only 14% of Mail readers ever voted Labour). The British Social Attitudes survey reveals a country far more progressive - at ease on all these issues, uncensorious about personal morality. In the world of Goodness Gracious Me and Lenny Henry, Britain, says the Runnymede Trust, is the least racist country in Europe. We liberals are closer to the majority. Hague is marooned in yesteryear with his shrinking blue-rinse party while we are swimming in the sea of pluralism, multiculturalism, complex families, difficult choices, all the muddle born of freedom. If we are the elite, that is because we are winning: British Social Attitudes shows people become more liberal the more educated they are. Conservatives have always been the stupid party. Graduates will soon be half the population, so Tories will be educated out of existence. To be liberal is to be free of superstition and irrational fear, open to the new, optimistic about the future, knowing there has never been a better time to be alive than now. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

webTitle: Anger as Hague is accused of playing the race card

fields.headline: Anger as Hague is accused of playing the race card
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Macpherson report - one year on
fields.trailText: William Hague sparked protests from across the political spectrum yesterday after a provocative speech on crime in which he blamed the Macpherson report into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence for a collapse in police morale.
fields.body:
William Hague sparked protests from across the political spectrum yesterday after a provocative speech on crime in which he blamed the Macpherson report into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence for a collapse in police morale.

Stephen's father, Neville, led the protests when he blamed the Tory leader for playing the race card in the run-up to the election. "He has been desperate to play the race card and has found a way to do it here."

Mr Lawrence's criticisms were echoed by politicians, senior police and the report's author.

Mr Hague, who dismissed the criticisms, suffered embarrassment last night when it emerged that the main crime figures in his speech were wrong. Tory officials blamed a "phrasing error" for Mr Hague's assertion that the number of arrests by the Metropolitan police, following stop and searches, fell from 18,752 a month to 11,858 after the Macpherson report.

Tory sources claimed the error was unimportant because the arrest figures showed a similar fall in real terms. These showed that arrests fell from 2,609 a month to 1,898.

Mr Hague used the fall in stop and search arrests as an example of how the Macpherson report has hampered the work of police. The report accused the Met of "institutional racism" and raised concerns that police use stop and search powers against black people without good reason.

In a speech to the rightwing Centre for Policy Studies, Mr Hague pledged to overturn the tide of liberal "political correctness" which he said had brought the criminal justice system to its knees.

He went on: "The next Conservative government will take on and defeat the attitude of the condescending liberal elite that has never trusted the police and now wants us to believe they are all racists. The tragedy of the Lawrence family and the further urgent work that needs to be done building up trust between our ethnic communities and the police do not excuse the way in which the Macpherson report has been used to brand every officer and every branch of the force as racist, has contributed directly to a collapse of police morale and recruitment and has led to a crisis on our streets."

His remarks drew a withering response from Downing Street which branded the speech "desperate and disreputable". Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, said: "Having lost on the economy, lost on the big arguments in Europe, his shadow home secretary having made a complete hash of their approach on law and order ... he is just casting around to get himself noticed."

Sir William Macpherson denied his report had caused an increase in crime. "I believe the police up and down the country are to be highly congratulated in buckling down and learning lessons from the report and attempting to put matters right," he said.

The Police Federation offered Mr Hague support. Its chairman, Fred Broughton, said some officers did have a sense of vulnerability in dealing with minority ethnic suspects which was apparent with the "negative effect on crime reduction."

Tony Burden, president of the Association of Chief Police Officers, backed Macpherson: "It identified some important issues for the police service to tackle and we should not allow anything to divert us away from our determination to gain the confidence of the black community through fair and effective policing."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, welcomed her leader's promise to encourage more stop and search activities by the police, saying: "We should all take the attitude that if we are stopped that is a cause of gratitude not resentment."

But one former minister feared that after the Tories' recent fall in the polls, Mr Hague had decided to shore up hardcore voters on the right.

Tory officials maintained that Mr Hague was speaking for the "mainstream majority".

His speech coincided with Home Office research warning that the use of untargeted stop and search is one factor hampering police efforts to recruit black and Asian officers to their ranks.

webTitle: Republican victory fails to prevent market slide

fields.headline: Republican victory fails to prevent market slide
fields.standfirst:
No sign of 'Bush bounce' to dispel gloom

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: No sign of 'Bush bounce' to dispel gloom
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Stock markets in the United States and Europe fell sharply yesterday as investors shrugged off George Bush's victory in the American presidential election, focusing instead on growing gloom about the outlook for global economic growth.

Financial analysts said a Republican in the White House was positive for business in the long run. But share prices were hit by continued selling of technology stocks and profit warnings from two of America's big banks.

There was no "Bush bounce" for any stock market. In London, the FTSE-100 closed down 139.2 at 6263.8 and other European stock markets also finished lower.

Some Wall Street experts suggested that a Bush victory had been expected since Saturday's initial US supreme court decision, so confirmation of the actual result of an avowedly business-friendly president was not enough to improve sentiment. But even those companies that appear to have most to gain from a Bush administration remained unmoved yesterday. Mr Bush is expected to take a softer line on anti-competitive issues than the Clinton administration, yet shares in Microsoft, the software company found guilty of anti-trust abuses, failed to respond.

Big tobacco, oil and drug companies are all expected to benefit from a Bush administration, as is the dollar.

More worrying for the Bush team is the slowdown of the economy. Many big US companies, such as Hewlett Packard and Kodak, have issued warnings that they will make less money than expected and consumers are spending less.

With America's central bankers meeting next week, President-elect Bush will be hoping that they act to stave off a possible economic slowdown before he gets into the White House. The incoming administration will not want to be associated with a recession.

"Inflation at the wholesale level remains very subdued," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp. "This gives the Federal Reserve all the latitude it needs to respond to the slowdown in the US economy by cutting interest rates." When the Fed meets next week for the last time this year, it is expected to abandon its bias towards raising the cost of borrowing but few predict a reduction in the cost of borrowing until next year.

For foreign investors, the crucial job is the treasury secretary, who will be the face of the administration to the markets and will work with the financial ministers of other leading nations on economic policy and market issues.

Widely tipped for the job are Wall Street financiers such as the retired Chase Manhattan chairman Walter Shipley, the chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston's private equity group, Jack Hennessy, and the Paine Webber chairman, Donald Marron. However, the nature and narrowness of Mr Bush's victory are likely to stymie many of his business-friendly policies.

webTitle: High court says Bangladeshi coup leaders must hang

fields.headline: High court says Bangladeshi coup leaders must hang
fields.trailText: Bangladesh's high court cleared the way yesterday for the execution of 10 former army officers found guilty of the 1975 murder of the country's independence leader, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, and most of his family.
fields.body:
Bangladesh's high court cleared the way yesterday for the execution of 10 former army officers found guilty of the 1975 murder of the country's independence leader, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, and most of his family.

But the two-member high court panel was split over the guilt of five others who had also been convicted and sentenced to hang by a lower court two years ago. One judge upheld death sentences against them, while the second acquitted them for lack of evidence. Their fate will now be decided by a third high court judge.

News of the split decision angered supporters of the ruling Awami League and hundreds of angry activists immediately went on a rampage in the capital, Dhaka, damaging cars and throwing stones at police after they were prevented from entering the court premises.

The authorities deployed 2,000 extra police as they attempted to protect the judges' homes.

Legal experts said that given the importance of the case, involving the murder of the nation's founder, a decision could be expected shortly.

A quick disposal of the case, independent observers said, could help the nation move forward by putting at rest, once and for all, the bitter past that has haunted the country for so long.

Almost all the 15 officers were direct beneficiaries of the military coup that toppled the government of Sheikh Mujib 25 years ago.

They were rewarded with plum diplomatic jobs overseas until the slain leader's daughter, Sheikh Hasina, became prime minister in 1996.

The coup leaders were pampered by successive governments including the Bangladesh Nationalist party of the former prime minister Khaleda Zia.

They were not only given overseas assignments, but their actions were indemnified by parliament.

Of the 15, only four are now in custody in Dhaka, including the mastermind of the coup, retired Lieutenant Colonel Farukur Rahman.

The rest, including the five officers whose fate is uncertain, are in hiding overseas. And they are unlikely to return even if they are exonerated as long as the Awami League is in power. The guilty 10 are almost certain to appeal to the supreme court. If that fails, the country's president has the power to commute the death sentences.

Legal experts said the highest court was unlikely to reverse the judgement as the coup leaders have publicly boasted of their "heroic act". They have appeared on television claiming that they saved Bangladesh from tyranny and lawlessness that characterised the Mujib era in the early 1970s.

Months before his assassination, Sheikh Mujib had imposed one-party rule, and his critics accused him of corruption. But Sheikh Hasina has insisted that her father would have returned democratic rule.

Since coming to power in 1996, she has made it her mission to punish his killers and excavate a past that had been all but wiped from official history. Five years ago she turned the family home into a museum in honour of her father.

Some 2,000 visitors a day gaze reverently at the blood stains and bullet holes on the staircase where the president fell. A sign invites tourists to examine the pieces of her mother's brain embedded in the ceiling.

Sheikh Hasina's three brothers, including the youngest, 10-year-old Sheikh Russel, were also murdered, together with 11 other members of the family.

The prime minister, then a housewife, and her only other sister, Rehana, were out of the country on the night of the killings.

webTitle: Judges get a lesson in sex and gender

fields.headline: Judges get a lesson in sex and gender
fields.standfirst: Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: The assertions that homosexuality is not contageous and mothers who work full-time are not neglectful might seem like pretty obvious statements of the truth. Hardly worth repeating, in fact. Unless, that is, you belong to that overwhelmingly male, white, middle-aged or elderly group educated mainly at single-sex public schools and known in the past for dropping spectacular social blunders - judges.
fields.body:
The assertions that homosexuality is not contageous and mothers who work full-time are not neglectful might seem like pretty obvious statements of the truth. Hardly worth repeating, in fact. Unless, that is, you belong to that overwhelmingly male, white, middle-aged or elderly group educated mainly at single-sex public schools and known in the past for dropping spectacular social blunders - judges.

In a bid to rid the bench of outdated prejudices the latest chapters of the Equal Treatment Bench Book, launched yesterday by the Judicial Studies Board includes guidelines and advice designed to pre vent those embarrassing or offensive interventions.

The book will introduce judges for the first time to the minefields of gender and sexual orientation.

They are already well up to speed on race, which was covered by the first part of the bench book published last year. That section informed them that smoking cannabis was an important part of religious experience for Rastafarians, who treated it as a sacrament.

The chapter on gender acknowledges that most judges and lawmakers are men and "some argue that existing law continues to reflect belief about men's and women's roles that are no longer the norm".

For example, "one needs to be careful not to regard a woman who works full-time as a selfish mother or neglectful of her children. She may also carry the main responsibility for their care. Conversely, a man who stays at home to look after children is not lazy or incompetent."

The judge who branded a rape victim guilty of contributory negligence and the one who told the jury that "women who say no don't always mean no" have long since retired. But judges, it seems, still need reminding of a 1973 case in which it was held that "whereas every consent involves submission, mere submission is not of itself consent".

Although defendants in rape cases can no longer cross-examine the woman personally, the guide notes state: "The demeaning experience of cold, skilful and remorseless questioning by a detached advocate can be even worse."

Judges are told that rape trauma syndrome may make a victim appear calm and composed, masking her true feelings. So her demeanour when giving evidence is not a guide to her truthfulness. And "contrary to common belief, the victim of rape whose attacker was known to her will frequently suffer trauma for longer than if the attacker was a stranger".

Few judges are gay, so perhaps judges need to be informed that "nearly all homosexuals were brought up in heterosexual homes", and "there is no evidence that gay men are more likely to abuse children than heterosexual men".

Bench marks

 No reputable medical opinion now suggests that homosexuality is a catchable or pathological condition.

 A woman who works full-time is not to be regarded as a selfish or neglectful mother.

 Avoid words that imply an evaluation of the sexes, however subtle. For example, use "husband and wife", instead of "man and wife".

 Do not assume that the male in a family is the main breadwinner.

 Being lesbian or gay has nothing whatsoever to do with paedophile desire.

webTitle: Pakistan bid to silence "Kalashnikov culture"

fields.headline: Generals target arms bazaar
fields.standfirst: Pakistan bids to silence village's replica rocket launchers and copy Kalashnikovs
fields.trailText: Pakistan bids to silence village's replica rocket launchers and copy Kalashnikovs
fields.byline: Rory McCarthy in Darra Adam Khel
fields.body:
In Mohammed Siddique's workshop craftsmen will make you any gun that you want. Cheap Kalashnikov working copies are in constant demand although pump-action shotguns are the new favourite of tribal leaders in neighbouring Afghanistan.

For generations, Darra Adam Khel, a village caught in the steep valleys of Pakistan's federally administered but lawless tribal areas, has thrived as one of the world's largest unofficial arms markets.

Nowadays, Darra has become an embarrassment to a military regime desperate to dam the flood of weapons flowing through Darra. The army wants the workshops to stop making and selling working guns and instead make replicas for display.

"People need guns here," said Mr Siddique. "They have family feuds and they never forget if they are wronged. They will take revenge. You need a gun for protection."

Two of Mr Siddique's men sit beside him on the workshop floor, wrapping greased gun barrels in copies of the Financial Times, preparing to send them to a customer in nearby Peshawar. "God bless our home," says a sign above their heads.

"[Weapons are] the only source of income for these people. They have no agricultural land, no other source of money. It has been this way for generations," said Mr Siddique.

At the small shops lining the main road, a cheap Kalashnikov copy sells for 2,500 rupees (about £30), while a genuine one costs seven or eight times as much. Away from the street self-taught craftsmen copy working anti-aircraft guns, hand grenades, and rocket launchers.

Occasionally, a customer walks out into the road and cracks off a volley into the air. The poor quality steel can affect accuracy, and occasionally causes a barrel to explode.

Backpackers used to flock to Darra, eager to pick up a souvenir single-bullet pen pistol, but today, the area is almost off-limits to foreigners. It is local Pakistanis and Afghans who buy such wares now.

Many locals keep weapons at home, ostensibly for hunting but mostly for show, while religious leaders need armed bodyguards. Many weapons are used by militants fighting the Indian army in Kashmir.

Since weapons poured into Afghanistan via Pakistan in the 1980s, a "Kalashnikov culture" has thrived. But now the first attempts to enforce some control are being made.

"Weapons have become a status symbol in our society. We now have hundreds of thousands of guns, Kalashnikovs, assault rifles, everything," said Moinuddin Haider, Pakistan's interior minister and a former general. "In a civilised society you don't take these weapons to political rallies or religious gatherings or on marches."

Thousands of gun licences have been issued indiscriminately in the past 20 years. So, in February, Mr Haider banned new ones being issued and announced an amnesty for illegal guns, and banned their display in public. He says he wants to employ some of the Darra craftsmen in the state-run ordnance factories.

But Mr Haider's reach may not extend into Darra. It is a tribal area run by tribal elders and Darra's craftsmen are reluctant to leave a business that has lasted generations for jobs in state-controlled areas.

"Maybe the government will give jobs to five or 10 people but there are more than 3,000 people working in Darra," said Mr Siddique. It is also clear that men such as him would have a lot to lose if Darra was forced out of business.

"Today, I sent seven sacks of guns to Afghanistan - pump-action shotguns. Each sack had 30 guns. In a year, I make more than 3,000 shipments to Afghanistan or Iran," he said.

webTitle: Government extends emergency flood aid

fields.headline: Government extends emergency flood aid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The government yesterday extended emergency flood aid, introduced for the October and November crisis, to cover the new spate of swamped houses and drowned roads.
fields.body:
The government yesterday extended emergency flood aid, introduced for the October and November crisis, to cover the new spate of swamped houses and drowned roads.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, guaranteed 100% grants to meet the bill for temporary rehousing, school closures and other "exceptional" costs, as 15 severe flood warnings were imposed across the country.

Much the biggest victim of the merciless weather sat sideways across a Lincolnshire river last night, a cargo ship carrying 27,000 tonnes of diesel fuel which was caught by squalls as she tried to manouevre to enter the inland port of Sutton Bridge.

Tugs were last night trying to free the Antiguan-registered Lagik, which has started to take in water through cracks in her hull, after ramming the bank of the river Nene.

The environment agency gave a pessimistic forecast for river levels in the Severn valley, warning that floods could reach four inches higher than last month's peak. A spokesman said high tides from the Bristol Channel, persistent rain and saturated water meadows were combining to cause rapid rises in the Severn.

Monitoring of the river suggests that the Tewkesbury area will see a 15ft 4in peak, compared to 15ft in November, and in Gloucester a rise to 14.7ft compared to 14.4ft last month.

Flooding is also expected to persist along the Great Western railway route to the south west, where stretches of track between Swindon and Bristol, and between Taunton and Exeter, are under water.

The latest storms have claimed at least six lives, and two more were provisionally added yesterday. Police called off their search for Danny Grimley, 19, who fell into the swollen river Irwell in Manchester on Tuesday. And the German master of the Stuttgart Express container vessel is missing, believed drowned, after being swept off the deck in force 10 gales off Lands End.

The National Farmers' Union is pitching for extra emergency funding by announcing a national audit of flood and storm damage to winter crops, many of which cannot survive more than three weeks' inundation. The report will go to the Ministry of Agriculture, which is liaising with the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

Yesterday's package from Mr Prescott offered full reimbursement of flooding costs to all local authorities beyond the 0.2% of total council budget.

The aid was originally set at 85% of costs, but the government said it was impressed by local councils' response to the crisis.

webTitle: Leader: Hague's comments on the Macpherson report

fields.headline: The Tories cave in
fields.standfirst:
When you are desperate, anything goes Mr Hague

Special report: Stephen Lawrence
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: In what one Tory MP declared would be "the most important speech on crime in a decade", William Hague called yesterday for a honest debate on law 'n' order.
fields.body:
In what one Tory MP declared would be "the most important speech on crime in a decade", William Hague called yesterday for a honest debate on law 'n' order. He then proceeded to string together a breathtaking collection of dishonest facts, misrepresentations and plain lies. In his desperation to cash in, he even fouled up his figures and later had to correct them. His most insidious claim was the suggestion that the Macpherson report on the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence had "branded" every Metropolitan police officer a racist. The tabloids - and the Daily Telegraph - will love it. As in earlier moments when he has run into trouble, Mr Hague adopted the tabloids' agenda and then sat back awaiting their adulation. He did not even have to wait for the Sun's. Leaks of the speech ensured that the Sun was salivating even before it was delivered.

As yesterday's leaks predicted, Mr Hague zeroed in on Macpherson's conclusion that the Met was suffering from "institutional racism". This, he claimed, had "contributed directly to a collapse of police morale and recruitment". There was no excuse for branding every officer a racist. But as Mr Hague must know, institutional racism means no such thing. There are three forms of racism: overt and intentional; disguised but deliberate; unintentional but adverse. Institutional racism is as much to do with the third as with the first two. This was clearly explained by Macpherson. Only the mischievous would misinterpret it.

Next came a dishonest link between the fall in stop and searches in London and the rise in street robberies in the country. Long before Macpherson, the Met was concerned by the disproportionate use of stops of black people - five times the rate for whites. Even before the report's publication, the Met had introduced more effective pilot schemes that reduced the number of black searches. The idea that searches stop street robberies is absurd. Certainly they pick up petty drug users - 60% of all stops find cannabis - but there is no way they can disclose what is in a suspect's mind. As for the impact on arrests, they only account for 10%.

Then came the stale old police numbers game. True, police numbers have gone down under Labour, but the start of the dip began - and continued for four years - under the Tories. And as yesterday's Home Office statistics show, they have started to climb again. Thankfully, there never was a golden era of a bobby on every corner. That would have been a waste of manpower. They would have had to wait 35 years to catch a burglar. Numbers at present are 25% higher than 25 years ago. But much more important than crude numbers is police efficiency. Belatedly, this is improving. Mr Hague made no reference to the huge drop in burglary (21%) and car crime (16%) achieved by better locks and bars.

To his credit, Charles Clarke, the police minister, conceded yesterday that Macpherson had affected morale. Which service would not have been hurt by such a damning indictment? But the police have moved on. The Met has accepted Macpherson. The chief police officers have accepted it. In the words of their 1998 chairman: racism is like alcoholism -"you can't do anything about your problem until you acknowledge it". On the day Macpherson was published , Mr Hague seemed to have accepted the report with his ringing declaration: "We must all learn the lessons of what went wrong." But since then the Telegraph and tabloids have mounted a backlash. Mr Hague's cave-in before them is a testimony to his weakness.

webTitle: Woman put her baby son in oven

fields.headline: Woman put her baby son in oven
fields.trailText: An woman has been jailed for five years for killing her month-old son by putting him in a microwave oven and turning it on.
fields.body:
An woman has been jailed for five years for killing her month-old son by putting him in a microwave oven and turning it on.

"I still love my son and I will always love my son," Elizabeth Renee Otte, 20, told a court in New Kent, Virginia. "I can honestly say that I can't remember doing this, if I did." Otte, who has epilepsy, has seizures that are often followed by blackouts which can last for up to 50 minutes.

Relatives told police that she appeared detached from her son but there were no signs that she wanted to harm him.

She had stopped medication when pregnant and had suffered more than 50 seizures before and since the birth.

Otte was charged with involuntary manslaughter and said that, while she did not admit guilt, she accepted there was enough evidence to convict. Judge John Alderman said: "It is possible that this child's death was a tragic accident."

webTitle: Australia arrests Nazi war suspect

fields.headline: Australia arrests Nazi war suspect
fields.trailText: Australia yesterday warned that the extradition of the alleged Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs to Latvia for trial could take up to two years.
fields.body:
Australia yesterday warned that the extradition of the alleged Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs to Latvia for trial could take up to two years.

Mr Kalejs, 87, who left Britain in January, was arrested at his Melbourne home on Wednesday after Australia received an official extradition request from Latvia, where he faces charges of genocide and war crimes.

Australia's justice minister Amanda Vanstone, said that the case could take up to two years if the alleged commander of a Nazi concentration camp and suspected member of a Latvian death squad sought a series of appeals.

Mr Kalejs, of Latvian origin but granted Australian citizenship in 1957, appeared before Melbourne magistrates court, where he was stripped of his passport before being released on bail to reappear on January 25.

Aivars Saulitis, of the Latvian Relief Society, part of Melbourne's close-knit Latvian community which has been sheltering the suspected war criminal, said Mr Kalejs was too senile to defend himself in court. "He can't hear properly or make much sense," Mr Saulitis was reported as saying.

Lawyers for Mr Kalejs argue he is too sick to travel and stand trial in the Latvian capital, Riga.

Mr Kalejs had been living in a Leicestershire retirement home after he was deported from Canada in 1997 and from the US three years earlier.

His arrest in Australia follows the recent signing of an extradition treaty between Australia and Latvia.

The Baltic state has spent most of this year preparing a case against Mr Kalejs, after appealing for international help in compiling a dossier of evidence. In September, Latvian prosecutors formally accused him of being a guard at the Salaspils concentration camp near Riga.

Mr Kalejs has admitted he served alongside officers from the notorious Arajs Kommando, a Latvian unit responsible for the deaths of 30,000 Jews and Gypsies during the Nazi occupation of Latvia from 1941 to 1944. But he claims he was studying at university when the killings occurred.

webTitle: Turkey blocks Nato deal on EU force

fields.headline: Turkey blocks Nato deal on EU force
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Turkey was blocking plans for the European Union's rapid reaction force last night by refusing to allow it to use Nato equipment in a future crisis.
fields.body:
Turkey was blocking plans for the European Union's rapid reaction force last night by refusing to allow it to use Nato equipment in a future crisis.

Alliance foreign ministers, meeting in Brussels, were struggling to issue a final communique after Ankara rejected pleas from Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, to withdraw objections to crucial arrangements between the fledgling EU force and Nato. Usually the content of end-of-year communiques is settled well in advance.

Bulent Ecevit, the Turkish prime minister, had earlier received a personal appeal from President Bill Clinton.

Turkey, a key member of Nato, is doggedly blocking "assured access" to Nato assets in an attempt to win full participation in EU military decision-making - despite not being a member of the union.

"Turkey has a particular concern in that it wants access to planning capabilities to be on a case-by-case rather than an assured basis," Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said.

Turkey has a difficult relationship with the EU, which has refused it membership for more than 30 years. It is worried that the planned 60,000-strong European force could operate in Cyprus or the Aegean, where Turkey is in conflict with Greece.

"What the Turks actually want is a kind of occasional membership of the EU," said one diplomat. "And that's just not possible."

Mrs Albright made clear why the US wanted assured access: "This is not a gift from Nato to the EU. Rather, it is in our own interest to avoid duplication and enable the EU to focus on improving capabilities in the field."

And in comments interpreted as a message to France, which has sent mixed signals about the autonomy of the European force from Nato, she warned: "In this effort, there is no room for rivalry, jealousy or complacency. The stakes are simply too high and the consequences of a failure to cooperate would weaken Nato, the EU and Europe as a whole."

French diplomats complained that France was being used as a "whipping boy" because Nato was bogged down in disputes over what terms to agree with the EU.

Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary-general, said he was confident that the US and Europe would not drift apart under President George W Bush.

"There is no danger of decoupling taking place," he said. "The Europeans are building capabilities they didn't have before. European defence and Nato are two sides of the same coin. The grand bargain for Europe is access to Nato assets."

webTitle: Sainsbury expected to announce sale of Homebase

fields.headline: Cemented Sainsbury expected to announce sale of Homebase
fields.trailText: Supermarkets group J Sainsbury is expected to announce today the sale of its DIY subsidiary Homebase to Schroder Ventures, the private equity firm.
fields.body:
Supermarkets group J Sainsbury is expected to announce today the sale of its DIY subsidiary Homebase to Schroder Ventures, the private equity firm.

Industry sources said Schroder was buying about 85% of Homebase for up to £800m, valuing the entire group at about £940m.

Richard Perks, senior analyst at the consultancy Retail Intelligence, said if the speculation was correct the terms of the deal would be disappointing.

"What Homebase needs is a partner willing to put money in, but this would effectively be a management buyout," he said.

French retailer Leroy Merlin was rumoured to have been in talks with Sainsbury about a possible joint venture, but negotiations with its owners, the Mulliez family, collapsed.

The sale follows Focus Do it All's acquisition of Wickes and Great Mills, and confirms that Britain's DIY retail sector is rapidly consolidating.

Schroder is expected to retain the Homebase management team, led by managing director Kate Swann, who has a strong marketing and retail background and is said to enjoy a good rapport with colleagues.

The sale of Homebase is crucial to allow the DIY chain the investment it needs to compete with Kingfisher's B&Q and to provide the supermarket group with more firepower to invest in its food business which has been losing market share.

Retail Intelligence estimates B&Q has a 23% share of the DIY market with Duke Street Capital's Focus Do It All in second place with 16% and Homebase trailing in third with about 13%.

Homebase is placed seventh in Europe while B&Q's Castorama joint venture is the clear market leader.

Sainsbury refused to comment on the timing of the announcement but said last month it expected to announce a deal before Christmas. Analysts say disposing of Homebase will allow the supermarket group to concentrate on its core business.

&#149 Sainsbury's shares were up 9p at 400p by the close.

webTitle: Euronext seeks market listing

fields.headline: Euronext seeks listing
fields.trailText: An alliance of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels stock markets intends to seek its own market listing next year in an attempt to take a leading role in any mergers among exchanges.
fields.body:
An alliance of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels stock markets intends to seek its own market listing next year in an attempt to take a leading role in any mergers among exchanges.

The Euronext grouping of markets managed to complete its alliance earlier this year while the London Stock Exchange and the Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt failed to cement their plans.

Jean-François Theodore, the head of the Paris exchange, told reporters: "We will try to list Euronext as soon as possible.

"We must first present consolidated accounts for the year 2000 but a reasonable timetable could be the second part of the first half, market conditions permitting."

Euronext's plans for a stock market flotation follow the decision taken earlier this week by the Deutsche Börse to proceed with its share sale.

The German exchange's stock market flotation had been delayed by the difficulties encountered with its planned merger with the London market.

The LSE has indicated that it, too, might one day seek a stock market listing although it is far from clear when it intends to proceed with such a move.

The LSE, which is being courted by the US hi-tech market Nasdaq, is also regarded as a potential partner for Euronext.

Mr Theodore indicated yesterday that he expected the LSE to play a pivotal role in any consolidation in Europe.

"The LSE has some strategic thinking to do ... But European consolidation is not conceivable without London playing a prominent role in it," Mr Theodore said.

Since the OM exchange of Sweden began its unsuccessful bid for the LSE earlier this year, the London market has been the subject of rumours about its future.

The OM bid forced abandonment of the London-Frankfurt merger and the LSE has since turned down an approach by Nasdaq.
fields.bodyText: An alliance of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels stock markets intends to seek its own market listing next year in an attempt to take a leading role in any mergers among exchanges. The Euronext grouping of markets managed to complete its alliance earlier this year while the London Stock Exchange and the Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt failed to cement their plans. Jean-François Theodore, the head of the Paris exchange, told reporters: "We will try to list Euronext as soon as possible. "We must first present consolidated accounts for the year 2000 but a reasonable timetable could be the second part of the first half, market conditions permitting." Euronext's plans for a stock market flotation follow the decision taken earlier this week by the Deutsche Börse to proceed with its share sale. The German exchange's stock market flotation had been delayed by the difficulties encountered with its planned merger with the London market. The LSE has indicated that it, too, might one day seek a stock market listing although it is far from clear when it intends to proceed with such a move. The LSE, which is being courted by the US hi-tech market Nasdaq, is also regarded as a potential partner for Euronext. Mr Theodore indicated yesterday that he expected the LSE to play a pivotal role in any consolidation in Europe. "The LSE has some strategic thinking to do ... But European consolidation is not conceivable without London playing a prominent role in it," Mr Theodore said. webTitle: Chase issues profits warning

fields.headline: Chase issues profits warning
fields.standfirst: Announcement of 5,000 job losses shocks market
fields.trailText: Chase Manhattan, the world's second largest bank, after Citigroup, yesterday shocked the markets with a profits warning and the announcement of 5,000 job losses as a result of its recent $30bn (£21bn) purchase of JP Morgan.
fields.body:
Chase Manhattan, the world's second largest bank, after Citigroup, yesterday shocked the markets with a profits warning and the announcement of 5,000 job losses as a result of its recent $30bn (£21bn) purchase of JP Morgan.

The warning, blamed on higher costs and weaker markets, prompted a sharp sell-off of US shares amid broader worries about an economic slowdown.

Investment bankers and administrative staff are expected to bear the brunt of the job cuts, which represent about 5% of the group's total worldwide workforce.

At the time of their merger in September, the two Wall Street banks refused to specify how many people would be sacked. Many employees at the two banks and Robert Fleming, the British bank bought by Chase earlier this year, have already left the group.

At the same time as paying for redundancies, the combined group has been forced to offer generous bonuses to keep its most valuable staff.

A joint statement issued by Chase and JP Morgan yesterday blamed "competitive pressures on compensation" as well as accounting overlaps at Flemings for the higher costs in the fourth quarter of this year.

The higher expenses, combined with weaker markets, meant earnings would be "substantially lower" than expected in the period, the group warned.

A round of mergers over the past year has put many financial services firms in a state of flux with a handful of key bankers able to demand record sums as a loyalty bonus. Employees are told the value of their bonuses before Christmas at most banks, including JP Morgan.

The Chase generosity might not prevent defections, however. One headhunter said he expected more departures at JP Morgan once bankers were awarded their first year-end bonus at the end of this month.

So far, the bank has avoided the sort of walk-outs that have bedevilled the merger of Credit Suisse First Boston and DLJ.

Yesterday's announcement also blamed a crunch in the world's currency markets, wider credit spreads and a decline in trading for the group's woes. However, it tried to ease concerns about its exposure to bad debts by announcing that its credit portfolios were "performing relatively well".

Shares in JP Morgan fell about 7% to just over $154 at midday in New York, helping to drag down the Dow Jones Industrial Average by 139 points. Shares in Chase fell almost 6% soon after the announcement.

Analysts were cheered by the news that the group expected to save more money from the merger than expected. The company has increased its expected cost savings estimate from $1.9bn to $3bn over two years.

The combined firm also expected one-time costs of the merger of $3.2bn, largely to pay for employee severance and retention packages.

The collapse of the hi-tech market in the US has hurt the performance of Chase Capital Partners, which invests in start-up or fledgling technology-driven companies.

The division has lost more than $300m in the value of its portfolio because of the downturn.

webTitle: Secret tape links leader to headless corpse

fields.headline: Secret tape links leader to headless corpse
fields.standfirst:
Ukrainian president accused of ordering murder of journalist

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Ukrainian government is shuddering under the weight of a mounting corruption scandal, involving the president Leonid Kuchma, a series of secretly taped foul-mouthed conversations and a headless corpse, believed to be that of a missing journalist.
fields.body:
The Ukrainian government is shuddering under the weight of a mounting corruption scandal, involving the president Leonid Kuchma, a series of secretly taped foul-mouthed conversations and a headless corpse, believed to be that of a missing journalist.

A parliamentary committee spent yesterday attempting to wade through a mire of allegations to establish the truth at the heart of the case.

They were examining the testimony of a former presidential bodyguard who claimed to have placed a digital tape recorder under the president's sofa, recording conversations in which Mr Kuchma allegedly ordered senior officials to dispose of the journalist.

These tapes were made public by the head of the opposition Socialist party, Oleksandr Moroz, who described them as irrefutable evidence linking Mr Kuchma to the disappearance of Georgy Gongadze, the editor of a Ukrainian internet newspaper which focused on corruption.

The president has denied that it is his voice on the tape and has initiated a slander action. "A large-scale provocation is taking place," a spokesman quoted Mr Kuchma as saying.

Dutch experts say the tapes do not appear to have been edited or tampered with, although no one has been able to prove that the voice belongs to the president.

Mr Gongadze disappeared on September 16. Amid growing pressure for a thorough investigation, Mr Kuchma said he would oversee the case himself but no breakthroughs have been made.

The former security service officer, Major Mykola Melnichenko, said he began bugging the president after becoming dismayed by the abuses of power he witnessed in the top levels of government. He said he hoped to "stop this regime's criminal activity". He is in hiding abroad.

On the tapes, a voice similar to the president's can be heard discussing in crude language the best way to get rid of "the bastard" Mr Gongadze. There is no discussion in the tapes of murder and eventually they opt for a kidnap operation.

"I'm telling you, dispose of him; throw him out. Give him to the Chechens... [indecipherable] and then ransom him," the voice orders. "Strip him, shit, leave him without his pants. Let him sit. Get it done simply, shit."

A headless, disfigured corpse was found near Kiev on November 3. Investigators said it was impossible to identify the body because the head could not be found and its hands had been treated in acid to remove the fingerprints.

But Mr Gongadze's family are convinced the body is his; jewellery belonging to him is said to have been found with the corpse and an x-ray to his left hand revealed traces of shrapnel - he injured the hand when he worked as a war correspondent.

Mr Kuchma has accused his opponents of trying to trigger a national crisis, just as international attention focuses on Ukraine for today's closure of the Chernobyl nuclear plant. He has also claimed that the whole affair has been orchestrated by western secret services, alarmed by the new bonds Ukraine is forging with Russia.

Other commentators have suggested that Gongadze's death may have been ordered by powerful business figures, damaged by reports in his Ukrainska Pravda.

Alexander Lavrinovich, the head of the parliamentary commission investigating the disappearance, said: "The remains of the body were brought to Kiev in the middle of November and we still don't have a positive identification - an unusually long time.

"No one has revealed what kind of analyses are being carried out and how much longer the process will continue for, which undermines one's confidence in the whole process.

"We are also concerned that no official examination of the tapes has been conducted; this is the responsibility of the prosecutors' office, which has been sent the tapes; we don't even know whether they intend to do this."

webTitle: Swiss corporate raider turns on Sweden's weathiest family

fields.headline: Corporate raider turns on Sweden's Wallenburg family
fields.trailText: Swiss corporate raider Martin Ebner, renowned for shaking up his country's main banking groups, has turned his attention to the Wallenbergs, Sweden's wealthiest family.
fields.body:
Swiss corporate raider Martin Ebner, renowned for shaking up his country's main banking groups, has turned his attention to the Wallenbergs, Sweden's wealthiest family.

Ebner's BZ Group announced yesterday that it had gained control of 5.1% of voting rights and 3.7% of the ordinary shares in the Wallenberg's Investor group, which owns stakes in several large companies, including telecoms business Ericsson and pharmaceuticals group AstraZeneca. BZ said it hoped to encourage a change in the shareholder structure of the Swedes' empire.

Ebner is renowned for taking significant stakes in companies and insisting their management increase shareholder returns, including by merger or acquisition. He was instrumental in engineering the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and its rival Swiss Banking Corporation.

Kurt Schiltknecht, a BZ board member, said it was attracted by the combination of a strong discount on the asset value of big companies where Investor has shares, as well as the drop in telecommunications share prices this year.

"If you can buy into these companies with a discount of 30% on asset value and you know Investor looks after its holdings, you can expect good returns," Mr Schiltknecht said.

BZ expects Investor's head, Percy Barnevik, to push for a single share structure or a buy-back scheme in the coming year. Either of these would be likely to lift the value of BZ's stake. "Our group has some know-how to handle holdings and shareholder value," Mr Schiltknecht said.

The 3.7% shareholding in Investor is partly held indirectly by BZ's Speciality Vision investment company, which seeks to take advantage of short-term price variations by turning around undervalued companies. Speciality's chairman, Johan Bjökman, is Swedish.

Mr Ebner 's attempts to promote shareholder value have not always won him friends, and Credit Suisse and Roche have resisted attempts by the banker to take a seat on their boards.

Mr Schiltknecht said BZ had no immediate plans for the Swedish company.

He acknowledged that Ericsson, part of Investor AB, became a more attractive proposition after recent drops in telecommunications share prices. "We thought that [telecommunication] stocks were overvalued and until now we were very hesitant."

webTitle: At this price?  Leeds Sporting

fields.headline: At this price?  Leeds Sporting
fields.trailText: While Leeds United fans are busy cheering on their club's latest record signing, defender Rio Ferdinand, the market yesterday gave its somewhat cooler assessment of the £18m footballer.
fields.body:
While Leeds United fans are busy cheering on their club's latest record signing, defender Rio Ferdinand, the market yesterday gave its somewhat cooler assessment of the £18m footballer.

It may be too early - both in sporting and financial terms - to judge Ferdinand's long-term value, but analysts have pointed out that at £18m he represents more than a third of parent company Leeds Sporting's market capitalisation of £46m. As such, he is too big gamble for some investors, it emerged yesterday.

Sporting's share price fell 3.8% to 12.75p at the close, after two investors are thought to have sold "mid-sized stakes" in the company. Barclays Global Investors disposed of all of its 4m shares in the company. The other shareholder was not named.

"I'm not alarmed," Sporting's financial director, Stephen Harrison, told reporters. But it is understood that, along with the premiership club's chairman, Peter Ridsdale, he immediately bought more than 2.5m of the shares to bolster the price.

Mr Harrison denied that the disposals reflected investor concern about the amount paid for Ferdinand. "We've spoken to each of our major shareholders and we're not getting that mes sage," he insisted. Virginie Lannevere, a leisure analyst at Sporting's house broker, HSBC Investment Bank, pointed out that team manager David O'Leary's plans to invest in a number of players had been known by the market for some time.

She suggested that the reason for investors pulling out of the football sector in general was that most clubs were fundamentally unsuited to the stock market. Asked if Sporting share price reflected the company's fundamental value, she said: "Of course not. Nobody has the slightest idea of the club's fundamental value."

With the uncertainties over the rules governing player transfers adding to investor caution across the sector, shares in Sporting should be sold.

webTitle: Clinton gives welcome to Putin pardon for US spy

fields.headline: Clinton gives welcome to Putin pardon for US spy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin moved swiftly to defuse a diplomatic row with George W Bush's incoming American administration yesterday by issuing a pardon to the convicted US spy Edmond Pope.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin moved swiftly to defuse a diplomatic row with George W Bush's incoming American administration yesterday by issuing a pardon to the convicted US spy Edmond Pope.

The pardon was granted as soon as Mr Putin was legally able to issue it - and arrived just a few hours after it became clear that Mr Bush would be the new American president. The US government had vigorously condemned Mr Pope's 20-year sentence in a hard labour prison.

"Being guided by principles of humanity, taking into account the health condition of the convict and his personal appeal, and based on the high level of relations between the Russian Federation and the United States of America, I order the pardon of Pope, Edmond Dean," the decree stated.

The pardon came through in the early hours of Thursday morning, but prison guards waited until Mr Pope woke up before telling him he was free. A spokesman for the Russian security services said the American left Moscow's notorious Lefortovo high-security jail in good health, and thanked staff for maintaining prison conditions to an international standard.

A source close to Mr Pope, however, commented that the businessman had complained that his five cellmates had often eaten all of his food and occasionally also ate his supply of tablets.

Mr Pope, who has lost two teeth and about 25 pounds as a result of poor diet during his eight-month incarceration, was flown to Germany where he was undergoing health checks last night. His family had expressed repeated concern that the rare form of bone cancer from which he suffers had returned. Later he was expected to fly back to America, to visit his terminally ill father.

Responding to the news, President Bill Clinton reiterated his conviction that Mr Pope's sentence had been unfair. "I welcome today's release _ and appreciate President's Putin's decision to pardon him," a written statement said. "Mr Pope's ordeal was unjustified. It is fortunate that humanitarian considerations prevailed in the end."

The White House national security adviser, PJ Crowley, said relations between the two countries would improve as a result of the release.

"It did have an impact on the relationship. It was something the president brought up repeatedly in their meetings this year and obviously it's something that President Putin has now put behind us."

Mr Pope, 54, made only brief comments as he left Moscow. "On the one hand I am glad, on the other hand I am sorry that all this happened," he told state television. "I did not want to harm Russian-US relations."

His lawyer, Pavel Astakhov, said Mr Pope expressed affection for Russia and its citizens as he departed and said he hoped to return to the country.

His mood on arrival at a military base in Germany was more elated. Wearing a blue hospital smock and waving an American flag, he shouted to reporters from the balcony of the barracks hospital: "It's great to be back in the real world. It's great. I feel good."

The former navy intelligence officer last week became the first western citizen to be convicted of spying in Russia since the end of the cold war and the first US citizen found guilty of espionage in Moscow for 40 years.

He had denied the charges, which centred on an accusation that he had tried to obtain classified plans for a high-speed Russian military torpedo. Mr Pope claimed that the material he was researching was freely available.

His supporters claimed that the entire trial process had been biased in favour of his prosecutors, the Federal Security Service. A presidential commission recommended clemency soon after the verdict was announced.
