webTitle: How Hague mugged Macpherson

fields.headline: How Hague mugged Macpherson
fields.standfirst:
Tory claims that report on Lawrence killing inhibits policing fail to match facts

Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: Tory claims that report on Lawrence killing inhibits policing fail to match facts
fields.body:
William Hague's claim

"The way in which the Macpherson report has been used to brand every officer and every branch of the force as racist, has contributed directly to a collapse of police morale and recruitment, and has led to a crisis on our streets."

Analysis

The Macpherson report did not brand every police officer as racist. It said the Metropolitan police was infected with "institutional racism". This it defined as a "collective failure of an organisation to provide a professional service to people because of their colour, culture or ethnic origin. It can be seen in processes, attitudes and behaviour which amounts to discrimination through unwitting prejudice, ignorance, thoughtlessness and racist stereotyping which disadvantage minority ethnic people ...We do not accept that a finding of institutional racism means all officers are racist." Recommendation 60 of the Macpherson report said powers of stop and search "should remain unchanged."

Police numbers have been in decline since 1993 when they peaked at 127,000, long before the publication of the Macpherson report in February 1999. Figures published yesterday show that in most forces numbers have started to rise again. In London, they fell this year by 1,200 but the Police Federation has also cited housing costs, uncompetitive pay and low unemployment as factors.

William Hague's claim

"We have had 21 months to assess impact of the Macpherson report. In that period the use of stop and search powers by the Met police has fallen. In February 1999, the Met made 18,752 arrests following stop and searches. In September this year, new provisional figures show that has dropped by a third to just 11,858 arrests."

Analysis

Conservative Central Office was forced to admit last night that William Hague had quoted the wrong figures. The correct figures for the level of arrests are 2,609 in February 1999 and 1,898 in September 2000 - a fall of 711 and not the 7,000 fewer arrests portrayed by the Tory leader. The figures he quoted related to the number of times stop and search powers were used.

In addition, the Metropolitan police say the record shows "improving statistics in relation to stop and search". In comparing December 1998 to December 1999 they note that the number of searches which were running at 300,000 a year had fallen by 38.23% but the arrest rate had improved from 14% to 16% as the tactic was targeted on those who were acting suspiciously or on the basis of intelligence. The Home Office also says it is not the number of stop and searches that is important but how they are used. The most common reason for arrest after being stopped on the street is that drugs have been found and yet drug offences have fallen in London in the past year. Macpherson did not recommend reducing use of stop and search powers; instead he said in order to combat discrimination against black and Asian people stops should be recorded and a written reason given by the officer.

William Hague's claim

"At the same time, street crime has soared - not just in London but around the country. This year's British Crime Survey shows robberies up 14%, muggings up 4% and violence against a stranger up 29%."

Analysis

Paul Wiles, Home Office research director, said yesterday there was no direct link between stop and search and street crime levels. Four studies of stop and search published last month said the evidence was that searches probably detect offenders for only a small proportion of all crimes but they can make a notable contribution to arrests. However, many arrests are for minor offences, such as possession of small amounts of cannabis. The Police Research Group also found that there was a small disruptive effect on criminal activities but little evidence that the practice deterred many criminals. Only one in 10 stops leads to an arrest.

William Hague's claim

"The people who are suffering most from the post-Macpherson collapse in police morale and the rise in street crime are members of the ethnic minority communities ... We will expect the police to use rigorously the powers [of stop and search] which they have been given to uphold the law and fight crime ... Political correctness will not be allowed to get in the way of law enforcement ... a disproportionate number of street robberies are committed by young black men, often against other black people, just as street violence and burglary tend to be committed by young white men."

Analysis

Criminal justice statistics repeatedly show that black and Asian communities suffer disproportionately from crime partly because they are concentrated on poor, inner city estates with the highest crime levels. Home Office research also confirms the different patterns of offending among black and white youths, partly due to more black youths being out on the streets. However, the Met police do not believe that stop and search is effective in reducing street robberies; instead they have launched intensive undercover surveillance operations to go after street gangs and muggers. No "politically correct" politician or police officer has recommended that stop and search powers should not be used. Indeed, both Tony Blair, Jack Straw, the home secretary, and the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, have urged constables to continue to use such powers.

Conclusion

William Hague has revived an argument - for the third time in a year - over claims from the Met police federation, the trade union, that the police had "retreated" from policing crime at the Notting Hill carnival, because they were under pressure to ignore black crime. Mr Hague's speech is a thinly coded repetition of the message purveyed by the Daily Telegraph and Daily Mail that "the liberal establishment" was somehow responsible for allowing black criminals to get away with it. The evidence shows Macpherson did not recommend reduction in the use of stop and search. Its use has fallen sharply but the Met says it is now used in a more targeted way and that surveillance operations are more effective in dealing with street muggings.

webTitle: It's spend, spend, spend in the shops

fields.headline: It's spend, spend, spend in the shops
fields.standfirst: Record sales confound the traditional whinge that shopkeepers face Christmas penury
fields.trailText: Record sales confound the traditional whinge that shopkeepers face Christmas penury
fields.body:
With only 10 days to go to Christmas, this is the time of year when Britain's retailers normally start to whinge about how tight-fisted consumers are being. Indeed, the pre-Christmas surveys from both the CBI and the British Retail Consortium carried their usual warnings about how the Scrooge-like behaviour of shoppers was threatening their members with penury.

Only when the official government figures for retail spending come out does it become apparent that at Christmas we tend to follow the "spend, spend, spend" philosophy of Viv Nicholson rather than Charles Dickens' famous character. Each year tends to beat the previous record.

Data released by the office for national statistics yesterday confirmed the familiar pattern, with retail sales volumes rising by 0.7% in November, against City expectations of a 0.2% gain. If consumers were keeping their purses closed, there was little evidence in the figures.

Nor was November simply a flash in the pan. In the latest three months, retail sales volumes are up 1.4% on the previous quarter and 4.5% ahead of the September to November period of 1999. Michael Saunders, economist at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said the year-on-year gain was close to the highest of the past decade.

What is more, the pick-up in spending was not the result of bargain-hunting shoppers taking advantage of deep discounting by retailers desperate to offload surplus stock. This has been the trend over the past 10 years, with consumers and retailers playing a cat-and-mouse game in which every attempt by stores to widen their profit margins is met with a buyers' strike.

However, in November prices actually went up slightly and consumers carried on buying. The non-seasonally adjusted deflator - an indication of price changes on the high street - rose slightly to minus 0.3% in November from a revised minus 0.4% in October. Had events followed their normal course, consumers would simply have sat on their hands in November and waited for panic-stricken retailers to bring forward their winter sales to the pre-Christmas period.

Although it is notoriously difficult to read the retail sales figures at the turn of the year because of the problems of seasonal adjustment of the raw data, yesterday's figures challenge the view that the economy is heading for a sharp slowdown, which would prompt an early cut in interest rates from the Bank of England.

Daniel Kaye, economist with Capital Economics, said: "Whatever pessimism has crept into business sentiment in recent months, there is little sign of consumers adjusting their expectations in the same way." He added that there was almost no evidence of the slowdown in private sector spending that the Bank's monetary policy committee has been waiting for to make room for the hefty planned increases in public spending over the next three years.

Further evidence that the economy is not as weak as some pundits suggest came from the CBI's monthly snapshot of manufacturing. This showed total orders were at their strongest since March 1998, with exports registering their best performance since the month after Labour was elected in May 1997.

Like retailers, manufacturers are responding to the healthier state of their order books by pushing up prices - a much-needed respite for some of them following several years in which margins have been ruthlessly squeezed by the strength of the pound. Ross Walker, analyst at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said: "It is ironic that, as economists fret about a global slowdown [and fall over each other in their rush to slash their interest rate forecasts], Britain's hard-pressed manufacturers are becoming more optimistic."

There are two ways of interpreting what is going on. Either yesterday's data are sending a false signal about the underlying state of the economy or the worries about the risk of a slowdown have been overdone.

With an election looming, the government would obviously prefer the more optimistic scenario. Labour's strategists, despite Tony Blair's big poll lead, would like a strong feel-good factor over the coming months. Wednesday's unemployment figures, which showed the eight-year downward trend in the jobless total levelling off, must have given them pause for thought. The number of people out of work and claiming benefit stands at 1.04m; Labour would dearly love it to dip below the million mark by polling day.

Now at least the government can take comfort from the fact that consumer confidence remains strong. The sting in the tail could be that interest rates might have to rise again before polling day to counter the attempt by retailers and manufacturers to widen their profit margins. However, in Labour's election war room an extra few pounds on the cost of a mortgage will no doubt be seen as preferable to the gloomier alternative of a sharp slowdown in economic growth and rising unemployment.

webTitle: What the papers say

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: US papers
fields.body:
US papers

New York Times

Having been in suspense for so long as to whose hand will be raised on January 20, the public now wants to see that person put both hands on the wheel.

Mr Bush must do what the supreme court failed to do in its crabbed decision. He has to endow a still slightly stunned electorate with a sense of completion, stability and rightness. Once the public sees that kind of progress from Mr Bush, they will press even the most recalcitrant Democrats to recognise his presidency as legitimate.

Washington Post

Mr Bush achieved his narrow victory in part by putting a softer face on his party - by his promise to be a uniter. It's a promise that will now be heavily tested. In tilting toward greater inclusiveness and a broader definition of public welfare, the president-elect did not so much abandon traditional party positions as rephrase them. In some ways he thereby did for the Republicans the reciprocal of what Bill Clinton did for the Democrats in 1992. As with Mr Clinton for eight years, so now with Mr Bush: a central question will be to what extent the change is cosmetic, to what extent real.

Chicago Tribune

Say this much for George W Bush: his margin of victory hasn't burdened him with high expectations in the eyes of his critics. Those who believe he's not up to the job expect his presidency to be nasty, brutish and short.

Los Angeles Times

It's time for small "d" democrats and small "r" republicans to stand up and be counted. Let Bush, Gore and the justices wait a little longer. Too late for that, you say? Then they are going to be waiting a lot longer for most voters' genuine respect.

Rest of the world

The Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan

The Republican party defined China as a "strategic competitor" in its election platform, which contrasted starkly with the Clinton administration's policy of engagement. Given this, we can assume that the new president may change his nation's foreign policy in a way that might affect Japan's security. For this reason, it is vital for Japan to pursue close talks with the Bush administration on security issues ...Tokyo and Washington must establish a more mature partnership.

Sovietskaya Rossia, Russia

Experience shows that we always have better relations - more stable, more healthy - with the Republicans than the Democrats. After the complete failure and bankruptcy of all the Yeltsin-Gore policies towards Moscow (its ties to Yeltsin), dubious relations between Gore and Chernomyrdin, the bombing of Serbia and now the failure of the American model in their own country - the Americans are losing their status as an idol both in the eyes of the Kremlin and of the majority of simple Russians.

Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Germany

Bush will not stand out as a "humanitarian interventionist" or adventurer. Instead, as a person who remains sceptical of peace missions, he will link the deployment of US troops to closely defined national interests.

Mr Bush, whose advisers make up for his lack of experience, will cause problems in areas that others see as priorities: international organisations, which he distrusts, and disarmament, that is to say, missile defence.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: The art of getting a head
fields.trailText: Science of Crime | Close and True | Trust Me
fields.body:
I felt my jaw drop. Much like the Montreal airport security staff when a human skull showed up on the x-ray of Kathy Reichs' hand luggage. It was facing forward, as if it knew where it was going. "Is that real?" they asked. She reassured them it was. They did not seem to enquire further. Kathy's travelling companions may be well-known. "I once carried a whole skeleton in a hockey bag."

She is an expert on old bones and Science of Crime (Channel 4) watched her work. "When a conventional autopsy is of no use, I tease what I can from bone." I was bearing up well enough until we reached the Anthropological Research Facility at Knoxville, Tennessee or, as it is known to its few friends, The Bone Farm. For 30 years some 300 human bodies have been left there to rot in three acres of woodland. All desire to see or even spell Tennessee left me just like that.

The Bone Farm is the pioneering project of Dr Bill Bass, a jovial old soul in a baseball cap and turquoise rubber gloves, who gave us the guided tour. "For the last 29 years I've looked at what happens to a body when it decays." I was reminded of Mrs Thatcher, who, while meeting the people, met a refuse collector. "And what do you collect?" she asked. "Refuse," he said, adding surreally, "and dead bodies". The lady rocked back momentarily on her Cuban heels. Then she said firmly "Well, someone's got to do it!"

Bill Bass does it. His manner, like Kathy Reichs', was down to earth. "If you have a body lying around with no clothes on, the maggots will leave the skin as an umbrella. The skin then will turn to leather." He tapped it like a little drum. Some of his bodies have a disconcerting tendency to slide downhill of their own volition. He threatens to spend the night in The Bone Farm, taking pot-shots at groundhogs.

You will be wondering where he gets 300 corpses. Some are unclaimed bodies. Some are donated either by the original owner or their relatives. Those conscientious and industrious cleaning teams, the insects, arrive in five waves corresponding to the five stages of decomposition, mop up all spillage and remove all perishable rags of flesh. And pathologists like Reichs can match the results against their cases.

She is also a detective story writer and seems to project onto her alter ego, a forensic pathologist called Temperance, the emotions she never shows herself ("I always have the feeling that the victim deserves something more passionate, more personal").

Close and True (ITV) is a very attractive legal series, wittily written and set in the grey grandeur of Newcastle. Robson Green, showing an energetic flair for comedy, is young, hot-headed and romantic. James Bolam is so jaundiced, he is recuperating in a mental hospital. ("I got married once. I never met a more miserable woman. I wasn't born like this, you know. This is all her. And the practice. And the dog." "Where is she now?" "The dog?" "No, the wife." "Aberystwyth.") Bolam seems to have played more parts in pyjamas than any other actor I know.

Green fought for a man's right to a bypass operation and won. But as his wife went into the hospital foyer to check on his progress, I heard myself think "Not behind glass. Women always scream behind glass." She screamed.

One of the bizarre spin-offs of Big Brother is Trust Me (Channel 4), a game show presented by Nick "Boo!" Bateman. It is set in a derelict factory in the East End. The walls, where there are walls, are leprous. The flooded floor is filthy and littered. If the squalid setting doesn't shred the nerves, at least it saves money. It was freezing. No dab of make-up had been wasted on Nick, who could have gone on as Rudolph without rehearsal.

In two prefabricated cabins, contestants tried to guess each other's trustworthiness. Male ballet dancers for instance v nightclub bouncers.

A small star turn was Roy's old mum. Haloed with an antimacassar, she confidingly described her bouncer son for the benefit of the increasingly sober ballet dancers. "He was a beautiful boy. He had naturally curly hair and everything but, through the fighting, it's made his nose collapse and it's spread across his face. He's got a false nose. Christmas Eve he ran into a hook, a meat hook, a big meat hook, and it ripped all his eyelids off. He used to have a lot of accidents like that. We'd say 'Oh, that boy!'"

Close and True (ITV) is a very attractive legal series, wittily written and set in the grey grandeur of Newcastle. Robson Green, showing an energetic flair for comedy, is young, hot-headed and romantic. James Bolam is so jaundiced, he is recuperating in a mental hospital. ("I got married once. I never met a more miserable woman. I wasn't born like this, you know. This is all her. And the practice. And the dog." "Where is she now?" "The dog?" "No, the wife." "Aberystwyth.") Bolam seems to have played more parts in pyjamas than any other actor I know. Green fought for a man's right to a bypass operation and won. But as his wife went into the hospital foyer to check on his progress, I heard myself think "Not behind glass. Women always scream behind glass." She screamed. One of the bizarre spin-offs of Big Brother is Trust Me (Channel 4), a game show presented by Nick "Boo!" Bateman. It is set in a derelict factory in the East End. The walls, where there are walls, are leprous. The flooded floor is filthy and littered. If the squalid setting doesn't shred the nerves, at least it saves money. It was freezing. No dab of make-up had been wasted on Nick, who could have gone on as Rudolph without rehearsal. In two prefabricated cabins, contestants tried to guess each other's trustworthiness. Male ballet dancers for instance v nightclub bouncers. A small star turn was Roy's old mum. Haloed with an antimacassar, she confidingly described her bouncer son for the benefit of the increasingly sober ballet dancers. "He was a beautiful boy. He had naturally curly hair and everything but, through the fighting, it's made his nose collapse and it's spread across his face. He's got a false nose. Christmas Eve he ran into a hook, a meat hook, a big meat hook, and it ripped all his eyelids off. He used to have a lot of accidents like that. We'd say 'Oh, that boy!'"

webTitle: TV: Pascal Wyse  on the art of televisual practical jokes

fields.headline: You've been framed
fields.standfirst: Channel 4's Candid Camera night tomorrow celebrates the art of the televisual practical joke. Some see the genre as satire at its best; others think it's just crass and degrading.  Pascal Wyse  looks at the arguments
fields.trailText: Channel 4's Candid Camera night tomorrow celebrates the art of the televisual practical joke. Some see the genre as satire at its best; others think it's just crass and degrading. Pascal Wyse looks at the arguments.
fields.body:
It only lasted a few seconds. But if you didn't have a television, it would have been worth buying one just to see it - the exquisite moment in which Noel Edmonds pooped in his own publicity dog dish, courtesy of Chris Morris and his Brass Eye show. There Noel was, in his own office, warning us of the effects of a made-up drug called cake, claiming that it affects a part of the brain called Shatner's bassoon. Welcome to the TV stitch-up, whose big brother is celebrated tomorrow night in Channel 4's Candid Camera evening.

Brass Eye was denounced by some critics as exploitative and sadistic - exactly the reasons why people loved Candid Camera. Since 1960, when Allen Funt, Candid Camera's creator, put his first proverbial banana-skin on the sidewalk of an unsuspecting New York public, we've been hooked.

There was a level of ingenuity and absurdity to the stitch-ups on the original show. A woman claims in a job interview that she's always being followed by a lady with a monkey on her head. The doubtful interviewer (the victim) tries tactfully to suggest that she should see someone about it. But when the woman goes out to the toilet and a lady arrives with a live monkey on her head, you can see the interviewer quite seriously questioning his own sanity - and even asking the interviewee which doctor she would go to.

The gags were often overly elaborate: a man sneezing down a telephone, while miles away the other caller is mysteriously sprayed by the other handset (taken - albeit disgustedly - as perfectly normal by the caller); diner stools that would suddenly telescope into the ground; cars with no engine, or ones which could split into two, each half going round an incredulous traffic cop; horses and postboxes that talked. Stars regularly helped out too - appearances by a young Woody Allen, Buster Keaton and Muhammad Ali.

These days, the popular television channels are stuffed with the cousins of the original Candid Camera. "Real" stuff like Police, Camera, Action where you can watch bank-robbers driving rather badly through fields. Or that ratings-rich area of programming where reality TV meets DIY stitch-up TV, scooping up everything from Blind Date to Big Brother. And one of the keys to the success of these shows - in this country, anyway - is that we know it'll all be OK in the end. When the family cat shuts itself in the microwave on You've Been Framed (and, more worryingly, dad is filming it), we're safe in the knowledge that the pet didn't boil in the bag and eventually emerged unscathed.

Examples from Candid Camera's international versions, however, reveal how the shock effects of TV framing have had to be cranked up. Even allowing for some national variations of taste (the Brazilians seem quite fond of framing you for murder in a toilet. Ha!), these clips show how the format has become an emotional snuff-movie.

"Smile, you're on Candid Camera!" might as well read "Smile, you're going to need a lifetime of psychiatric help, your baby's drowned and your grandma is in the spinal injuries unit!" People break down, fearing their lives are in danger, or are told that they've killed someone. An Italian TV presenter flying in a small plane watches in horror as the pilot falls out and a "terrified" cameraman (in reality, a qualified pilot) takes the controls.

"If I'd known she was going to fear for her life, I wouldn't have done it," remarks the director. He was clearly expecting a more philosophical reaction to the prospect of being put into a coffin by shovel. On another clip, where a celebrity is persuaded he's killed someone, the German director explains, "Our aim was to see him cry. That makes the people laugh."

Candid Camera knew how to prepare for a reaction and give it plenty of time to develop - the victim was the star. Dom Joly's Trigger Happy TV is a welcome return to the more surreal aspects of the show, but in some ways his performances - brave and sometimes inspiringly silly - outweigh the often stunned public response.

In Brass Eye, Chris Morris knew precisely how to use the media to fool the media and get his victims to perform. His creation of the made-up drug, cake, revealed how pundits are far too busy enjoying the fact that they're being asked for their opinion to think carefully about the question or their answer.

The paraphernalia that persuades them that it's all legitimate - cameras, set, researchers, logo, Morris's spot-on manner - is the very stuff that records the fatal garbage that falls from their mouths. (Ironically, the Gotcha! king himself, Noel Edmonds, was unable to see the funny side of getting a taste of his own medicine from Morris. Perhaps he should have checked whether there was a part of the brain called Shatner's bassoon before he read it to camera.)

But of course, none of us would fall for anything like that, would we? Who would take racing tips from a talking horse? Or be fooled by Ali G? Or believe a daft newspaper story? No, not us. Well, if you'll just take a look behind you...

 Candid Camera Night, tomorrow, from 9pm, Channel 4

webTitle: Advertising: What the Virgin Mobile ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Virgin Mobile ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Virgin Mobile ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: Two 30-something couples are exchanging Christmas presents. Finally it's "Michael"'s turn. His wife hands him a package, saying "Happy Christmas, Michael." He excitedly rips the wrapping off, then, plainly disappointed, says "What's this?" "It's a phone, Michael," she replies, but he says he wanted a Virgin Mobile. "I wanted cheap calls and no line rental. You get both with Virgin Mobile," he whines, then petulantly throws the gift on the floor. His friend tells him to calm down, but he explodes, attacking a nearby display of Christmas cards. "Calm down? That's how I feel inside!" he says. The endline is: "Spoil someone rotten..."

The jargon: This hilarious spot, which is the second in a pre-Christmas campaign, is aimed at telling folk that Virgin Mobiles are the perfect Christmas present because they offer both cheap calls and no line rental (most networks offer only one of these apparently).

Personality: Basically, everyone will be buying mobiles this Christmas. However, as this is Virgin, you are more likely, as with Virgin consumers generally, to be under 35 (rivals BT Cellnet and Vodafone tend to go for the more grown-up bracket).

Financial status: Five years ago only rich people could afford mobile phones. Now everyone can, so your "financial status" could be anything. Virgin's phones in fact range from a generally affordable £29.99 to a decidedly over-fancy Samsung M100 for £299.99.

Telling lifestyle detail: You probably just use your mobile for leisure purposes, to exchange text messages with your mates and organise a rendezvous down the pub rather than for irritating "I'm walking into the office" business reasons.

Other relevant data: The guy who so brilliantly plays Spoilt Michael is the actor Victor Maguire, of Bread and Goodnight Sweetheart fame. Word has it that in the third and final ad, airing on Boxing Day, he finally gets his phone.

webTitle: Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: In Search Of The Black Madonna | Jazz Legends
fields.body:
Bonnie Greer was raised in Chicago as a Roman Catholic and spent much of her childhood wondering why the icons were not darkly Semitic or, like her, black. She has recently been In Search Of The Black Madonna (11.0am, Radio 4), and found more of them than might be expected. The most famous, of course, is in Poland, but there's another in Notting Hill. It turns out to be smaller and paler than she remembered and acquired its complexion from years of being pickled in holy smoke.

Jimmy Smith occupies a unique place among Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3). Single-handedly he carved out a role for the Hammond electronic organ. He has, of course, had dozens of subsequent imitators but his remarkable talent held him constantly at the top of the charts. Many of his sessions were recorded on the Blue Note label, which far-sightedly allowed some tracks to roll on for 20 minutes or more.

webTitle: Food: Where to eat out in under 15 minutes

fields.headline: Quick bites
fields.standfirst: Where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.trailText: Where to eat out in under 15 minutes.
fields.body:
Bushmills Inn
9 Dunluce Street, Bushmills, Co Antrim.
Tel: 028-2073 2339

Not many people know this, but Bushmills has the world's oldest licensed whiskey distillery, and the village is by the Giant's Causeway. The Bushmills Inn, however, is worth any trek just by itself. There is the salmon snip, a thinly sliced, lightly grilled salmon fillet served with stir-fried vegetables and baby potatoes (£6.95); and seared lamb's liver on a bed of champ glorified by a caramelised onion gravy topped with deep-fried leeks (£6.90). To qualify for a quick bite, you had better stick to a bowl of brotchan (described as "aitin' and drinkin' soup") and a basket of home baked breads, all yours for £2.25.

webTitle: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Channel 5 - you've gotta love it. Even if you don't watch it, you should look at the listings just to get a flavour of what you're missing. Recent favourites include Stars In Their Bras and Blokes, Birds & Bikes. Now we hear that the channel is bringing us its own twist on the gameshow madness that has swept ITV and BBC1 - sort of.

Who Wants 2 B Sillionaire is only a pilot at the moment so we don't know if we'll be treated to a lengthy run of the show. But it features an unknown presenter, one Chuck Thomas, who spends his time seeking crazy ways to be silly on air. Geddit? But perhaps the most alarming thing about the show is that it's being executive-produced by Timmy Mallet. Now there's a reason to take a holiday in February.

Writing about television is always a fraught business. Not least if you're actually working in the business as well as observing it. Celebrated critic Victor Lewis-Smith found himself facing just such a conflict-of-interests dilemma earlier this month when his production company's Omnibus documentary about Dudley Moore aired on BBC1. Lewis-Smith trailed the programme in his column in The Mirror two days before the show went out, opining: "It's a bittersweet tribute to the life, music and comedy of one of Britain's greatest talents." He also promised an exclusive article with a "behind-the-scenes look" at the making of the programme, which duly appeared in The Mirror - handily, on the very day the programme went out.

And the programme was indeed "bittersweet", featuring shots of Dud, suffering with progressive supranuclear palsy, sitting (on a beach, oddly) listening to one of his earliest compositions being played for him.

So much for the show. But what of the reviewer? Could the man writing in The Mirror have been the same Victor Lewis-Smith who's on record as saying "I never have, nor ever will, review any Associated-Rediffusion programmes." No, didn't think so.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast

webTitle: Food on the net

fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.standfirst: www.christmasrecipe.com
fields.trailText: christmasrecipe.com
fields.body:
If you're chomping at the bit to be making Yeast Raised Christmas Waffles - let's face it, who isn't? - all you need to know is here. Recipes are supplied by cooks from all over the world - eg, Jennifer Bopp's au gratin potatoes, bless her cotton socks. Elsewhere, there's Darlene Coleman's ornament dough, and recipes for stollen, panettone and cranberry swirl coffee cake.

Pros: There are even recipes for the vegetarian Christmas - tofu turkey - which "Becky" says is "so darn clever and tasty". Thanks, Becky, for that one.

Cons: With instructions for making Aunt Phyllis's magnificent cheese ball, christmasrecipes.com is sometimes a little hard to take seriously.

webTitle: Passnotes: No:1783 Spot

fields.headline: No:1783
fields.standfirst: Spot
fields.trailText: Spot
fields.body:
Aw bless, look at his little wet nose! He is rather cute, isn't he?

How can you resist those puppy-dog eyes? Well 537 (or 930) Florida voters simply couldn't help themselves.

I meant the one on the left. Ah, yes, yes. The fluffy one.

Who is that goddamn son-of-a-bitch? That's Spot, the new top dog at the White House.

And why, pray, is he called Spot? Why, because he's covered in spots, obviously.

Oh right, I thought they were dimples. I wouldn't count on it, buster.

And is he a pedigree? Absolutely. Spot F (for Fetcher) Bush is a springer spaniel and was born at the White House; he is the son of Millie, George Bush Snr's dog.

So has Spot been of valuable assistance during the presidential campaign? You betchya. Spot presides over the Kids section of the governor of Texas homepage, where he is clad in a funky pink T-shirt, armband and blue flares, and gives the kids "cool" after-school tips such as "Help around the house" and "Do your homework". Yo!

Sure sounds like one happenin' hound. Oh yeah, and what's more, Spot tells us that he enjoys "playing sports and reading".

Blimey, that's one talented pooch. Shouldn't we notify Esther Rantzen? Spot's talents don't end there...

Don't tell me, he can say the word "sausages"? No, but his web page is also available in Spanish.

"Salchichas" then. Well you've got to secure that Latino vote somehow.

What kind of books is Spot into? Well, according to the website, one of Spot's favourite is Sod Houses on the Great Plains by Glen Rounds.

I take it that's not an imperative. Hardly.

And he's a keen sportsman to boot? Uh-huh. Spot says, "I love to play tennis with the Governor. He hits the ball across the lawn with a tennis racket and I chase it".

Hasn't Dubya got better things to be doing with his time? It's probably best to keep him occupied.

webTitle: Food: where to eat out for under £15

fields.headline: Cheapskate
fields.standfirst: Where to eat out for under £15
fields.trailText: Where to eat out for under £15.
fields.body:
Plough Inn
3 The Square, Hillsborough, Co Down.
Tel: 028-9268 2985

Peter Mandelson's official residence is across the street but now that the hub of political activity has shifted - for the moment at least - to Stormont, Hillsborough is reverting to its charming, sleepy self. Things at Derek Patterson's Plough Inn are far from sleepy, however. Top of the Plough's pops is roast Atlantic cod with split pea mash and chive beurre blanc (£9.50), which will fortify you in times of self-doubt, revitalise in times of hangovers and generally dust you down and spruce you up for another day. Fish is a speciality. Other pleasures include lemon crusted salmon, arctic char, monkfish, seabass, marlin and Japanese torpedo prawns.

webTitle: Food: Just out

fields.headline: Just out
fields.standfirst: Fig-and-almond wheel
fields.trailText: Fig-and-almond wheel
fields.body:
Form: Small, fat disc about 13cm across and 3cm deep, weighing 500g and made of compressed figs and whole almonds.

Flavour: Delicate; gently figgy with toffee-ish notes; this is very dense with almonds going crunch all over the place.

Verdict: Catalonia's answer to Italy's panforte; and a very nice addition to the Christmas nibbles it is, too. Perhaps the dentally challenged should avoid it, and people with false teeth certainly should (the seeds of dried figs have a nasty habit of getting under the dentures and causing mayhem). The rest will find it curiously addictive, as I just have.

Price: Round about the £6-£7 mark from yer smarter deli.

webTitle: Food: On the menu

fields.headline: On the menu
fields.standfirst: Dragee
fields.trailText: Dragee
fields.body:
Is it an edible cross dresser? Hardly. It's a sweetie, sweetie. A French sweetie at that.

And what form does it take? A nut, usually almond, is enrobed in layer after layer of sugar mixed with gum arabic, which hardens until each is crisp, crunchy and nicely sweet. Some clever clogs also use chocolate to coat the nuts, but, technically speaking, this is not a dragee.

What if I am allergic to nuts? Then look for dragees with chocolate, seed or fruit paste centres.

Where do I find them? In your stocking this Christmas.

Anything else I should know? The dragee is a direct descendant of the English comfit, which, sadly, is no longer with us.

webTitle: Letters: Asylum scandal

fields.headline: Asylum scandal
fields.trailText: Jeremy Hardy rightly draws attention to the massive increase in asylum applicants being refused on the technical grounds that they have failed to return a complex "statement of evidence" form within a wholly unreasonable 10-day time limit.
fields.body:
 Jeremy Hardy rightly draws attention to the massive increase in asylum applicants being refused on the technical grounds that they have failed to return a complex "statement of evidence" form within a wholly unreasonable 10-day time limit. But the situation is even worse than he suggests. Compared to early 1999 (before this procedure became the norm) the proportion of applications refused on such grounds has increased not four-fold but 38-fold - from 1% to 38%. Moreover, they are refused even if the Home Office has the form by the time it makes its decision - Alice in Wonderland stuff that sits uneasily with the Human Rights Act.

A few weeks from now, Jack Straw will announce that the Home Office is meeting his target of deciding most asylum applications within two months. What he is unlikely to say is that this is being achieved by a deliberate policy of not even looking at a large proportion of them.

David Harker
Chief executive,
National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux

Jeremy Hardy wrongly suggests that asylum seekers can not use vouchers issued by the national asylum support service to buy toys for their children (Worse off, 2,000 years on, December 13). This is completely incorrect. Unlike some local authority schemes, asylum seekers can use their vouchers in over 23,500 retail outlets to buy whatever they want. The support that asylum seekers get from the NASS, which includes free furnished accommodation and no utility or council tax bills, is broadly equivalent to income support levels.

Barbara Roche MP
Minister of state, Home Office

Your article (No man's land, G2, December 13) does not make clear the difficult conditions under which the French Red Cross shelter at Sangatte, Calais operates. To tackle the problem of the hundreds of people who were sleeping rough in streets and parks, the French government asked the French Red Cross to set up a basic emergency shelter. It was not intended to be a reception centre; people are offered a roof over their heads, three meals a day and washing facilities.

As the situation has become a longer term one, the French Red Cross have made improvements within the remit they have been given by the government. The Red Cross movement operates within its fundamental principles of humanity, impartiality and neutrality. The desperate situation in Calais cannot be resolved by the French Red Cross alone.

Sam Younger
Director general,
British Red Cross

webTitle: Car bomb attack foiled in Belfast

fields.headline: Car bomb attack foiled in Belfast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Police arrested two men and intercepted a bomb, thought to have been the work of dissident republicans, in the centre of Belfast yesterday, hours after President Clinton had left the city with promises of US help in a crackdown on renegade terrorists.
fields.body:
Police arrested two men and intercepted a bomb, thought to have been the work of dissident republicans, in the centre of Belfast yesterday, hours after President Clinton had left the city with promises of US help in a crackdown on renegade terrorists.

The device, in a plastic box in a holdall, contained 1.5lbs of Semtex with a timer, ready for use. Security sources said it was probably intended as an under-car booby trap, to kill a particular individual rather than for a large scale attack.

The RUC, acting on intelligence, swooped on a car which they believe had been driven from west Belfast, and detectives were last night questioning two suspects, aged 16 and 21, at Gough barracks, Armagh.

The previous night, President Clinton, speaking in the city's £93m Odyssey arena, had pledged utmost co-operation with British and Irish authorities to root out terrorists opposed to the Good Friday agreement.

The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, had earlier warned of the danger of dissident violence, both in Northern Ireland and in mainland Britain.

Police fear the device could have been aimed at a loyalist or Protestant target, in an attempt to escalate sectarian attacks. A Protestant taxi driver, Trevor Kell, and a Catholic workman, Gary Moore, were shot dead last week.

Another murder the day after President Clinton's high profile farewell visit would have been assured maximum publicity.

Sinn Fein wants the government to scale down security, particularly in the republican heartland of South Armagh. This is one of the disputes stalling the peace process, along with nationalists' call for the full implementation of the Patten policing reforms. Yesterday's find will add weight to the unionist argument that the dissident threat remains too great to contemplate further demilitarisation.

Ken Maginnis, the Ulster Unionist party's spokesman on security, said: "The greatest injustice to society as a whole is that Patten has failed to take into consideration the levels of criminality and terrorism, and the changes are being made in a virtual vacuum."

Les Rodgers, chairman of the Police Federation, which represents most of the RUC's 13,000 officers, was furious that his members were not told details of the plan to implement recommendations in the police bill before they leaked to the media.

The plan sets out a recommended timetable for change, including merging special branch and CID by April, shutting the Gough interrogation centre by autumn, and phasing out the full time reserve force by early 2002.

"This bomb doesn't augur well," said Mr Rodgers. "We need officers on the ground."

 Mr Mandelson is to challenge a decision to free the loyalist leader Johnny Adair, who was re-imprisoned five months ago because of his alleged influence on an internecine feud which has claimed seven lives since.

The sentence review commission, set up under the Good Friday agreement to rule on the early release of paramilitary prisoners, issued a preliminary finding that the Ulster Freedom Fighter leader should be allowed out of jail.

Lawyers for the prison service are to contest this. Adair's counsel will put his case at a hearing at Maghaberry prison, Co Antrim, where he is held.

The Ulster Democratic party chairman, John White, a close friend of Adair's, insisted the UFF leader is now a firm supporter of the peace process.

webTitle: Exhibition to reveal UK's hidden art to the public eye

fields.headline: Exhibition to reveal UK's hidden art to the public eye
fields.trailText: Scores of works of art came from behind some of the grandest and most private walls in Scotland yesterday, for a rare public showing,  writes Maev Kennedy.
fields.body:
Scores of works of art came from behind some of the grandest and most private walls in Scotland yesterday, for a rare public showing, writes Maev Kennedy.

Portraits and landscapes by Gainsborough and Scottish painter Raeburn hang side by side with family treasures, including Sir Walter Scott's glasses and a backgammon set once owned by Mary, Queen of Scots.

The exhibition, jointly organised by the Historic Houses Association and Sotheby's in Glasgow, is at the Burrell Collection in Glasgow until February.

The pieces have been exempted from inheritance tax over the last century, under a system as controversial in Scotland as in England. The government is considering how to ensure greater public access.

The 150 works of art, including portraits, jewellery and silver, come from private collections in Scotland and the Borders, and many have never been seen in public before.

The exemption was introduced to end the flood of art being sold overseas by private owners of historic houses faced with huge death duty bills. Exemption has only been granted for important pieces, which have a significant association with either the house or the family.

In return, the objects must remain in the UK and there must be public access. In practice it has been difficult for the public to find out about these treasures and to make appointments to view them.

The Historic Houses Association has argued that although their members include the owners of some of the most palatial great houses, many own small family homes which are impossible to open to the public, on grounds of security and physical access.

Temporary loans of works of art to local museums or exhibitions have been proposed as an alternative to scrapping the system of exemption.

webTitle: Is Liverpool the new Hollywood?

fields.headline: Boom town
fields.standfirst: Samuel L Jackson having a beer in a bowling alley, American producers on the terraces at Anfield, film crews around every corner...Emma Brockes reports on how Liverpool is becoming the place to make a movie
fields.trailText: Samuel L Jackson having a beer in a bowling alley, American producers on the terraces at Anfield, film crews around every corner...Emma Brockes reports on how Liverpool is becoming the place to make a movie
fields.body:
In a pub on a Liverpool housing estate, a crowd of extras dressed as Manchester United supporters are trying their best to look aggressive. "For fuck's sake, not you again," a man repeats, rehearsing his inflection. Production hands dither round him muttering "Ugly ones to the back, please" and a small explosion goes off in the corner. The man's friend, who does not have a speaking role, snorts loudly between takes and points out that it's only a masochistic Man U supporter who would talk with a Liverpool accent. When they duck outside for a fag, they pull coats over their football shirts and boast of how they'd burn them - if wardrobe didn't impose fines for that kind of insubordination.

Here on the set of The 51st State - a film that pitches Samuel L Jackson in wacky juxtaposition with Ricky Tomlinson, Robert Carlyle, Sean Pertwee and Michael Starke (Sinbad off Brookside) - producers are happy to tolerate a little regional inaccuracy for the charms of shooting in a city where driving across town takes 15 minutes and, until recently, you could always get a parking space. The film, written by first-time screenwriter Stel Pavlou while he was working in Threshers off licence, is a black comedy in which Jackson plays an American chemist who concocts a super-drug and goes to Liverpool to flog it. There, he hooks up with Robert Carlyle, an American-loathing local, and together they take on Ricky Tomlinson, a sloppy, small-time drug dealer. The city council is pleased to observe that the film makes great use of the Liverpool skyline and is part of a mini-renaissance that has made it impossible to get a hotel room in the city for the best part of three months.

Since September, five feature films have been shot in Liverpool: My Kingdom, a movie made for Sky starring Richard Harris and Lynn Redgrave; Parole Officer, written by and starring Steve Coogan in surreal partnership with Omar Sharif; In His Life, a John Lennon biopic for the American network NBC; a shoot 'em up called Al's Lads, and The 51st State, the biggest of the lot. Add to this Liam, a slice of social realism written by Jimmy McGovern and directed by Stephen Frears, and recently released Brit-gangster thriller Going Off Big Time, and you can see why the Liverpool Film Office has launched a snazzy website and declared the boom officially in session.

"It's just like being in LA," says Peter Barnes, producer of Al's Lads, which chronicles the fortunes of three Liverpool waiters on the Mauretania who jump overboard and swim to the American coast, finally pitching up in Chicago and stumbling across the city's gangsters. "Every time you went round a corner, there was another film crew. At one point, we were in the same building as My Kingdom and The 51st State. We had to compare schedules to insure against collisions."

"Can you imagine anything better?" says Michael Starke, in his trailer on the set of The 51st State, in which he plays a policeman. "Driving to work every day from my home in Liverpool and finding myself on a Hollywood production with Samuel L Jackson..."

Liverpool's suitability as a film location is partly down to its acres of dilapidated factory space (or "bomb sites" as producers call them) which can be dressed up to look like any number of pre-war inner cities. Al's Lads, for example, is set in 1927 Chicago - the Al in the title refers to Al Capone - which, say producers, would have been almost impossible to shoot in the redeveloped centre of modern day Chicago. Liverpool on the other hand, is passably unreconstructed and has that distressed look beloved of directors in search of urban grit.

"We needed warehouses for illegal fight halls," says Peter Barnes who lives in the Wirral and for the first time in his career has been able to commute to work. "We needed speakeasies, we needed prohibition era nightclubs. And in Liverpool we could get access to all of them without being crippled by costs. Liverpool looks more like 1927 Chicago than Chicago does."

Barnes and his fellow producers estimate that production costs are cut by up to 25% by filming somewhere like Liverpool; more scenes can be shot in a single day when the traffic between locations doesn't hold up half the production. The only downside, says Ronny Yu, the director of The 51st State and who also directed Bride of Chucky, is the bloody awful weather. "I would come back to Liverpool in an instant, but only if I could shoot entirely indoors," he says. "I have had to totally redo scenes because it is blue sky one moment and hurling it down the next." He calls action on a stunt in which Ricky Tomlinson is suspended beneath a 22-tonne crate, before observing, apparently at random, that "the men in Liverpool are all really ugly, but the women are beautiful. Why is that?"

"It's that whole British standing in the rain experience," says Peter Barnes of filming in Liverpool. "There has been a run on trailers and we had a couple of prices that suddenly got hyped - local businesses are catching on - but other than that it's been a joy filming here."

The idea of precious Hollywood film units roughing it in Merseyside has been widely enjoyed by locals. "This is a tough town," marvels Andras Hamori, producer of The 51st State - who is more accustomed to filming in LA. "The women here are very hard, very tough. You come to the city only knowing it for the Beatles and Liverpool football club, and you find something else altogether. You can tell that it's a town that has suffered a lot."

While most locals have welcomed the crews with open arms - there are Liverpudlian extras who haven't had a day off in three months and the local economy has had a cash injection that the Film Office estimates to be running into millions - there have been some uneasy moments of culture clash.

"It's a question of how you approach things," says a security manager affectionately known as Keith the Thief, who worked on In the Name of the Father and is currently engaged on The 51st State. When the crew was filming on a closed stretch of motorway outside Manchester, a large gang of youths gathered and threatened a set invasion. A rock went through one of the unit's buses, before order was reimposed. "If it had come to a fight, we would have been battered," says Keith enthusiastically. "If you swagger into a deprived area acting like a big shot, you will get a lot of resentment. But I invited the kids on set and got them all autographs. They were waving at us when the bus pulled out."

Ricky Tomlinson's only condition of participating in the boom is that the foreign crews make an effort to hire local people. "I've always said that studios who film in Liverpool are like seagulls," he says, in the minutes before filming his stunt. "They fly in, shit all over you, and fly out again. None of this is any good unless it helps the people of Liverpool."

Locals aren't easily impressed in this part of the world and the Hollywood invasion has gone largely unremarked. Keith the Thief is fond of relating how Emma Thompson used to walk unmolested between her hotel, the In the Name of the Father set and Marks & Spencer. Michael Owen is one of the very few celebrities who can attract a crowd; everyone else is treated unceremoniously. Samuel L Jackson has earned respect, though. "Sam's the man," say extras repeatedly. "We've seen him bowling in town. He'll have a beer with the fellas."

Michael Starke stored up all his bravado and, approaching Jackson on set one day, asked if he would do him a favour and ring Louis Emerick, Starke's fellow actor who plays Mick on Brookside and is a big Jackson fan. Jackson obliged and left a "Yo, man" message on the answer machine. It is still being talked about on the Close.

The countervailing experience is that of the American crews, and their wonderment in observing ordinary life in Liverpool. One scene in The 51st State was filmed with 500 extras on the terraces at Anfield, in which they all sang You'll Never Walk Alone, and its rival terrace song Glory, Glory Man United. "I have never seen grown men spontaneously sing like that," marvelled one American producer. "I mean, they knew all the words. In America, you might get cheering at a hockey game, but singing? No way."

And so the two worlds of Liverpool and Hollywood have established an easy, if bizarre, co-existence.

No way." And so the two worlds of Liverpool and Hollywood have established an easy, if bizarre, co-existence.

webTitle: Andrew Pulver's take on the Brat Pack

fields.headline: The year of the brat
fields.standfirst: In 1985 New York magazine coined the term 'Brat Pack' and a generation of movie actors was born.  Andrew Pulver  pays tribute to the stars of The Breakfast Club and St Elmo's Fire
fields.trailText: In 1985 New York magazine coined the term 'Brat Pack' and a generation of movie actors was born. Andrew Pulver pays tribute to the stars of The Breakfast Club and St Elmo's Fire
fields.body:
In the 1960s, a bunch of Hollywooders smoked and drank and canoodled their off-screen lives into public attention. They were the Rat Pack. Two decades later, things had changed. After the Summer of Love and the punk upheaval, the movie audience's social demographic had jolted downwards by a similar 20 years or so. As the 1980s dawned there were teens running around all over the planet with hard currency in their pocket and not a whole lot - cinematically speaking - to spend it on. Enter the Brat Pack.

From the outside, they looked like a group as internally coherent as the Rats - incestuous, vain, hedonist and spoilt beyond belief. A goodly proportion of them enjoyed a head start in the movie business, being the sons and daughters of powerful Hollywood figures. Others infiltrated the scene via television shows and working the audition circuit. The Brat Pack weren't the best actors of their generation, nor did they make the best movies, but in some indefinable way they distilled the spirit of their age, and earned an ambiguous, collective place in the hearts of the hormone-racked adolescents who voraciously sucked down one movie after another.

From our 21st century vantage point a decade and a half later, even the most enduring Brat Pack products seem clumsily scripted and ineptly put together - much like the music videos of similar vintage - but it's impossible to overestimate the emotional charge that much of their work carried for the serried ranks of teenagers who saw themselves, heightened and idealised maybe, flashing across the screen.

The Brat Pack movies told all kinds of stories, some of them simple, some of them ridiculous, some moving, some nausea-inducing. Not all of them were teen movies, for as the Pack got older, so did their movies, and had them tickling around the issues that beset young adults. Not every teen movie was a Brat Pack movie; there were stars and talents working outside the gilded sphere of privilege who made their own contribution to a fondly remembered genre. Still, teen tales of resentment, self- loathing and wide-eyed gratification form the staple of the Brat Pack oeuvre, and, although the combination always changed, they were all linked by the unrelenting gang-mentality arrogance that the Brats brought with them.

The intervening years have only added to the Brat Pack's lustre. The kids who slavishly watched the movies - say you were 15 in 1983 - grew up into the world-weary, ultra-knowing Generation X, a do-nothing generation that cherished and treasured its own formative experiences with a fervour and self-regard that's become almost embarrassing. And where did this self-regard come from? The Brats themselves set the example, feeding and inspiring as many teen demons as they appeared to exorcise. Appropriately enough, the Brat Pack have all gone their separate ways: some have become huge stars, others workaday actors; yet others are nursing career revivals and negotiating parole conditions. But once upon a time, they were all revelling in the limitless possibilities and awesome potential that lay ahead.

The high point of the Brat Pack was the summer of 1985. The Breakfast Club was out, and St Elmo's Fire in the can. New York magazine, that June, ran a story identifying for the first time the existence of a new generation of Hollywood players. Rob Lowe, Judd Nelson and Emilio Estevez graced the cover, radiating whatever energy it took to par-tay all night. Writer David Blum characterised the threesome living life to the limit at LA's Hard Rock Café. With benefit of hindsight, some of Blum's assertions make interesting reading. He describes Emilio Estevez as the Brat Pack's unofficial president. He assures readers that Estevez's career as a major writer-director is only a matter of time. Molly Ringwald doesn't get a single mention. Harry Dean Stanton is name-checked as the Brat Pack's spiritual father. And, according to Blum, the movie that changed Hollywood, that brought the Brat Pack together... is Taps.

Now that the heyday of the Brat Pack is past, some readjustment is in order. First off: who, precisely, are the Brat Pack? Most would agree that Estevez, Ringwald, Lowe and Nelson exemplify the Brat Pack, but what defines their membership? And what about awesomely Bratty talents like Sean Penn, who by and large swerved by the teen movie cycle that is somehow central to the Brat Pack oeuvre?

As is the way of history, it takes time for coincidence to become a phenomenon. The heart and soul of the Brat Pack, in retrospect, were a gang of nine: the principal casts of two movies, The Breakfast Club and St Elmo's Fire, both released in 1985. Emilio Estevez, Andrew McCarthy, Robert Hepler Lowe, Demetria Gene Guynes (we know her better as Demi Moore, the surname taken from her first husband Freddie), Judd Nelson, Mary Megan Winningham, Molly Ringwald, Michael Anthony Hall (he swapped his first two names) and Alexandra Elizabeth Sheedy.

What's become apparent, years later, is that appreciation of the 80s teen movies reflects that of the teens themselves - grown-ups just didn't understand them. But why did this outpouring of emotion wait until the 1980s to well up and explode, like a pustule on an adolescent nose? Teens had been around, as a socially and economically identifiable force, since the 1950s. They had their own icons in James Dean and Marlon Brando, Tuesday Weld and Natalie Wood. And they had their own movies: from The Wild One and Rebel Without a Cause in the mid-1950s to Beach Blanket Bingo and Muscle Beach Party in the mid-1960s, teens could thrill to the alternate impulses of sassing the old-timers and oiling their glistening pecs in the surf.

Ironically, when all this came to an end in the late 1960s as the Hollywood new wave rushed the gates of the palace, it signalled an end to what few reasons there might have been for the curious teen to haunt the movie theatre. Although undeniably Hollywood's 70s generation initiated a golden age, they did it by making adult films. And not pornography either, although to audiences of the time there was occasional confusion. The era that brought us MASH, The Godfather and Bonnie and Clyde also spawned Deep Throat, The Story of O and Emmanuelle. But the golden age of the movie brats couldn't last. How could it? They didn't make movies for teens.

Those who did - George Lucas and Steven Spielberg - changed the face of the industry yet again in the mid-1970s. Jaws and Star Wars hauled in the kind of young audiences who were largely alienated by the Movie Brats' later efforts, and Hollywood faced the tough truth that artistic fertility had coincided with economic downturn. It emerged from the 1970s knowing that teens were at least part of the answer to its problems. Years before Star Wars, however, George Lucas had pointed the way. If ever a film-maker had his finger on the pulse, it was Lucas. His second feature, American Graffiti, released in 1973 was a bittersweet memoir of his own high-school days in Modesto 10 years earlier. The big thing, though, about American Graffiti was it took $115m, on an investment of $750,000. One sweet deal. Then followed low-spend, high-yield teen movies ranging from National Lampoon's Animal House to Porky's and Halloween.

The first unarguable Brat Pack movie arrived in 1983, when Francis Ford Coppola corralled a bunch of the brightest young actors for his answer to American Graffiti. The Outsiders was another 60s-set tale of youth rebellion, and through its offices Rob Lowe, Tom Cruise, Emilio Estevez and C Thomas Howell all forced their way onto the Hollywood map. The Outsiders acted as the high point of a family tree, with its participants going on to make a flood of often-successful movies in each others' company over the next five years. The 1985 high point came when two ensemble movies, The Breakfast Club and St Elmo's Fire, were released within months of each other, sharing cast members and a similar confidence in their distillation of the teen experience. The penny dropped; the label stuck. By 1988, the Brat Pack cycle was pretty much over: the key Brats had gone their separate ways. In the eternally 1980s way, no one actually wanted to be identified with the label that made them famous.

All these movies share a central factor: an unashamed and unaffected deployment of archetypes. The poster for The Breakfast Club shoved it right up front, enumerating its principals as "a brain, a beauty, a jock, a rebel, and a recluse". In their unswerving recycling of these basic units, teen movies often resemble the classic structure of fairy tales, or primitive mythology. Ugly ducklings are everywhere, menacing ogres are there to be repulsed (as often by a shower of vomit as anything else). But teen movies are also instinctively sociological: located in strictly defined and controlled communities, at their best they offer a compelling and subtle analysis of a bewildering social network with a pecking order of its own. Teens make the perfect models for this: old enough to recognise and filter social hierarchies, yet too young to rise above it.

It was in this framework that the Brat Pack were to make their movies: an unlikely conjunction of the rankest exploitation and most tremulous of emotions. Uniquely among cinematic genres, the teen movie could veer from the most leering bra-tearing eyeful to the most sickening of humiliations - often in the very next shot. The best of the teen movies possess a kind of freewheeling insanity that is as turbulent as its central characters' hormones. The 70s auteurs, who were blown out of the water by Hollywood's commercial revival in the latter half of the decade, may not have approved of what came after them, but in engineering the collapse of the old studio system they broke open Hollywood's floodgates for a kind of continuous revolution, a never-ending panic that ensured that the teen movie could expend all its anarchic energy. And for that we should be grateful.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: Good and bad in  the US entertainment of 2000

fields.headline: Nine things I hate about you...and five I love
fields.standfirst: Many things  were bad about US entertainment in 2000. A few weren't
fields.trailText: Many things were bad about US entertainment in 2000. A few weren't
fields.body:
Year's end approaches and with it the avalanche of Ten Best Lists. Every year I get about five magazines calling me for these. It's nice to be asked, but nothing doing. Instead, here's an unscientific, bigoted, contradictory, illogical, and dyspeptic rundown of (nine) American media products, people and phenomena that particularly annoyed me this year; and, below, an unscientific, bigoted, contradictory, illogical and dyspeptic rundown of the stuff that didn't.

1. Gwyneth Paltrow and Ben Affleck

Boy, it's a crowded field but my bétes noires of 2000 handily fought off challenges from the likes of rinky-dink Meg Ryan, box office idiot savant Adam Sandler, Madonna (well, at least she's out of my neighbourhood) and mockney-nob Guy Ritchie, Judge Katherine Smith, Lynne Cheney, and dependably tiresome but inactive hardy perennials like Henry Jaglom, Hal Hartley and David Lynch. My nightmare scenario was fulfilled by Bounce, which teamed our two winners in a winningly emetic combination. That dog at the gates of Hell has two heads, not three.

2. Reality TV

We've had docu-soaps, reality TV and doctored documentaries with plot points and story arcs concocted by committee. We had Survivor USA, Big Brother USA, The 1901 House, The Frontier Show (manufactured misery, 1880s style). And Fox TV, which brought us Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire? (who'll probably knock you about), will soon bring us Temptation Island, in which four couples preparing to commit to long-term relationships spend a month on an island teeming with horny singles who'll try to seduce them asunder. Cap'n Jerry Springer is truly at the helm of the Good Ship Disinfotainment.

3. The electoral quagmire

The farce itself is no bad thing. It's at least demonstrating to Americans how politically polarised their country is and that every level of the allegedly august and impartial judiciary is in the grip, or the gift, of self-serving ideological placemen. But the media coverage has been disgraceful - from Fox TV's decision to call Bush the winner (one of his cousins, a Fox consultant, saw to that) to the feeding frenzy that now greets the merest press release. And poor Dubya Bush looks deeply unhappy about being the likely victor. Little wonder: to quote Texas political commentator Molly Ivins, if you put that boy's brain in a bumblebee, it'd fly backwards.

4. Battlefield Earth

Barking, leg-lifting dog (or runt) of the year - nothing else even came close. But every reverse for the Church of Scientology is one more victory for us "normals". Thus it was nice to see the man the public associates most closely with the group, John Travolta, fall flat on his well-fed backside in this tedious and inept, insanely expensive pseudo-epic. But guess what - the sequel's already in the pipeline. People of Earth! Before it arrives, we must devise and construct super-rockets and motherships, abandon our planet to the pod-people of Chairman Ron and immediately colonise Saturn.

5. The action movie genre

Gone in 60 Seconds? My toilet flushes faster than that - and it's much more fun to watch. The Art of War? The Arse of Bore, more like. And what do you mean, a Get Carter remake? Get away from the Get Carter remake is much sounder advice. The spent and exhausted genre produced two semi-flaccid successes this year: John Woo's Mission: Impossible 2 (a journeyman outing for the master) and the cute but stupid Charlie's Angels. It seems that, apart from Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, action movies have few surprises left for us. Time to kickstart the abattoir!

6. Happy endings

An evergreen bugbear. Families are reunited, misery is headed off at the pass, true love prevails, the guy gets the gal, the villain is mailed back to his mum in 20 separate marmalade jars and everybody rides off into a glorious sunset. Raise your snout to the breeze and you can detect the familiar stench of freshly laid Hollywood horseshit. I realise we go to the movies to seek release from our daily dread, but the tyranny of the happy ending is now as bad as Stalin's dictates on Socialist Realism. Surprise me! Kill the good guy for a change.

7. The following words...

"A masterpiece!" "Jaw-droppingly awesome!" "A roller-coaster ride from start to finish!" "An adrenaline-pumping, heart-stopping adventure!" "The most fun I've had at the movies this season!" "Strap yourself in and hold on tight!" "Two thumbs up!" "It's indelibly etched in your memory!" "Wow! A film that will knock your socks off!" "[Insert stars' names here] give standout performances sure to be remembered at Oscar time!" "Thrilling!" "It's top-tier movie escapism!" "Smart, sophisticated and sexy! The chemistry between the stars literally explodes!"

8 ...and the fools who write them

Which is to say film critics, among whom I must include (and therefore indict) myself. I've used the word masterpiece a few times myself, which I think is actually worse and more dishonest than most of the hyperbolic tripe quoted above (most of which was probably purchased from or blackmailed out of critics by studio PR flacks, and all of which comes verbatim from one week's worth of press movie ads). As a breed we critics have collectively lowered our quality thresholds to ensure that we can deal with at least some of the trash that washes up in our multiplexes on a Friday. And thanks to the wonderful innovation that scientists call the Quote-Whore, we know that the threshold may yet descend through the floor and into the sewer.

9. Ten best lists

Because I can't think of even five movies released last year that I'd pay to see again, not even on video. Because lists are a form of sexual sublimation and ego-food for Hornby-esque sadsack losers without dates.

The good stuff

1. Robert Downey, Jr

The most gifted actor of his generation (etc - but it is true), Downey has become both a poster child for pharmacological overkill and the most visible martyr of America's dementedly misguided War on Drugs. How could a troubled and fragile thespian genius be so persecuted? OJ Simpson is still walking the streets and Downey may be going back to jail.

2. Russell Crowe

We already knew from The Insider that Crowe was a fine, subtle, vanity-free actor, happy to ruin his looks to play pudgy and useless. But Gladiator and Proof of Life prove that he's also a great movie star. One is not the same as the other, and the two rarely combine in one actor. Crowe is as manly as Connery and as subtle as Robert Ryan. Pity he sounds like such a prick in real life.

3. The Daily Show with Jon Stewart

The funniest show on US television - a combination of spoof CNN and spoof Letterman, The Daily Show delivers fake news that eviscerates the real news. Jon Stewart for president!

4. Mainly About Lindsay Anderson

Gavin Lambert's affectionate biography - an account of Anderson's depressingly attenuated career - is one of the best movie memoirs ever. Anderson's chosen gravestone epitaph: "Surrounded by fucking idiots."

5. The coming strikes

I don't want to see jobbing actors starve, but I have an idle reverie about the benefits of an extended writers' and directors' strike next year. The strike lasts forever, and the new studio material dries up. Exhibitors fall back on foreign and independent films to fill schedules. Surprisingly, movies starring nobodies do astonishingly well. Armed with this knowledge, studios and producers abandon the grim mathematics of $20m stars and their vain and baleful influence. The strike ends, the small fry happily resume their careers and the marquee-value morons find themselves stranded on high, arid ground, like dinosaurs ripe for extinction. Bring it on!
