Kill the good guy for a change. 7. The following words... "A masterpiece!" "Jaw-droppingly awesome!" "A roller-coaster ride from start to finish!" "An adrenaline-pumping, heart-stopping adventure!" "The most fun I've had at the movies this season!" "Strap yourself in and hold on tight!" "Two thumbs up!" "It's indelibly etched in your memory!" "Wow! A film that will knock your socks off!" "[Insert stars' names here] give standout performances sure to be remembered at Oscar time!" "Thrilling!" "It's top-tier movie escapism!" "Smart, sophisticated and sexy! The chemistry between the stars literally explodes!" 8 ...and the fools who write them Which is to say film critics, among whom I must include (and therefore indict) myself. I've used the word masterpiece a few times myself, which I think is actually worse and more dishonest than most of the hyperbolic tripe quoted above (most of which was probably purchased from or blackmailed out of critics by studio PR flacks, and all of which comes verbatim from one week's worth of press movie ads). As a breed we critics have collectively lowered our quality thresholds to ensure that we can deal with at least some of the trash that washes up in our multiplexes on a Friday. And thanks to the wonderful innovation that scientists call the Quote-Whore, we know that the threshold may yet descend through the floor and into the sewer. 9. Ten best lists Because I can't think of even five movies released last year that I'd pay to see again, not even on video. Because lists are a form of sexual sublimation and ego-food for Hornby-esque sadsack losers without dates. The good stuff 1. Robert Downey, Jr The most gifted actor of his generation (etc - but it is true), Downey has become both a poster child for pharmacological overkill and the most visible martyr of America's dementedly misguided War on Drugs. How could a troubled and fragile thespian genius be so persecuted? OJ Simpson is still walking the streets and Downey may be going back to jail. 2. Russell Crowe We already knew from The Insider that Crowe was a fine, subtle, vanity-free actor, happy to ruin his looks to play pudgy and useless. But Gladiator and Proof of Life prove that he's also a great movie star. One is not the same as the other, and the two rarely combine in one actor. Crowe is as manly as Connery and as subtle as Robert Ryan. Pity he sounds like such a prick in real life. 3. The Daily Show with Jon Stewart The funniest show on US television - a combination of spoof CNN and spoof Letterman, The Daily Show delivers fake news that eviscerates the real news. Jon Stewart for president! 4. Mainly About Lindsay Anderson Gavin Lambert's affectionate biography - an account of Anderson's depressingly attenuated career - is one of the best movie memoirs ever. Anderson's chosen gravestone epitaph: "Surrounded by fucking idiots." 5. The coming strikes I don't want to see jobbing actors starve, but I have an idle reverie about the benefits of an extended writers' and directors' strike next year. The strike lasts forever, and the new studio material dries up. Exhibitors fall back on foreign and independent films to fill schedules. Surprisingly, movies starring nobodies do astonishingly well. Armed with this knowledge, studios and producers abandon the grim mathematics of $20m stars and their vain and baleful influence. The strike ends, the small fry happily resume their careers and the marquee-value morons find themselves stranded on high, arid ground, like dinosaurs ripe for extinction. Bring it on!

webTitle: Ford gambles on the euro

fields.headline: Ford gambles on the euro
fields.standfirst: Dagenham plant wins £420m  Industrial action spreads in Vauxhall protest
fields.trailText: Dagenham plant wins £420m  Industrial action spreads in Vauxhall protest.
fields.body:
Ford, the UK's biggest car maker, is to invest $600m (£420m) expanding its diesel engine plant at Dagenham in the expectation that Britain will join the eurozone within five years.

The US company, which has just announced plans to halt car assembly at Dagenham, is believed to have taken a £1.2bn hit over the last 12 months due to the high price of the pound against the euro.

Nick Scheele, chairman of Ford Europe, yesterday said he was pursuing investment in this country for Ford, Jaguar and Land Rover on the basis that the government would drop the pound.

He said: "We have a fundamental belief that the UK will enter the euro and that currency is not a long-term strategic issue."

Mr Scheele has been a strong campaigner for closer links with Europe but has always avoided putting a time frame on when he believes Britain should join the eurozone.

But sources confirmed that the investment in new facilities at Dagenham had been made on a five-year time frame. One well placed insider said: "It is reasonable for you to assume we would like to see entry within that period."

Ford's stance puts further pressure on the government to stop wavering on the single currency issue in the run up to a general election or face further uncertainty inside a battered British car industry.

Analysts say Ford is heading for a significantly higher loss than the £120m it ran up in Britain last year due to overcapacity and downward pressure on prices. The company has more than 28% of its cost base in Britain.

Speaking after a conference to launch a manufacturing think tank report Mr Scheele expressed his belief that Britain had a future in car production as long as plants, the labour force and their suppliers remained "fully flexible".

Mr Scheele said it had been forced to take its decision to halt car manufacturing from 2002 at Dagenham and make 1,300 redundancies because it was not as flexible as the plants it was competing with. He was surprised at General Motors' move to shut Vauxhall's automobile assembly plant at Luton with the loss of 2,000 jobs and said it would have no effect on Ford.

Some industry experts believe that GM opted to closed its Bedfordshire factory to ensure it did not fall behind its rival on overheads.

Mr Scheele said there was still enormous overcapacity in western Europe with sales running at a record 17m units but capacity being between 23m and 24m. At least 8m of the vehicles are coming from outside Europe, mainly the Far East.

Ford, the world's second largest car maker, has decided to cut its North American production output in the first quarter of the new financial year in a move to closer match supply and demand on that side of the Atlantic. Car production will be chopped by 20% and trucks by 4%. Some assembly plants will be made idle next week to cut excess inventories of unsold cars.

Ford Europe expects to be in the red this year but hopes this will be a low point with a slight upturn in 2001. The company has announced a $1bn restructuring charge to be taken this year to cover the European operations. Ford and its various subsidiaries employ 50,000 staff in Britain.

 MG Rover said it had sold more than its target of 200,000 cars this year, in a sign that the car maker's afflicted brand name is clawing back consumer confidence. It said demand had been particularly buoyant in December in Britain.

webTitle: Prescott package gets a rough ride

fields.headline: Prescott package gets a rough ride
fields.standfirst:
£8.4bn boost for transport highlights deputy PM's rift with Macdonald as critics say road schemes are the winners

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: £8.4bn boost for transport highlights deputy PM's rift with Macdonald as critics say road schemes are the winners.
fields.body:
The government's £8.4bn boost to local transport schemes yesterday highlighted deepening divisions between John Prescott and his transport minister, Lord Macdonald, after the package revived a string of contentious road schemes once opposed by the deputy prime minister.

Despite the dispersal of more than half the funds to public transport projects - including bus lanes, two new light railways and even cycle paths - environmental groups accused ministers of a policy u-turn, three years after they said public transport should take priority and that new roads should only be built "as a last resort".

Yesterday's package, the first instalment of a 10 year, £180bn public and privately funded transport programme, included £3bn over five years for road maintainance and up to £1bn for 39 roadbuilding schemes, among them 14 bypasses from the overcrowded West Midlands to the Cornish holiday routes.

Mr Prescott argued that "every region is a winner in today's £8.4bn investment boost. This money will make a real difference to everyone, however they travel and wherever they live".

In the face of growing complaints about a "sticking plaster" transport strategy, he insisted the proposals provide "a proper balance between spending on roads and spending on public transport" reversing years of under-investment.

But Bernard Jenkin, the Tory transport spokesman, said investment had fallen since 1997 and that, in the first four years of Labour rule, the government had invested less on transport in total than in any of the previous 18 Conservative years.

"Mr Prescott is pretending to be a generous Santa Claus, but in reality he is Scrooge." Mr Jenkin said Mr Prescott had failed in his 1997 pledge to reduce car journeys. None of his new schemes would even be started by election day.

The Liberal Democrat transport spokesman, Don Foster, said: "The plans will not lead to reduction in road traffic. John Prescott has shot himself in the foot. We are determined to hold him to his promise to reduce the number of journeys by car."

Confined only to England, the plan also angered pro-public transport groups like Transport 2000 which had viewed yesterday's announcement as a test of government's good faith on the environment.

The CBI applauded the package - "business will always judge governments by what they do, rather than what they say" - and offered a welcome to integrated local transport schemes which will "help people get to work and goods to market".

The Council for the Protection of Rural England gave a mixed response - "a jackpot for local transport, but also a tinderbox of controversy over possible new roads."

It prompted backbench critics on both sides to claim that Lord Macdonald, who joined the Prescott team last year, had won the day, with the backing of pro-car elements in the Downing Street policy-making machine.

Even before yesterday's statement, Mr Prescott and his lieutenant, a former shipyard union activist turned media tycoon, appeared to be at cross-purposes over how the government should respond to the crisis on the railways as pressure mounted for a takeover of Railtrack's operations if chaos continued.

With Lord Macdonald strongly opposed to the government taking a strategic stake in the privatised track and station operator, some of the deputy PM's closest advisers are now arguing for radical options to be considered.

These include either giving Railtrack special trust status, to operate as a public-private venture, or creating a rail agencysimilar way to the highways agency, detached from the Whitehall machine. Both options could avoid charges of rail renationalisation, while appealing to a growing number of voters who believe ministers will have to take stronger action to sort out Railtrack.

Although Lord Macdonald's avowedly pro-car stance and direct line to Downing Street has clearly irritated Mr Prescott, insiders at the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions where the transport minister is officially a deputy to Mr Prescott, play down talk of a rift.

But they accept that the two are very different personalities, "chalk and cheese". With Blair aides worried about the political fallout from a chaotic Christmas and New Year on the railways, Mr Prescott's chief transport adviser, David Begg, warned yesterday that urgent action would have to be taken against Railtrack if services were still being disrupted by Easter.

Regional round-up

Some of the transport schemes that received funding yesterday:

North-east
Tyne and Wear Centrelink (£26.4m) - dedicated busway connecting MetroCentre with Gateshead and Newcastle; Tyne and Wear (£9.6m) - doubling the track capacity of a section of the Metro network

North-west
Greater Manchester urban traffic control system (£5.5m); Warrington system (£5.1m)

Yorkshire and Humberside
South Yorkshire (Doncaster) A638 bus corridor (£12.1m) million); East Leeds link road (£20.7m) between Leeds inner ring road, Aire Valley employment area and the M1

East Midlands
Derby City (£23.4m) - project combining traffic management and bus priority measures.

West Midlands
Hagley Road bus scheme (£13.6m); West Midlands outer circle bus scheme (£21.3m)

East of England
Southend-on-Sea A13 passengers transport corridor (£14.5m)

South-east
Crawley (£23.9m) bus priority and guided bus scheme to improve journey times

South-west
Plymouth (£8.4m); Salisbury, Wiltshire, package (£13.7m) Four bus park and ride sites, bus priority and cycling measures, pedestrianisation and traffic management

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
EC holds off on United decision
The European commission has extended its deadline to rule on plans by United Airlines to buy US Airways after the companies offered concessions on competition concerns. The deadline was extended to January 12 from December 21.
fields.body:
EC holds off on United decision
The European commission has extended its deadline to rule on plans by United Airlines to buy US Airways after the companies offered concessions on competition concerns. The deadline was extended to January 12 from December 21.

United had proposed buying US Airways, the sixth-ranked US carrier, in May for $4.3bn (£3bn). United is already the world's largest airline. The Brussels commission has the power to vet all mergers involving companies with combined global turnover of €5bn ($4.43bn) as long as at least two of the firms involved have sales within the EU of €250m.

Teather to stay independent
Teather & Greenwood stockbrokers yesterday insisted it is determined to stay independent despite the trend toward consolidation amongst smaller finance houses.

The company announced a pretax profit for the six months to October of £3.67m, up 81%, driven by growth across all areas.

Jeremy Delmar-Morgan, the chairman, said: "The first half of the year produced very profitable growth. We continue to view the future with considerable optimism."

The company is paying a maiden interim dividend of 0.5p.

Profits fall at GTech
GTech, the world's leading lottery operator and software supplier to Camelot, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit had fallen nearly 20%, - but it had still met Wall Street estimates on the strength of a 17% reduction in operating costs.

"We're continuing to evaluate our positioning in the market," chairman Bruce Turner said. "We expect that there will be further [cost cutting] actions to enhance our competitiveness even further."

L&G appoints Goldman Sachs
Legal & General has appointed Goldman Sachs and Lazard as its investment bankers. The company has also reappointed UBS Warburg and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson as corporate brokers. Speculation that Barclays Bank might be preparing a bid for L&G was dismissed by industry sources.

Norway lists Statoil
The Norwegian government is to list state oil and gas firm Statoil next year by selling a stake of between 10% and 25% and issuing new shares. "This means Statoil will be able to do better in the international oil market and be a leading company in the European gas market for many years," said prime minister Jens Stoltenberg.

webTitle: Post Office wins delivery reprieve in Europe

fields.headline: PO wins delivery reprieve
fields.trailText: The Post Office scored a significant victory in Europe last night after MEPs watered down controversial proposals to abolish its monopoly in 2003.
fields.body:
The Post Office scored a significant victory in Europe last night after MEPs watered down controversial proposals to abolish its monopoly in 2003.

In a move which might thwart the European commission's plans to abolish post office monopolies altogether, the MEPs voted to put off drastic liberalisation and to open up the market far more gradually than Brussels wants.

The EC is pushing for the Post Office to lose its monopoly for all letters weighing more than 50 grams but MEPs raised that figure to 150 grams - the Royal Mail's preferred option - and voted to delay the introduction of competition for at least two years.

The Post Office last night welcomed the vote but warned that the EC's proposals, if eventually implemented, could cost it up to £400m a year in lost revenues.

"This is good news for us: 150 grams would allow us to provide a universal service while still allowing substantial levels of competition," a spokeswoman said.

"The real fear with the EC's proposals is that you'll get companies cherry-picking the best bits, such as the area within the M25, and if you do that there is a risk that universal service would fall to bits."

At present Britain's postal service is heavily cross-subsidised, with deliveries to its more remote areas costing the Royal Mail far more than the service it provides for densely populated districts such as London.

If too much competition is brought in too quickly, it believes that people living in sparsely populated areas would end up paying far more for their mail as a result.

Brian Simpson, a Labour MEP who opposes the EC's plans, hailed the vote as a decisive step in the battle to fend off privatisation by stealth of the Royal Mail.

webTitle: 'Death threats' to cleared TV hard man

fields.headline: 'Death threats' to cleared TV man
fields.trailText: Television hard man Dave Courtney was yesterday cleared of attempting to pervert the course of justice.
fields.body:
Television hard man Dave Courtney was yesterday cleared of attempting to pervert the course of justice. But the man who played in The Paradise Club and in real life was head minder at two Kray funerals, disclosed after the Old Bailey verdict that he had received two death threats since the start of the case.

During the trial, he was branded by the prosecution as a police informer, allegedly involved in a scheme to plant drugs on a model involved in a custody battle with her husband.

Courtney, 41, from south London, denied the charge and was cleared after it was claimed he had been using a corrupt policeman, who earlier pleaded guilty to being involved in the plot, for his own ends.

The model, Kim James, 28, was arrested after cocaine was found in her car but later cleared of involvement.

Her ex-husband Simon James, 34, of Battersea, south London, and private investigator Jonathan Rees, 46, of Thornton Heath, Surrey, were found guilty of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. They will be sentenced today with corrupt ex-detective constable Austin Warnes, 38, of Bexleyheath,Kent.

James Cook, 45, of Tadworth, Surrey, was cleared by the jury.

webTitle: Message dismays one-nation Tories

fields.headline: Message dismays one-nation Tories
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Macpherson report - one year on
fields.trailText: William Hague delighted one-nation Tories at this year's party conference when he welcomed their plea for a return to the centre ground, where the next election will be won.
fields.body:
William Hague delighted one-nation Tories at this year's party conference when he welcomed their plea for a return to the centre ground, where the next election will be won.

The same moderate Tories were dismayed yesterday by Mr Hague's provocative speech on crime which raised fears that - with the Tories slumping in the polls - Mr Hague has decided to tack to the right in the run-up to the election.

With no sign of a Tory victory, and indications that the party could be heading for a repeat of its 1997 defeat, they fear that Mr Hague has decided to tailor his message to appeal to core voters.

The Conservative leader has mastered a technique for drumming up support among his party's hardcore supporters in a way that enrages moderate Tories who yearn for a return to the days of one-nation conservatism.

The Tory leader's team of young staffers carefully monitors the outpourings of the rightwing press, usually on law and order, before picking on an issue which will guarantee favourable headlines in the Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph.

Mr Hague's provocative intervention on crime yesterday was his most successful foray to the right since taking over as leader in 1997. He secured positive headlines in the Telegraph and the Mail on his criticisms of the Macpherson report which, thanks to the briefing overnight, glossed over the more balanced elements of the speech.

Before Mr Hague had even stood up to make his speech at lunchtime, he had won plaudits from the Tories' "hang and flog 'em brigade". Moderate Tories, however, were exasperated.

One former one-nation minister, who asked to remain anonymous, said he was dismayed by the speech. "There is a lot of truth in what William said, particularly his criticism of Macpherson for describing the Met as institutionally racist. But that message has been put across in such a strident way that it has obscured William's other message that he is concerned about black victims of crime.

webTitle: Bush aims to reform voting system

fields.headline: Bush aims to reform voting system
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Republican political leaders attempted yesterday to head off widespread dismay over America's election arrangements, less than 24 hours after the flawed voting process had finally handed the US presidency to Texas governor George W Bush.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington,  Duncan Campbell  in Austin  and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Republican political leaders attempted yesterday to head off widespread dismay over America's election arrangements, less than 24 hours after the flawed voting process had finally handed the US presidency to Texas governor George W Bush.

Mr Bush's brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, announced a wide-ranging inquiry into the state's voting and counting methods, while the secretary of state, Katherine Harris, unveiled plans for a wholesale upgrade of Florida's controversial voting machines.

In Washington, the Republican Senate leader Trent Lott said election law reform could be at the top of the Bush administration's legislative priorities as it seeks to consolidate its legitimacy after the bitterest presidential contest in living memory.

Republican leaders realise they could face a massive voter backlash in 2002 and 2004 if they are not seen to take prompt action to guarantee future fairness in a system that so manifestly failed to do so in this year's contest.

On his first full day as America's official leader-in-waiting, President-elect Bush attended a prayer meeting in Austin, Texas, while aides announced that he will travel to Washington next week to meet President Clinton and his Democratic rival Al Gore, who finally conceded defeat on Wednesday after 36 days of protests over the voting in Florida.

Mr Bush spent the day taking telephone calls of congratulation from world leaders. The first call came from Tony Blair. "President-elect Bush said he was very aware of the special relationship between our two countries and said he was pleased that this was the first phone call with a foreign leader since being declared president-elect," a Downing Street spokesman said.

The outgoing US president, Bill Clinton, warned his successor against leading the US into the kind of isolation he hinted at through out the presidential campaign. Mr Clinton challenged him to maintain the prime role of the US in intervening worldwide in the interests of security and to contribute heavily in helping the developing world. Mr Bush's campaign team created apprehension in the Balkans during the election by saying he would pull US troops out.

Mr Clinton threw down a gauntlet to the former Texas governor during a speech at Warwick University at the end of his three-day visit to Ireland and Britain. In his last big foreign policy speech, he said there was a wonderful opportunity for peace and prosperity in this century. "For eight years, I have done what I could to lead my country down that path. I think for the rest of our lives we had better stay on it."

Jeb Bush, facing a re-election fight in less than two years and under pressure to act from friend and foe alike, told a press conference in Tallahassee that he was establishing a bipartisan taskforce to make recommendations for new Florida laws on "election procedures, standards and technology" and to craft new arrangements "that every Floridian can be proud of" In Washington, Senator Lott acknowledged that Mr Bush wanted immediate federal action on the voting debacles.

Washington and Austin were full of signs of the presidential transition moving into top gear after Wednesday's concession by Mr Gore, who received many plaudits from all sides for the manner and tone of his withdrawal speech.

webTitle: Tape raises new claims in Hamilton case

fields.headline: Tape raises new claims in Hamilton case
fields.trailText: New evidence showed that the "disgraceful activities" of Mohamed Al Fayed's camp during Neil Hamilton's cash for questions libel action continued even after the verdict, the court of appeal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
New evidence showed that the "disgraceful activities" of Mohamed Al Fayed's camp during Neil Hamilton's cash for questions libel action continued even after the verdict, the court of appeal heard yesterday.

The former MP's QC, Anthony Boswood, said that his solicitors were approached on Wednesday afternoon by former armed robber turned journalist John McVicar with a tape of an alleged conversation between Benjamin Pell and a freelance journalist, Mark Hollingsworth.

Mr Hamilton claims he would not have lost his libel action, which left him with estimated costs of £2m, if the court had known that the Harrods boss was allegedly involved in paying £10,000 for legal documents which Mr Pell was said to have taken from dustbins outside the chambers of Mr Hamilton's lawyers. He says that the verdict should be set aside, given Mr Fayed's "gross impropriety".

Mr Fayed has told the appeal court he had no knowledge of the stolen legal documents.

Mr Boswood has alleged that Mr Hollingsworth, who was engaged by Mr Fayed to help with the Hamilton litigation, took the documents to Mr Al Fayed's security chief, John Macnamara, and was paid £10,000 in cash with the promise of a further £10,000.

Yesterday, Mr Boswood said the tape "appears to show these disgraceful activities continuing beyond the conclusion of the trial and into the stage of appeal and post-trial litigation unabated".

Mr Hamilton had sued Mr Fayed over claims in a January 1997 Channel 4 Dispatches programme that he accepted cash payments, gift vouchers and a free holiday at the Paris Ritz in return for asking parliamentary questions on behalf of Mr Fayed.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Ministers may back down on tube plan

fields.headline: Ministers may back down on tube plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, was facing growing isolation over his plans to part privatise the London Underground as alternative proposals put forward by mayor Ken Livingstone won growing political and business support.
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, was facing growing isolation over his plans to part privatise the London Underground as alternative proposals put forward by mayor Ken Livingstone won growing political and business support.

Mr Livingstone was pinning his hopes on signs that the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, was willing to compromise between the proposals doggedly defended by Mr Prescott and those set out this week by Robert Kiley, Mr Livingstone's nominee as London's new commissioner of transport.

In an intensive four day public relations drive, Mr Kiley, the man credited with saving the New York subway, is pressing his alternative scheme of keeping the Underground in one piece and and in public hands with a bond issue supported by fare revenue. He would target £10bn investment on track, signals and tunnels.

Yesterday the Conservative transport spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, swung behind the Kiley plan saying "his scheme is infinitely preferable to the complete mess of the PPP. We are currently giving it serious and active consideration".

In a potentially crucial development, the national audit office will today to publish its evaluation of the "public sector comparator" being used by the London Underground and the government to decide whether the public private partnership represents better value for money than keeping the scheme in the public sector.

Mr Prescott and Lord Macdonald will meet Mr Kiley today for a second time in a week. The deputy prime minister has said he will shelve his plan if the NAO report shows there are fundamental flaws in his proposals. The report is not expected to reject the PPP option outright but will provide enough critical ammunition to challenge the government's methodology. An aide to Mr Prescott insisted the deputy prime minister was "not about to change his mind. We are standing by the model of the PPP. What Kiley is proposing is a different animal".

Mr Livingstone has backed off from legal challenges in an effort to strike a deal. Mr Kiley wants details of the private sector bids, but the government is refusing on the grounds that they are commercially confidential.

Mr Kiley has warned contracts drawn up with private sector bidders to run the tube are "most unlikely to produce the performance necessary to restore the system to a good state of repair".

His own blueprint claims £10bn can be raised over 15 years through a mixture of passenger revenue, congestion charging, a £250m annual government grant and cash raised from the private sector.

Mr Kiley proposes a limited company would sell about £2bn worth of bonds to the private sector to finance tube development. The plan is different from that previously proposed by Mr Livingstone since there is no government guarantee on the bonds, so ensuring the taxpayer is not the lender of the last resort.

Maintenance work would be contracted out with penalties or threat of loss of contract for sub-standard performance. Responsibility would remain with a single board.

Mr Kiley is opposed to divsion of the tube into different sections, an idea integral to the PPP, because he believes it creates a safety risk similar to the difficulties currently crippling the railways.

Mr Prescott's PPP would see private sector consortiums taking over lines, while signals services and train services would remain in the public sector.

webTitle: Free lunch at the pub with no power

fields.headline: Free lunch at the pub with no power
fields.trailText: He chatted with the regulars and washed down the food with half a pint but at the end of the improptu visit to a London pub, the outgoing president of the United States failed to reach for his wallet.
fields.body:
He chatted with the regulars and washed down the food with half a pint but at the end of the improptu visit to a London pub, the outgoing president of the United States failed to reach for his wallet.

Challenging the adage "there's no such thing as a free lunch", he polished off gumbo prawns, smoked trout and pecan nut pate, a club sandwich, half a pint of organic lager and a diet Coca Cola, costing a total of £24.70, in the Portobello Gold.

After antique shopping in the Portobello Road with Hillary and Chelsea, Mr Clinton spent 40 minutes standing at the bar chatting to a few of the regulars about Bush's victory and the preceding tussle for the top job.

Mike Bell, owner of the pub, only learned that the president wanted to drop in when more than 20 of his dark-suited security men came in and looked around. "They bloody well did not pay the bill, but I have got an address of someone in America I can send the bill to," Mr Bell said. "He told me: 'I'm in the last stretch of my presidency so I can relax a little.'"

A power cut earlier in the morning had left the pub without electricity and the staff rallied around to make a cold meal.

While Mr Clinton was in the pub, a delivery of oysters from Strangford Lough in Northern Ireland aroused the suspicions of his security men who searched the delivery man for explosives.

The glass the president used was washed and placed back on the shelf before he left to prevent his fingerprints being obtained.

Caroline McBride, office manager of the Portobello Gold, said. "We were in the middle of a power cut so everyone pitched in to try and prepare something for him. We managed some bar snacks and lit some candles."

One of the regulars asked the president if he believed he could have won another term, if he was able to run for a third term. "He said he thought he'd have won again," Ms McBride said.

"He was like a guy on holiday. It was all very casual and relaxed. We were all quite touched because when he left he shook all of our hands and thanked us and said that he didn't often get to do this sort of thing."

After putting on a long woollen coat over his dark suit, the president and his entourage slipped back into the waiting fleet of black limousines.

webTitle: Mugabe turns fire on white employers

fields.headline: Mugabe turns fire on white employers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe shifted his attack on Zimbabwe's whites yesterday to the one group he has left untouched until now - powerful business interests.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe shifted his attack on Zimbabwe's whites yesterday to the one group he has left untouched until now - powerful business interests.

Mr Mugabe made the extraordinary claim that his government has no control over the economy, in an attempt to blame white-owned firms for mass unemployment, rising prices and the country's deepening financial crisis.

Business leaders condemned Mr Mugabe's speech to a special congress of his ruling Zanu-PF party, in which he branded the "white man" as the "real enemy". They said some of Zimbabwe's main employers were likely to be driven out if they feared becoming the target of violent attacks like those directed at farmers.

Until now, Mr Mugabe's verbal assaults have largely focused on white farm-owners. He has avoided confrontation with powerful white business interests, but with the economy contracting, by more than 5% this year and probably double that next year, the president needs scapegoats.

Mr Mugabe confessed to his party that Zimbabwe's economy "is modestly performing" and that most people are suffering "severe hardships" from fuel shortages, high unemployment, rising prices and foreign exchange shortages which have curtailed imports.

But he brushed aside charges that government overspending, corruption and its seizure of farms are to blame.

"Many people blame us, the government, our party, for all the economic ills that affect our country, but those who control the economy are a racial group...They discriminate in every way possible against the majority of the people, they determine how far we can go and what changes are possible," he said.

"We do not create employment because we do not own our means of production. They who control our economy are the ones who create employment and not the government."

Mr Mugabe's accusations are unlikely to convince the majority of Zimbabwe's voters, who grow more disenchanted with him by the day. But his attack will further dent business confidence in Zimbabwe.

"He blames everybody but the Spice Girls. It's ludicrous. He is looking for ways to cover up his deficiencies and failures," said Danny Meyer, a former head of Zimbabwe's chamber of commerce. "It's getting to the stage where people are shrinking their businesses because it is so difficult to carry on. Entrepreneurs are leaving, not just whites but blacks and Asians too."

In his speech, Mr Mugabe also turned on whites in general. "They say: 'I'm white and so I have the divine right to ride roughshod over all others who don't have my skin colour, especially the black ones.' Goodness me. What do they think we are?" he said. "Our party must continue to strike fear in the hearts of the white man, our real enemy."

The president said the government will defy court rulings barring it from seizing white-owned farms without compensation and ordering the "war veterans" who have occupied farms to leave.

The denunciation of court rulings has led to fears for judges' safety amid warnings from the justice ministry that war veterans and Zanu-PF supporters are preparing to use violence to force those who hand down orders against the government to resign.

"It is a very sad development because the judges are defenceless," said Augustine Chikumira, permanent secretary in the ministry. "The matter is now in the hands of the police because they have a duty to protect all citizens."

But the police have failed to protect farmers from attack, and have defied court orders to remove war veterans from illegally occupied land. The police are also stalling on the inquiry into Tuesday's murder of a white farmer, Henry Elsworth, by war veterans.

The veterans' leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi, warned of more confrontation.

"We are not talking to farmers because dialogue has broken down and I don't think it's going to resume. We are now fighting for our land and whosoever is killed, it's tough luck," he said.

webTitle: Scientists find clue to long life in fruit flies

fields.headline: Scientists find clue to long life in fruit flies
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: U S scientists have found a way to double the lifespan of a fruit fly. They altered a gene, bred new flies with it, and watched them survive for up to 71 days instead of 37. It could one day lead to a long-life pill for humans.
fields.body:
U S scientists have found a way to double the lifespan of a fruit fly. They altered a gene, bred new flies with it, and watched them survive for up to 71 days instead of 37. It could one day lead to a long-life pill for humans.

"This study points to the possibility that if you can genetically alter metabolism, you can alter lifespan," said David Finkelstein, of the US National Institute of Aging where the research was done. There may be many genes that control aging. In 1998, a scientist at the California Institute of Technology discovered a fruit fly gene that affected aging and called it Methuselah. But the latest gene is called Indy, short for I'm Not Dead Yet, a line uttered by a supposed plague victim in Monty Python and the Holy Grail.

Fruit flies share 80% of their genes with humans, but have very short lives, which helps researchers identify the properties of their genes quickly.

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Tetbury, Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Tetbury, Gloucestershire
fields.body:
Rumours alleging a dearth of rural policing are belied by my recent experience. I know a guaranteed method of maximising police attention in the comfort of your own home. All you need to do is apply for the renewal of a shotgun certificate, or advise of the sale of a weapon, and then just sit back and wait.

In my case the above course of action resulted in four visits by uniformed officers of the law in three weeks, a barrage of recorded telephone calls as we sought mutually convenient dates and times, and the eventual issue of a new five-year certificate. Every officer was entirely pleasant in the conduct of his or her duties, even the one who looked at me solemnly as he filled in yet another form and asked "Any mental instability, sir?"

This saga started when I concluded that, having given up fun farming with our flock of Herdwicks, I didn't really need the double-barrelled FN 12-bore, semi-choked, which, with magnum cartridges, could kill a fox at 30 yards. But young Pat, who has rough shooting rights over a bit of hill, expressed an interest in a second gun and we came to an agreement. He took it off my hands for a modest sum, we recorded the matter on our respective certificates and sent them off. The first two police visits were about the transfer and attachment of my welded steel armoury cabinet to the wall of the barn conversion in the courtyard. Meanwhile, or so I'm advised, a chat in a lowlife pub and a grubby packet of currency will buy me anything in the field of unlicensed killing weaponry up to the scale of a Kalashnikov. I will not be putting this to the test.

webTitle: Magazine no longer in tune with tastes of teenagers

fields.headline: Magazine no longer in tune with tastes of teenagers
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Melody Maker's glory days were already well behind it when I joined as a freelancer in 1985. Its circulation had dropped from 200,000 in the prog-rock early 1970s to 75,000.
fields.body:
Melody Maker's glory days were already well behind it when I joined as a freelancer in 1985. Its circulation had dropped from 200,000 in the prog-rock early 1970s to 75,000.

The office was an open-plan shambles in central London, around the corner from the NME. The rivalry was real, with both papers, along with the now-defunct Sounds, chasing the same few acts for exclusives.

Floundering for direction, MM embraced grisly goth bands such as The Mission, while the NME, always a step ahead, was running the first British interviews with seminal hip hoppers. MM had also been slow off the mark with punk, dismissing it as insignificant.

Despite such weaknesses, and its cluttered design, it was known as the musicians' paper, and the biggest bands, including Queen, Suede and David Bowie's Spiders from Mars, formed through its classifieds.

What finally killed it was something no one could have foreseen. Britpop came along in the mid-1990s and suddenly everyone from broadsheets to fashion magazines were covering the antics of Oasis and Blur. Melody Maker should have been ideally placed to benefit, and for once it got there early, but when the Gallaghers began turning up in Vogue there was no need to read an inky weekly.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mountain guide cleared
fields.body:
Mountain guide cleared

Mountain guide Roger Wild, 47, was yesterday cleared of blame for the deaths of four venture scouts in an avalanche on Aonach Mor, near Ben Nevis, west Scotland, in December 1998. A fatal accident inquiry report found he was not responsible for the deaths of Emma Ray, 29, and Paul Hopkins, 28, both from Wilmington, Kent, Matthew Lewis, 28, and Ian Edwards, 30, both from Dartford, Kent.

Big rise in sex diseases

Sexually transmitted diseases in the UK have reached a 10-year high, according to public health laboratory service figures published today. Rates of chlamydia and gonorrhoea have risen dramatically.

Ex-spy in line for freedom award

Former MI5 agent David Shayler has been shortlisted for the Index on Censorship international whistleblower of the year award, set up to recognise individuals who have stood up for freedom of speech.

Wrong body cremated

Grieving relatives cremated the wrong person after the Co-operative Funeral Service mixed up the body of a woman, who was supposed to be buried, for that of a man with a similar surname, it was revealed yesterday.

Police spread a little cheer

Police are sending Birmingham's most prolific burglars and robbers Christmas cards with the message: "May the peace and joy of Christmas be with you the whole year through. Thinking of you this Christmas and into the New Year, Best wishes, Thornhill Road police."

Two questioned over boy's death

Two 17-year-old youths were being questioned by police yesterday after Ross Doyle, nine, was knocked down by a car and killed near his home in Oxford on Wednesday evening.

Army steps up hunt for recruit

The search for a missing 16-year-old army recruit, Christopher Lee Garrett, was stepped up last night after more than 60 soldiers and an RAF helicopter failed to find any clues. He was last seen on Tuesday evening at the Army Foundation College at Harrogate, north Yorkshire.

Asylum seekers TB warning

Asylum seekers entering the UK through Heathrow have tuberculosis rates 22% higher than the British average, a study shows today. The findings highlight the need for tighter TB screening, say researchers.

David Coleman to leave BBC

David Coleman, 74, the "voice of BBC sport", is leaving the corporation after 46 years. His contract expires at the end of the year and will not be renewed.

webTitle: Judges wrong to rule out 'illegal' DNA evidence

fields.headline: Judges wrong to rule out 'illegal' DNA evidence
fields.standfirst: Law lords' decision too late to allow retrial of murder and rape cases
fields.trailText: Two men linked by "compelling" DNA evidence to a brutal rape and a murder can never be convicted of the crimes even though five law lords decided yesterday that judges in the crown court and court of appeal were wrong to exclude the evidence as inadmissible.
fields.body:
Two men linked by "compelling" DNA evidence to a brutal rape and a murder can never be convicted of the crimes even though five law lords decided yesterday that judges in the crown court and court of appeal were wrong to exclude the evidence as inadmissible.

The two men went free after rulings that DNA samples from other investigations matched to DNA found at the murder and rape crime scenes could not be put before juries because the Police and Criminal Evidence Act required samples to be destroyed if the defendant was acquitted. Both were previously acquitted of the other offences - a burglary and a drug-related offence.

But despite the law lords' ruling yesterday, neither can be tried again for the murder or the rape because they have been cleared and cannot be tried on the same facts. The man accused of rape was acquitted after the evidence of the match with the earlier DNA sample was ruled inadmissible at his trial. The other man, Michael Weir, was convicted of murder but had his conviction quashed after the appeal court ruled that the DNA evidence allowed at his trial had been inadmissible.

Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, referred the case to the Lords after the appeal court ruling caused an outcry. The law lords ruled that the appeal judges were wrong to exclude the evidence, even though it had been kept in breach of the act. Lord Steyn said: "In my view the austere interpretation which the court of appeal adopted is not only in conflict with the plain words of the statute but also produces results which are contrary to good sense."

Lord Cooke of Thorndon said there was no principle that unlawfully obtained evidence was not admissible.

Respect for the privacy of de fendants was not the only value at stake, said Lord Hutton, adding: "The purpose of the criminal law is to protect citizens from harm and that there must be fairness to all, to the victim and to the public as well as to defendants."

Lord Steyn said: "The purpose of the criminal law is to permit everyone to go about their daily lives without fear of harm to person or property. And it is in the interests of everyone that serious crime should be effectively investigated and prosecuted."

The rape case involved a man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, who allegedly broke into the London home of a 66-year-old woman in January 1997, tied her hands with flex and raped her before putting her in a hall cupboard. Police found her 18 hours later.

Lord Steyn said: "The ordeal of the woman was horrendous and the offence of rape was of the utmost gravity."

A DNA profile was obtained from semen found on the woman and included in the national DNA database.

A year later the man was charged with an unrelated offence of burglary, when he gave a false name to the police.

A DNA sample was taken but he was acquitted, and therefore the sample should have been destroyed. Two months later a match was made between the DNA samples. Further DNA profiling found that the chances of the samples not being from the same man were one in 17m.

The man was charged with burglary, assault and rape and at his trial the prosecution relied solely on DNA evidence, which the judge ruled was inadmissible.

Weir was sentenced to life at the Old Bailey in July 1999, after being linked by a DNA sample to the murder of the owner of a flat in north London in January 1998. But the DNA sample was taken after he was charged with drugs- related offences in August 1997, and acquitted.

webTitle: Whitehall unlikely to hit target for women in top jobs

fields.headline: Whitehall unlikely to hit target for women in top jobs
fields.trailText: Britain's most powerful civil servant admitted that Whitehall will have great difficulty in meeting its target of opening one in three top jobs to highly qualified women.
fields.body:
Britain's most powerful civil servant admitted that Whitehall will have great difficulty in meeting its target of opening one in three top jobs to highly qualified women.

The warning from Sir Richard Wilson, head of the civil service and cabinet secretary, came yesterday as a report revealed that women still have serious problems breaking the glass ceiling in the public sector.

Figures released in the civil service annual report reveal that although the percentage of women getting jobs among the top 3,000 civil servants has jumped from 17.8% to 22%, it was still far short of the government's target of 35%.

Among the most senior civil servants - from under secretaries to permanent secretaries - the percentage of women had risen from 12.7% to 18%. But this still fell far short of the government's target of 25%.

Sir Richard said yesterday: "Although for the first time among new recruits there is a parity between men and women getting jobs, we will have great difficulty in reaching the 35% target among senior civil servant posts." His views were confirmed yesterday by a report from the Hansard commission on Women at the Top.

The report's author, Karen Ross, called for a "strong steer" from government to encourage action from employers to ensure that qualified women are not passed over for promotion in government, the civil service, the courts, the NHS and the education system.

The commission chairwoman, Lady Howe, said: "The attitudinal barrier - the clubby culture as we sometimes called it - to women entering the very top decision making levels remains firmly fixed."

Yesterday's report comes 10 years after the commission's first study, and finds that, while there has been some progress, it has come "nowhere near" matching the abilities and ambitions of the most talented women.

The Hansard Society director, Shelagh Diplock, said: "Since the launch of the influential commission report in 1990, there has been much talk of women moving up and even taking over from men in the world of work and public life.

"Dr Ross's report is a timely reminder that urgent consideration still has to be given to ensuring that women's talents are properly valued in the public sector."

The civil service annual report showed that Whitehall's record has improved in recruiting people from ethnic minorities and disabilities. More top jobs are open to people from outside and inititatives are being made to get better feedback from staff.

webTitle: Toddlers in parental leave protest

fields.headline: Child's pay
fields.standfirst: Toddlers in parental leave protest
fields.trailText: They were working on the rationale that this is a government that listens to truckers. But the convoy blocking the entrance of the Department of Trade and Industry yesterday bore little resemblance to the burly hauliers at the forefront of the fuel protest.
fields.body:
They were working on the rationale that this is a government that listens to truckers. But the convoy blocking the entrance of the Department of Trade and Industry yesterday bore little resemblance to the burly hauliers at the forefront of the fuel protest.

The "baby blockade", with eight-year-old Harry Cooke, from Brixton, south London, clutching a "Please pay parental leave" balloon, saw around a dozen toddlers and babes in arms turn up with their toy trucks and tractors, plus grinning parents.

The parents, representing 77 organisations including the Maternity Alliance, the NSPCC and unions, were protesting that parental leave, which was introduced a year ago and permits 13 weeks' leave up until a child's fifth birthday, is only offered to parents of babies born after December 15 1999, is too inflexible, with only four weeks being permitted each year, and - most crucially - is not paid.

webTitle: Mafia 'built UN's citadel of justice'

fields.headline: Mafia 'built UN's citadel of justice'
fields.trailText: A Palermo conference centre hosting a United Nations forum on international organised crime was itself largely built by the Mafia, it has been claimed.
fields.body:
A Palermo conference centre hosting a United Nations forum on international organised crime was itself largely built by the Mafia, it has been claimed.

The embarrassing allegation, contained in two anonymous letters sent to the city judicial authorities, is now the subject of an investigation by Palermo magistrates.

Details of the investigation were published yesterday by the newspaper La Repubblica. "The palace of the anti-mafia was built by the Mafia. All of it, from the foundations to the roof," the paper said.

Contracts for construction work on the modern glass and steel complex, which will house judicial offices once the UN delegates have moved on, were divided up among mafia-owned firms, it said.

Pietro Grasso, Palermo's chief public prosecutor, confirmed yesterday that his office had opened an investigation into the claims, contained in the one-page letters posted on September 18.

The news is a further blow for the mayor of Palermo, Leoluca Orlando, whose name was published in a list of politicians and businessmen allegedly linked to the Mafia on the eve of the meeting .

Mr Orlando is considered a hero of the struggle to liberate Sicily from the mob's stranglehold, and investigators said the allegation that he was a Mafia accomplice was an old claim from an unreliable witness.

The inquiry will seek to determine whether Mafia-controlled firms won contracts to build the "justice citadel", which will house 28 court rooms and 370 offices in a 37,000 square metre complex.

News of the investigation will come as a shock to those - notably the executive director of the UN office for drug control and crime prevention, Pino Arlacchi - who recently suggested that the Mafia was on its last legs, and to residents of Palermo who were proud of their city's unaccustomed status as a role model in the fight against organised crime.

The first contract for the building was won by a Rome company called Sinces Chiementin, which was secretly controlled by one of the Mafia's most ruthless bosses, Giovanni Brusca, La Repubblica said.

Before the first excavator moved into action, the plans for the entire complex were said to be in the hands of Toto Riina, the now imprisoned "boss of bosses". The man who gave him refuge during his last days on the run, Giuseppe Montalbano, owned another of the firms involved in the construction work, the paper said.

Among the delegates in Palermo yesterday was David Trimble, the Northern Ireland first minister, who attended a symposium on the role of civil society in countering organised crime. Mr Trimble hoped to learn from the Sicilian experience of breaking the social influence of organised crime groups.

"I have been warning of the danger of a mafia-type culture developing in Northern Ireland as paramilitaries move out of terrorism into organised crime," he said. "The peace process will not have been successful if we simply replace one kind of organised crime with another."

webTitle: MP to push bill for easier adoption

fields.headline: MP to push bill for easier adoption
fields.trailText: Plans to make it easier for more parents to adopt could become law after an MP yesterday won the right to introduce new legislation through a private member's bill.
fields.body:
Plans to make it easier for more parents to adopt could become law after an MP yesterday won the right to introduce new legislation through a private member's bill.

Caroline Spelman, Tory MP for Meriden, is to introduce a bill which would set up a national register of would-be adoptive parents as well as national eligibility criteria. At the moment criteria on age, race, sexuality and even weight can differ from one local authority to another. Ms Spelman won the right to introduce the plans when she came sixth in yesterday's ballot of MPs to bring forward a private member's bill. The ballot, held at the start of each parliamentary session, allows those in the top half dozen or so an opportunity to introduce bills on their pet subjects.

Ms Spelman's bill could have tacit government backing, after Tony Blair signalled his intention of addressing adoption law earlier this year. webTitle: Melody Maker pensioned off

fields.headline: Melody Maker pensioned off
fields.standfirst:
Declining sales put paid to veteran of music press

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Declining sales put paid to veteran of music press
fields.body:
The wrinkly rocker of the British music press, Melody Maker, has finally been pensioned off, overtaken by its hip younger rival NME.

The Maker, as it is affectionately known, has been published weekly since 1926. But it was finally killed off by IPC, owners of both publications, blaming falling sales which made the music paper "unsustainable".

News of the closure of the world's oldest weekly pop magazine puts a question mark over the future of other music publications which have been experiencing declining sales.

Two weeks ago the monthly music magazine Select was forced to close because of falling readership and competition from the internet, in particular bands' own websites. The 90s saw the demise of Sounds, reflecting an increasingly competitive market.

Critics said NME had always outperformed its rival and had learned better than Melody Maker from the underground press. It had picked up more quickly on both punk-as-politics and post-punk as post-modernism.

By contrast, Melody Maker looked turgid and limped along with 10 page articles on the band Yes, and with a design which reflected the then editor Ray Coleman's belief that "it should look like the Daily Telegraph". It earned the unenviable nickname Monotony Maker.

At its last audited circulation, Melody Maker was selling 32,500 copies, the lowest figure in its history, down 14.9% year on year. Few bands bothered advertising gigs because readership was so low.

The magazine also failed to get interviews with frontline pop groups as most preferred NME. There were few big name writers left either, most having been poached or defected to other publications.

In a last attempt to revive the flagging magazine's fortunes, IPC changed Melody Maker's format from broadsheet to magazine size in October last year. It hoped to attract younger readers in the 16 to 20 bracket rather than the 22-year-old age group. But this proved disastrous and reduced readership still further.

In an interview with NME's music website, IPC's managing director, Mike Soutar, said: "We are merging Melody Maker into the NME brand. The final issue of Melody Maker will be published at Christmas.

"We are ceasing the magazine's publication because, unfortunately, market conditions made continued publishing impossible. The magazine was doing exactly what it should have been doing but the readers were just not there in sufficient numbers to keep it viable." Mr Soutar said various options had been investigated, including changing the magazine to a monthly.

"But as Emap's recent closure of Select magazine indicates, the monthly indie rock market is as tough as the weekly market."

Last night, Radio One disc jockey Steve Lamacq said Melody Maker had always been perceived as the musicians' paper. It was founded as a magazine for musicians, and most major bands and Britpop groups found fellow band members through ads in its classified section.

"That's the one thing NME will look to retain, because Melody Maker has been an integral part of the music scene," he said.

"Editorially, the magazine was really about jazz in the mid-70s and prog rock. It got into punk slightly quicker than the NME and evolved during the 80s into something that was more left of centre, indie and alternative rock. In the last 20 years, that sort of music has been in and out of fashion, but Melody Maker was always behind the NME in sales.

"For a while, Melody Maker was more well known in the States than NME but it never really capitalised on the times when it was doing well in this country. But it has been going down, in tandem with most other publications, for the past five or six years."

He added: "The closure was a business decision. Melody Maker was just not selling enough copies to keep it going. If you go back 10 years, you would scour the Melody Maker for singles reviews and think 'I'll buy that because it sounds quite good'. But now if you go through the singles reviews in both NME and Melody Maker, you will have already heard two-thirds of those on the radio.

"Also, you can get gossip from the internet. Many bands have their own websites that give you far more information than the music press. Garbage, Ash and the Offspring all have regularly updated diaries of what they are doing, so you are getting that info straight from the horse's mouth."

webTitle: Political rivals awarded TV time to balance Blair show

fields.headline: Political rivals awarded TV time to balance Blair show
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A series of political broadcasts running at peak viewing times over the next week could be the result of a crucial ruling by the independent television commission, ordering Scottish Television to make its screens available to opposition parties following the prime minister's question and answer show on ITV on Tuesday night.
fields.body:
It's the Christmas TV schedule no one would have picked. A series of political broadcasts running at peak viewing times over the next week.

But it could be the result of a crucial ruling by the independent television commission ordering Scottish Television to make its screens available to opposition parties following the prime minister's question and answer show on ITV on Tuesday night.

The live 7pm broadcast, Ask the Prime Minister, which saw Mr Blair grilled by members of the public, was the subject of complaints to the ITC by the Conservatives and the Scottish National party. They said it was unfair and that it would give Labour a tactical advantage in next week's Falkirk West byelection.

In a statement issued yesterday, the ITC upheld the complaints and said the programme had relevance to the byelection, which is scheduled for December 21. It directed STV to provide "relevant major political parties in Scotland an opportunity to comment on current political issues in a manner proportionate to the party political dimension of the opportunity afforded to the Rt Hon Tony Blair MP and the Labour party".

The commission said any broadcasts should be transmitted at peak time on or before December 20 but it denied yesterday that the ruling meant each party had to be offered a similar hour-long slot.

"It does not actually say that," said an ITC spokeswoman. "It has got to be proportionate to what was done for the Labour party, but we don't specify the exact length or format. It is now up to STV to come up with a formula before the byelection which is acceptable to the ITC."

STV officials immediately sought clarification of the ruling and took legal advice. They said they did not believe the prime minister's programme was in contravention of the code of impartiality but said they had taken advice from the ITC before it had been screened north of the border.

"It is simply not clear what is being asked of us," said the STV managing director, Sandy Ross. "We have a duty to consider all courses of action to make sense of these rules."

The SNP leader, John Swinney, said the ruling was a vindication of the party's complaints but also had crucial implications for the next general election campaign.

The Scottish Liberal Democrat spokesman Iain Smith said the prime minister was given the opportunity "time after time" to make points of benefit to the Labour party.

London Weekend Television, the show's producer, said it had been scheduled before the byelection date was announced, but steps were taken to avoid issues relevant to the contest.

webTitle: New Labour millionaire appointed vice-chairman of the BBC

fields.headline: 'Tony crony' joins BBC board
fields.standfirst:
New Labour millionaire Gavyn Davies in line for chair

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Downing Street ran into a fresh row over "cronyism" yesterday when the multi-millionaire New Labour economist Gavyn Davies was appointed vice-chairman of the BBC.
fields.body:
Downing Street ran into a fresh row over "cronyism" yesterday when the multi-millionaire New Labour economist Gavyn Davies was appointed vice-chairman of the BBC.

Tony Blair was accused of prejudicing the impartiality of the corporation after No 10 announced the appointment of Mr Davies, whose partner Sue Nye works for Gordon Brown.

Mr Davies, 50, who became a multi-millionaire when Goldman Sachs was floated on the stock exchange last year, will replace Lady Young of Old Scone, who retired last month.

A member of Harold Wilson and James Callaghan's policy units, Mr Davies chaired the independent review into the funding of the BBC in 1999. In his report he said the governors, whom he now joins, were poor regulators because they were too closely associated with BBC management.

Mr Davies, who will remain chief economist at Goldman Sachs, said he looked forward to taking up the appointment, which will be part-time.

"The BBC plays a vital role in the culture of our nation and in supporting our democracy," he said. "I am excited at the prospect of helping to sustain the BBC's impact and creativity in the future."

His appointment puts him in prime position to succeed Sir Christopher Bland as chairman when his term ends in 2003. No 10 acted quickly to head off the accusation of cronyism by saying that Mr Davies was the personal choice of Sir Christopher, who was appointed by the Tories. Mr Davies was appointed according to the "Nolan" rules, designed to prevent political bias in public appointments.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, said: "The BBC got the man that they wanted. Sir Christopher Bland indicated to us that he and his colleagues at the BBC had no doubt that Gavyn Davies was the best person."

A Downing Street statement said he had "not undertaken any significant political activity in the last five years".

Sir Christopher said: "Gavyn Davies is a strong supporter of the BBC and has a deep understanding of and belief in the value of public service broadcasting in the digital age."

"His economic, business and broadcasting expertise will make him a valuable member of the board of governors."

The Tories, whose campaign to prevent the appointment of the Labour supporter Greg Dyke as director general backfired in spectacular fashion, decided to remain quiet about the appointment. Sir Christopher, who enthusiastically backed Mr Dyke's appointment, publicly rebuked William Hague for his intervention.

The Liberal Democrats' broadcasting spokesman, Norman Baker, said: "The BBC are at pains to stress their political impartiality. But that is difficult to sustain with the appointment of someone who is so close to New Labour. This looks like Tony's cronies."

Mr Davies has been tipped for a series of high-profile jobs because of his links with New Labour. He has often been spoken of as a possible governor of the Bank of England.

webTitle: Who Wants to be a Millionaire? still on air in 20 years - according to Avesco

fields.headline: Avesco presents 2020 vision for Millionaire
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Britain's most popular game show, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? will still be on air in 20 years, according to the media company Avesco, which is reaping rewards from the programme's success.
fields.body:
Britain's most popular game show, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? will still be on air in 20 years, according to the media company Avesco, which is reaping rewards from the programme's success.

Avesco's half-year profits rose 86% to £5.7m thanks its 49% stake in Complete Communications, which owns the show's producer, Celador.

Chief executive David Nicholson believes Millionaire will amount to far more than a short-term craze. He compared it to long runners such as Bruce Forsyth's Play Your Cards Right and Jeopardy in the US.

"It'll still be on air in 2020. There are plenty of long-running shows out there which have had nothing like Millionaire's profile."

More than 2,000 episodes have been aired, in 35 countries. The show was recently introduced to viewers in France, Iceland and Russia, and had a record-breaking run on national television in India.

Royalties are beginning to roll in from a Who Wants to be a Millionaire? boardgame and electronic versions have been released for games consoles.

Mr Nicholson said there were plenty of opportunities still to explore, including "new media" ventures such as offering an internet version.

Avesco's income from Complete Communications rose from £301,000 to £2.82m. Mr Nicholson said: "We've got to be very, very pleased with those returns. It's given us substantial profits and cash flow."

The remaining 51% of Complete is held by a number of shareholders, including the comedian Jasper Carrott.

Mr Nicholson admitted Avesco's interest in Who Wants to be a Millionaire? was beginning to overshadow the rest of its activities: "Our expectation is that Millionaire will overtake the contribution from our core activities within a year."

The rump of Avesco's business is corporate presentations, such as organising displays for the Detroit motor show.

Avesco's shares, which had reached £12 this year, slipped 20p to 745p.

webTitle: Leader: Bush and Putin

fields.headline: Mr Putin gets to work
fields.standfirst:
George W Bush will find him a handful
Special report: Russia
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: With intriguing symbolism, the first day of the Bush ascendancy has coincided with the first visit to Cuba by   a Russian leader since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
fields.body:
With intriguing symbolism, the first day of the Bush ascendancy has coincided with the first visit to Cuba by a Russian leader since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Vladimir Putin is a pushy chap. Since succeeding Boris Yeltsin last March, he has been busily challenging America's global hegemony, as seen from Moscow, at every opportunity. He has intervened directly in the US-led Middle East peace process, given succour to Iraq, and resumed arms sales to Iran and Libya. He visited North Korea, that most roguish of US-designated "rogue states", and cheekily claimed to have curbed its menacing missiles. He went to India, bidding to revive Soviet-era ties in direct competition with Bill Clinton's efforts to woo Delhi last spring; and has increased military and political cooperation with China - identified by Mr Bush as a potential 21st-century antagonist. Mr Putin regularly stresses Russia's national interests in the Balkans, its opposition to Nato expansion and its deep dislike of Mr Bush's plans for a treaty-busting national missile defence system. Now here he is in Havana, getting chummy with America's chief bogeyman, Fidel Castro.

Mr Putin's aim is partly new business and investment; partly recovery of old debts. But this geopolitical assertiveness is also a broader expression of his determination to make Russia a force in the world again. Although a distracted Washington has taken its eye off the ball, the challenge this represents to the US president-designate should not be minimised. Mr Putin is six years younger than Mr Bush, tougher and more experienced, and probably a lot smarter.

In some areas, US-Russian interests coincide. Both countries seek to curb international terrorism; an accord was signed in Moscow this week. Both worry about Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Islamic insurgencies in central Asia. Both are pledged to promote bilateral trade; and Russia badly needs US support for further loans and credit to support market reforms. Mr Putin says he wants good relations with the west. Hence his cosy chats with Tony Blair and his pardoning of a US "spy". He has even indicated flexibility on NMD and Nato issues. But there is a darker, scarier side to Mr Putin, as seen in Chechnya. This Putin has a vision of a proud, revived Russia again advancing at home and abroad to the tune of the old Red Army anthem. His vision has power, purpose and coherence. Is poor Dubya ready for this? You tell us.

webTitle: Cheney builds the Bush team

fields.headline: Cheney builds the Bush team
fields.standfirst:
Taking over 7,000 jobs to fill as new administration moves in

Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Taking over 7,000 jobs to fill as new administration moves in
fields.body:
Officials of the federal General Services Administration yesterday presented America's new vice-president elect, Dick Cheney, with the keys to the official Washington city centre offices where the incoming team will be based for the next five weeks.

America's new Republican government is formally known as the Bush-Cheney administration, but the handover signalled that it might be more accurate to call it the Cheney-Bush team.

While it was left to Mr Cheney to take yet another of the important steps towards installing the new government in the US capital, president elect George W Bush went to church and held private meetings in Austin yesterday, much as he has done for most of the past month.

In the weeks since election day, it has been Mr Cheney who has set up the Bush transition team, who has interviewed potential members of the administration, and who has taken charge of negotiations with congressional lead ers about the legislative agenda.

The government-in-waiting had been based in Washington's Virginia suburbs, near to Mr Cheney's home, while the court wrangles in Florida were being played out. Now they can begin moving in to 90,000 sq ft of offices just two blocks away from the White House.

Just as important, Mr Cheney also got access yesterday to $5.3m dollars (£3.6m) that are set aside in the federal budget to pay for the transition.

"We're moving forward with the transition," Mr Cheney said. "Things are going well."

For a man who suffered a fourth minor heart attack only last month, Mr Cheney is being forced to set a demanding pace and carry out a punishing schedule as he takes up a role which seems more akin to that of prime minister than the traditional marginal vice-presidential role.

Mr Cheney exemplifies the much noticed fact that many of the most important posts in the new Bush administration will be taken by people who also worked for the new president's father when he was in office a decade ago. But his background - as a former congressman, White House chief of staff and defence secretary - also fills in many of the gaps in Mr Bush's own experience.
