webTitle: The watershed moment in film that was ... Emmanuelle

fields.headline: My kind of woman
fields.standfirst: Emmanuelle was the original soft-core, soft-focus romp - and marked a watershed moment in British censorship. It also gave a young  Alex Cox  a daring new chat-up line
fields.trailText: Emmanuelle was the original soft-core, soft-focus romp - and marked a watershed moment in British censorship. It also gave a young Alex Cox a daring new chat-up line
fields.body:
In 1974 I saw a film which powerfully influenced me for several weeks. It was Emmanuelle - a controversial but highly popular soft-core porno movie based on a scandalous bestseller about the sex lives of bored, rich, French expatriates in Thailand. It was directed by a fashion photographer called Just Jaeckin and starred a fabulously beautiful woman one assumed was French but who turned out to be Dutch - Sylvia Kristel. Emmanuelle's only "known" element was the former newwave actor Alain Cuny. Cuny, who hated the project, played a tuxedoed roué who seduces the eponymous heroine. His character's name was Mario.

I was so impressed by Emmanuelle and Cuny's absurdist performance that I decided to try his pick-up line "Let me take you to the dernières limites... of erotisme!" on all practical occasions. It did not work.

Emmanuelle, on the other hand, worked very well. As the US trailer breathlessly intoned, "Twelve million Frenchmen stood in line for it!" I suspect there were a few Frenchwomen in that line as well. James Ferman, who was then the British film censor, recalls seeing Emmanuelle in a cinema full of groups of young women. It was the first sex film to play in "normal" British cinemas: Ferman says it was "the first film [of its genre] that didn't play to the raincoat brigade".

Emmanuelle suffered the lash of censorship. A scene in a bar - shot by another director, disowned by Jaeckin - was cut by the BBFC, as was a sequence in which Mario encourages the rape of Emmanuelle as part of her sexual "education". Kristel disliked the scene and refused to play it in an erotic way. "I pulled faces," she recalls. Today Ferman defends cutting the rape scene. He feels the BBFC can afford greater licence in scenes of consensual sex, but that rape fantasies should still be forbidden. He makes his case well, though his view is not shared by feminists such as Linda Ruth Williams or Nadine Strossen, of the American Civil Liberties Union. Emmanuelle was screened uncut in American cinemas: I saw it there a few years later, along with Jaeckin's banned-in-Britain The Story of O. Neither film left me feeling particularly corrupted.

Just Jaeckin says his film was the first to portray lesbianism in a positive way: in fact it was preceded by the similar Bilitis and Thérèse and Isabelle. But these films didn't reach the wide audience Jaeckin's feature did. Emmanuelle set the template for 1,000 soft-focus softcore fantasy sequences on film and paper. Emmanuelle quickly became a franchise, more than one franchise in fact. French producer Alain Sirisky made a series of subsequent features all claiming to be based on the book by Emanuelle Arsan. Kristel appeared in at least four of them. The Italians, unbeatable at generic rip-offs, came up with their own series of Emanuelle movies - note the single "m"!

Their series starred Laura Gemser. While Kristel's Emmanuelle was a bored European housewife, sometimes vulnerable, sometimes manipulative, often naked, Gemser's Emanuelle was a New York-based Indonesian photojournalist who in the course of her work often had to get naked.

The genre ran out of steam in the mid-1980s: as videos became ubiquitous, porno went portable. A sure sign of any form's demise is its being absorbed into the popular culture via a Carry On film: the Carry On Emmannuelle (with an extra "n") followed inevitably. Today one of the franchises continues in a series of cable and straight-to-video movies, but Emmanuelle is seen no more on the big screen. Not that anything remotely similar has taken its place there. With the exception of the Emmanuelle-ish Eyes Wide Shut, sex is almost invisible now in a cinema geared to knee-jerk scenes of sentimentality and violence.

But the Emmanuelle films remain, entertaining, sexy, and a little mad. They may also seem old-fashioned, arch, vapid, camp. They are atrociously dubbed. It's hard to imagine them being taken seriously, or giving real offence. But they were controversial and ground-breaking in 1974 - forcing back the power of film censorship in France, Britain and elsewhere. My enthusiasm for these films is not just that I find them funny and a turn-on. I like them in the same way I enjoyed The Trip, Django, Trash, and The War Game. These were all films from which the "authorities" of the day felt British viewers must be protected.

Yet the individual quality of these films is less important than the civil liberty issues they represent. The Lord Chamberlain no longer gets to censor the theatre, and high court judges have less jurisdiction over whether or not our servants can read Lady Chatterley. Yet films and television - particularly films - are subject to a degree of paternalistic control in this country which seems inexplicable as soon as one travels abroad.

Gemser eventually got bored by a career which culminated in Emanuelle Vs the Cannibals. Having scrupulously saved her money, she retired to the mountains outside Rome. Kristel remains a working actress, living in Amsterdam. The two worked together only once, on the first sequel, Emmanuelle: the Joys of a Woman. For my money this is the best of the series. Joys of a Woman takes up where Emmanuelle left off. In a brief hour and a half, it escorts the viewer on a "tour" of erotic situations in the same way that Sergio Leone's masterpiece, Once Upon a Time in the West, leads us through a landscape of western movie conventions.

The film begins aboard a packet steamer. Emmanuelle has booked a stateroom. But lo! No staterooms are available. After rejecting the advances of a sleazy crew member, she finds herself in a dormitory full of semi-naked Asian women. A fellow passenger, clad in white underwear (one of the film's recurrent motifs!) tells Emmanuelle how she was raped at school. There is a flashback demonstrating this. But this is pure fantasy, as the lupine Emmanuelle is aware. Her fellow traveller's story is just that - a story, designed to entice Emmanuelle to lustful deeds.

As the film progresses, further archetypal sexual situations present themselves, like the gunfighters and villainous railroad magnates of Leone's film. Emmanuelle has sex with a black dance instructor, a tattooed polo player, her husband, and deflowers an ingenue. There is erotic massage. There is cartoon sex (still banned by the BBFC for its "explicitness"!). Emmanuelle is no longer the innocent, but the manipulatrix. She provokes increasingly bizarre situations, and fantasises about having sex with three sailors (clad in sailor suits, of course). But she is always in control.

As if to emphasize the comedy inherent in all this, the director includes a character called "the aviator". First seen taking a bath (this is the only softcore Emmanuelle film to show frontal male nudity), the aviator hangs around the heroine's lavish pad with a huge aeroplane propeller - a sexual symbol, or a surrealist one? He and she never have sex, and the aviator finally announces: "Well, I'm off to the airport." (People are always off to the airport in these movies: the shot of the plane taking off replacing the venerable train-entering-the-tunnel). "Don't forget your propeller," Emmanuelle's husband replies.

Emmanuelle: the Joys of a Woman was directed by another fashion photographer, Francis Giacobetti. I called him at his Paris flat and tried to chat about about his quite remarkable film. Giacobetti demurred. "It is very charming of you to call, and I am happy to talk to you about almost anything. I'm actually a bit of an Anglophile! But Emmanuelle 2? No - I have no time for these films. They are rubbish!"

Perhaps they are. So are most motion pictures. But I think Giacobetti is too critical of his own work, with its powerful cine-referential images, dreamlike, erotic and surreal. Even 26 years on, show me a beautiful Dutch woman and an aviator leaning against his propeller, and I'll still offer to take them to the dernières limites de l'érotisme...

In my dreams.

 Alex Cox's documentary Emmanuelle - A Hard Look will be shown on Channel 4 in the New Year.

webTitle: The best intelligent pet scene

fields.headline: The best intelligent pet scene
fields.standfirst: Meet the parents
fields.trailText: Meet the parents
fields.body:
Having arrived at his prospective in-laws with fiancée Pam Byrnes (Teri Polo), Greg Focker (Ben Stiller) watches as Pam's father Jack (Robert De Niro) summons his pet cat, Jinx. Pam and her mother Dina (Blythe Danner) stand beside him.

"Hello Jinxy! Come to Daddy!"

Bounding up the hallway, the cat jumps into Jack's arms. Jack beams at Greg.

"Jinxy, say hello to Greg! Say 'Hello', Jinx!"

The cat holds up its front paw. Everyone gasps in admiration.

Greg turns to Pam.

"I didn't know you had a cat."

"Yeah, Daddy got him when I moved to Chicago. And then he had a new best friend."

Dina leans toward him.

"Oh Greg, he's even taught him to use a potty. It's so weird."

"What's so weird about it?" Jack blusters. "Now we don't have to smell kitty litter all day. Right, Jinxy?"

Greg tries to find the right thing to say.

"That's incredible. How did you teach the cat to use the toilet?"

"Oh, that was easy Greg. I just designed a litter box, put it inside the toilet, and then when he got used to it, I took it away."

"Well, that makes sense."

"But I don't think he likes it very much," coos Dina.

"Plus," says Greg, "now you got another guy around the house to leave the seat up."

Greg waits for someone to laugh. Jack stares at Greg as if he were insane.

"He can't lift the seat, Greg. He lacks the strength. And opposable thumbs."

See also: Babe, Dr Dolittle

Don't see also: Beethoven's 2nd

Pointless trivia: The film's director, Jay Roach, is married to Susannah Hoffs, singer from The Bangles.

webTitle: Medical students face higher debts

fields.headline: Medical students face higher debts
fields.trailText: Debts among medical students have risen by 22% over the last year and are particularly hitting students from working class households, a survey by the British Medical Association has found.
fields.body:
Debts among medical students have risen by 22% over the last year and are particularly hitting students from working class households, a survey by the British Medical Association has found.

By the final year of study the total average debt for medical students was just over £9,400.

The BMA's Medical Students Committee, says that the growing debts are alienating the few students from non-professional backgrounds who enrol onto medical courses.

About one in nine of the 2,000 students responding to the survey said that they had no debts. The average level of debt for students was £5,979 and the highest figure was £27,350. The survey found that 6% of students, and 22% of final year students, had a total debt of over £15,000.

Debt were estimated by adding together the outstanding amounts of student loans, overdrafts, bank loans and money owing on credit cards.

The group most likely to have debts over £5,000 were students with parents in skilled manual jobs.

The amount of money students receive from parents also depends on social background, found the survey. Two fifths of those with parents from manual occupations received no money from their parents - more than double that of those from a 'white collar' background.

Overall, the average amount received by those who received some money was £3,214 - about 3% higher than last year's figure of £3,134.

Earlier this year the Medical Students Committee wrote to health secretray, Alan Milburn, expressing fears that potential applicants from lower income backgrounds are being excluded from medicine. The committee said that after maintenance grants were abolished, many students have been forced to secure additional financial support - usually from their families or increasingly from credit card companies.

The survey confirms that medical schools remain the enclave of the upper and middle classes despite attempts to widen access to all social groups.

Just over four-fifths of the students surveyed came from a family in which the main breadwinner was in a professional or managerial occupation. The largest single occupational group was teachers (15%) followed by doctors and related professions (14%) and engineers and technologists (9%). Only 10% came from families where the main breadwinner was in a 'blue collar' or manual occupation.

Andrew Rissik's Troy, a four-and-a-half-hour radio trilogy, was first broadcast in 1998. Gina Landor's adaptation fillets 75 minutes from the original to show an old story from a new perspective. The siege of Troy and the behaviour of Menelaus and Agamemnon is told through the testimony of Helen and Klytemnestra, sisters who are central to the drama and yet somehow seem peripheral to the derring-do of the men in most versions of the story.

This doesn't entirely escape the pitfalls of the one-person play, and there are odd moments when the production, with its projected map of the Aegean, has the feel of a geography lesson. But for the most part it is an unusually riveting solo-actor piece thanks to a simple, clever design, a winning performance from Landor herself, and Rissik's spine-tingling writing, which is hard and dazzling like a beautiful diamond and yet is touched by compassion and wisdom. At the very least, this production should encourage some enterprising company to look back at the original and consider its suitability for a full staging.

The piece begins and ends with Helen. But these are two very different women. The first rises like a mermaid out of a sea of pink. This woman knows she is beautiful, but takes no pleasure in it. Her beauty is deadly, her situation desperate. She cannot love her husband Menelaus - "I never open my mouth; he never closes his." She is easy prey for Paris. She colludes in her own seduction and yet is surprised by love that is "roused like thunder from a summer sky".

Many years and a lifetime later we meet Helen again. She has been stripped of her beauty and her illusions, and yet now she glows. She lost herself in love and found herself in the process.

In between we see Klytemnestra, in mourning for her life and her daughter Iphigenia sacrificed on the altar of her father's desire for success in war. No, men do not go to war over women but for reasons of their own: empire, glory, treasure. Klytemnestra's story demonstrates the truth of that. Landor is excellent, and Emily Couper's design provides a shroud-like set behind which candles burn. But it is Rissik's writing that makes you catch your breath, with its constantly surprising turns of phrase. "Legends are like dreams, they tell us what we need to know," suggests Rissik. Here, he uses ancient stories to show us how to live and love.

 Until December 23. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

webTitle: AtomFilms and Shockwave.com announce merger

fields.headline: AtomFilms and Shockwave.com announce merger
fields.trailText: Two of the internet's leading entertainment sites, Shockwave.com and AtomFilms announced today that they are to merge, in a move that looks set to create the world's leading next-generation entertainment company
fields.body:
Two of the internet's leading entertainment sites, Shockwave.com and AtomFilms announced today that they are to merge. The move will create what could well be the world's leading next-generation entertainment company. The new company will enjoy an unparalleled distribution platform on existing and emerging channels through relationships with more than 100 partners worldwide - including internet sites, broadband services, television, airlines and wireless devices.

The merger is to combine both company's assets and users: AtomFilms and Shockwave have over 30m registered users, and access to 150m worldwide viewers.

Rob Burgess, chairman and chief executive officer of Macromedia and chairman of shockwave.com is to be chairman of the new company, whose headquarters will be in San Francisco. Michael Comish, managing director of Atom Films Europe, will become president.

"AtomFilms and shockwave.com were both created to pioneer new forms of consumer entertainment and to develop new business models for content creators," said Burgess. "By joining the energies and talents of these two highly creative companies, we have the potential to change the way people are entertained around the world."

webTitle: Softening the financial blow of Christmas

fields.headline: Softening the financial blow of Christmas
fields.trailText: 'Tis definitely the season to be jolly. MoneyUnlimited doesn't want to spoil the fun, but does think it's worth mentioning the impact the festive season can have on your finances.
fields.body:
'Tis definitely the season to be jolly. MoneyUnlimited doesn't want to spoil the fun, but does think it's worth mentioning the impact the festive season can have on your finances.

Christmas and the New Year bring their very own insurance risks. Keep them in the back of your mind and, hopefully, you won't be filling in claims forms in the New Year. Here's a few of them:

Drinking and driving
Drinking and driving could lead to a massive increase in your car insurance premiums: up to £400, according to the AA.
A 36-year-old man with a no-claims bonus would, it said, be paying £654 before a drink driving conviction and £1,064 after. And that's assuming someone will insure him. The AA canvassed its members and found three-quarters saying they would not quote for any driver immediately after a drinking offence, whilst half would still not consider insuring him five years after the conviction. An insurance hangover, indeed.

Mini-cabs
If you live in London, beware. Police believe thousands of unlicensed and uninsured mini-cab drivers will be cashing in on the transport dearth over Christmas. If you have an accident whilst travelling in one of these cabs, you can forget about compensation. And drivers should be equally cautious. A crash with one of these cabs will leave you picking up the insurance bill.

Theft
According to Direct Line, burglaries go up 25% over Christmas, with thieves making a £73.2m profit. Drawing back the curtains so the neighbourhood can see your lovely tree with all the presents underneath is, therefore, not a sensible thing to do.

Some insurers, including Direct Line and Royal & SunAlliance, automatically increase home contents cover by 10% over Christmas. But if you're buying expensive gifts, such as a computer or state of the art sound system, it's worth checking that your insurance covers them. Make sure locks on doors and windows are secure - particularly important if you're among the 28% of adults who spend Christmas away from home - and keep those presents hidden.

Fire
Lights and decorations can overload power points, so don't plug them all in the same place and check the plugs have the right fuse: Christmas tree lights need a three amp fuse. Don't leave flexes trailing across the floor and don't leave the tree lights on when you go to bed.

Pets
Fido and Fifi can get quite sick over the festive season if a few precautionary measures aren't taken. First and foremost, don't give your dog chocolate. It contains theobromine which is toxic to dogs, affecting their nervous and cardiovascular systems. Treatment usually involves an operation and this gets expensive. A dog who ate a chocolate orange costs his owner, or in this case his insurer, £543.40.

Wrapping, tree decorations and pine needles can also be hazardous. One cat ate all the wrapping paper and ribbons off the presents and had to have a £110 operation to get 30 metres of ribbon out of her stomach. Pine needles get stuck in animals' throats and tinsel can make them choke.

Holly, mistletoe and poinsettias should also be kept out of reach. Eating them can cause your pet's heartbeat and blood pressure to drop.

Merry Christmas!

webTitle: A pretty inequitable life

fields.headline: A pretty inequitable life
fields.standfirst: One million consumers stand to make losses as a result of the latest financial industry debacle. But could the crisis have been stemmed?
fields.trailText: One million consumers stand to make losses as a result of the latest financial industry debacle. But could the crisis have been stemmed?
fields.body:
The man supposed to protect investors and future pensioners is under siege. Sir Howard Davies, high-profile chairman of the super City regulator the Financial Services Authority, faces tough questions about his role in the run-up to the humiliating end of Equitable Life's 238-year history. More than 1m consumers are facing losses after Equitable Life decided to close its doors to new business.

According to some in the City it is the biggest crisis to hit the financial industry since Barings went bust in 1995. True, Equitable is still solvent but unlike Barings it was unable to find a buyer. Equitable said it needed £1.5bn to solve its problems. Experts warned it was closer to £7.5bn. As many as 15 potential bidders have walked away.

As a result, the recriminations have started to fly and most are being hurled at the FSA. Where was it? The Liberal Democrats want an inquiry. Should the regulator have allowed Equitable to continue selling policies until late last week, despite the fact the law lords had ruled in July, forcing the mutual to put itself up for sale?

Should the FSA help the million Equitable policy-holders who face lower returns than in the past? Perhaps more crucially, questions are being raised about whether something could have been done sooner to prevent Equitable finding itself in a situation where it did not have assets to continue selling new policies while maintaining its obligations to existing policyholders.

Such questions are legitimate. The answers are made more difficult by the fiendishly complicated nature of the insurance industry and the sweeping changes to the way the business is regulated which have been made since the Blair government came to power.

Until January 1998, the Department of Trade and Industry was responsible for regulating insurers. Responsibility was then handed to the Treasury for a year before it was passed to the FSA (Labour's invention) in January 1999. Because of legislative delays, the FSA does not get its full powers until next year.

To add to the confusion, the sales forces of insurers are regulated by a separate body, the Personal Investment Authority, which is itself in the process of being folded into the FSA. There is also a government actuaries department, a sort of independent actuarial body, which was once part of the DTI but now relocating to the FSA's offices in Canary Wharf. As things stand the body regulating Equitable Life is indeed the FSA.

As to its responsibility: the FSA does have a legitimate defence for allowing Equitable to continue selling policies for the four months while the mutual sought a buyer, if it genuinely believed that a buyer could be found. The regulator argues that it had been led to believe that there was plenty of interest in the firm. It says that a business which is selling policies is bound to be more attractive to a potential buyer.

But this raises another question. What was so terrifying about Equitable that 15 potential bidders, Prudential being the last, walked away?

As things stand, Equitable policy holders will have to pay a 10% penalty to move their policy to another issuer in the face of warnings that their pay out will be lower in the future. Because Equitable needs to sell off its more risky and potentially more rewarding equities to buy bonds, which are safer but less profitable, policy holders will fare worse. The graph shows the projections for the pensions industry as a whole. Pensioners are going to be retiring with less; those relying on less risky gilts investment will be considerably worse off.

In its defence, the FSA says that without it the Equitable might have been in a worse state. Equitable met all its solvency requirements but the rules were changed by the law lords judgment, which few could have predicted. But should the FSA have realised that Equitable was treading such a fine line, and demanded it put more money into reserves?

This is easy for the FSA to answer. It did not have the power to demand that Equitable put more into its reserves. It will, though, be able to do so under new powers it receives next year.

Equitable boasted that it was able to pay its higher returns because it did not build up a surplus. This is a contentious issue which is causing problems for other firms with these "inherited estates" - Axa will be in court next week defending its plans. If it had built up a big surplus, Equitable might then have been forced to shed its mutuality because its assets would have looked more attractive to a bidder. That raises separate questions about the future of mutuals.

Once all the potential buyers of Equitable had walked away, the other option open to the FSA would have been to rescue it. Its answer here is that unlike Barings, Equitable was not bust. There was no systemic risk, another potential reason to intervene. The FSA says it is moving away from the "smoke-filled room" approach of the past. Persuading a potential rescuer to do something against its financial interests is now frowned upon.

None of this helps policy holders left at a disadvantage. And what about the role of the investment bankers, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, who were looking for a buyer for Equitable? What about the board of directors of Equitable Life? So far only former chief executive Alan Nash has fallen on his sword. Where were the actuaries?

With so many questions outstanding, a full-scale public inquiry may be the only way to stop the recriminations flying.

Jill Treanor is the Guardian's deputy city editor

webTitle: Theatre review: More Grimm Tales

fields.headline: Grimm up north as panto meets pathology
fields.standfirst:
More Grimm Tales
Newcastle Playhouse
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
More Grimm Tales
Newcastle Playhouse
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Carol Ann Duffy's and Tim Supple's theatrical transformation of the old fairy tales has proved such a hit on Tyneside that for the second year running it's Grimm up north. In this Northern Stage Ensemble production, the potency of the macabre marvels is experienced through total immersion in a twilight netherworld, where the rough-shod and supernatural rub shoulders.

The enchanting direction and design by Neil Murray adapts theatre-in-the-round to theatre-in-a-clearing, wrapping the audience around the stump of some mighty oak, while leafy tendrils and distant turrets wind out towards the furthest reaches of the auditorium. Tina MacHugh's bosky lighting completes the impression that you could be taking part in a Breughel.

The second Supple-Duffy selection from the Grimm oeuvre mixes lesser-known heroic sagas (Iron Hans) with anthropomorphic knock-about (The Musicians of Bremen) and favourite names, including Rumplestiltskin and a Snow White which has more to do with pathology than pantomime. It is often said that the power of pure story-telling will still seduce the Nintendo generation. Frankly, most of the youngsters here will probably want to plug straight into the Playstation for a bit of soothing respite. Grimm Tales are not all talking hedgehogs and porcelain princesses. There's more casual murder, mutilation, dismemberment and cannibalism on stage than you'd expect to find in the most grotesque of horror-flicks.

It is the moral ambivalence of the Grimm world that is really disturbing. Whereas most fairy tales make a clear distinction between good and evil, in this sinister, shifting universe the boundaries become blurred. The Tale of Brother Scamp, for instance, is an astonishingly audacious raspberry at conventional religion. Scamp freeloads his way through life, then caps it all off by smuggling his way into heaven. Earthly indulgence and eternal reward appear confusingly arbitrary.

Put like this, the Tales hardly seem to recommended viewing for the religious, the squeamish or even children. Why everyone enjoys them so much, of course, is precisely because they hover in this subversive fourth-dimension. Grimm tales are gloriously un-PC. There's no apology for a bunch of dwarves who make a girl do their housework. What is Rumplestiltskin's sweated labour, spinning gold through the night, supposed to tell us about the exploitation of leprechauns?

There is any amount of anodyne children's entertainment at Christmas. But if you do choose to go down to the woods today, you're sure of a big surprise.

 Until January 20. Box office: 0191-230 5151.

webTitle: Tips to help you cope financially with Christmas

fields.headline: Tips to help you cope financially with Christmas
fields.standfirst: Need to sort out your finances before Christmas? Trying to find a credit card to take the strain? MoneyUnlimited Editor Marianne Curphey has the answers
fields.trailText: How much money do you reckon you need to spend in order to have a good Christmas? Around £100? As much as £800?
fields.body:
How much money do you reckon you need to spend in order to have a good Christmas? Around £100? As much as £800?

While most people would agree that rampant materialism is hardly compatible with the spirit of the season, you still need to buy presents for family and friends and provide food and drink for visitors.

Whether your budget extends to a couple of book tokens for close family or an extravagant party on the scale of Michael Douglas' wedding to Catherine Zeta Jones, it's usually a relief when the January pay cheque arrives.

But how can you get through Christmas without cramping your style? Here's a few practical suggestions, plus some tips for ensuring that when January comes, your finances will be in better shape.

&#149 Set a budget
Not as easy as it sounds. It can be scary to cost out exactly how much you are likely to spend over the party season which starts in earnest the week before Christmas. Don't forget to include allowances for taxis and tips. This way you'll know whether you are going to go into the red, and be ready to

&#149 Sort out an overdraft in advance
If you know that you haven't got enough in the bank to remain solvent until January, think about the cheapest way of borrowing. Personal loans and credit cards are expensive credit, and you are likely to get the most favourable terms from the bank where you already have your current account.
Some allow free overdrafts up to £250, others reduce the interest rate if the overdraft is pre-arranged. If you go overdrawn without notifying your bank first, you could be penalised quite heavily.

&#149You can find the current account that is right for you in our Data section of MoneyUnlimited

Compare current accounts

&#149 Choose the right credit card for your needs
The credit card market is now extremely competitive and you can choose the card that best suits your lifestyle.
For example, if you rarely manage to pay off the bill in full each month you would be better suited to a card which charged you an annual fee but which had a low rate of interest.
If you always settle your account within the interest-free period then the APR rate will be unimportant to you and you should choose a card for the other benefits, such as cashback or AirMiles that it offers.

&#149 Bear in mind that although credit cards are useful for very short-term borrowing, the interest rates can be prohibitive, particularly with store cards. Check the APR before you sign up.

&#149 Some of the new online banks, like Cahoot, have a selection of credit cards depending on your financial requirements. You can use the credit card comparison tool on the Data pages of this site.

Compare credit cards

The New Year is a good time to review your financial options and think about ways to make your money work harder. One option is to:

&#149Remortgage your home
How does your mortgage rate compare to the best in the market? If you are paying a variable rate it is likely to be much less competitive than fixed and capped rate special offers that lenders regularly offer new customers.

Sadly, as an existing customer you may not have access to the best deals and may need to move to a different provider.

Compare mortgage rates

Here's a couple of points to bear in mind:

&#149 You may be charged an administration fee of around £300 to set up a fixed, discounted and capped rate mortgage.

&#149 You may also be obliged to buy the lender's buildings and contents insurance which is unlikely to be the best deal on the market.

&#149 Unless the mortgage deal is unbeatable, you should shop around for buildings insurance. Depending on the size of your home and its location, you could save yourself anything from £50 to £150.

webTitle: Classical review: BBCSO/ Krivine

fields.headline: BBCSO/ Krivine
fields.standfirst:
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Emmanuel Krivine, the Franco-Russian conductor now in his mid-50s, has been one of music's better kept secrets. He came to conducting late, after a career as a violinist, and since 1987 has been associated with the Orchestre National de Lyon. He has recorded little, toured and guested elsewhere even less. Whoever invited him to appear with the BBC Sympnony Orchestra deserves a medal, for this was a very impressive achievement.

His programme was billed as a concert of French music, though it would be fairer to say that the dominant theme was the influence of French poetry on music, for the centrepiece was Britten's Les Illuminations, his Rimbaud setting from 1939.

Britten plays games with gender, just as Rimbaud's poetry swirls round images of gayness, bisexuality and hermaphroditism in language that prefigures Proust. Addressed to "a Being Beautious" of "double sex", the cycle explores an emotional terrain in which the sex of the beloved floats into redundancy, and can be sung either by a soprano (as at its premiere) or by a tenor (it was written for Peter Pears).

It used to be done with incredible coyness, though Krivine and his soloist, Barbara Bonney, invest it with astonishing erotic blatancy. A deep pall of decadence hangs over the string tone, which sometimes lifts to reveal hovering textures of languid luminosity. Bonney, sewn into a blue-spangled sheath and looking like some dangerous love goddess, sculpts the phrases with an unbridled sensuality of tone.

In Fauré's Masques et Bergamasques, Krivine avoids nostalgic sentimentality - always a danger with Fauré - though he can't quite disguise the fact that the BBCSO sound is a fraction too opulent for a work that needs a trifle more edge.

After the interval, he turned to Debussy, coupling the Mallarmé-inspired Prélude à l'après-midi d'un faune with La Mer, revving both works up a bit and reminding us in the process that musical impressionism works better in performance when it's not equated with shapeless dawdling. We need to hear Krivine again.

webTitle: Classical review: RLPO/Pesek

fields.headline: RLPO/Pesek
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall
Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall
Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.body:
If hearing a 16-year-old playing Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto doesn't seem like an enthralling prospect, that may be because teenage virtuosi - and there are a fair number - can be something of a mixed blessing.

Ilya Gringolts is definitely not in the superficial class. His solo career is only just beginning to blossom; he is still studying with Perlman at the Juilliard School and has made only a handful of recordings. But to hear him with the RLPO may have been an experience never to be repeated. In a few years they probably won't be able to afford him.

Listening to Gringolts' Tchaikovsky makes you wonder why it was considered unplayable at the time of its composition. Effortless virtuosity can be boring; but when warmed through by a vivid sense of poetry it is intensely rewarding. No matter how passionately he scrubbed away at the triple- and quadruple-stopped chords, he never produced a single ugly or harsh sound, and in the lyrical passages a gloriously silky tone poured from his violin like liquid gold. A weird sense of immobility crept into the slow movement; mesmerised, I half-expected the violin to drop quietly out of his hands. A soloist unafraid of such stillness is rare enough; to control it like this at 16 is just plain spooky.

Dvorak's Seventh Symphony was written with posterity in mind. Inspired by the recent premiere of Brahms's Third Symphony in 1883, Dvorak began work on his own Seventh the following year, and Brahms's influence is perceptible not only in the scoring but also in the sheer mastery of symphonic architecture. The happy-go-lucky Bohemian stereotype is almost entirely absent; its opening movement is darkly ominous, and the concluding D major radiance of the finale is hard-won.

Pesek's combination of discipline and free rein was just right for it; he has a knack of standing back and letting the music sing when it wants to, without losing an ounce of control. The Poco adagio was on the brisk side for its chorale opening; but Pesek's overall pacing and shaping was miraculous. The RLPO were on inspired form throughout, with some especially gorgeous wind playing in the second movement.

webTitle: Classical review: London Sinfonietta/ Schuller

fields.headline: Birthday party for Schuller the pioneer
fields.standfirst:
London Sinfonietta/ Schuller
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
London Sinfonietta/ Schuller
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Gunther Schuller was born in the right place (the US) and at the right time (1925) to confront the complexities and contradictions of mid-20th-century music head-on. Can you reconcile postwar modernism in both contemporary music and jazz in one all-embracing meta-music? Can you integrate the excitement and subtlety of jazz with the precision and purpose of classical music; the existential puzzles of indeterminacy with the vertiginous leaps and formal constraints of improvisation? Well, maybe sometimes, maybe never, but whatever your take on these thorny issues, you can be sure that Gunther Schuller has been there, done that and annotated the T-shirt.

In fact he has done so much, as performer, composer, writer, educator and all-round musical enabler that he can be easily overlooked, or bracketed with just one slice of his wide-ranging talents. This concert, to mark his 75th birthday, saw several ensembles put together under the aegis of the London Sinfonietta. It was a chance to join the dots and hear music from several stages and genres of his long career as a composer/arranger.

The Symphony for Brass and Percussion was a nice surprise. Composed by the self-taught Schuller before he turned 25, it shows his unmistakably American individualism. He describes how the ideas grew from playing French horn in an orchestra, and the piece was impressive for being a players' piece - though carefully crafted and structured in four movements - that explored the timbral possibilities of the brass section from the inside, in much the way that hands-on contemporaries such as Stockhausen would experiment with tape and electronics a few years later.

There were several jazz arrangements written for, and featuring, Joe Lovano (tenor sax and bass clarinet), including Crepuscule with Nellie (written by Thelonious Monk for his wife) and Duke Ellington's Prelude to a Kiss. Lament for M was Schuller's own tribute to his late wife, Marjorie. The programme also included Tre Invenzione (1972), the kind of brittle, late-modernist score the Sinfonietta can do in their sleep, but the most effective pieces dated from the late 1950s and early 1960s. Night Music, Transformation and Densities 1 were superb works for medium-sized ensembles that integrated jazz and "serious" performance gestures in an elegant and unforced way, swinging (where appropriate) without dropping a note. Even when extensively notated, there was room for the distinctive timbres of jazz players such as Guy Barker, Chris Laurence, Anthony Kerr and Edwin Schuller (the composer's son) to emerge from, and merge with, the ensemble sound.

The setting for the concert - an overlit "straight" presentation with long gaps between numbers while the stage was re-arranged - was dry and disappointing. You longed for the pace and atmosphere that Schuller achieves so naturally in a piece such as Headin' Out, Movin' In (1994) to be applied to the evening's celebration. It is heartening that there are many fine musicians prepared to tackle such challenges. Whenever the qualities of jazz and contemporary music are integrated without compromise and with Gunther Schuller is one of the pioneers we can thank. Many happy returns!

webTitle: Pop review: Sneaker Pimps

fields.headline: Odd mix from the Pimps
fields.standfirst:
Sneaker Pimps
LA2
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Sneaker Pimps
LA2
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Of the trip hop acts to emerge in the wake of Portishead in the mid-1990s, Morcheeba embraced a more conventional soul-dance style and Moloko got discovered by the Ibiza set. Sneaker Pimps lost Anglo-Indonesian singer Kelli Dayton, guitarist Chris Corner assumed vocal chores for the second album, Splinter (1999), and the band threatened to implode during a gruelling tour of the US.

They look pretty ravaged tonight, in a sexily dishevelled, rock-star way. They could be a boy band on the skids. Guitarist/bassist Joe Wilson has the suit and, well, heft of a bouncer, and drummer David Westlake, also wearing a tie, is no oil painting, but keyboardist Liam Howe is - in his capped-sleeve T-shirt - a regular teen dream. Corner also has pin-up potential, even if his hairstyle would give sleepless nights to Limahl of the 1980s comedy hunks Kajagoogoo. Dressed in white flared jeans and a sheer white top that sticks to his skinny frame like cling-film, the snake-hipped frontman looks as though he is performing before a stadium crowd, or auditioning for the sequel to Velvet Goldmine, all insectoid elegance and heroin chic.

If they're an odd visual mix, Sneaker Pimps' music is even harder to define. It's too undynamic to appeal to indie kids and not rhythmic enough to draw the dance fraternity (although the likes of DJ and Mixmag still write about them). Curl is typical, with its slow, atmospheric groove reminiscent of U2 during their "techno" phase. Unfortunately, much of the detail and drama of their songs is lost in the transition from studio to stage. The band readily acknowledge this, telling an interviewer: "We weren't designed to perform songs live."

And so Destroying Angel loses the cloying, sickly-sweet intimacy of its CD counterpart. Half Life, too, lacks the torpid sensuality of the recorded version. All you can hear is the steady, heavy beat of the drums and the mannered vocals, any trace of Hartlepool, Corner's birthplace, smothered by his mid-Atlantic drawl. Low Five features John Barry-esque keyboard sounds and could, at a stretch, be a James Bond theme were a Bassey or a Cher to give it the camp diva treatment. They also preview their third album, provisionally titled Bloodsport, with the track Blue Movie, which plays on the connection between religion and sex.

Corner returns alone for an acoustic encore, recasting himself as Bowie circa Hunky Dory, and seems genuinely touched by the response. "You're beautiful," he tells his small yet devoted army of fans, although how many of them rush out to buy that third LP remains to be seen.

webTitle: Lloyds TSB/Abbey National takeover question

fields.headline: Another day of paralysis for takeover panel
fields.standfirst:
It is time to force Lloyds' hand

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is time to force Lloyds' hand
fields.body:
London's esteemed takeover panel managed to get through another day yesterday without saying or doing anything meaningful on the pressing matter of Lloyds TSB/Abbey National.

To recap, Lloyds has told Abbey what it would be prepared to pay if it bid for Abbey and the rest of us how it would proceed with the acquisition and what the financial shape of the combined entity might be. But it has not tabled a bid under the terms of the City's takeover code.

Abbey, on the other hand, has spent two months mulling a merger with Bank of Scotland, and so far has produced nothing substantive. It has, of course, been distracted by the non-bid from Lloyds, which has now made it clear that if Abbey and BoS proceed it will turn hostile - in a formal, kick down the doors sort of way.

There is a view in the Square Mile that this sort of thing - one company holding another under siege without formally tabling its terms and allowing the takeover clock to tick - has come to be acceptable to the panel.

If that is so, it is worrying, because one of the principles behind establishment of the code was that one company should not be free to issue an open-dated takeover threat to a rival, thereby potentially paralysing its business.

The suspicion here is that the takeover panel itself has become paralysed. Over many years, the panel's structure and procedures have been held up as a model of self-regulation, not just in the City but across all the world's main financial centres. Despite the panel's non-statutory nature, market participants feel duty bound to abide by its decisions. It has respect.

With this in hand, a good portion of the panel's extraordinary power has been derived from its ability to act with flexibility. The code is carefully written and is followed to the letter, but in quite subtle ways the panel's officials have always retained the right to decide what the letters actually say. In short, the panel has maintained (and regularly executed) the right to intervene when it sees the spirit of its rules being breached.

But the City of London is not the parochial place it once was. For a start, too many takeovers and mergers are now cross-border affairs - and the financial community is, quite naturally, begging for conformity of rules and regulations between different jurisdictions. Along the way, the trend to place everything on a statutory footing is proving irresistible.

Witness the machinations over the European Commission's takeover directive, which aims to put merger and acquisition rules on a standardised footing across the continent. Wednesday's amendments by the European parliament, making corporate "poison pill" defences easier, will lead to many more months of pork-barrel negotiations before some sort of meaningful directive is possible.

While this has been going on, the City's panel has been left drifting around in some sort of limbo. Its old ways of getting things done (or stopped) are on the way out; instead it is facing a future where decisions are likely to be challenged in the courts. In future, its officials will have to act much more as technicians than arbitrators. In the meantime, it seems it has lost the confidence to act, allowing one of Britain's most powerful banks to skirt around the existing hard-wired code with abandon. Unwittingly or otherwise, Lloyds is fast bringing a great City institution into disrepute.

Big worry

Not a good day all round for the new-look American banking combine Chase. To cap a profits warning issued on Wall Street and confirmation of yet more job cuts, it has lost the business of a leading FTSE 100 company.

Legal & General revealed yesterday that it had ditched JP Morgan, now part of the Chase empire, as one of its financial advisers. L&G, which had tried to do a deal with NatWest last year before the Scots stepped in, has also dropped Schroders, now gobbled up by the investment banking arm of another US financial services group, Citigroup.

A penalty, perhaps, for its failed deal with NatWest. Or, it was suggested, maybe a sign that L&G is planning to try to sell itself again.

More likely, however, the move is a reflection of that fact that L&G feels lost and unloved inside these newly enlarged bulge-bracket firms. It looks significant that it has replaced its former adviser with Lazards, an independent firm, and Goldman Sachs, a big US firm but one which is not locked in the internal political upheaval of a merger of its own.

Getting to be as big as possible as fast as possible is an assumed priority in the world of investment banking. But the assumption that their customers agree with the strategy might be premature. L&G may prove to be something of a trend setter.

While this has been going on, the City's panel has been left drifting around in some sort of limbo. Its old ways of getting things done (or stopped) are on the way out; instead it is facing a future where decisions are likely to be challenged in the courts. In future, its officials will have to act much more as technicians than arbitrators. In the meantime, it seems it has lost the confidence to act, allowing one of Britain's most powerful banks to skirt around the existing hard-wired code with abandon. Unwittingly or otherwise, Lloyds is fast bringing a great City institution into disrepute. Big worry Not a good day all round for the new-look American banking combine Chase. To cap a profits warning issued on Wall Street and confirmation of yet more job cuts, it has lost the business of a leading FTSE 100 company. Legal & General revealed yesterday that it had ditched JP Morgan, now part of the Chase empire, as one of its financial advisers. L&G, which had tried to do a deal with NatWest last year before the Scots stepped in, has also dropped Schroders, now gobbled up by the investment banking arm of another US financial services group, Citigroup. A penalty, perhaps, for its failed deal with NatWest. Or, it was suggested, maybe a sign that L&G is planning to try to sell itself again. More likely, however, the move is a reflection of that fact that L&G feels lost and unloved inside these newly enlarged bulge-bracket firms. It looks significant that it has replaced its former adviser with Lazards, an independent firm, and Goldman Sachs, a big US firm but one which is not locked in the internal political upheaval of a merger of its own. Getting to be as big as possible as fast as possible is an assumed priority in the world of investment banking. But the assumption that their customers agree with the strategy might be premature. L&G may prove to be something of a trend setter.

webTitle: Theatre review: Guys and Dolls

fields.headline: Guys and Dolls
fields.standfirst:
Crucible
Sheffield
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Crucible
Sheffield
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Luck is being a real lady to the Crucible. The theatre continues to prove it is on a roll by nabbing a winner in the Frank Loesser musical based on Damon Runyon's short stories. Low life has never looked so attractive as it does here in the company of Nathan Detroit, a New York crap-game convenor, and his shady friends who have colourful names such as Harry the Horse and Nicely-Nicely.

Rachel Kavanaugh's production may lack the sharp outfits, delivery and choreography of the National Theatre's revival a few years back, but it pulls out all the stops when it counts with numbers such as Sit Down You're Rocking the Boat, and its generally low-key approach brings out every ounce of humanity in this teeming mess of tricksters and cheats, lovers and losers.

Peter McKintosh has come up with nifty costumes that make the guys vivid and larger than life. And he provides a clever set in which New York's skyscrapers fan the entire stage like glittering shark's teeth - seductive and dangerous, like the city itself. In fact one thing the production does really well is to match the upbeat exuberance of the music and lyrics with some of the fag-end, three-o'clock-in-the-morning haze of Runyon's original downbeat stories.

This is particularly apt for that "famous fiancée" Miss Adelaide, whose mother thinks she is married and has five kids - although she has failed to get Nathan Detroit to the altar after 14 years of engagement. In Tracie Bennett's blistering performance, she emerges as a figure who is as tragic as she is comic.

Bennett is nicely matched by Ian Bartholomew's Nathan Detroit, who so suggests the kind of Peter Pannish man who can never make a commitment that you know at the end, after agreeing to marry Adelaide, that it won't be long before he is back to his old tricks again.

It takes a while for Claire Carrie, as Sister Sarah Brown, to find both her voice and her spark, but Harry Burton's Sky Masterson - who takes on the Salvation Army do-gooder as a bet but then really falls for her - has just the right degree of raffish charm to make running off with him to Havana not completely out of the question.

But the city of New York is the real star, and Kavanaugh's production brings out its inhabitants foibles and follies, bewitchment and fascination, so that they emerge like ghosts, silhouetted against the skyline, forever telling their stories to anyone who will listen.

 Until January 20. Box office: 0114 249 6000.
